Police suspect that it could be a case of drunken driving and are yet to ascertain the fact. “The rider the bike could not control the vehicle since it was plying at high speed. The injured persons are out of danger,’’ Keesara Inspector J Narender Goud told TOI.

Title: Karnataka farmers join Amaravati ryots, held
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: Police on Monday arrested farmers from Karanataka who had come in support of Amaravati ’s farmers protesting the decentralisation of the state’s capital. Police intercepted the farmers who came from various parts of Karnataka at Kanaka Durga Varadhi and moved them to Krishna Lanka Police Station on Monday evening.

About 100 farmers from Bellary, Sindhanur, Rayachur, Mandya, Yadagiri and Goppala areas arrived in Vijayawada on Monday morning. They participated in the protest organised by Amaravati Parirakshana Joint Action Committee at Dharna Chowk in Vijayawada. Speaking at Dharna Chowk, the farmers from Karnataka said that they had come to extend solidarity to farmers of Amaravati who had given away their lands for the construction of the capital city. They said the state government’s oppression of peaceful protests and the way women were treated were condemnable.

Meanwhile, TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu demanded the immediate release of the farmers. He said he would hold a dharana at Amaravati if the farmers were not released soon.

Title: Pack of stray dogs mauls 4-year-old boy to death
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

LUDHIANA: A pack of stray dogs mauled a 4-year-old boy to death in Bahomajra village of Khanna on Sunday evening.

Viraj Kumar was playing outside his house when the canines attacked him.

His father Prem Chand, a labourer, said in his police complaint, “I, along with my family, live in a rented accommodation here. A garbage dump near our house attracts stray dogs. On Sunday evening, my son was playing outside our house when the dogs attacked him. On hearing his screams, my wife and and daughter rushed out and found dogs biting him. They rushed him to Khanna civil hospital, from where he was referred to Rajindra Hospital, Patiala. But he died on the way.”

Sadar Khanna police station SHO inspector Baljinder Singh said, “Before informing the police, the family had cremated the body. We have asked them to record their statement.”

Title: Chauka lagayenge? SS League survey done, result in March
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

INDORE: Centre’s appointed teams that came here to verify claims of Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) and collect feedback under seven-star garbage-free city rating and also for main survey under Swachh Survekshan (SS) League 2020 completed their work on Saturday. A 15-member team was in city for around 17 days for physical verification for seven-star protocol under Garbage Free Cities (GFC) component of survey. This team conducted extensive survey of every ward and collected 40 pictorial evidence from each ward. It also interviewed citizens and corporation staff to verify IMC’s claims on various parameters.

Another team from Centre came to city for field observation work under main survey of SS League 2020. This survey was conducted on different indicators such as beautification, encroachment on storm water drains and water bodies, level of dust in air, visible beautification in slum and old parts of city, presence of litter bins in markets, presence of stray animals etc. This team also shared personal observations on these parameters. “While star rating survey concluded on Jan 25, main survey concluded on Jan 26,” said sources. Corporation officials said that they did not have any role to play in the survey. IMC commissioner Asheesh Singh said that they received a formal confirmation from the Centre about completion of both surveys. “We did not have any role to play in both surveys. They had their own criteria of assessment and took a lot of pictures and also collected feedback form citizens,” he said. The results are expected to be announced in March after completion of survey of all cities across country. Indore has already clinched top position in the first two quarters of SSL League-2020 among list of cities with more than 10 lakh population. Results of third quarter, as well as that of ODF++ and water plus certifications are also awaited.

Title: Over 6,000 wait for driving licence over new smart format
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

INDORE: Over 6000 driving licence applicants are running post to pillar to get their licence since more than past 20 days. The reason — Indore regional transport office ( RTO ) has stopped using conventional cards to print driving licence and officials claim that there is a delay in arrival of smart cards as recommended by the Centre.

The applicants include around 2500 people, who had applied for renewal or re-issuance of driving licence. Some applicants, who applied for licence in December are yet to receive licence.

“I had applied for renewal of my driving licence on December 10. I haven’t received the licence till date. Even officials concerned are not ready to explain reason behind this delay,” said Dev Kishan Nadda.

Trapti Goyal, who had applied for fresh licence on December 17, face the same problem. “Officials are not able to give a specific date about when I am going to get my driving licence issued. I passed the test, but I cannot drive because I don’t have licence,” she said.

Ministry of road transport and highways had earlier announced to modify format of driving licences to laminated cards without chip or smart card type driving licence.

It had prescribed a common standard format and design of driving licence for the whole country, which includes placement of information, standardization of fonts etc.

An instruction regarding implementation of the same was issued by department a month ago. Since then, agency engaged in printing of licence has stopped work.

Assistant regional transport officer Archana Mishra said that the matter has already been brought to the notice of authorities. “We are expecting new cards within a day or two. Once they are delivered we will start issuing licences,” she added.

Title: Move unjust to poor, backward classes: TDP
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu

AMARAVATI: TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu alleged that chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy decided to abolish the council only out of vengeance after the council chairman referred the three-capital cities and CRDA repeal bills to the select committee.

“TDP had given an opportunity to Duvvarapu Ramarao, who hails from most backward community Rajaka (washermen) as they never had any representation in the assembly. The council’s abolition would render great injustice to those unrepresented sections,” Naidu said.

He also found fault with the CM’s statement about the presence of intellectuals in the assembly. “About 86 YSRC legislators are facing criminal cases. They are a gang of s and thugs. They are not intellectuals. The YSRC enacted a drama even during voting on the resolution as the speaker’s first count was 121 and then increased to 133,” he alleged.

He further said that Jagan has been talking about only six states having councils but ignored the fact that 10 other states have requested for a revival of the council. “The CM is spending close to Rs 30 crore per year on his security to attend courts but expressing inability to spend on the council, which is laughable,” Naidu said.

Many TDP MLCs too termed the government’s decision to abolish the legislative council as “anti-poor”. Speaking to reporters after the assembly taking up discussion on the issue, TDP MLCs Duvvarapu Ramarao, BT Naidu, Tippe Swamy and Gourivani Srinivasulu demanded that the chief minister should explain how he plans to help people from the most backward communities to be part of the legislature after abolishing the council. “Many of us are from the most backward communities. We can’t contest direct elections due to our poor financial status. We got an opportunity to serve people only due to the presence of the council. Its abolition is a big blow to is,” said Ramarao.

He found fault with the government campaign that the council has been rejecting bills cleared by the assembly. Ramarao said the council cleared 32 bills sent by the assembly in the last few months and made amendments only to two bills — English medium in schools and SC-ST commissions. “We have not rejected the two bills. We have sent them back with amendments,” he said, while adding that the council chairman referred the capital decentralisation and CRDA repeal bills to the select committee only to take people’s views due to their controversial nature.

In fact, referring the bills to the select committee should not be construed as rejection, he said. “The chief minister has taken a unilateral decision to abolish the legislative body as he could not digest the presence of backward communities in the council,” he alleged.

Title: Odisha government comes out with Lingaraj rehab plan
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Lingaraj Temple

BHUBANESWAR: Chief minister Naveen Patnaik on Monday announced a rehabilitation and resettlement policy for the Ekamra Plan that aims to revive and preserve the heritage value and grandeur of the historic Lingaraj Temple and its surroundings.

Under the plan, steps will be taken to preserve the heritage of around 66 acres surrounding the Lingaraj Temple and Bindu Sagar. The state government has already announced projects under the Ekamra Kshetra Amenities and Monuments Revival Action Plan worth around Rs 700 crore. The rehabilitation and resettlement policy is part of that action plan.

Besides government institutions, private land will be acquired while encroachment will also be removed from the area. As per the rehabilitation and resettlement policy, all residential and commercial units having clear title of the land would be acquired through direct purchase method prescribed by the state government while compensation will be given as per the Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition, Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act, 2013.

There shall be an option to provide land instead of compensation amount having equal market value of the land to be acquired. “Immediate assistance of Rs 1 lakh per family will be provided towards expenses related to transportation and immediate arrangements. Each family shall be provided with Rs 15,000 per month for a period of Rs 12 months from the date of acquisition of property,” said an official.

Also, every residential unit owner will be paid Rs 20 lakh as one-time settlement allowance over and above the compensation prescribed in the 2013 compensation law.

According to the policy, all commercial units having clear deed of the land will also be acquired through direct purchase method. Owners of commercial establishments will get allowance of Rs 1 lakh per unit towards expenses related to transportation. Monthly assistance of Rs 15,000 and Rs 20,000 will also be provided to shop owners having built up area of less than or equal to 200 square/feet and more than 200 square/feet, respectively, the package states.

The shop owners have also been given three options either to accept a shop unit at an available place at 50 per cent of the market value or to accept a shop at the new market complex to be developed on payment of 50 per cent cost. They can also opt for a one-time settlement amount of Rs 20 lakh.

The policy also said that the listed street vendors will be provided with a one-time rehabilitation assistance of Rs 30,000 in two instalments. A vending plan will be prepared to allocate space to the affected street vendors.

To assist affected government offices and institutions, a committee headed by the BMC commissioner will be formed to take a call on it. Similar method will also be applied to compensate religious institutions. State government sources said the rehabilitation and resettlement policy will be implemented by the BMC commissioner in consultation with the Khurda district collector.

EoM

Title: 336 marshals to regulate traffic at 28 chowks
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Times News Network

Ludhiana: With Ludhiana Police launching Traffic Marshal Scheme in the city, 336 marshals will regulate vehicular flow at 28 main chowks in the first phase.

On January 31, the police had made announcements, asking residents to join as traffic marshals. As many as 100 chowks and roads have been identified where the marshals will be deployed.

They will be divided into two categories: those between 16-year-old and 18-year-old and those from 18-year-old to 65-year-old. In the first category, only schoolchildren can enrol themselves. They will be deployed outside their schools for regulating vehicular flow under the supervision of their teachers.

Commissioner of police Rakesh Agrawal said, “As of now, 336 traffic marshals have been enrolled. They will be deployed at 28 main chowks, with each team comprising 12 persons. Of these 12, some will come every day from 8am to 11am and others from 4pm to 8pm to assist police in controlling traffic at these points. These marshals have been given training. Gradually, the scheme will be extended to 100 chowks, each of which will have 24 persons on duty.”

The areas selected in the first phase include Mata Rani Chowk, Old Saji Mandi Chowk, Jagraon Bridge, Bharat Nagar Chowk, Hero Bakery Chowk, Mini Secretariat crossing, Samrala Chowk, Dugri canal bridge traffic lights, Fountain Chowk, Ghumar Mandi Chowk, Bhai Bala Chowk, PAU gate 4, Rajpura Chowk, Deep Hospital crossing (entry and exist), Raikhy Cinema Chowk, Feroze Gandhi Market, Durga Mata Mandir, Arti Chowk, Jalandhar Bypass Chowk, Saggu Chowk, Dandi Swami Chowk, Cemetery Road, Chattri Chowk, Old Session Court Chowk, Basti Jodhewal Chowk, Sherpur Chowk and Jamalpur traffic lights.

“The traffic marshals will be given dummy challan books. The challans they issue will not entail monetary fines. Instead, violator will have to perform traffic duties for up to 8 hours. A traffic committee will be formed which will decide on the hours for traffic duty — a community service. Traffic marshals will be given ID cards and certificates,” Agrawal added.

A person enlisted as traffic marshal will hold this post for a period of two years. If any traffic marshal is found abusing his or her official position or guilty of misconduct, then he can be removed from the post.

The DCP (traffic) will act as nodal officer for the scheme.

DCP (traffic) Sukhpal Singh Brar said, “The marshals were on duty on January 26. Now, they will join from January 28.”

Title: Coronavirus alert: Health department starts screening fliers
Content:
An area at the Bhubaneswar airport has been earmarked for screening passengers

BHUBANESWAR/JHARSUGUDA: The state government on Sunday started screening of passengers from Kuala Lumpur in view of Malaysia confirming some cases of coronavirus (2019 n-CoV) there.Odisha has, however, not found a single suspected case of corona that has killed more than 80 in China.After taking stock of the situation here, health secretary Nikunja Bihari Dhal on Monday said, “Our vulnerability is because of the direct flight from Malaysia, which has confirmed three n-CoV cases. A health team is stationed at the airport to check people flying from there. No suspected cases have been reported so far.”Bhubaneswar has only one direct international flight (AirAsia) connecting the city with Kuala Lumpur four days a week. Dhal said there is no cause of panic. Only alertness is needed. “Those having recent travel history to affected countries and developing symptoms of acute fever, running nose, cough sore throat and shortness of breath should report to the health unit stationed at the airport,” he said. Dhal said the state has also requested the Union health ministry to ensure facility for thermal screening of passengers, in which a thermal imager measures temperature from radiation from people screened. The Centre has already made such facility available in seven airports having flights to China and Hong Kong. The government also asked the hotels to ensure international travellers, particularly those who have travelled to affected countries in past one month,, make self-declaration about their health condition.Ajit Kumar Mohanty, director public health, said the suspected cases, if any, will be clinically examined in the isolation room in the airport and the persons would be shifted to the Capital Hospital.V V Rao, director, Biju Patnaik International Airport , said, “Commuters coming from Malaysia or with travel history to China are making a self-declaration about their clinical condition. Anyone having suspected symptoms is supposed to report the same to immigration authorities, who in turn will alert the health authorities.”The Capital Hospital besides AIIMS Bhubaneswar, SCB Medical College and Hospital Cuttack, VSS Institute of Medical Sciences and Research Burla and District Headquarters Hospital, Jharsuguda, have readied isolation wards for possible cases.Saroj Samal, district collector (Jharsuguda), after reviewing the preparedness there, said, “Screening of suspected passengers will be done at Jharsuguda airport from Tuesday. “We have also asked Vedanta Ltd Jharsuguda (aluminum company) for information regarding any official, who are from China or visiting China relating to any business. We will screen them as well,” he said.The Paradip port set up a special Coronavirus help desk and started thermal screening for crew members for shipsChief medical officer (CMO), Paradip Port Hospital , Prahallad Panda said temperature is being screened for all crew members of the ships coming from other countries after their arrival in the port. “We have set up an isolation ward in the hospital at Paradip to treat any suspected patient. Crew members, who exhibit the symptoms, will be sent to the hospital for further testing,” he said.

Title: Stay is only on Sectt demolition: HC to Telangana
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The Telangana high court on Monday made it clear that it had only stayed the demolition of the existing secretariat building in Hyderabad in the past. The court added that this order will in no way prevents the state from preparing a new design for its proposed new secretariat complex.

The bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy said this while resuming the hearing in a batch of PILs that challenged the proposed move to demolish the existing secretariat building and raise a new one in its place.

The state counsel informed the bench that they are planning to raise the structure at a cost of Rs 300 crore to Rs 400 crore but could not prepare a plan so far on account of the stay.

The bench told him that they stayed only the demolition and not the work of preparing a new plan and design. The bench also wondered as to how the state counsel was pouring out the estimated costs of the building even without a plan on hand. The bench expressed its dissatisfaction over the incomplete affidavit filed by the principal secretary of the R&B department and sought a detailed counter from him by Feb 12.

Title: Lokesh Nara calls for resignation of ministers Bose, Ramana
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

TDP national general secretary and MLC Nara Lokesh

AMARAVATI: TDP national general secretary and MLC Nara Lokesh said ministers Pilli Subhash Chandra Bose and Mopidevi Venkata Ramana should quit the cabinet after the decision to abolish the council.

Lokesh said both Bose and Ramana were representing the council in the cabinet and have lost the moral right to continue as ministers. Lokesh said all YSRC members in the council including chief whip Ummareddi Venkateswarlu should quit the council even before Parliament passes the bill to bring the abolition to effect.

“The cabinet and assembly have passed a resolution. How could YSRC members continue as members in the council when the party and the government have decided to abolish the Upper House?” asked Lokesh. He said that the two MLCs who switched sides to YSRC from TDP should also resign as they have lost the moral right to continue as members. Lokesh said Jagan had taken the call to abolish the council only out of vengeance against Amaravati. He said Jagan was acting against people and would taste their anger.

Former legislator Vangaveeti Radhakrishna said Jagan should dissolve the assembly if had the guts to face people. He visited the farmers’ dharna camp in the capital and extended his support. He said that Jagan would go to any extent to make his word final.

Title: Leopard found dead in Valparai
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Coimbatore: A three-year-old male leopard was found dead in a tea estate at Vellamalaimattam in Valparai town on Saturday.

Estate workers, who found the carcass, alerted Valparai forest range officer S Senthilkumar.

The officials took the carcass to the advanced wildlife management training centre at Attakatti, where postmortem was carried out on Sunday. According to the postmortem report, the animal had suffered injuries on its neck and legs. It could have been injured in a fight with another leopard.

“Male leopards often fight with each other over female leopards. Samples were taken from the dead animal,” deputy field director of Anaimalai Tiger Reserve AS Marimuthu said.

The samples will be sent to the regional forensic science laboratory at Race Course.

The carcass was burnt. The forest department sensitized the estate workers about leopard movement in the region.

Title: GTDC to punish staff using clout to cancel transfers
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Panaji: Goa Tourism Development Corporation (GTDC) has decided to take action against staffers who make requests backed by a minister or MLA to cancel their transfer orders or hold them in abeyance. The corporation, however, has not specificed what kind of action it will take.

During GTDC’s last board meeting, it was pointed out that the phemonenon of staffers approaching MLAs and ministers to cancel their transfer orders hampers the smooth functioning of the corporation.

Thus, it passed a resolution, signed by MD Nikhil Desai, that stated “the need to curb such practices adopted by staff of the corporation”.

A GTDC board member, however, said that it’s not an easy practice to stop. “Who will bell the cat?” he asked. “The practice is widespread and common in other departments too. Going to an elected representative is the easiest way to get a transfer order reversed, or to get a transfer to a preferable location.”

Another board member said it would be interesting to see what kind of action would be taken against staffers who resort to applying political pressure.“Most (officials) comply when a request is received from a political boss, lest they have to pay the price for not obliging,” he said. The GTDC, incorporated under the Companies Act, is governed by rules applicable for government servants.

A senior official said that a government employee can be transferred to any part of the state, and they have to adhere to it. “Elected representatives should not entertain such requests just because the staffer happens to be their constituent,” the official said.

Title: Campuses, city Shaheen Baghs keep protest flag flying on R-Day
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Kolkata: The anti-CAA protests around Republic Day celebrations spilled over to Monday on campuses across the city.

Students formed a human chain and read the Preamble to the constitution. The precincts of Presidency University reverberated with the preamble to the constitution on Monday evening as more than 200 students of the institution formed a human chain to protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act and the proposed National Register for Citizens.

The students of the university have been protesting on various forums and participating in protest meetings even outside campus demanding a roll back of CAA.

The call for Monday’s human chain was given by the Presidency University Unit of Students’ Federation of India but several other students too joined in.

“We are celebrating Republic day by protesting against the draconian CAA which discriminates on the basis of religion. The law is anti-poor and anti-marginalised communities. The students will keep protesting will the law is not repealed,” said Debnil Paul of the history department.

After reading the Preamble to the constitution, the students formed a human chain that stretched from the main gate till the other end of the portico.

At Jadavpur University, young poet Amir Aziz recited several poems of dissent. His poem Jamia ki larkiya has gone viral. He spoke to close to 300 students of the university on Monday afternoon.

“They are dividing people so that nobody asks them the uncomfortable questions about jobs, education, safety of women and children. This is why they have brought CAA and proposing NRC . The secular fabric of this nation is in danger,” said Aziz.

On Sunday Republic day was observed at all the five sit-in spots in Kolkata and Howrah with hoisting of the national flag followed by the national anthem.

At Zakaria Street, local people along with students took out a procession from Nakhoda Mosque to Jorasanko to observe the Republic Day. The rallyists carried the national flag and posters against the CAA and NRC.

“Nakhoda Mosque and Jorasanko are not merely landmarks but a symbol of love and amity between the several communities that reside in Kolkata. CAA and NRC are an attempt to divide the people on religious lines but the citizens of the country will foil such attempts by the BJP,” said Angshuman Sarkar, a student who participated in the rally.

At Park Circus the national flag was hoisted at 11 am. “Hundreds of people attended the Republic day celebration here. Throughout the day we had several programmes celebrating this beautiful republic we call our country,’ said a volunteer at Park Circus. Even on Sunday, several homemakers were present at Park Circus Maidan to celebrate Republic Day. “We started the day with hoisting the National Flag and singing the National Anthem. We went to participate in the human chain after that,” said Bilqis Begum, a homemaker from Rippon Street.

At the sit-in at Nawab Ali Park in Ekbalpore, a health check-up camp was organised for over 500 people. “Many members participated in the human chain while others organised a small Republic Day programme at the park itself. In the later half of the day we organised a health camp for over 500 people. We are planning to organise more camps like these in the coming days,” said Arshad Parvez Khan, one of the organisers.

The sit-in near Chaplin Square on Hogg Street attracted more than 1,000 people on Republic Day. “Several activists dropped by to address the gathering which listened with rapt attention,” said Amitava Ghosh, a member of the Joint Forum against NRC.

At Howrah’s Pilkhana several students from local colleges staged a small play and raised slogans against CAA and NRC along with the local people.

Title: ‘Mapusa bus stand needs attention’
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Saligao: After inspecting the KTC bus stand at Mapusa on Monday, officials of 13 government departments found that it “was in a bad state and needs attention”.

The officials had conducted the inspection along with the district road safety council.

The inspection team found that the bus stand lacks hygiene, and that some of the eateries did not have FDA licence, while most of the outlets operated in unhygienic conditions. The team has also directed the transport department to put up zebra crossings along the bus bays for the safety of pedestrians.

The team also noticed that the entry and exit roads of the bus stand were in a very bad state and that there was no notification board for bus routes at the stand.

The inspection was initiated by Goa Consumer Action Network (GOACAN) with assistance from the Mapusa deputy collector’s office.

The team comprised officials from the road transport department, health, FDA, legal metrology, KTC, PWD, electricity department, civil supplies, traffic and police.

Title: Parking fees at malls collectors’ call: HC
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: The high court on Monday directed joint collectors in all districts to consider representations from petitioners in a PIL challenging the collection of parking fee at malls and theatres and to take necessary action if they found the practice illegal.

N N Grace, general secretary, Mundadugu Praja Party , moved the high court seeking directions to the government and officials concerned to prevent movie theatres and shopping malls from collecting parking fee from consumers. On behalf of the petitioner, J Sravan Kumar argued that collection of parking fee from consumers was in violation of Section 31 of the Andhra Pradesh Apartments Promotion of Constructions and Ownership Act 1987 and as well as violation of the court orders.

He argued that joint collectors in districts were not taking any action despite giving representations to them.

Disposing the petition, the bench headed by chief justice of the high court Justice J K Maheswari and Justice Nainala Jayasurya directed the joint collectors to take action against the movie theatres and shopping malls if they found the collection of parking fee illegal.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: High court orders affidavit on govt buildings painted in party colours
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: In view of the upcoming panchayat elections, the high court on Monday directed the state election commission to file an affidavit with regard to painting of government offices in party colours. The court directed the election commission to take action as per the norms specified by law.

One Muppa Venkateswara Rao from Guntur district had moved the high court against the inaction of government officials after the panchayat building of Pallapadu was painted in the colours of YSRC flag. He argued in his petition that if the offices were to be painted in party colours it could affect the voting pattern.

Earlier, the high court had directed the state government not to paint any government building in the colours of political parties.

On Monday, the petitioner’s advocate argued that as the government is preparing to conduct elections to local bodies, the government offices, painted in party colours, must be repainted.

Taking the arguments of the petitioner into consideration, the AP high court bench headed by the chief justice J K Maheswari and Justcie Nainala Jayasurya directed the state election commission to take action according to the law and asked to it file an affidavit over the issue and posted the matter for further hearing on February 5.

Title: 22-year-old woman gang-raped, one held
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

LUDHIANA: The police on Saturday booked two men for raping a married woman and two women for helping the accused commit the crime. Later in the day, one of the accused was arrested.

In her police complaint, the 22-year-old survivor said, “A woman and her daughter-in-law, who live in my neighbourhood, are my family friends. Around 8pm on January 25, the woman called me up and asked me to meet her at Tajpur Road. When I reached Tajpur Road, she, along with her daughter-in-law, was waiting for me. From there, we boarded an autorickshaw and reached Transport Nagar.”

The trio then went to the accused women’s tea shop. “The woman’s son and his friend were at the shop. A few minutes later, the woman and her daughter-in-law left, saying they would return soon. On finding me alone, her son and his friend started harassing me. They then raped me and threatened me against speaking about the incident,” she added.

On returning home, she apprised her husband of the incident and he took her to the police station to lodge a complaint.

Investigating officer assistant sub-inspector Ranjeet Singh said, “A case has been registered under sections 376 (rape), 506 (criminal intimidation), 120-B (criminal conspiracy), 34 (act done by several persons in furtherance of common intention) of the IPC. One accused, a labourer, has been arrested and a manhunt launched to trace the other.”

Title: Swachh survey: Corporation workers answer queries posed to residents
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Citizen's feedback is one parametre that helps the city to score more marks and top the cleanest city ranking

COIMBATORE: S Thangasubha , a resident of Race Course , was doing household chores when three sanitary workers of the city corporation knocked on her door on Monday morning.

They had come to conduct a survey about the city’s cleanliness, the workers told the 29-year-old woman and sought her mobile number. Within seconds, Thangasubha received a one-time password. The workers asked her to share the OTP, which she did. They thanked her and asked her to give her husband’s mobile number. They left the place after getting the OTP sent to his number.

Thangasubha had no clue what it was about. “As the workers used to collect garbage from my house and inspect the house during the anti-dengue drive, I knew them well. That’s why I shared the mobile numbers and OTPs. When I demanded to know what they were doing, they said it was for a survey and left the place in a hurry, saying that they had to meet targets,” she told TOI.

It took some time for Ramanthapuram-based Murugan, who also shared his mobile number and OTP, to realise that he had let the workers complete Swachh Survekshan 2020 on his behalf. “Not even once the sanitary workers collected waste from our doorstep. Garbage bins in the locality are cleared only once in five days. As a result, stay dogs thrive here,” he said.

“What is the point of achieving high marks in the survey without implementing anything on the ground? I don’t mind giving full marks to the city corporation if it would have at least shown willingness to keep the city clean,” Murugan said.

But the workers said they were also kept in the dark about the exercise. “We would gladly explain about the survey only if we knew what it was about. Our supervisors had obtained our mobile numbers, answered the questions on their own and completed the survey by entering the OTPs. We are doing it because we were asked to do so,” a permanent worker of the corporation said.

The corporation has been adopting a similar procedure to record the most number of feedback from residents for the survey, conducted by the ministry of housing and urban affairs. Public were asked to rate their city for eight parameters, including whether dry waste and wet waste are segregated at source and cleanliness of community toilets.

According to the Swachh Survekshan portal, the city corporation has obtained 89,211 votes 16,199 registered through the portal and validated through OTP, 72,643 through Vote for Your City app and 369 through Swachhata app to get the most number of votes in the state.

Citizens’ feedback is one of the parameters that help the city score more marks and top the cleanest city ranking, a corporation official said. “Corporation officials along with Swachh Bharat ambassadors have been creating awareness about the survey in educational institutions. Field-level workers have been distributing pamphlets and making people fill the survey at their doorstep.”

Public participation is important than the marks, said R Raveendran, one of the ambassadors. “During the drive at colleges, we explain about the importance about the survey and about the questionnaire. We don’t interfere with their right to vote.”

A senior corporation official refuted the allegation. “Cleanliness of the city has improved significantly in the last few months, thanks to the cleaning drives conducted during night. Door-to-door garbage collection has been streamlined. As many people are not at all interested in participating in the survey, our sanitary workers are helping them to submit it after explaining the questions,” he said.

Title: Odisha nod likely for driving licence applicants to upload documents
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

BHUBANESWAR: The state transport department is going to launch an online platform to enable DL (driving licence ) applicants to upload requisite documents online. Though applicants currently apply for the DL online, they have to carry documents like age and address proofs (original and photocopy) physically to the regional transport office (RTO) and submit them to the authorities.

“Our online application is almost ready. We are likely to launch it in next few days. In the proposed initiative, all DL-related documents can be uploaded online, preventing any paperwork in the regional transport offices,” said state transport commissioner Sanjeeb Panda.

The department said the proposed online facility, dubbed as document management system , is part of the state government’s 5T (transparency, teamwork, technology, timeframe and transformation) initiative for faster service delivery and improved user experience.

An official in a regional transport office said the document management system will ease their pressure. “We are now examining documents and accepting photocopies of the documents from the applicants. Soon, applicants are just required to approach us with their appointment letter and original documents. We will not receive any documents. We will only match the uploaded documents with their original ones,” another officer said.

A few days ago, the transport department launched instant online learners licence (LL) by scrapping the system of approval by the RTOs to issue LL to applicants, who successfully clear the computerised test. An official source said a staggering 7.9 lakh LLs were issued by RTOs across the state between September 2019 and December 2019. Interestingly, only 3.48 lakh LLs were issued across the state in 2018.

“We also recorded substantial increase in online collection of revenue in RTOs through Sarathi online application. Under the 5T policy, we have already introduced single receipt system of collecting the service charges of private service provider at RTOs along with the government fees,” an officer said.

State transport authority said the recent removal of middlemen from the premises of regional transport offices and massive awareness drives resulted in smooth and transparent delivery of services to people. There is a plan to install computers with touchscreen facility at RTOs for convenience of applicants, who are not conversant with computer mouse . Attempts are also being made to install such touchscreen computers for mock test for LL applicants. All applicants can try a mock test before sitting for the main LL test, said an official.

Title: Foresters remove deer killed by wild dogs near village
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

The deer was hunted by a pack of wild dogs near Mudholi on Friday

Nagpur: Should a wild animal killed by predators be removed by the forest department ? The question was raised by conservationists after Tadoba-Andhari Tiger Reserve (TATR) forest officials lifted a deer killed by wild dogs. The foresters, though, claim it was necessitated since stray feral dogs were eating the kill, and may have passed on some infections to the wild dogs.

Eyewitnesses said the deer was hunted by a pack of wild dogs on Friday near Mudholi, in protected forest under Tadoba buffer. The forest is contiguous to the core area and the prey was chased over a long distance by the dogs.

However, owing to morning chores of local villagers, the kill was left at the site. When foresters came to know about it, they removed the fresh deer carcass and conducted post-mortem and disposed it of.

Deputy director (buffer) G Guruprasad confirmed the deer was killed by wild dogs. “We removed the carcass as feral dogs from the village had moved in to eat it. With the fear that it would infect the wild dogs or any other predators, we did not take a risk. The spot where the deer was killed was hardly 200 metres away from the village.”

Conservationists working in and around Tadoba said, “This is against nature. Ideally, the forest officials should have monitored the kill by making a machan, or the deer could have been shifted into the forest area, instead of disposing it of. By removing the deer, wild dogs were deprived of their food.”

National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA) does not have guidelines for such cases. “With regard to cattle kills, there are directions to monitor them because people many times resort to revenge killing of predators by poisoning the cattle. There are many incidents where tigers have been killed due to poisoning of cattle,” said experts.

Title: Work on Cortalim service road begins
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

The detour is expected to ease traffic snarls on the Cortalim stretch

PANAJI: By the end of February 2020, commuters can finally expect to be relieved from the frequent traffic congestion presently plaguing Cortalim junction. Dilip Buildcon has finally received the required clearance from the forest department and work on the service road from Cortalim junction to RK Marbles in Thane has begun. Once traffic is diverted via this service road, it will also enable work on the superstructure of the eight-lane Zuari bridge to progress at a faster pace, said officials of Dilip Buildcon, contractors for the massive project.

Work of levelling the ground for the 2.5km-long Cortalim service road is already under way. “The work was on hold because of pending clearance from the forest department. They have now given the clearance and we have started constructing the service road. It should be ready for use within a month,” said Atul Joshi, vice-president (constructions), Dilip Buildcon.

The contractor had asked for traffic to be diverted on the Cortalim stretch during the advanced stages of construction of the new Zuari bridge in view of the safety of commuters during the construction.

Once traffic is diverted via this road, it will increase travel distance from Panaji to Margao route by around 2.5km. Plans for this service road were first finalised in December 2018, but work has started only now, 13 months later. The two-lane service road, estimated to cost Rs 18 crore, will run parallel to the railway line.

While the bridge has been paid for by the Union ministry of road transport and highway (MoRTH), the state government has to fund this diversion.

Officials said that once the four-lane highway expansion work on the Cortalim stretch is over, this two-lane service road, to be built on land leased from Konkan Railways, is likely to continue as an alternative route.

The decision to create the service road was taken under Manohar Parrikar’s tenure as CM, but the road kept hitting multiple hurdles.

Title: German firm redesigns pedestrian-friendly project
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Coimbatore: Two months after turning the Big Bazaar Road and Raja Street at Town Hall colourful by implementing tactical urbanism on pilot basis to improve facilities for pedestrians and cyclists, German company Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH submitted a permanent design for the stretch to the city corporation on Monday.

“The permanent design was made based on the feedback received during the 14-day-long trail period from commuters. The designs were made keeping the historical significance of the stretch and it would resemble the existing structure and design. We have also requested the corporation to arrange a stakeholders’ meeting. During the meet, the design will be presented and feedback will also be incorporated,” said Ranjith Parvathapuram, urban transport expert with GIZ.

“We have given a facelift to the clock tower and provided tabletop crossing at the junctions. Tabletop crossing would ensure safety of pedestrians. We propose to remove the dead space between the shops and the bus stop by integrating them. Also, with the help of corporation officials, we will identify intersections that are to be redesigned. There are 80 such intersections in the city. As it is difficult to redesign all the intersections, we are in talks with the stakeholders to identify 10 to 15 critical intersections,” Parvathapuram said.

The firm had signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with the city corporation to implement integrated sustainable urban transport systems for smart cities (SMART-SUT) project in the city. As part of the initiative, 300 kilometres of non-motorized transport routes and 26 pedestrian activity centres were identified. The project is estimated to cost Rs 1,700 crores to be implemented in five phases in 15 years.

Title: Apartment assn raises stink on VMC move
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Vijayawada: Vijayawada Municipal Corporation’s (VMC) proposal to classify apartments as bulk garbage generators is sparking controversy.

The civic body is eyeing to engage special agencies to collect waste from bulk garbage generators. Residents of apartments and residential colony welfare organisations are gearing up to agitate against the move.

VMC which is focused on improving sanitation in the city has started implementing door-to-door garbage collection.

Taxpayers association strongly condemned the proposal of classifying apartments as bulk waste generators. MV Anjaneyulu, secretary of the association said Vijayawada Municipal Corporation was shirking its responsibilities.

“Each and every flat in the apartment is classified as a separate assessment. Each and every flat owner is paying property and other taxes to the Vijayawada Municipal Corporation.

Engaging private agencies to collect garbage from apartments will be a huge burden on the inhabitants of the residential complexes. “We will not let this happen at any cost,” he said.

Left parties urged VMC to withdraw the decision on classifying apartments as bulk garbage generators.

Title: Festival of Ideas for a week next yr: CM
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Panaji: Efforts will be made to ensure that the next edition of DD Kosambi Festival of Ideas is seven days long, said chief minister Pramod Sawant.

He was speaking at the inauguration of the four-day festival at Kala Academy on Monday. “We must continue to hold this festival forever,” Sawant said. “This time we had it only for four days. However, we will try to arrange for it to go on for seven days so that more thinkers, educationists and eminent persons deliver their speeches at this festival,” he said.

Sawant also pointed out that unlike the previous years, all the speakers in this edition of the festival are women.

The speakers this year include Olympic medallist and retired Indian weightlifter Karnam Malleswari, the first Indian woman medallist in the paralympics Deepa Malik, the first woman sarpanch with an MBA, Chhavi Rajawat, and CEO of Northern Arc Capital Kshama Fernandes. “This festival is the government’s effort to help improve people’s minds in various areas like literature and science There is no age bar when it some to gathering information or new ideas,” Sawant said.

Title: Respond on English medium move, Andhra Pradesh govt told
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: The high court on Monday directed the state and Union government to file affidavits in the PIL challenging the introduction of English medium in all government schools from primary level.

The chief spokesperson of BJP, Andhra Pradesh , Srinivasa Sudhish Rambotla and one Guntupalli Srinivas from Eluru had moved the high court challenging the state government’s decision.

The petitioners argued that government order 85 issued by the school education department is in violation of the Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act, 2009.

Rambotla argued that the state government cannot make any law in contravention with the central law. Moreover, the right to select the medium of instruction should be with the children and they should not be forced to take English medium, he stated. While the state government sought more time to file the counter, the petitioners’ advocate claimed that the government is going ahead with the implementation of GO 85 and public money is being spent to print textbooks. Responding to the petitioners argument, the high court said that they would recover the costs from the officials concerned if the need arises and posted the matter for hearing on February 4.

Title: FIR against two organisers of Roshan Bagh protest
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

ALLAHABAD: A protester from Roshan Bagh has accused two key members of the organising group of molesting and threatening her and also stopping her from expressing her views at the agitation.

Hundreds of people, mostly women, have been sitting in protest against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) and the proposed National Register for Citizens (NRC) exercise, in Mansoor Ali Park in the locality since January 12.

In an FIR lodged on Sunday night, the woman protester has accused two key members of the organising group—Sara Ahmad Siddiqui and Umar Khalid. The FIR was lodged under sections 354, 323, 504 and 506 of IPC.

The woman has said that Sara and Umar not only stopped her from delivering a speech but a group of five to six volunteers also thrashed her. She complained that they threatened her with dire consequences if she came to the park again.

Allahabad SSP Satyarth Aniruddha Pankaj said, “We have lodged an FIR against Sara and Umar based on the complaint”.

He also said that police were keeping a close watch on the protest.

Title: Minister inaugurates exhibition on Ganga Yatra, development projects
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Ganga Aarti and Bhajan evening was organised at Sarsaiyya Ghat in the city on Monday evening to mark the launc... Read More

KANPUR: State minister for industrial development Satish Mahana, on Monday, inaugurated Ganga Yatra and Development Exhibition at Nana Rao Park in Bithoor on the day of commencement of Ganga Yatra from Ballia and Bijnor.

He offered flowers to the statue of Ganga installed at the Media centre here and said Ganga Yatra launched from two different places would assemble in Kanpur on January 31. Addressing the gathering, Mahana said that a big public meeting would be held at Ganga Barrage on the arrival of both the teams of Ganga Yatra in the city and appealed to the denizens to reach there in a large number to make it a huge success.

Title: ‘By God’s grace, I was back from the jaws of death’
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nagpur: What would you do if a tiger suddenly appears before you? Well, it is the tiger that will decide, not you. Virendra Dayaram Sahare (45) of Sindpuri had a horrifying experience when a tiger pounced on him, but left him alive on Friday.

The video showing a tiger grabbing Sahare went viral on Friday, sending a chill down the spine of viewers. The incident occurred in Binaki when the tiger was being chased by an unruly mob of villagers. Binaki is 5km away from Sindpuri. And the question doing the rounds is, what was Sahare doing there?

Narrating his ordeal to TOI from his hospital bed in Bhandara district, Sahare, a marginal farmer, said, “I had never seen a tiger in my life. While returning from Bapera, where I had gone to procure ‘dhan’ rice, I saw a crowd making a big noise to chase the tiger out. The beast was in the bushes on the other side of the road. It had already attacked one villager.”

“I was curious to sight the tiger. After parking my two-wheeler near a farm, I chose the isolated farm bund to have a glimpse of it. There were two more persons there. Even as the crowd shouted, the furious tiger came out and crossed the road and straightway headed towards the farm bund where I was standing,” recalled Sahare.

“The two persons standing near me vanished, but before I could gather myself, the tiger pounced on me and within seconds I was brought down. The tiger sat on my back, grabbing me with his paws. I didn’t panic and the one sensible thing that I did was to lower my head downwards and hold it with both hands so that the tiger doesn’t catch my neck,” said Sahare.

As the crowd, with stones in their hands, turned towards the tiger, it left Sahare and ran away. “I tried getting up but couldn’t as I suffered deep bruises on my back. Due to the weight of the tiger on my body, I also suffered a fracture on my right leg and injuries on the hand. After primary treatment in Sihora, I was shifted to Bhandara,” the victim said.

“There is myth that a cat has nine lives, but I have only one and by God’s grace, I was back from the jaws of death. It’s like a rebirth for me. The one who is guarded by God cannot be killed by anyone. Or else, can you ever imagine freeing yourself from the clutches of a tiger, considered the most ferocious and powerful animal?,” added Sahare.

His condition is said to be stable. The poor farmer, who owns 1.5-acre agriculture land, has a wife named Meena, son Dinesh, who is studying in Std XII and daughter Pallavi, a student of class XI.

“We will provide help to the three persons who were injured in the tiger attack. People are responsible for the mess as the drama continued from 12 noon till 7pm. The tiger had made a kill and had the villagers given it a safe passage, it would have left. The horrifying video also conveys the message that the tiger attacked Sahare in self-defence and the motive was not to kill him,” said Bhandara deputy conservator of forests (DyCF) Vivek Hoshing.

Title: BIEAP Intermediate exams 2020 to begin today
Content: VIJAYAWADA: Board of Intermediate Education Andhra Pradesh (BIEAP) is on overdrive making elaborate arrangements for examinations. The practical tests and ethics and human values examination will be held on Tuesday.BIEAP secretary V Rama Krishna said around 3,37,054 students across the state will attend the examinations — 2,46,653 MPC students; 90,401 BiPC students; and 66,611 vocational courses students.Hall tickets are available for download on the official website of the Intermediate board. The morning session of the examinations will commence from 9am to 1pm and afternoon sessions from 2 pm to 5pm, he said.In a bid to prevent cheating, BIEAP has arranged CCTV surveillance systems at examination halls across the state and stringent action will be initiated against students and colleges which ignore wrongdoing, Rama Krishna said.BIEAP officials said they had examined centers and amenities available there. Parents and students can contact BIEAP on its Whatsapp number 9391282578 for queries relating to the examinations, he added. tnn

Title: Basic education department clerk caught taking bribe, arrested
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: A man who was appointed as junior assistant clerk in the basic education department on compassionate grounds in 2018 after his first wife’s death was allegedly caught red-handed by the Anti-Corruption Bureau sleuths for taking Rs 6,000 as bribe from an assistant teacher on the pretext of releasing his pending arrear papers.

The accused was identified as Rahul Gupta, 37, a resident of sector-7 Awas Vikas Colony under Jagdispura police station. He was nabbed from Avantibai intersection under the jurisdiction of Fatehabad police, at around 2:20 pm while counting notes which were marked by ACB, Agra unit.

A complaint was lodged on January 25 with ACB Agra unit by one Bhola Singh, 38, an assistant teacher posted at the government primary school in Puragugran Brahman village, Fatehabad block.

Speaking with TOI, Bhola Singh said, “Rahul Gupta was demanding a bribe in order to release the papers of eight months of pending arrears, which is around Rs 3 lakh. Initially, he demanded 10% of the total arrear. Later, he agreed on Rs 6,000 cash. I decided to expose him, and contacted ACB unit of Agra in charge, inspector Jaspal Singh Pawar , who helped me to catch the corrupt junior assistant clerk.”

Inspector Mahesh Chandra Gautam, member of the ACB unit that caught the accused clerk, said, “After Rahul’s first wife Gunjan’s death supposedly due to brain hemorrhage in 2012, he got a government job on compassionate ground in September 2018. He was married with Gunjan for four years. Later, he married another woman, a teacher in a private school. Technically, after the second marriage, the basic education department should have removed him from the job, but he continued in the post by allegedly hiding his marital status from the department.”

Gautam added, “We received inputs about him on asking for a bribe from the department’s employee on the pretext of releasing his documents and finally, managed to arrest him.”

At the time of filing this report, ACB was filing an FIR against him at Fatehabad police station.

Title: Anti-CAA violence: Autopsy report of 5 in Firozabad confirms death due to bullet injury
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: A special investigation team led by Firozabad SP (rural) Rajesh Kumar, which is probing the December 20 violence, has claimed that autopsy reports of five out of seven men killed in anti-CAA violence in the district confirmed their death due to bullet injuries. The other two victims had laceration wounds.

According to police, the men died of gunshot were Mohammad Shafeeq (45), Armaan (24), Mohammad Haroon (33), Nabi Jaan (22) and Mukim (20), while Rashid (33) and Mohammad Abrar (28) succumbed to other injuries.

TOI accessed three autopsy reports, including that of Mohammad Shafeeq, Armaan and Mohammad Abrar. Two of the victims – Mohammad Shafeeq, whose postmortem was conducted by doctors at Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital, and Armaan, whose autopsy was conducted by doctors at Firozabad’s district hospital, stated that duo had suffered bullet wounds (entry) of 2.8x1cm and 1x1cm, respectively. While in the case of Mohammad Abrar, no bullet injury was mentioned in the report. It just stated “laceration wound 4x2cm bone deep over the upper vertebral column. Peeling off skin and bad sore present extensively over the back of shoulder, buttocks and both thighs”.

Speaking with TOI, Abdul Mutalib (22), younger brother of Abrar, said, “My brother had suffered bullet injury in his spinal cord and was operated at Delhi’s Apollo Hospital after the intervention of Delhi government, but post-mortem report conducted by Firozabad doctors makes no mention of bullet injury. The autopsy report has flaw and I don’t accept it.”

When contacted, Firozabad SP Sachindra Patel said, “All the cases are under investigation by specially constituted special investigation team (SIT).”

Talking to TOI, SIT head and SP (rural) Rajesh Kumar said, “The autopsy reports claims only five died of gunshot injuries, while two had laceration wounds. Since not a single bullet was recovered from the victims’ bodies, we have asked the forensic team to investigate, as what kind of weapon was used to shoot the victims.”

Meanwhile, SP (city) Prabal Pratap Singh said, “I have not seen all the autopsy reports but I knew that six men had suffered bullet injuries, but if SIT has found that only five had suffered bullet injuries, then their finding is more authentic.”

Title: Republic Day celebrated with patriotic fervour
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

KANPUR: City celebrated Republic Day amidst patriotic atmosphere on Sunday. Tricolour was hoisted at all government offices, schools and colleges and other places.

Industrial development minister of UP Satish Mahana was the chief guest at Republic Day celebrations at Reserve Police lines. During the programme, he said that constitution had given us rights and some duties. All of us should perform duties for the country.

District magistrate Kanpur Nagar Dr Brahma Dev Ram Tiwari hoisted National flag at Collectorate office and felicitated the freedom fighters and their family members. Later, he celebrated Republic day with kids of Spastic Centre at Phoolbagh. Children of Spastic centre presented a cultural programme and also presented a sapling to the DM. The children presented a tableau based on Pulwama attack and recited patriotic songs on the occasion.

District judge Ashok Kumar hoisted the flag at Kanpur judiciary building and at Kanpur Bar Association .

Title: Coimbatore: Days after wife’s delivery, nine organs of brain-dead man donated
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The wife of a 29-year-old man, who suffered brain death due to an accident when he was rushing her to a hospital for delivery, agreed to donate nine of his organs on Sunday.

On Thursday, V Gowtham, 29, an engineer, was driving his wife Manimekalai, 26, who was in severe labour pain, from N Ganapathy Palayam, in Tirupur to KMCH in Sulur in a car. When they were driving through Mettukkadu, Gowtham collided head-on with another four-wheeler.

“Gowtham suffered head injuries but Manimekalai, who was pregnant, did not suffer any major injuries,” a KMCH spokesperson said. Both were rushed to KMCH, Sulur.

While Manimekalai managed to deliver her baby via C-section the same evening, Gowtham was transferred to KMCH Avinashi Road for specialized treatment, where doctors desperately tried to release the pressure in his skull. However, he did not respond to treatment. From Saturday evening, doctors began performing the sleep apnea tests.

On Sunday, doctors declared him brain dead. Gowtham’s wife and parents Viswanathan and Samundiswari were informed. The couple had not even celebrated their first anniversary, which falls in February.

“Manimekalai who is understandably devastated was the most receptive initially, when the option of donating his organs came up. It was she who kept repeating that at least her husband’s organs can keep other people alive instead of it going waste,” said one of their relatives, Selvaraj. On Sunday afternoon, the family agreed to donate his organs.

On Monday, teams from four hospitals, across two cities, began the surgery to harvest the organs from Gowtham’s body. While his lung was donated to a patient in Chennai-based Global Hospitals, his liver went to MIOT Hospital and heart valves to Frontline hospital. While a kidney was transplanted in KMCH itself, the other kidney was donated to a patient in GKNM Hospital. His eyes were sent to a private hospital, while skin and bones were sent to Ganga Hospital.

Title: Kolkata: Priests to turn social pivots in ‘trying times’
Content:
The Preamble being read out at Christ the King Church on Republic Day

KOLKATA: A three-day annual meet of Catholic priests started on Monday to discuss how they should reinvent their roles “in these difficult times.” Every year, priests of the churches under the archdiocese of Kolkata attend the annual meet to discuss church-related issues but this year is different since the church leadership is looking at how individual priests can take on the roles of social pivots in their respective parishes.While the first two days will see discussions on church-related issues like lack of priests, the last day will have an open house where citizenship-related issues and how priests should dispel fears among the poor and illiterate people are likely to come up.Both the Roman Catholic church and the Church of North India (CNI) have taken lead roles in leading the anti-CAA/NRC movement in the city. They have both taken to the streets in mobilising support for the Constitution and have pledged to stand by all those whose citizenship claim might come under question despite their domicile and other bona fide status. The Preamble has been read in churches. Churches have also played a key role in the United Interfaith-organised human chain across the city in support of the Constitution.“The role of a priest is to talk to the poor and insecure people residing within his parish and assure them of support. So during the meet, when the conversation naturally moves towards the issue of the fear rhetoric, will will remind the priest of his added responsibilities at such times and how he should take the poor and insecure of all faiths under his wing,” said archbishop Thomas D’Souza. He added that every priest should treat all people residing within his parish equally and should not only cater to the Christians.The meet is taking place at Proggaloy, a training centre for Catholic priests at Barasat. “We will listen to the issues of individual churches of different parishes that are typical of such meets and try to look for solutions but we will have to look at the bigger picture too,” said vicar general Dominic Gomes, who had taken the lead role in getting Preambles printed and circulated to be read inside churches after Mass on Republic Day.Father Rodney of Loyola Church felt that since his church is located in Kidderpore, he interacts a lot with people from minority communities and has been working towards dispelling doubts and fears in their minds. “We hope this meet brings further clarity about our roles in these times because people of all communities look up to us for support,” he said.

Title: With three new cases, swine flu rears head in Meerut
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

MEERUT: An advisory issued by the health department after three cases of swine flu were reported in Meerut city has returned spotlight on the deadly disease after a hiatus of some months. With three cases reported in the first month of the year, the health department is making sure all their arrangements are complete.

According to details provided by the health department, the first case in Meerut, reported on Thursday, was of a 62-year-old man. Next day, his 28-year-old son was also diagnosed positive. The elderly man was detected with symptoms that were eventually detected as swine flu, had just returned from Roorkee, where he had gone for a wedding a few days ago. Both of them live in Sadar . The third case was reported from Phool Bagh Colony on Saturday.

“An advisory has been issued in the matter and all residents have been asked to report any symptoms directly to the doctor. Meanwhile, private hospitals have been asked to make isolation wards for patients with swine flu. This is because many private hospitals put Swine Flu patients in ICU with other patients, despite our instructions that the disease is communicable and patients should be kept in isolation wards. This is not correct, and so, all private hospitals have been asked to make separate wards for swine flu, to ensure that neither other patients nor hospital staffs get infected,” said Dr Raj Kumar, chief medical officer, Meerut.

The last case of swine flu reported in Meerut was on October 17, 2019. A total of 399 cases of swine flu were reported in 2019, against 24 cases in 2018.

Areas where the swine flu affected live are being surveilled to check if there are more, unknown cases. Awareness camps are also being organised in these places so that people in these areas can exercise caution. Also, epidemiological study and travel history of patients is being checked, said health department authorities.

Title: ‘Nothing more rewarding if one’s passion-driven achievement makes country feel proud of you’
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

The Crypto Price Tracker is a portfolio management and price tracking tool for cryptocurrencies that does price tracking and customizable alerts. It tracks the prices of over 1,000 cryptocurrencies from over 18 exchanges in 32 fiat currencies. It also provides price charts for all monitored cryptocurrencies during the last one day, one week, one month, three months, and one year.

Meerut: At just 18, this Saharanpur girl who home–schooled herself has PM Narendra Modi tweeting about her achievements, “I am delighted that the very talented Harshita Arora has been conferred the Bal Shakti Puraskar 2020….” She is the proud recipient of Bal Shakti Puruskar (Innovation category) for developing a number of apps, including the Crypto Price Tracker – a best-selling app in Canada and the US, and a food app. She is also a co-founder of a $9 million dollar startup funded by renowned venture capitalists.

Currently living in San Francisco on O-1 visa, granted to only those who demonstrate extraordinary ability by achieving international acclaim, Harshita flew down to India after learning she had been selected for the award.

This self-taught innovator dropped out of school when she was 14 as she was “not cut out for common courses” to pursue her dream of developing apps. When she was 16, she was conferred upon ‘Woman of the Year Award’ in Toronto in Canada at the CryptoChicks Hackathon Conference.

Daughter of a local financer and a homemaker mother, Harshita is now aspiring to graduate from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) to “gain enough knowledge to work on Brain Computer Interface (BCI)”.

“There is nothing more rewarding if one’s passion-driven achievement makes your country feel proud of you. This award (Bal Shakti Puruskar) is a reflection of that. And, Prime Minister Modi acknowledging that. What more can you ask for? He congratulated me and asked me where I was from,” Harshita said after the PM gave her the award.

After meeting her, Modi on Friday tweeted about Harshita, “She has been focussing on a wide range of sectors. Her passion towards science, technology and human welfare is clearly visible.”

Harshita was just 16 when the app that updates users about price fluctuations in more than 1,000 cryptocurrencies in 32 countries had become one of the most sought-after paid apps on Apple’s App store.

The first time she heard about cryptocurrencies was in 2016. She soon got into Bitcoin mining, the basic underlying technology and cryptography. Not that the sudden stardom has come easy. When Harshita introduced the iOS app, she was at the receiving end of a lot of cynicism, with some doubting that a girl of her age could build an iOS platform like that and others accusing her of plagiarizing the app. All that is behind her now.

Harshita told TOI, “Ever since I was 13 and was introduced to designing concepts, I began reading IT magazines and the latest developments in the field. I learned about cryptocurrency and how it worked. Then I interacted with my internet friends and real investors in the currency to understand what they wanted in an app.

Soon enough I undertook a four-week MIT Launch , a (a high school entrepreneur programme) which helped me a lot.” This was a four-week long entrepreneurship programme for people between 15 and 19 years of age.

At present, Harshita is developing a sustainable transportation commuting app which will work in San Francisco and nearby areas and is the co-founder of the startup.

Title: Held for sloganeering, former AMU student released on bail
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Agra: The ex-student of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) who was arrested on Sunday for shouting slogans against the VC along with some other students at the official Republic Day function, was released on bail on Monday.

Ahmad Mujtaba Faraz was granted bail after two AMU faculty members — Prof Mohammad Mohibul Haque and Prof Imrana Naseem — stood surety for him. Earlier on Sunday night, students who were protesting for Faraz’s release at Chungi gate ended their dharna after being assured of support by faculty members.

On Sunday, four students were detained by police after the varsity’s proctor team handed them over to cops for raising slogans against the vice-chancellor, when he began addressing the gathering at the official Republic Day function on campus. The students were identified as Tahir Azmi and Siddhartha Gulati from the engineering department, BA student Rafiuddin and ex-student Ahmad Mujtaba Faraz.

Later in the evening, police released the current students, while Faraz was sent to judicial remand under Section 151 of CrPc, for creating disturbance. The students had shouted “Go back” as the VC began his Republic Day speech, to protest against his not protecting students and allowing police inside campus on December 15, which left several students injured. AMU students have been demanding the VC’s resignation ever since.

The students detained on Sunday alleged that the proctor team had manhandled them, and that some anti-socials had also attacked them. They claimed that instead of protecting varsity students, the proctor team took handed them over to police.

When the news spread on campus, scores of students, including women, gathered outside the proctor’s office and shouted slogans, “Yeh jo dehshatgardi hai, uske peeche vardi hai (police terror is behind the fear among students)”.

Title: 45 bird species, two more than last year, spotted in Hastinapur: Census
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Members of AWC Volunteer's Group.

MEERUT: The presence of 45 species of resident and migratory birds has been recorded by birders and students who participated in the Asian Waterbird Census ( AWC ) 2020 in the Hastinapur Range of Hastinapur Wildlife Sanctuary on January 13. In the previous census, 43 species were recorded. The total bird count also registered an increase in numbers this year.

Student volunteers’ team from the department of zoology, Chaudhary Charan Singh University, led by professor A K Chaubey successfully carried out the census. The census was coordinated by AWC, Delhi state coordinator TK Roy, an ecologist. He also accompanied the team.

According to Roy, “In all, 45 species of resident and winter migratory were recorded in the just concluded census against 43 last year. The total population of birds was 3,103 in comparison to previous year’s 2,705.”

Some of the species spotted were Graylag geese, Bar-headed geese, Ruddy shelduck and Gadwal. Some threatened species that figure in the IUCN Red List such as Woolly-necked stork , Painted stork and Sarus crane were also spotted.

The census further observed that the global climate change impact delayed arrival of migratory water birds from far Central Asia and North Asia for wintering here.

The AWC is an integral part of the global waterbird monitoring programme, the International Waterbird Census (IWC) of Wetlands International. The AWC was initiated in 1987 in the Indian subcontinent and since has grown rapidly to cover major regions of Asia, from Afghanistan to Japan, Southeast Asia and Australasia. The census covers the entire east Asian– Australasian flyway and a large part of Central Asian flyway.

Title: Identify chest pain, get loading dose if it’s heart related: Doc
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nagpur: Hypertension and heart troubles have become so common these days that people relate every chest pain to heart attack. While chest pain can be one of the prime symptoms of heart attack, every chest pain is not going to land your heart in trouble. On Saturday, cardiologist Dr Rhishikesh Umalkar explained how patients can evaluate chest pain and keep themselves risk free in any situation with proper use of ‘loading dose’.

“Chest pain should never be ignored. Sometimes it can be a non-cardiac chest pain . In case it radiates to the shoulders, arms or jaw, it could be a sign of heart attack. It’s always better to identify the type of pain and rush to the doctor for proper treatment,” said Dr Umalkar.

According to him, if chest pain is accompanied by chest tightness, squeezing, heaviness, or a crushing sensation, one should not wait for the echocardiogram (ECG) and get the loading dose which is must for dissolving clot.

“ECG detects heart movements at least one hour late. It’s always better not to wait and go for the loading dose. It has no side effect. I suggest physicians and diabetologist to keep the loading dose ready in their clinics,” Dr Umalkar said.

He also suggested that family history, habits like smoking, obesity, elevated cholesterol and diabetes are risk factors for heart attacks.

Umalkar was speaking at a continuing medical education (CME) event on new drugs in diabetes and hypertension, organized on Saturday by Indian Medical Association (IMA) Nagpur chapter.

Diabetologist Dr Himanshu Patil said that new drug combination for type 2 diabetes not only controls sugar but also reduces weight.

“Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists and sodium-glucose cotransporter type 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors are newest glucose-lowering agents. Both classes have showed a cardiovascular protection along with sugar control. So, patients with type 2 diabetes along with high cardiovascular risk should be prescribed these new medicines,” he said and added that these medicines prove very effective, especially in the long-term treatment of diabetes and hypertension.

Title: As CM Yogi Adityanath flagged off Ganga Yatra in Bijnor, women protest against notices to ‘vacate land’
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

BIJNOR: The women from Bijnor’s Rampur Thakra village protested, on Monday, over notices sent to them to vacate their village as the land they are living on reportedly belongs to the forest department. Interestingly, this is the same area where UP CM Yogi Adityanath flagged off the Ganga Yatra.

This comes even as the Allahabad High Court has ruled in favour of the forest department, which claimed that the land on the banks of Ganga where the villagers live belongs to Hastinapur sanctuary and reserve forest area.

In the final minutes of CM’s speech at Ganga Barrage, a dozen of women and children suddenly got up and started raising slogans such as ‘Yogi Adityanath jindabad, humari mange puri karo’. They were voicing their concerns as they have been served notices several times to vacate the village land. The officers at the venue tried to stop them. They gave assurance to look into their demands.

Notably, Rampur Thakara village is located around 10 km from Bijnor city on the banks of Ganga River. The village comprises a population of around 600 with its own school, government road and power connections. Around 80% people are from schedule caste here.

Villagers avail of all government facility. They have a pradhan as well. This village falls under Salempur Mathana village and part of Hastinapur sanctuary area. Primarily farmers, the families also own nearly 66 hectare (726 bighas) of agricultural land which is said to be of forest land.

According to officials, the village in the sanctuary area was declared “illegal” in 2011. The forest department served notices to farmers who were engaged in farming on the 66 hectare of land here. Forest authorities had asked them not to do any farming for now. The village is said to be 40 years old but because of its location in sanctuary area, it has been declared “illegal”. Even the HC has given clear instructions in this matter.
