Title: Kolkata: One Billion Rising to turn spotlight on CAA and NRC
Content:
TMC women activists shout slogan during a protest against NRC and CAA in Kolkata on Monday. (ANI Photo)

KOLKATA: A directive, sent to the Loreto nuns about how the One Billion Rising (OBR) movement is being envisaged for this year by the Delhi headquarters, focuses on NRC and CAA. The OBR has been happening for six years in the city and focussing on the issues related to women safety as the movement was started by Eve Ensler in 2012 to fight sexual harassment and rape. The OBR in the city has been planned at Allen Park on January 31.With the word “rising” being spontaneously akin to nationwide protests against the CAA and NRC , the programme of the city OBR will revolve around these issues this year. The Kolkata Mary Ward Social Centre, a Loreto resource and development centre for social change inside Loreto Entally, which organizes the OBR, had already planned a discussion on the issues while the directive from the headquarters has come as a shot in the arm.“The nationwide protests against CAA and NRC will become an integral part of the OBRs everywhere this time. The OBRs across the country have joined hands with networks, organisations, universities, colleges and students who are protesting against the issues,” the directive reads.The event at Allen Park will see the presence of mayor Firhad Hakim, chief secretary Rajiva Sinha and all top cops in the city. “We will discuss inequality challenges faced by people across the country, instead of keeping it limited to the issues pertaining to women,” said Sister Monica Suchiang, the Loreto nun, who is the chief of the Centre. “I am happy that the OBR has a broader perspective this time. India has been celebrated across the globe for its Constitution that promotes equality and justice. Suddenly everything is being challenged and the country has risen as a whole…” said Anglo Indian MLA Shane Calvert, who will be chairing the discussion.

Title: CPCB: E-tailers must collect plastic waste they generate
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

NEW DELHI: E-commerce platforms , Amazon and Flipkart , must fulfil their extended producer responsibility under the Plastic Waste Management Rules , 2016, and need to put in place a system for collecting back the plastic waste generated due to the packaging of their products, Central Pollution Control Board ( CPCB ) told National Green Tribunal (NGT) on Tuesday.The apex pollution monitoring body told the green tribunal that according to provisions 9(2) of the Plastic Waste Management Rules, 2016, “Primary responsibility for collection of used multi-layered plastic sachet or pouches or packaging is of producers, importers and brand owners who introduce the products in the market.”“Amazon Retail India Private Limited and Flipkart Private limited are involved in packaging and selling of other companies’ products and thus introducing plastic packaging in the market. They need to fulfil their extended producer responsibility under PWM rules and should obtain registration as brand owner after submitting proper documents,” it said.The CPCB submission came in response to a plea filed by a 16-year-old boy, who had earlier approached the tribunal to stop e-commerce giants from excessive plastic use in their packaging. Aditya Dubey, through his legal guardian, had pleaded the NGT to direct Amazon and Flipkart to stop excessive use of plastic in packaging the goods delivered by the firms.“Single-use plastic is non-biodegradable and ultimately contaminates soil and water,” Dubey highlighted in the petition. He added the two companies have not made arrangements for either taking back the plastic material or ensuring that it is recycled.“Plastic packaging constitutes 43% of the total plastic waste generated in India and it is imperative that a direction be issued to the respondents that they should stop using plastic packaging materials and shift to environment friendly packaging option,” the plea had said.

Title: UP: Inspired by crime shows, youth murders Noida girl to fake death of his girlfriend
Content:
Accused man in police custody

MEERUT: In a major breakthrough, local cops in Bulandshahr claim to have solved the murder mystery of a woman whose body was recovered from Sikandrabad area on January 26. The deceased was identified as 20-year-old Poonam, a resident of Jarcha area in Noida who used to work at a mobile company.A couple, in their 20s and native of Bulandshahr, have been arrested for orchestrating and executing the murder of Poonam. According to police, the two arrested accused - Kapil and Ruby Sharma - were in a relationship and were planning to marry but the family of the girl was against it.The couple, inspired by television crime shows, decided to fake death of Ruby by killing another girl, disfigure her face to conceal identity and put on Ruby’s clothes and ornaments on the body to disguise the murder of another girl as that of Ruby.“During a detailed interrogation it was revealed that Kapil was in a relationship with Ruby. The couple decided to elope after dumping Poonam’s body in cattle shed and setting it on fire to conceal her identity and disguise it as Ruby’s. This is a premeditated murder,” Atul Srivastava, SP (city) Bulandshahr said.The accused Kapil, as per plan, befriended Poonam recently and took her out on January 25 on the pretext of shopping. At a deserted location, Kapil strangulated Poonam using car seat belt and later abandoned her body inside a cattle enclosure next to Ruby’s house in Sikandrabad area of Bulandshahr.In the meanwhile, Poonam’s family in Noida alerted the local police about their missing daughter and raised suspicion on Kapil following which Noida police alerted their counterparts in Bulandshahr. An FIR of abduction was registered at Sikandrabad police station in Bulandshahr.Kapil, the main accused, was arrested in time before he could completely disfigure the face and execute the final leg of his plan. Based on his inputs, body of Poonam was recovered from the cattle shed next to Ruby’s house. Later, Ruby was also arrested.In Video: Crime shows inspire youth to kill girl to fake girlfriend’s death

Title: Former MLA’s son surrenders in 4-year-old attempt-to-murder case
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: Vijay Pratap Singh Yadav , the son of former Sirsaganj MLA Hariom Yadav , on Monday, surrendered in Firozabad district court in a four-year-old case involved an attempt to murder his rival.

Vijay, the former Firozabad district council president , was booked in October 2015 at Shikohabad police station, under IPC sections 147 (rioting), 504 (provoke breach of peace), 452 (house-trespass), 307 (attempt to murder) and 120B (criminal conspiracy) based on the written complaint of Vasudev, the nephew of the victim, Ramesh Chandra.

In the FIR, Vasudev had alleged that Vijay and group of armed men had attacked his uncle Ramesh Chandra for standing in the district council president election. “At around 4am, a gang lead by Hariom’s son attacked Ramesh while he was sleeping in bed,” read the FIR.

According to additional district government counsel Narendra Kumar Rathor, “Vijay surrendered in the court of additional session judge VIII, Arvind Kumar Yadav, after he received no relief from Allahabad high court and was asked to file a bail plea in the district court. The court has sent Vijay to jail and will hear his bail plea on Tuesday.”

Title: Couple found unconscious in hotel room, woman dies
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: Mathura police on Monday registered a case of murder against a man in connection with the death of a woman under mysterious circumstances in a hotel in Vrindavan. The man was also found in an unconscious state in the same room and was admitted to hospital in a critical condition.

According to police, the couple had checked into the hotel on Sunday at around 2.30 pm. Both were found in an unconscious state in their room. The woman was identified as Mamta Misra (38) and the man, who is in hospital, is Shazi Khan, 38. The duo hailed from Delhi’s Paschim Puri , said police.

Talking to TOI, SP (city) A K Meena said the hotel staff informed police about the couple. When the police reached there, the woman was found lying on the floor and the man was in the toilet. They immediately rushed them to hospital, where Mamta was declared dead and the man was referred to Agra hospital as his condition was critical. Now, his condition is stable and he has been shifted to a ward, said doctors at Agra Medical College.

The SP told TOI that the couple is suspected to have consumed some poisonous substance. He said a medicine bottle was found from the crime spot and vomit was spread on a bed. But there were no marks of struggle in the room or on their bodies. “The forensic team has collected all evidence from the room and the medicine bottle has been sent for examination,” he said, adding that the woman’s stomach was washed and its contents have also been collected for examination.

He said the woman’s body has been sent for postmortem and further investigations are on.

Her husband, Deendayal Misra, who reached Vrindavan in the afternoon after being informed by police, told mediapersons that he was not aware of her sudden arrival to Vrindavan. “We used to come to Vrindavan, but I was not aware about this visit,” said Misra, adding that he did not know anything about Khan.

An FIR has been registered against Khan under IPC section 328 (causing hurt by means of poisons) and 302 (murder) on a complaint filed by the woman’s husband, at Vrindavan police station.

Title: Butterfly park opened to public on Republic Day in Saharanpur
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

MEERUT: A butterfly park spread over four acres in erstwhile Company Garden, now renamed Subhas Chandra Park, was opened to public on the occasion of Republic Day on Sunday in Saharanpur. The park has 74 species of host plants for butterflies and the authorities expect that at least 70 species of butterflies will be attracted here over the next three months when the flowers bloom.

Saharanpur divisional commissioner Sanjay Kumar said, “The much awaited butterfly park spread over four acres inside the 121-acre Subhas Chandra Park was opened for people on the occasion of Republic Day. The park funded by the Saharanpur Development Authority has around 74 species of various host plants for attracting butterflies, a water body, a gazebo and a trail of around 1,200 meters. The plants here shall bloom within next three months and we expect them to be attract over 70 species of butterflies.”

Kumar further said it shall serve as an eco-learning place for all who visit the park. Earlier, Lucknow and Kanpur in UP have to their credit one butterfly park each. Butterflies and moths are symbols of a quality, healthy and green ecosystem. They are an important part of the food chain and help in pollinating flowers.

It should be noted that the Company Park was renamed Subhas Chandra Park on the 124th birth anniversary of Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose on January 23.

Title: BJP MLA: Priyanka Gandhi visiting stone-pelters, saying ‘koi patthar se na maare…’
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi

MUZAFFARNAGAR: BJP MLA from Khatauli Vikram Saini , known for making controversial remarks, hit a new low on Monday when he referred to Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi as someone “who is roaming around and visiting stoke-pelters at their homes and saying ‘koi patthar se na mare mere diwane ko’.” He was referring to Gandhi’s recent visits to the homes of the victims of the anti-CAA protests.

Saini was speaking at a public rally which was also addressed by UP CM Yogi Adityanath a while later in Muzaffarnagar as a part of the state government’s five-day Ganga Yatra.

In August last year, a day after the Centre moved to scrap special privileges to J&K under Article 370, Saini had said that Muslims in the country should be happy that they can now marry “gori” Kashmiri girls without any fear. He added that bachelors in BJP are now welcome to go to Kashmir, buy plots of land and get married.

In February, the MLA had offered to go to Pakistan with a nuclear bomb attached to him and destroy the neighbouring country.

The same month, he also said at a public function, "I have told my wife to keep producing more children, although she had told me that two were enough."

A month earlier in January, he had said, “Those who feel unsafe in this country are anti-nationals and do not deserve to live. Give me a ministry and I'll attach a bomb to their posteriors and blast them.”

Title: Coimbatore: Doctors remove 1 kg of hair from girl’s stomach
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: About a kilogram of hair was removed from the stomach of a 13-year-old girl at VGM Gastro Centre in the city recently.

A few days ago, the girl, a resident of Kalapatti, was admitted with complaints of acute pain in her upper abdomen. A CT scan report revealed a ball of loosely-woven fibrous tissue inside her stomach, but it later turned out to be a bunch of hair in the shape of the stomach, according to a press release from the hospital.

The release said that doctors had tried to remove it endoscopically but in vain. It was then decided to do laparoscopy on the child.

“A surgical gasteroenterology team headed by Dr Gokul Kirubashankar performed laparoscopy on the child. The stomach of the child was cut open and a sterile plastic bag called endo bag was passed through the stomach to collect the bunch of hair without spilling it into the peritoneal cavity,” the release added.

During the counselling, it was learned that the child went into depression after a close relative passed away. As a result, she had been eating her own hair and was losing weight due to poor appetite and continuous vomiting.

Without understanding the problem that the child has been going through, her parents had assumed that the child had been losing hair due to poor nutrition.

“This is the first such case I have seen in my 32 years of experience and the disease – trichobezoar – is extremely rare,” chairman of the hospital Dr VG Mohan Prasad said.

Title: Muslim women stage protest against CAA on Republic Day
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: There is no stopping protesters against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) in Uttar Pradesh . On Republic Day, a group of around 60 Muslim women staged a protest against the Act outside Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University’s Paliwal Park campus.

The protestors claimed that they are not associated with any organization. The women in burkha refused to reveal their identity. They were carrying the tricolor and posters against the CAA, National Population Register (NPR) and National Register for Citizens (NRC).

One of the protestors told TOI, “We have gathered to oppose the CAA as it is anti-constitutional and aimed at targeting Muslims. We want the government to immediately roll back the CAA and drop the idea of NPR and NRC. Otherwise, we the women of Agra will go on an indefinite strike like the one taking place in Shaheen Bagh in Delhi.”

The protest continued for over 30 minutes. Protesters dispersed after the arrival of police.

Ajay Kaushal, station officer, Hariparwat police station, said, “A few women had gathered outside Agra University just to click pictures of protesting against CAA. Soon after police reached spot, they dispersed. No case has been registered in the entire matter.”

Title: UP: Teenager killed in celebratory firing
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: Celebratory firing during a birthday party killed a 15-year-old-year-old girl in Firozabad district.

The incident occurred on Sunday night in Tapa Khurd village under Uttar police jurisdiction. The victim was identified as Sadhana of Shahzadpur village under Karhal police jurisdiction of Mainpuri district. The victim had come to her elder sister Nitesh’s home along with her father Sukhvasi to attend a birthday party when she sustained a bullet injury.

Speaking to TOI, Uttar station house officer Keshav Dutt Sharma said, “During the birthday celebration, Nitesh’s brother-in-law Akash Kumar (20) indulged in celebratory firing. He had borrowed a licenced rifle of his relative Pramod to fire shots in the air. One of the bullets fired from the rifle hit the teenager and she succumbed to her injuries.”

“After the incident, accused Akash and rifle owner Pramod went absconding. Based on victim’s father’s written complaint, we have registered a case against Akash but will also take action against Pramod for handing over his rifle to Akash,” SHO added.

Sadhana’s body was handed over to her family on Monday after autopsy.

Title: Vadodara airport judged cleanest, safest
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

VADODARA: Vadodara airport has been judged as country’s cleanest and safest airport in the category of airports having annual passenger handling capacity of 1.5 million.

London-based World Record and Quality Certification Limited has bestowed the quality certificate to Vadodara airport. The certificate was handed over to Vadodara airport director Charan Singh in presence of Vadodara MP Ranjan Bhatt during 71st Republic Day celebrations organised at the new integrated terminal building of the Airports Authority of India on Sunday.

“For three consecutive years, we have been judged as the cleanest and safest airport in this category,” said Singh, adding that a team had conducted audit of the airport after which the airport was selected for the quality certification.

The airport currently witnesses 26 flight movements and handles nearly 3,000 passengers with flight connectivity to Delhi, Mumbai, Bengaluru and Hyderabad.

From February 8, Indigo airlines is starting a new evening flight to Mumbai for which bookings have already started. With the new flight, the city will have four daily flights to Mumbai.

Title: City hosts BRASCON 2020
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Vadodara: City was host to a three-days national conference – BRASCON 2020, one of country’s largest breast meeting organized with the theme of ‘comprehensive update on all breast tissues’.

The conference, which ended on Sunday, was organized under the aegis of the Breast Reconstructive and Aesthetic Surgery Association (BRASA).

The conference covered areas spanning from aesthetic, reconstructive, oncoplastic, benign breast disease, oncology, radiotherapy to radio-diagnosis among others. “Thirteen eminent international faculty as well as top doctors from across India shared their expertise on surgical techniques, approaches and advances in their respective fields,” said Dr Sandeep Sharma, plastic surgeon and organizing chairman of BRASCON 2020.

Dr Peter Cordeiro, chief of plastic surgery at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital, New York, Dr Vinay Shankhdar, chief at Tata Memorial Hospital, Mumbai and Dr Bhagwat Mathur, breast surgeon at London, were among those who participated in the scientific deliberations.

Title: 100 sovereigns, Rs 10 lakh stolen from bizman’s home
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Coimbatore: The city police have formed three teams to nab the burglars, who decamped with 100 sovereigns of gold ornaments and Rs 10 lakh from a businessman’s house at Periyar Nagar East in Masakkalipalayam near Singanallur.

Houseowner Adam Shah had left for Thoothukudi last Friday along with his family to attend a function. They returned on Sunday around 8pm to find the rear door broke open and valuables kept in a wardrobe in the ground floor bedroom missing.

The Singanallur (crime) police inspected the spot. Deputy commissioner of police (crime) ES Uma also visited the crime scene and conducted inquiry with the neighbours. Fingerprint experts lifted a print. A sniffer dog was also pressed into service.

“The neighbours told us that they did not see any strangers in the area. The businessman had not installed CCTV cameras,” said a senior police officer.

The Singanallur police have registered a case.

Title: Agra: Traders give ‘negative’ feedback in Swachh Survekshan survey
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

AGRA: Continuing their indefinite strike over the issue of parking fee, Sanjay Place traders on Monday started submitting ‘negative’ feedback in the central government cleanliness survey Swachh Survekshan 2020. The survey is scheduled to conclude on January 31. This comes like a major trouble for Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) administration .

Traders stated that they rated AMC a ‘zero’ on various parameters as the situation of cleanliness has worsened in the city. Besides, a 22.65 crore scam related to door-to-door garbage collection had also surfaced earlier this month.

Swachh Survekshan Survey covers over 4,370 cities across the country and ranks are accorded to them based on cleanliness and other parameters. Citizen feedback is a key component of the survey as it carries 25% weightage in the 6,000 mark survey.

On Monday, traders’ indefinite strike completed fourteen days. Traders have been protesting against the AMC administration for charging parking fee at 38 places in the market since January 14.

President of the Sanjay Place Welfare Association KN Agnihotri said, “Over 100 traders have rated the civic body zero on various parameters of the Swachh Surveskshan Survey because condition of sanitation and hygiene in the city has worsened in the recent past. Sewage problem in Sanjay Place has not been resolved even after repeated complaints. Besides, a major scam took place in the name of door-to-door garbage collection.”

Through public announcement system and phone calls, AMC is spreading awareness about the citizen feedback for Swachh Survekshan Survey. Citizens are being requested to give a high score and a ‘positive’ feedback.

Secretary of the market association Hiren Agarwal said, “We have been protesting since past fourteen days but no AMC official has come to address our issues. We would not be able to cooperate with the civic body administration in getting a good rank in the survey. All the traders will urge their family members and customers to give a negative feedback to AMC as cleanliness in major parts of the city remains in a very poor state.”

Talking to TOI, municipal commissioner Arun Prakash said, “Giving a negative feedback in Swachh Survekshan Survey just to pressurize the AMC administration is in a very bad taste. We will try to ensure that their feedbacks are not counted. In this regard, a letter will be sent to the ministry of urban development.”

Meanwhile, over 50 traders have registered their complaint against AMC on the state government’s Integrated Grievances Redressal System (IGRS).

Title: Court defers Hajipur rape case verdict to February 6
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Disappointed villagers from Hajipur gathered at the sarpanch office after the verdict was postponed to Februar... Read More

Title: Two men returned from China last week, both healthy
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Vadodara: Health department officials of the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) are keeping a close tab on the health of two individuals from the city who returned recently from China. The condition of the two individuals is said to be healthy so far.

VMC officials said that the two men who were around 40-year-old had returned from China after a business trip. Their details were shared with the VMC by state health officials. After they arrived last week, the health officials are keeping in touch with them and inquiring about any ailments.

“So far, they have not shown any flu-like symptoms or respiratory ailments. We have to monitor them for 28 days,” said an official adding that as per protocols their details could not be disclosed.

Title: SHIL business growth in kitchen segment across Bengal clocks 40%
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Kolkata: New housing projects across the city are paving way for growth in the business of kitchen appliance segment. In recent times, the buyers of new flats have been commonly installing chimneys and other tech-based appliances to protect the interiors of their kitchens. That the city contributes to 50% of the country’s total kitchen appliance market beckons the Somany Home Innovation ( SHIL ) group to concentrate on the West Bengal market.

On the backdrop of the launch of the 100th Kitchen Galleria off Kalyani Express Highway, Rakesh Kaul, CEO and whole time director of the company, said, “Our kitchen appliance segment is raking in maximum revenue for our overall brand portfolio. Our business clocks around 40% growth in the Bengal market where we are launching several new products to meet customers’ demands.”

“We have a customers’ base of over five lakh consumers who are using our kitchen products in Bengal while there is a steady increase of 20,000 consumers on an average across the state every month,” he added.

The company is targeting about 50 distribution points and 1,000 retailers across the state in the next 12 to 18 months. Though the company manufactures several kitchen appliances , the sale of chimneys has picked the pace recently.

At present, the company’s business banks upon 30 distribution points and nearly 700 retailers across the state where they have opened 15 kitchen galleries so far.

“The market in Bengal has been growing at a rate of 60% when compared to the last fiscal. Our market estimate says that we have more than 15% share of chimneys market in this state,” said Kaul.

Title: Revenue inspector warns VAO for seizing sand-laden truck
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Tirupur: An audio clip of a revenue inspector (RI) warning a village administrative officer (VAO) for impounding a sand-laden truck at Pongalur near Palladam in the district and threatening him to release the vehicle immediately went viral on social media on Monday.

While Tirupur sub-collector S Kavitha has initiated an inquiry against Pongalur revenue inspector Eswari, collector K Vijayakarthikeyan told reporters that disciplinary action would be taken against the RI if found guilty.

On January 24, Kattur village administrative officer Karthi seized a truck at Pongalur for smuggling sand.

Within a few hours, Eswari called Karthi over phone and questioned him for seizing the truck. The whole conversations between the two were audio recorded. When Karthi replied that he seized the vehicle as it did not have required documents, Eswari said, “The vehicle is being operated with required permit and documents. They (the vehicle’s owner) have seen (bribed) from tahsildar to collector. While only RI has power to seize vehicles, how could you do it? Better release it or tashildar would come on your line.”

Karthi could be heard replying to her: “If so, I have caught the vehicle which did not have documents, and you (RI) come and seize it.” He also questioned her whether the same vehicle owner had bribed her too. Eswari replied that she would seize a vehicle only if she finds it.

After the audio clip went viral, the district administration directed Tirupur sub-collector Kavitha to hold an inquiry.

District revenue officer R Sukumar said, “The sub-collector is conducting inquiry with Eswari. Appropriate action will be taken after the inquiry.”

Title: Youth from Telangana scales Mt. Aconcagua
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Thukaram on Mt. Aconcagua

HYDERABAD: A tribal youth from Rangareddy district, 21-year-old Amgoth Thukaram has successfully scaled Mount Aconcagua in South America, the highest mountain outside of Asia.

Thukaram scaled Aconcagua despite inclement and harsh weather conditions of snowfall and incessant rains.

While seven mountaineers tried to scale the mountain, only three, including Tukaram, managed to scale it successfully and survived the harsh and arduous track.

Recounting his experiences and heralding the dangers of global warming, he said that there is an urgent need to preserve ecological balances and avoid polluting our rivers and skies.

He also thanked Tridandi Chinnajiyar Swami who sponsored his Mt. Aconcagua expedition. He is expected to reach Hyderabad on February 1.

“It is my dream and goal to scale the highest mountain peaks of the world,” he said.

The feat is part of Thukaram’s tryst with adventure as he has climbed the three highest mountain peaks of the world within nine months.

He had scaled Mount Everest in Asia on May 22 last year, Mount Elbrus in Europe on July 27 last year and now he has successfully scaled Mount Aconcagua.

Tukaram was born in Thakkalapally Thanda of Yacharam Mandal.

He hails from a poor family with a rural background. He has been climbing peaks since the last three years.

Title: Worker injured as scaffolding for solar dome collapses
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

The structure collapsed amid heavy traffic movement

VADODARA: Labourers working on the ambitious solar dome project of the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) had a narrow escape when the bamboo scaffolding to fix aluminium composite panel (ACP) sheets on the ceiling collapsed on the Akota-Dandiabazaar link road. One worker was injured and was rushed to a hospital for treatment on Monday.

The labours were in the process of removing the scaffolding when the structure collapsed amid heavy traffic movement.

To facilitate work on the solar dome, the traffic on the stretch where the dome is coming up has been closed on one lane. Scaffoldings have been erected through the width of the other lane to fix ACP sheets. The dome is a steel structure on which ACP sheets are being fixed. Solar panels that will generate power will be installed on ceiling of the dome.

VMC officials said that the scaffolding was to be dismantled and erected at another location along the road. “While around 20 workers were present there, only around six were involved in bringing down the scaffoldings,” an official said.

VMC commissioner Nalin Updhyay said that the worker was first taken to the SSG Hospital and then a private hospital. He added that the injuries to the worker were not serious.

The solar dome project has been a jinxed affair marred with delays. It as conceptualised in 2014, but is yet to be completed.

Scaffolding fell earlier too

Vadodara: Two cars were damaged and others had a close shave when the metal scaffolding erected for work on the solar dome had collapsed in May 2017 too. Till this incident, work was conducted by closing only a part of one of the lanes and keeping it open for traffic in the remaining portion. After this incident, it was decided to close the entire lane for traffic while working on any portion of the ceiling or the roof of the dome. Only one lane is used for traffic at such times.

Title: Smart City projects in Salem reviewed
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

SALEM: Commissioner for municipal administration K Baskaran on Monday inspected the ongoing Smart City projects in Salem. He directed Salem municipal corporation (SMC) officials to complete the works within the stipulated timings.

Baskaran reviewed area-based development projects in the Salem old bus stand area and the VOC Flower Market area, which covers 690 acres. “Traffic management, water management and the underground drainage system will be given priority in the area-based development projects,” the CMA said. Besides, the reconstruction of Salem old bus stand at a cost of Rs 92.13 crore, renovation of Periyar Market, Bose maidan and the Nehru auditorium at a cost of Rs 165 crore, water management project at a cost of Rs 81 crore, construction of the underground drainage system at a cost of Rs 114 crore and a rail-over bridge project in Ponnammapet area at a cost of Rs 30 crore were also reviewed. After visits to project sites, he convened a meeting with SMC officials at the corporation office. Additional director for municipal administration M Asokan, corporation commissioner R Sadheesh and principal chief engineer M Pugazhendhi participated in the meeting.

Title: Cat stranded on sun shade in 5th floor rescued
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Tirupur: Fire and rescue services personnel rescued a pregnant cat which got stranded on a sun shade in the fifth floor of the collectorate building here on Monday.

After being informed, the rescue personnel from the Tirupur south fire service station reached the spot. “We tied a net beneath the sun shade and made the cat to jump into it. When we brought it down, we found it was pregnant,” a fire and rescue services official said.

Meanwhile, the forest department rescued a hedgehog aged about three years from a house at VIP Garden on Kangeyam Road. It was the second hedgehog rescued in the past two weeks in the city.

“We were informed that the hedgehog had entered a house. We went three and rescued it. We released the hedgehog at Kaithamalai near Uthukuli, where the animal would feel safer,” Tirupur forest ranger S Mahes said. tnn

Title: Chennai: Youth tries to save two women, drowns
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A 20-year-old man from Maharashtra, who with two friends tried to save two women from drowning off Elliot’s beach in Besant Nagar on Sunday, died, police said. The deceased youth was identified as Mayur Wadaskar .

A police officer said Kaviya, 18, and Poornima, 18, Bengaluru natives who are students of VIT Vellore, came to the beach along with three other friends. While the others stood on the shore, thee two women moved to the water’s edge and suddenly went missing. Their friends believed they were playing and called out to them. A couple of minutes later, when there was no response, the three on the shore cried for help.

Mayur and his friends Ankit, 20, of Delhi and Anand, 23, of Rajasthan, heard the cry for help and jumped in. They too were dragged in. The three young men had recently joined a private firm in Ennore as trainees and were staying in Mandaveli.

A team of the patrol police and some fishermen rushed into the sea and pulled out all the five. While Kaviya and Mayur were sent to the Rajiv Gandhi Government General hospital where the youth died, the others were sent to the Royapettah Government Hospital. The Sastri Nagar police registered a case of accidental death.

Incidents of drowning at Elliot’s continue with alarming frequency despite repeated warnings, say police. “We have all-terrain (ATV) vehicles at the beach, mainly to discourage people from entering the sea,” said a police officer. The warning boards however serve no purpose, he said.

The famous beach is incidentally home to the Schmidt memorial, in remembarance of Danish sailor K A J Schmidt who died trying to save a girl there in 1930.

Title: Chennai: Kottur ‘forest’ to give 200 tonnes of O2
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

The forest is coming up following the Miyawaki scheme — a Japanese method of growing different varieties of t... Read More

CHENNAI: The urban forest that Greater Chennai Corporation (GCC) is growing on a small patch of land near Kotturpuram MRTS station will consume 43.5 tonnes of carbon dioxide and give out 200 tonnes of oxygen every year after maturity, the civic body’s official statistics showed.

According to BBC Science Focus magazine, a human breathes about 9.5 tonnes of air in a year, but oxygen only makes up about 23% of that air, by mass. A person only extracts a little over a third of the oxygen from each breath. That works out to a total of about 740kg of oxygen a year. Which is, very roughly, seven or eight trees’ worth.

The forest which is coming up on 20,000sqft is being done according the Miyawaki scheme a Japanese method of growing different varieties of trees on a small patch of land using organic manure. The site was earlier a dump yard for construction debris. In all, 1,600 tonnes of debris was removed from the area to plant trees, an official said.

The corporation said 2,000 saplings of 40 varieties have been planted at the spot at a gap of 1m. Saplings include traditional varieties like poongan, peepal and neem. Fruit-bearing trees would also be part of the forest.

In the first year, the forest would consume 11.7 tonnes of carbon dioxide and give out four tonnes of oxygen.

The civic body sources said this calculation was provided by a consultant based on already established studies.

Dr S Balaji, former principal chief conservator of forests and a forestry expert, told TOI that the extent of carbon dioxide consumed is based on the number of leaves, thickness of the trunk and the weight of a tree. Plants and trees consume carbon dioxide during the day to synthesise biomass and in the process give out oxygen.

“For trees that grow faster, like bamboo, the rate of photosynthesis is higher and hence it would give out more oxygen,” he said. The Miyawaki system uses organic manure and soil for growing trees. Wet waste (converted to manure), coir, cow dung and other similar material is used as an organic manure.

Title: After residents face harrowing time, traffic plan put on hold
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Dehradun: After witnessing traffic congestion at various locations across the city on the fourth day of the ongoing special traffic plan on Monday, the police department has now decided to put the plan on hold.

This comes after peoplefaced a harrowing time on the roads for the past few days. Himanshu Kumar, a student of St Thomas, told TOI,“ I live in Premnagar and on all the days that the plan was implemented, I reached my school late by an hour. My daily schedule was completely disturbed because of the police experiment.” Saurav Singh, another student, added,“This is a wrong time for the experiment especially for the students as we are preparing for our board exams. Currently, the practicals and pre-boards are in progress and if we get late now, it becomes difficult for us to make up for the lost time.”

Many residents complained that they faced difficulties in reaching places that were just a few hundred metres from their residence. “At Rajpur Road, there was a circumtitious route plan in place to reach the petrol pump which otherwise takes just a few minutes to reach from my place. But on Monday, I had to travel a few extra kilometres to reach it in order to fill up my vehicle,” said Vishwas Pal, a resident.

Meanwhile, police officials acknowledged that there were some shortcomings in the plan which they will address after taking feedbacks and suggestions from the public.

SSP Dehradun Arun Mohan Joshi told TOI, “The experiment went off well with some positive results. At the same time, it has helped us in knowing the bottlenecks and problems in the process. Therefore, the normal traffic plan will come into existence from Tuesday and we will work on the future course of action.”

He added that once the smart city projects start, the special traffic plan will be put in place. ‘Once the project work begins, we will implement the special traffic plan after resolving all the issues. To find solutions we will constitute teams, which will interact with people from different sections of the society.”

Title: Citizenship seekers may have to prove faith
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

A lawyer during a pro-CAA rally in Mumbai

NEW DELHI: The Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) rules, being given final touches, are likely to require eligible migrants to furnish documents establishing country of origin, date of arrival prior to the cutoff and religious identity while there won’t be any need for proof of religious persecution.

Migrants or refugees from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan need to prove they belong to one of six minority faiths — Hindu, Sikh, Christian, Jain, Buddhist or Parsi. The documents recording religion of migrants applying for Indian citizenship under CAA must pertain to the period prior to December 31, 2014, a senior government functionary said.

The functionary added no documents may, however, be sought to establish that the applicant came to India on account of religious persecution back home. “The ground of religious persecution includes fear of religious persecution as well. So, no documentation may be necessary,” the functionary said.

Sources indicated that the CAA rules may not allow the state administration much role in processing applications. “State and local administration’s role will be minimal. While the application process will be entirely online, a central authority may be designated in the states to process claims,” a source said.

It was pointed out that CAA rules are likely to incorporate the suggestion made by Assam government for a short, time-bound application window for Bangladeshi migrants in the state.

Indications are that documentation requirements for citizenship applications under CAA may extensively borrow from existing long-term visa policy for migrants belonging to six minority faiths in Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan.

Any document issued by the governments of Afghanistan, Bangladesh or Pakistan or from any government authority or agency clearly showing the religion of the applicant — like a school certificate for example — can be furnished to establish membership of minority community.

Similarly, citizenship of the applicant for long-term visa can be proved by furnishing documents such as copy of the old passport or any other document issued by government authorities or agencies in these countries such as birth certificate, educational certificate by board or university, certificate of enrolment and study in schools, government-issued license, land and tenancy records.

Documents to prove the date of entry of long-term visa applicant into India include slip issued by census enumerators in India to such persons while conducting NPR prior to December 31, 2014, insurance policies issued by companies in India, bank and/or post office account, court and tribunal records in India, government-issued licence and land and tenancy records, permanent residential certificate, document showing service or employment, gram panchayat secretary certificate and Aadhaar card (all issued in India).

Title: Barodians swing to Zumba tunes on Happy Streets
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Despite biting cold, Zumba enthusiasts flocked to the street to shake their legs to the beats of music and enj... Read More

VADODARA: The Sayajibaug Road became alive at the crack of dawn on Sunday as Barodians from all walks of life converged on this stretch to enjoy Happy Streets, a Times of India initiative.

Despite biting cold, Zumba enthusiasts flocked to the street to shake their legs to the beats of music and enjoy the workout.

Kids displayed their painting skills on the street and some played snakes and ladders too. Youngsters played badminton and football, while couples were seen taking lots of selfies. A group of Barodians also played garba amid loud cheers by the spectators.

Title: Karnataka: Rs 48,000 stolen from Gali Anjaneya temple
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

File photo of Gali Anjaneya Temple

BENGALURU: Byatarayanapura police launched a manhunt for those who allegedly stole Rs 48,000 cash from a cupboard inside Sri Gali Anjaneya Swamy temple on Mysuru Road recently. Police registered a case of burglary against unknown persons based on a complaint filed by BV Manjunatha, a trustee of the temple.

Manjunatha told police that the robbery took place around 11.45pm on January 15 and filed a complaint a few days later after ascertaining the stolen amount. “Going by CCTV footage, the miscreants entered the temple premises by climbing the compound wall and later took the cupboard key kept in the cash counter. They opened the cupboard and fled with the cash,” Manjunatha said.

Title: 70% of higher edu institutions in state are not accredited: NAAC director
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Coimbatore: About 70% of the higher education institutions in the state have not acquired accreditation from the National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC), said S C Sharma, the director of the council. Of the total 2,462 higher education institutions, only 781 have acquired accreditation.

Sharma, who was in the city on Monday to participate in the inauguration of Bharat Ratna Prof CNR Rao Research Centre at Avinashilingam Institute for Home Science and Higher Education for Women, told reporters that higher education institutions including engineering colleges, arts and science colleges in Tamil Nadu were lagging behind in getting the NAAC accreditation.

“While certain colleges and autonomous colleges in the state have been doing well, there is much scope for improvement,” he said.

Comparing with Maharashtra, which has been doing well in getting NAAC accreditation, the director said around 75% of higher education institutions have got NAAC accreditation in Maharashtra. “The Maharashtra government had introduced a clause linking salaries of faculty members with NAAC accreditation. So automatically all institutions come forward to get accredited. Tamil Nadu should also follow the same,” he said.

Other key areas in which higher education institutions in the state have been lagging are research, innovation and patents and filling vacant faculty posts, he said.

NAAC, an autonomous body funded by the University Grants Commission, assesses and accredits higher education institutions in the country. It grades institutions in a scale of 1 to 4. Government higher education institutions become eligible for receiving funds only if they get a good NAAC score.

Speaking of the revamped NAAC accreditation mechanism, Sharma said they had finalised the new method around three weeks. The new method was based majorly on information and communication technology and it had minimal human intervention. There were around 93 metrics which would capture the entire details of the institution.

“The institution’s self-study report comprises 70% of the accreditation process. We would also get student satisfaction survey for the institutions. The rest 30% of the accreditation process was based on the assessment. We have around 3,500 assessors to conduct the assessment across the country,” said Sharma. Once the institutions upload their documents and self-study report, the data verification and validation will be conducted. Subsequently, the system would select the institution to be visited, he said. The process would be completed within three to four months, he said.

NAAC is spreading awareness about the accreditation process to institutions, Sharma said. “Our mandate is to handhold government institutions and those from rural areas. We encourage them to get accredited,” he said.

Title: Woman panel summons Coimbatore SP
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Coimbatore: The national commission for women (NCW), New Delhi, has summoned the superintendent of police, Coimbatore, to appear before it on February 4 pertaining to a petition submitted by the wife of a AIADMK cadre. The AIADMK cadre, Rajkumar, was found dead at Kaliyappagoundenpudur near Pollachi on August 24, 2018. The Coimbatore rural police registered a case under Section 174 CrPC.

However, his wife Abhirami shot off petitions to the NCW and national human rights commission (NHRC) claiming that she suspected foul play in her husband’s death. She requested the commissions to order the police to alter the suspicious death case to murder. Last week, the national commission for women summoned SP Sujit Kumar to appear before it on February 4.

Police said already Abhirami had sent more than 100 petitions to police officials to alter the case to murder. The officials had decided to send a detailed report in connection with the case to the national commission for women. tnn

Title: Govt studying feasibility of new sugar factory: Gaude
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Panaji: Cooperation minister Govind Gaude said that the government is studying the feasibility of setting up a new sugar factory that can be operational throughout the year.

The present Sanjivani Cooperative Sugar Factory at Dharbandora is shut, putting farmers in a predicament, this crushing season.

“Extraction of sugar and ethanol is the way forward. An expression of interest is under way to see the viability and technical feasibility. We will analyse everything. It is the government’s intention to have a factory running 365 days of the year, instead of 70 days as the present one runs,” Gaude said.

Hitting out at the opposition for demanding that steps should be taken for the plant’s revival, the minister said the factory is old with machinery that is almost 50 years old.

Title: No Indian Muslim will be affected by CAA: Defence minister Rajnath Singh
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Defence minister Rajnath Singh at the pro-CAA convention in Mangaluru on Monday

MANGALU RU: Defence minister Rajnath Singh asserted that not a single Muslim in India will be thrown out of the country due to the proposed National Register of Citizens and said the Bharatiya Janata Party will throw its might behind the community if a single member feels persecuted by the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. This is in line with Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s motto of Sab ka saath, sab ka Vikas aur sab ka vishwas, Rajnath added at a pro-CAA rally here on Monday.

Assailing Congress for spreading fear among Muslims regarding a law that both houses of Parliament debated and passed, Rajnath addressed the mammoth rally organised by the district unit of BJP. He said BJP has merely fulfilled a wish that Mahatma Gandh had directed the Congress to do post-Independence. This was also in the resolution adopted by the Congress Working Committee on November 25, 1947, he said.

Asking the crowd if the government discriminated based on religion in implementing its various programmes such as Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana, Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana, Ayushman Bharat or in providing infrastructure works, Rajnath wondered how the same government could discriminate with CAA. “How can the opposition accuse us of being discriminatory with this step their leaders wanted?” he asked.

Reminding the Congress that it implemented the NRC based on a Supreme Court directive, he said, “NRC naam ki chidiya hum (BJP) logon ne nahin laya tha!” CAA is a balm the government is using to apply on souls of persecuted minorities from India’s theocratically ruled neighbours and is not to hurt any Indian citizen, he said, adding that Congress can’t see anything good the government does.

Noting that there is a concerted attempt on part of the Congress to drive a wedge between Hindus and Muslims using CAA, Rajnath said it wouldn’t be surprising if foreign powers are behind it. The former BJP national chief exhorted the party’s rank and file to explain to Muslims that their citizenship is not under threat and they will continue to enjoy their rights as any other citizen.

Rajnath said the opposition should not forget the ‘national dharma’. Let the opposition question the continuing persecution of minorities in neighbouring Pakistan, he said. While CAA is only to accommodate persecuted minorities from Afghanistan, Pakistan and Bangladesh, majority of whom are Dalits, why should anyone have any objection to it? he asked. Noting that as home minister in the Modi government’s first innings, he had given citizenship to over 600 Muslims including Pakistani singer Adnan Sami, Rajnath said Muslims from theocratic neighbours wanting to become Indian citizens are still able to do so under CAA provisions. Even with NPR that Congress introduced in 2010, no one will be forced to give their personal details such as their father’s name or date of birth, he said.

Title: Top officials visit homes of SSLC students in Karkala
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Udupi: Top officers and politicians of Udupi visited 554 houses of students appearing for SSLC exams on Monday. Deputy commissioner G Jagadeesha visited eight houses in Hebri. This is part of the ‘Mane Mana Bheti’ programme under Mission-100 Karkala launched by block education officer (BEO) GS Shashidhar, aimed at securing 100% results in SSLC exams.

Shashidhar said that top officers from the district including deputy commissioner G Jagadeesha, zilla panchayat CEO Preeti Gehlot, superintendent of police N Vishnuvardhan, taluk panchayat executive officer Dr Major Harsha, MLA V Sunil Kumar, former MLC Ganesh Karnik, DDPI Sheshashayana Karinja, doctors and industrialists visited nearly 10 houses each on a single day. The idea of 100 VIPS visiting homes of SSLC students was mooted my MLA Sunil Kumar, he said.

Udupi SP N Vishnuvardhan who visited nine houses in Bailoor said, “This exercise should help in boosting the morale and confidence of the students and help them perform better. I casually asked students about their future dreams. Many were keen on answering civil service exams and becoming top officers,” he said, adding that he is looking forward to visiting more homes.

Every day, education department officers are visiting at least 10-15 houses between 5am-7am and 7pm-9pm to ensure that students wake up in the morning and study well. Students also discuss with officers the problems they face in school or the subjects they have difficulty in learning. It is a surprise visit and students are not informed in advance about the officer’s visit.

This year, 2,567 students from Karkala will be appearing for SSLC exams.

Title: File report on hoardings or face summons: Madras HC to bureaucrats
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Madras high court

CHENNAI: The Madras high court has warned higher officials of the state home department saying it would be constrained to summon them to court if they fail to file a comprehensive report on the number of FIRs/CSR registered/issued and action taken in connection with unauthorised banners.

A division bench of Justice M Sathyanarayanan and Justice R Hamelatha made the observation on Monday, while hearing a batch of pleas, including petitions moved by social activist Traffic Ramaswamy seeking action against authorities who failed to check erection of illegal banners endangering public safety and inconveniencing road-users.

When the pleas came up for hearing on Monday, the judges pointed out that the authorities had so far not filed any such report despite orders passed by the court, and said that it would be constrained to summon senior officers of the home department if the report is not made available by February 27.

To this, government pleader Jayaprakash Narayanan submitted that after the death of techie Subhasree, who was run over by a truck after an illegal banner placed by an AIADMK functionary fell on her in September last, such offences have come down drastically in view of strict enforcement by the authorities.

Recording the submissions, the bench wondered why the officials are failing to file a report. This apart, the bench also heard another plea moved by Ramaswamy seeking to restrain the state from issuing government sponsored advertisements with pictures of former chief minister J Jayalalithaa , as she was ‘convicted’ by the Supreme Court in the disproportionate assets case.

“This court takes note of the fact that the conviction of the former chief minister has been set aside by the Karnataka high court and in the further appeal, the Supreme Court rendered the verdict after her demise,” the court said. The judges then directed the Tamil Nadu government to file an affidavit as to its policy on release of advertisements with pictures of former chief minister after taking note of Supreme Court judgment in the Manzoor Alikhan case. The court also directed the registry to delink the plea from the batch and post it on February 27, separately.

Title: HC seeks affidavit from EC on repainting of govt offices
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Vijayawada: In view of the upcoming panchayat elections, the high court on Monday directed the state election commission to file an affidavit with regard to painting of government offices in party colours. The high court directed the election commission to take action as per the norms specified by law.

One Muppa Venkateswara Rao from Guntur district had moved the high court against the inaction of government officials after the panchayat building of Pallapadu was painted in the colours of YSRC flag. He argued in his petition that if the government offices were to be painted in party colours it could affect the voting pattern.

Earlier, the high court had directed the state government not to paint any government building in the colours of political parties.

On Monday, the petitioner’s advocate argued that as the state government is preparing to conduct elections to local bodies, the government offices, painted in party colours, must be repainted. Taking the arguments of the petitioner into consideration, the high court bench headed by the chief justice J K Maheswari and Justcie Nainala Jayasurya directed the state election commission to take action according to the law and asked to it file an affidavit over the issue and posted the matter for further hearing on February 5.

Title: File counter over English medium move: HC to govt
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Vijayawada: The high court on Monday directed the state and Union government to file affidavits in the PIL challenging the introduction of English medium in all government schools. The chief spokesperson of BJP, AP, Srinivasa Sudhish Rambotla and Guntupalli Srinivas from Eluru had moved the HC challenging the state government’s decision.

The petitioners argued that government order 85 is in violation of the Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act, 2009. Rambotla argued that the state government cannot make any law in contravention with the central law. Moreover, the right to select the medium of instruction should be with the children and they should not be forced to take English medium, he stated.

While the state government sought more time to file the counter , the petitioners’ advocate claimed that the government is going ahead with the implementation of GO 85 and public money is being spent to print textbooks.

Responding to the petitioners argument, the high court said that they would recover the costs from the officials concerned if the need arises and posted the matter for further hearing on February 4.

Title: Loan fraud case: More trouble for Transstroy
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Rayapati Sambasiva Rao

HYDERABAD: Former MP Rayapati Sambasiva Rao-owned Transstroy India Ltd could land itself in further trouble with the Enforcement Directorate ( ED ) deciding to issue an Enforcement Case Information Report (ECIR) under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act, 2002.

Highly-placed sources said ECIR would be issued based on a CBI FIR against Transstroy in a loan fraud case.

ED has already registered a Foreign Exchange Management Act (FEMA) case against Transstroy for irregularities in foreign exchange transactions. ED is probing allegations that the company has transferred funds to Singapore and Russia violating the FEMA rules. ED is also probing into the affairs of a joint venture company, Polavaram Project Transstory and JSC EC UES. The latter is a Russian company.

CBI, in its FIR, named Transstroy, promoter-chairman Sambasiva Rao, MD Cherukuri Sridhar and another director Suryadevara Srinivasa Babji.

CBI found that the accused had inflated stocks and balance sheets of the company in its probe. The accused were believed to have diverted funds of consortium banks to the tune of Rs 3,822 crore. CBI is also probing into allegations of Rs 794 crore written off in the name of adjustments towards reserves and surplus.

The probe also revealed that financial documents were manipulated. The difference amount of manipulation was to the tune of Rs 2,298 crore.

In the FEMA case, it was found that Rs 15.34 crore was transferred to Transstroy Singapore PET Ltd, a subsidiary of Transstroy India, in 2013-14 from Bank of Baroda without the permission of the lenders.

It may be recalled CBI sleuths had conducted searches on the premises of the accused earlier.

Title: Security guard electrocuted at pharma company’s unit in Waghodiya
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: A contractual security guard died of electrocution at Alembic Pharmaceuticals’ Jarod facility in Waghodiya taluka on Sunday morning.

The deceased Mahesh Thakor (45) was moving a portable ladder after completing the preparations for celebrations of Republic Day. Police said that when Thakor was about to place the ladder in a corner, the top end of the ladder touched a live wire and Thakor suffered a shock and died on the spot.

Thakor was a resident of Kamrol village. A case of accidental death was registered at Waghodiya police station.

Title: CM V Narayanasamy, his colleagues must apologise to Padma awardees: Kiran Bedi
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Lieutenant government Kiran Bedi

PUDUCHERRY: Lieutenant government Kiran Bedi on Monday said chief minister V Narayanasamy and his cabinet colleagues must express their regret to the two Padma awardees from Puducherry and artists from Jammu and Kashmir and Arunachal Pradesh deputed by the Union government to perform at the 'At Home' reception hosted by the Raj Nivas on the Republic Day for disrespecting the sanctity of a national event on Sunday.

Bedi said Narayanasamy and others must also express their regret to the office of the lieutenant governor. Narayanasamy and others left the reception midway after a Raj Nivas staff member requested him to honour the Padma awardees, who were invited by Raj Nivas to attend the reception.

Narayanasamy was quick to decline the invite pointing out that he was not formally informed about the programme (honouring Padma awardees) and left Raj Nivas within a few minutes. His cabinet colleagues followed suit.

"The ‘At Home’ Invites by Raj Nivas this time was more diverse, inclusive and spontaneous. It was also decided to invite more award winners up to the last day, who were recipients of meritorious awards at the Republic Day parade. This included the Padma Awardees too on whom the announcement came on the late evening before. We invited both the Awardees so that Puducherrians get an immediate opportunity to greet these national heroes. Both the Padma Awardees were gracious to attend even at such short notice. Once present in the audience our Comptroller Raj Nivas Mrs Asha Gupta considered it respectful to recognize the presence of the Padma Awardees by requesting the HCM (honourable chief minister) to present a shawl to them. She thought it would be befitting the occasion that the HCM does the honours. The HCM instead of welcoming this offer shouted back and argued back, saying 'how can it be done without his prior intimation and prior approval?' There was a great deal of embarrassment. This was right in the presence of select invitees and all the senior officers of the administration," Bedi said in a WhatsApp post.

She pointed out that the ‘At Home’ is not a private event. "It’s an event of national sanctity. It’s also an annual gathering of respected people from all walks of life, specially invited, to celebrate the most important national event the year. This time as was suggested in the Governors' Conference by the Hon'ble President of India to make the ‘At Home’ more diverse and inclusive with an element of celebrations and recognition. We are grateful to the GOI Ministry of Art and Culture who sent their artists all the way to perform here and regret the behaviour of our elected representatives towards ignoring them. And disrespecting our Padma Awardees by refusing to appreciate their presence. They ought to express their regret to two Padma Awardees, the J&K and Arunachal Pradesh artists sent by Govt of India also. Besides to the office of Lt Gov for disrespecting the sanctity of a national event," she said. Bedi said people in top positions are role models to youth and others. "They influence the next generation and impact others. I hope such a happening does not reoccur in the next At Home held at the Raj Nivas," she said.

Title: Cops brace to tackle traffic woes in prep for capital rush
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Visakhapatnam: As the city gears up to become executive capital of the state, city police are preparing to take on the challenge that will be posed by an expansion in traffic infrastructure.

The executive capital will require a far more extensive urban transport system and than what is in place now and the primary considerations for city traffic police will be managing traffic. The number of vehicles in the city has grown exponentially, at over 13 lakh in 2019, up from 5.5 lakh in 2012.

Two-wheelers continue to dominate city roads, accounting for over 80 per cent of total vehicular population, followed by cars at 10 per cent. Once the executive capital shifts to Vizag, at least 25,000 vehicles, including over 10,000 SUVs, will be added to the city’s roads.

City police commissioner Rajiv Kumar Meena said that private vehicles dominate in the city in the absence of an efficient public transport system. Vehicular movement is bound to increase and traffic management will be the biggest challenge for the police, the commissioner added.

Little scope exists, however, to widen roads within city limits. Issues such as road engineering works, construction of parking lots by local bodies, widening key roads and expanding junctions remain to be addressed.

“There is an urgent need to complete the widening of the Anandapuram-Anakapalle highway via Sabbavaram and also widen the Anakapalle-Tagarapuvalasa road road to mitigate traffic chaos in the city,” said ACP (traffic) MRK Raju.

Poor last-mile connectivity continues to be a problem, said K Lokanadham, district secretary of the Communist Party of India (Marxist), and more buses and local trains can help the city handle the shift to executive capital status. In the absence of local trains and a limited fleet of buses, private vehicles have been choking city roads, he added.

A software professional in the city said the government should instead address key issues in Vizag, such as traffic and security, before relocating the capital from Amaravati. The GVMC should also focus on completing the BRTS project, he added.

Another professional added that the government should consider introducing CNG-run city bus services to mitigate pollution and focus on road infrastructure and the public transport system.

Besides constructing flyovers and setting up traffic signal points and foot-overbridges (FOB), manpower in the traffic wing needs to be increased by adding at least another 400 cops to the existing 500.

Title: Delhi move to affect politics outside Pb?
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Jalandhar: Shiromani Akali Dal’s decision not to contest Delhi assembly elections, and its top brass remaining indecisive in taking a clear line and letting its Delhi unit decide on the issue, could have a far-reaching effect — end of the predominance of Punjab-based Akali leaders in deciding the political direction of Sikhs in other states and letting them take their own political decisions.

SAD’s Delhi unit has not yet decided what position it would take for the February 8 assembly polls. For decades, Akali Dal would have a say in the political affairs of Sikhs in states neighbouring Punjab, especially in Haryana and Delhi. At the same time, it would speak up on issues concerning Sikhs in distant states as well.

However, recent political developments, first in Haryana and now in Delhi, could be a turning point for the Punjab-based SAD’s politics in other states. In the past, Sikh leaders in Delhi, through their factions of Akali Dal, had been taking their own political lines also. However, Akali leadership of Punjab would have a say in their affairs. In Haryana also, it would play a significant role in leveraging Sikh voters.

Earlier, SAD had an alliance with the Indian National Lok Dal (INLD) as its party patron and former Punjab chief minister Parkash Singh Badal enjoyed close friendship with the Chautala family. This time, SAD faced an embarrassing situation after BJP refused to have an alliance with it for Haryana polls, despite its repeated expressions of interest.

Till around 40 years ago, Jag Asra Guru Ott (JAGO) party leader Manjit Singh GK’s father, late Jathedar Santokh Singh, would take his own path in Delhi, while maintaining a love-hate relationship with Punjab-based top leaders of Akali Dal. Nearly two decades ago, it was Paramjit Singh Sarna who charted his own path and minimised the influence of Badal and his family in the Sikh affairs of Delhi by taking away control of the Delhi Sikh Gurdwara Management Committee (DSGMC).

However, Punjab-based Akali leadership still played a significant part in deciding political course of the Sikhs in Delhi. “Akali Dal should confine its politics to Punjab only as it has been calling itself a Punjabi party and should leave Sikhs of other states to decide their own political course. They know local factors and politics better. They are wise enough to take their own decisions,” said former Rajya Sabha MP Tarlochan Singh, who remains one of Delhi-based key articulators of Sikh issues.

Sikh author Gurbachan Singh said the development in Delhi reflected the diminishing influence of the Badal-led Akali Dal in the political affairs of Sikhs in neighbouring states. “In a few years, Sikhs of these states would play politics that is independent of Akali Dal in Punjab,” he said.

Title: Collectors to take call on parking fee
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Vijayawada: The high court on Monday directed joint collectors in all districts to consider representations from petitioners in a PIL challenging the collection of parking fee at shopping malls and theatres and to take necessary action if they found the practice illegal.

N N Grace, general secretary, Mundadugu Praja Party, moved the high court seeking directions to the government and officials concerned to prevent movie theatres and shopping malls from collecting parking fee. On behalf of the petitioner, J Sravan Kumar argued that collection of parking fee was in violation of Section 31 of the AP Apartments Promotion of Constructions and Ownership Act 1987 and as well as violation of the high court orders.

He argued that joint collectors in districts were not taking any action despite giving representations to them.

Disposing the petition, the bench headed by chief justice of the high court Justice J K Maheswari and Justice Nainala Jayasurya directed the joint collectors to take action against the movie theatres and shopping malls if they found the collection of parking fee illegal. The HC also directed to recover money from them if it was illegal. tnn

Title: Passengers fume as ‘parked’ cars block airport driveway
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

With the city airport doing away the time limit for cars which come to drop or pick up passengers on the main ... Read More

COIMBATORE: With the city airport doing away the time limit for cars which come to drop or pick up passengers on the main road in front of the airport entrance, several drivers are seen parking their cars on the road and wait for customers. Some parked cars hinder vehicular movements as they wait upto 10min blocking the entry and exit gates completely. Passengers, who are in a hurry, lose valuable time because of this.

Several cars lined up close to the kerb to pick up passengers on Monday at 10am when a Spicejet flight from Chennai and an Indigo flight from another destination landed. The cars which came later started occupying next two lanes to wait for passengers, leaving several cars that came to drop off and pick up passengers stranded away from the airport.

“I took the 10am flight as I could reach my office by 10.15am. But I am stuck in my car and it is already 10.15am,” said Kumar K, a businessman, who had to sit inside his car and wait for two cars in front of him to clear the path.

Earlier, cars could pick up and drop off passengers at the airport without paying any charge as long as they exited within five minutes. Cars that take more than five minutes had to pay Rs 50.

Airport director N Mahalingam said the rule was withdrawn two months ago as people who had to pay take time to search for change, delaying other passengers also. “So, we decided to charge people who want to park their vehicles in the parking area,” he said.

The director admitted that some cars were taking advantage of this decision and parking on the driveway for free. “We have now employed two service men to clear such jams and ensure they don’t happen again,” said Mahalingam.

Title: AU to hold PGECET from May 2 to 4
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The AP state council of higher education (APSCHE) has asked Andhra University to conducting the post graduate engineering common entrance test ( PGECET ).

Andhra University college of engineering principal Prof P Srinivasa Rao will be the convener of the test, which would be held from May 2 to 4.

The test is categorised into 13 different categories depending on the availability and qualifying degree.

AU has been conducting the common entrance test for admissions into ME/MTech/MPharm courses, on behalf of APSCHE for the last several years.

Around 26,000 students took the online test in 42 test centres spread across 16 cities of Andhra Pradesh and Telangana last year. The varsity will also set up five helpline centres for certificate verification and counselling process.

Title: Padma awards: Was not aware of Kiran Bedi's decision, Puducherry CM claims
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

CM V Narayanasami

PUDUCHERRY: Chief minister V Narayanasamy on Monday accused lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi of flouting the conventions at the 'At Home' reception hosted by Raj Nivas .

Speaking to reporters, he claimed that he was not aware of the Raj Nivas’ decision to honour Padma awardees (until he was invited during the reception to honour them).

He said the government was happy that two people from Puducherry were conferred with Padma awards. He said the lieutenant governor could have honoured the awardees in an exclusive function at her office instead of choosing the At Home reception that too without any prior intimation to him and others.

“It is the Republic Day celebrations and all of a sudden an announcement was made (inviting him to honour Padma awardees). I did not get any formal intimation on honouring them during the celebration. I stood up and questioned them how they can make an announcement without any formal intimation. It is against the conventions, rules and laws,” Narayanasamy said.

He also accused Bedi of running a parallel government bypassing the government elected by the people in a democratic manner. He said Bedi on receiving any complaints from any quarters must forward them to the secretaries concerned and the secretaries must probe into the complaints and consult the ministers concerned before submitting a report to the lieutenant governor.

“But the lieutenant governor has been violating all rules, regulations, laws and high court’s order. She forwards the complaints directly to the heads of the departments and orders them to probe into the complaints and submit a report to her. The Madras high court has categorically declared that the lieutenant governor has no independent powers and authority and the lieutenant governor must act as per the aid and advice of the council of ministers. She has appealed against the order and the high court has reserved its order after arguments. The order must be pronounced anytime. She continues to flout the order. It shows that she has no knowledge of administration,” said Narayanasamy.

He said Madras high court declared that minister-in-charge along with the council of ministers headed by the chief minister are empowered to run the government and the secretaries including the chief secretary are bound to follow the same. He said the high court also declared that secretaries are not empowered to issue orders on their own or upon the instructions of the administrator.

Rebuking her charges that elected members are bullying officials, he said it was the lieutenant governor who has been threatening and intimidating officials to follow her orders else she will make adverse remarks on their confidential reports or direct the CBI to initiate inquiries against them.

Title: Congress sarpanch’s son killed near Batala
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

BATALA: The son of a sarpanch owing allegiance to the Congress was shot dead near Batala town of Gurdaspur on Monday.

Jasbir Singh alias Golu was the son of Harpura village sarpanch Sukhjinder Kaur. Superintendent of police (headquarters) Jasbir Singh Rai said accused Harinder Singh alias Raja fired seven times at Jasbir after an altercation. Rai said the murder was not political, but a fallout of a rivalry. A source said Jasbir was close to Sri Hargobindpur MLA Balwinder Singh Laddi. He was rushed to the civil hospital, but was declared brought dead. Raja was undergoing imprisonment in a previous case and was out on bail for his marriage on February 16.

The SP said the accused fled from the scene. He has been booked under Section 302 (murder) of the IPC at Ghuman police station. This is the third instance in three months where a person with political links has been shot dead in Majha. On November 19, 2019, Dalbir Singh of the Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD), a former two-time sarpanch of Dhilwan village near Batala, was murdered .Assailants had attacked Dalbir with sickles and sharp-edged weapons before spraying half a dozen bullets on him.

On January 2, Baba Gurdeep Singh, a former Akali sarpanch of Umarpur village in Amritsar, who was returning home after paying obeisance at a local gurdwara was shot dead by three motorcycle-borne assailants.

Title: Rs 12 lakh stolen from Amazon office in Haridwar
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Haridwar: Cash and valuable items worth Rs 12 lakh was stolen from the office of online shopping company Amazon in Kankhal area of Haridwar late on Sunday.

The accused broke into the office and damaged the CCTV cameras.

Following the incident, the senior superintendent of police (SSP) removed station house officer for negligence and formed several teams to trace the accused.

A case has also been registered against unknown people under section 379 (punishment of theft ) of the Indian Penal Code.

Circle Officer Ajay Singh said, “Thieves broke in from the front gate and stole cash and other valuable items. They also damaged the CCTV cameras and removed the DVR from the cameras. A case has been registered and further investigation is going on. SHO Hariom Singh Chauhan has been removed for negligence in duty.”Rs

Title: Punjab safest in country, says top cop
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nawanshahr: DGP Dinkar Gupta has said Punjab is the safest state in the country, but police have to remain vigilant as it is a border state.
