Title: Turmeric processing unit at ICAR soon, to boost farming
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: In a move aimed at propagating turmeric cultivation in the state, Old Goa-based ICAR-Central Coastal Agricultural Research Institute (CCARI) will set up a turmeric processing unit at its premises. The initiative, that will be taken up in the upcoming financial year, is expected to boost the turmeric trade for the state’s spice farmers.“Curcumin boasts of anti-cancerous properties. We plan to establish a processing unit here that will encourage farmers to cultivate turmeric. The crop grows very well in Goan soil. Also, it can be cultivated as an inter-crop in cashew orchards, thus bringing additional income to farmers,” said ICAR-CCARI director EB Chakurkar.The institute is already carrying out studies on the various properties of turmeric such as the estimation of its curcumin, production capacity and per hectare yield.“We can provide the technology, but the execution must be done by the state government through the agriculture department and Agriculture Technology Management Agency (ATMA),” Chakurkar said.ATMA’s North Goa wing is already in the process of large-scale cultivation of cultivating turmeric.“ICAR-CCARI has recommended the cultivation of the Pratibha variety of turmeric. We will take saplings from them and distribute them among farmers by May. We will start planting them at nurseries across the state in June,” said ATMA’s North Goa project director Dilip Paranjape.While turmeric has medicinal properties, its frequent use in Indian kitchens as a cooking ingredient gives the crop a wide market. ATMA now plans to conduct a spices exposure visit for farmers to Karnataka and Kerala.“First we want to motivate farmer groups to raise the crop so that each can grow about 2,000 saplings. We will distribute the seeds among four to five farmer groups in North Goa,” Paranjape said.

Title: Coronavirus in Jaipur: Medicos quarantined at Sawai Man Singh Hospital
Content:
A security guard outside the isolation ward at SMS Hospital where the 25-year-old patient was kept on Monday

JAIPUR: A 25-yer-old medical student, resident of Sanganer in Jaipur, studying in Hubei University of Chinese Medicine in Wuhan of China, where novel coronavirus (nCoV) has played havoc, has been quarantined at Sawai Man Singh (SMS) Hospital as he is suffering from similar symptoms of the virus. Apart from suspected case of nCoV, there are other 17 such students from the same university, who are under monitoring of the health department.The suspected patient returned from China to India on January 12. He was under monitoring of the health department. He developed influenza like illeness symptoms such as cough, fever and runny nose on January 24. Alert health department officials immediately reported the case to higher authorities of the health department and admitted him to the isolation ward of the SMS Hospital.“Taking precautionary measures, a team of two doctors and four nursing staff have conducted survey in neighbourhood of residence of the suspected nCoV patient,” chief medical health officer (Jaipur-II), Dr Hansraj Bhadaliya told TOI.All the medical students belong to Jaipur, Hanumangarh, Sikar and Barmer. A student from Sikar district told ToI that he had returned from China on January 12. “The university declared holidays from January 10. There is a scare of nCoV,” said a medical student from Sikar, who has been studying in the university since 2018 for MBBS course. The health authorities have directed chief medical health officers of all the four districts to keep monitoring health of the students returning from China. However, the suspected nCoV student doing well, the hospital claimed.The patient was brought to the hospital with symptoms such as runny nose, headache, cough and sore throat. Since, he has returned from China recently, the health authorities have taken it seriously and kept in isolation ward. “He is fine. We have kept him in isolation ward as a precautionary measure. Since he was suffering from similar symptoms, we have admitted him last (Sunday) evening,” said Dr DS Meena, medical superintendent, SMS Hospital.Moreover, health minister Raghu Sharma has directed the officials to conduct screening of the family members of the suspected nCoV patient. Sharma said that he has directed the officials to keep monitoring health of 18 students reached Rajasthan from China’s Wuhan for 28 days.

Title: National panel asks HNB university to probe assistant prof’s caste certificate
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Dehradun: Acting on a complaint filed by a Pauri Garhwal based RTI activist Santosh Mamgain, national commission for backward classes has issued direction to Hemwati Nandan Bahuguna (HNB) University to probe the complaint against the recruitment of an assistant professor on the basis of a caste certificate against the reservation norms in 2012.

Mamgain, who also heads the Society for Revolution against Corruption, based in Srinagar, had given a detailed complaint that chronologically explained the illegality of the appointment of the assistant professor. The RTI activist said, “The assistant professor belongs to Jat community which is not under the reservation quota but the university officials still appointed him in 2012. I had written to the commission to take action against the university and the assistant professor.”

On January 7, the commission had written to registrar and vice-chancellor of HNB Garhwal University to conduct an inquiry into the matter and take strict action. The commission has sought the follow-up action of the complaint to be submitted within 15 days of receiving the letter signed by undersecretary, J Ravishankar. Mamgain said, “The assistant professor, Yoga department, continues to work in the university. I had called up the SDM (Gwalior) in Madhya Pradesh, who had issued the caste certificate and he told me that the Jat community is given reservation in the state but not in any central government university.”

The RTI activist is surprised that in spite of the clear direction that the post was for reserved category in 2012 still, the university officials at that time made the appointment in violation of all reservation norms.

Meanwhile, the university registrar, AK Jha, said on Monday, “The vice-chancellor has constituted an inquiry panel of senior professors to look into the matter and report within a week. The commission shall also be apprised about the outcome of the committee report.”

Title: Kodai hotel owner undertakes to raze deviated portion
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Madurai: The Kodaikanal municipality has been directed to de-seal a portion of J H Residency hotel at Kodaikanal in Dindigul district, which was constructed in deviation of building norms, after its partner gave an undertaking to the Madras high court to demolish a portion of the building.

In his petition, P Hendry, stated that as a portion of the hotel came under deviation as per the new master plan of the Kodaikanal municipality, it was sealed by the officials. Hence, he moved the high court Madurai bench in 2019, seeking to de-seal the building for him to use it for the purpose of primary residential zone as per the new master plan.

The Kodaikanal municipal commissioner in his counter affidavit stated that based on an earlier order, several buildings which were in violation to the building norms in Kodaikanal were locked and sealed by the officials. The court also directed to lock and seal religious institutions which were in violation of the building norms. The court passed an interim order granting exemption educational institutions, residential buildings, government buildings, hospitals, banks, small shops like bakeries, barber shops, vegetable shops, groceries and small hotels from lock and seal.

He stated that subsequently, a new master plan was published by the government. As per the directions of the court, the petitioner has to approach the secretary of housing and urban development department who is a competent authority to take action in this regard.

When the petition was taken up for hearing on Monday, the petitioner’s counsel submitted that he had given an undertaking to demolish the deviated portion if the portion was de-sealed.

Recording the undertaking, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran directed the municipality officials to de-seal the building for the petitioner to demolish the deviated portion. The judges also allowed the petitioner to submit an application before authorities for plan approval after demolishing the deviated portion.

Title: Annual Radhasapthami festival to be celebrated in Tirumala on February 1
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Tirupati: The additional executive officer of Tirumala Tirupati, Devasthanams AV Dharma Reddy, on Monday reviewed the arrangements being made for the annual Radhasapthami festival slated to be celebrated on February 1.

Touted as mini-Brahmotsavams, during Radhasapthami festival Lord Malayappa Swamy along with his two divine consorts Goddess Sridevi and Bhudevi bless the devotees in seven different processions in a single day.

As the series of processions starts with ‘‘Surya Prabha Vahanam” at around 5.30 am and concludes with the ‘‘Chandra Prabha Vahanam” at 9 pm, TTD officials are putting in place German sheds for the devotees. TNN

Title: 2 men run over by train in Rudrapur
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Rudrapur: Two men, both in their twenties, were run over by a train on Sunday night while they were out for a walk near a railway crossing in Singh colony of the city.

Police officials on Monday said that Raju Kumar, 27, a resident of village Bhura Rani in the city and Manoj, 25, a resident of Almora, were dead before they could be admitted at a hospital.

Police rushed to the spot after being alerted by local residents of Singh Colony. The two bodies were found on the railway track at 12 midnight. “Both of the deceased worked as photographers. We have informed their families. The bodies have been sent for post mortem,” said station house officer (SHO) of Rudrapur police station KC Bhatt.

Title: Sedition case: Raids on in state to nab Sharjeel Imam
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Sharjeel Imam

PATNA: More than half a dozen locations in Jehanabad and state capital Patna have been raided by a joint team of Delhi, Uttar Pradesh and Bihar police in the past 48 hours to arrest Jawaharlal Nehru University student Sharjeel Imam in a sedition case .

After Saturday night’s raid at Imam’s ancestral house at Kako in Jehanabad, the joint team raided several places in Patna, including at Sabzibagh in Phulwarishariff, where a 24-hour Shahin Bagh-like protests are on.

Imam, one of the early organisers of the anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) protest at Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh, had allegedly made “seditious” statements at Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) by giving a call to cut off Assam from the rest of India.

Jehanabad SP Maneesh told TOI that raids were carried out at his ancestral place at Kako Bazar. He added that some family members were quizzed by the joint team. Intelligence sleuths also interrogated Imam’s close relatives and a few of them have been detained.

Cases have been lodged against Imam in Aligarh, Assam and Delhi for allegedly giving a provocative speech at AMU on January 16, a video of which went viral on social media.

“We are cooperating with the police teams from outside the state in their investigation. There is no case pending against Imam here,” the SP said.

Sources said some relatives of Imam live in Patna as well. “Some family members of Sharjeel stay in Patna. We can’t share more information related to the investigation as it’s a sensitive issue. Senior officials are monitoring the operation,” an officer posted at the police headquarters in Patna said.

Sharjeel wrote on his Facebook profile that he is from Patna and did his schooling from St Xavier’s High School here as well as DPS-Vasant Kunj in Delhi. Later, he joined IIT-Bombay from where he did his post-graduation in computer science. He also worked as an IT programmer at the University of Copenhagen before coming to JNU, where he is a student at the Centre for Historical Studies.

His family members have defended him by claiming that his statements have been exaggerated. “I initially tried to stop Sharjeel when he insisted that we have to fight against CAA and NRC. It is true he is against NRC and CAA but his statement has been blown out of proportion. Now, everyone is after him,” Sharjeel’s mother told a news channel at Jehanabad on Monday.

Sharjeel’s uncle Arshad Imam claimed that Sharjeel is being used for political mileage in Delhi elections. “It is true that Sharjeel started the dharna at Shaheen Bagh and said we should protest NRC, CAA and NPR. Every Indian has the right to express his opinion and he did the same through the dharna…His entire speech of 40 minutes has been cut to 40 seconds to create a wrong impression about him, possibly for political reasons in Delhi elections,” Arshad said.

Meanwhile, another video of Sharjeel has surfaced, in which he is heard asking people sitting on dharna in a village reportedly in Gaya district to come out of villages and block national highways in a bid to cut- off vehicular movements between states.

He goes on to say that Muslim protestors should not get up from the streets “till the detention camps in Assam are closed”.

(Inputs by Abdul Qadir in Gaya)

Title: Bhujbal all set to revive Boat club project
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nashik: District guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal has initiated the steps to revive his pet project : Boat club and water sports centre.

Bhujbal on Monday chaired the district planning committee meeting for deciding the outlay of the district in the next financial year, which would be sent to the state government for final approval.

The meeting was attended by MPs and MLAs of the district along with officials of the district administration, including district collector Suraj Mandhare. “The district has requested the state government to grant an additional amount of Rs 185 crore in the next fiscal that will be utilised for schemes like boat club, tribal welfare and kalagram project,” a district official said.

According to him, Bhujbal is keen to revive the boat club project that he had planned during his earlier stint as the guardian minister. “If the state government gives its nod for the additional allocation, the total outlay for Nashik district would swell to Rs 958 crore,” he said.

The boat club project, inaugurated in 2014, apparently failed to take off after the NDA government came to power. The boats procured for the project were sent to elsewhere in the state as they were gathering dust.

During Monday’s meeting, Bhujbal directed the officials to spend the remaining amount of the total allocation for the current financial year. So far, the district has received over 40% of the Rs 791 crore allocated for Nashik in this financial year.

“The guardian minister has directed the officials to speed up the work of pending projects so that remaining amount could be utilised for the benefit of the people of the district,” the official said.

Meanwhile, during his speech after unfurling the Tri-colour during the Republic Day, Bhujbal said the top priority of the present government is to ameliorate the plight of the farmers of the district and common man.

“The district administration has linked Aadhhar numbers of 1.36 lakh farmers with their bank accounts under the crop loan waiver scheme,” he said.

Bhujbal also lauded the district administration as Nashik has become the first district in the state implement the Right to Service Act. As many as 81 services have been brought under this and the officials of these departments concerned will have to dispose applications in a time-bound manner or face action.

Title: HC to hear batch of pleas on Big Temple consecration today
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Madurai: The Madras high court has adjourned a batch of cases in connection with the consecration of the Brihadeeswara Temple at Thanjavur district to Tuesday (January 28), after two advocates made mentions of the petitions about protecting the ancient monument and seeking to conduct the ceremony in Tamil.

An advocate referred to the petition filed by M Saravanan, seeking to quash the order which was passed for conducting the consecration ceremony of the Big Temple in order to protect the ancient monument as the temple management did not obtain permission from the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). Similarly, another advocate made a mention of the petition filed by P Maniarasan, who is the coordinator of Thanjai Periya Kovil Urimai Meetpu Kuzhu seeking to conduct the consecration in Tamil language by Tamil archagars.

After these mentions were made on Monday, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran adjourned the batch of cases to Tuesday.

Saravanan, an advocate from Madurai, stated that the Brihadeeswara Temple is a declared monument as per the Ancient Monuments and Archaeological Sites and Remains Act, 1958. He stated that arrangements are being made by the Thanjavur Aranmanai Devasthanam to organise the consecration of the temple on February 5. A huge pandal has been set up for the length of 178ft to house the yaga salai with 110 yaga kundams to perform various rituals.

Though arrangements are being made, the devasthanam has not obtained permission from the ASI as it is their duty to safeguard and preserve the ancient monument as per the Act. When the consecration of the temple was organised in 1997, there was a major fire accident in which 48 people were killed and several others injured. He stated that this apart, there was also a considerable damage to the ancient monument.

Hence, the petitioner moved the high court to quash the order and also sought to grant interim injunction for conducting the ceremony.

Title: Zonal RTO nets Rs 32L as penalty in special drive
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Trichy: The regional transport office ( RTO ) in Trichy zone has netted Rs 32.72 lakh as penalty from vehicles including omnibuses for collecting excess fare and plying without paying road tax. A total of 24 vehicles, including four omnibuses were detained by the transport department officials during the special inspection carried out across Trichy, Perambalur, Ariyalur and Karur districts.

RTO sources said that Trichy zone having jurisdiction over the six main RTOs in the four districts, was involved in a special drive from January 11 to January 21. Around 10 RTOs and motor vehicle inspectors were fielded on the city outskirts and Trichy - Chennai, Trichy - Karur and Trichy - Thanjavur national highways targeting the heavy movement of vehicles before and after Pongal festival.

During the drive, as many as 1,787 omnibuses and 2,115 other category vehicles were inspected by the officials. “Check reports were issued to 268 omnibuses and 327 other category vehicles for various violations including excess fare collection and unethical modification in the vehicles. A fine of Rs 8 lakh was collected from such erring vehicles on the spot,” a senior official in Trichy RTO zone said.

Compounding fee of Rs 18.71 lakh was also levied on the vehicles caught for plying without permits and non-payment of taxes. tnn

Title: Amit Shah wants Arvind Kejriwal to visit Shaheen Bagh, spell out stance on Sharjeel Imam
Content:
Amit Shah

NEW DELHI: Addressing a crowd at Rithala in northwest Delhi on Monday, Union home minister Amit Shah dared chief minister Arvind Kejriwal to make his stance on the Shaheen Bagh protests clear.“Kejriwalji, are you in favour of action against Sharjeel Imam or not? Are you are with the people of Shaheen Bagh or not? Please tell the people of Delhi,” Shah said, adding that Delhi Police has booked Imam, a Jawaharlal Nehru University student, on the charge of sedition for his comment of “trying to cut the chicken’s neck” and break the northeast from the rest of the country.He also dared the AAP chief to visit the anti-CAA protest site so that people of Delhi could decide whom to vote for in the assembly elections. “You people say you are with Shaheen Bagh. If you have the guts then go and sit with them. And let Delhi decide,” said Shah.He also took a dig at Aam Aadmi Party chief’s tweet rebuttals to his various statements. “I talk about water, you tweet immediately. I talk about electricity, about buses, about CCTV cameras, and you tweet immediately. Today, too, you should. Two years back, there were ‘tukde tukde’ slogans at JNU. Now you should clarify whether you are giving permission to put those who shouted the slogans in jail?...Tell people of Delhi,” Shah said, alleging that the Delhi government was not allowing prosecution of those who raised the slogans.Earlier, in his speech, the senior BJP leader said that by voting for BJP, people will ensure safety and security of the country and the Capital. “I am here to appeal for Rithala candidate Manish Chaudhary. I see this crowd and can say for sure that he will be your MLA. It will decide both Delhi ki ‘dasha’ (state) and ‘disha’ (direction)”.Accusing the Delhi chief minister of spreading lies, he said he was stooping to very low level of politics. “Governments usually get awards for good roads, water, electricity, agricultural, health or industrial development. The Kejriwal government didn’t get a single award. But one award they got was for lying. They are No. 1. If a contest for telling lies is held, Kejriwal will be awarded the first prize,” Shah said.Later, the BJP star campaigner addressed another nukkad sabha at Mahavir Enclave for Janakpuri candidate Ashish Sood. He led the crowd with ‘Bharat Mata ki Jai’ chants even as it began drizzling. “I appeal to you to give Modiji the Delhi government this time. In five years, we will make it the world’s best capital city…Kejriwal said Yamuna water will be cleaned. Has it happened? (The crowd said ‘no’) Go to Allahabad Kumbh and take a dip, Kejriwal babu. Modiji and Yogiji have done such great work, go and see.”During both meetings, the home minister also spoke on Section 370, Kashmir, surgical strikes, health schemes of Modi government, regularisation of unauthorised colonies besides other issues.

Title: Evaluation: Universities told to recover money from teachers
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Collegiate education department has once again appealed to all state-run universities to recover from teaching faculties the money they had received for evaluation of answer papers of regular college students.

The appeal, said the department, was made in line with the UGC regulation 2010, which holds that paper evaluation of students is part of teachers’ responsibility and hence, the practice of making additional payments to teachers for the same is unacceptable. After Comptroller and Accountant General had pointed out that the universities in the state had together spent over Rs 39 crore for the payment of answer paper valuation, the state government had started initiating steps to recoup the additional amount given to college teachers. However, universities have not yet been able to calculate the extra amount given to each of the evaluators.

“...the government has ordered the universities concerned to quantify the amount given to the faculty members for the evaluation of answer scripts of regular students and recover the amount urgently from them and then release the remaining 20% of the amount in connection with the fourth instalment of sixth UGC pay revision arrears to the teachers,” an order issued by the department said.

Following the government decision to withhold 20% of pay revision arrears, several college teachers had successfully challenged the same in courts. However, universities’ failure in collating the details and initiating recovery procedures have lead to a deadlock. After CAG raised flag, universities now don’t pay additional remuneration to faculties for evaluating answer papers of regular students.

“The fact is that no university is in possession of exact details regarding the amount of money given to faculties for evaluation of answer papers of regular students. Some sort of consensus has now been reached. The varsities would adopt an agreeable formula for fixing the amount to be recovered from each faculty,” sources said.

The resistance from pro-Left teachers’ unions too has diminished over the years and they too have decided to forgo the additional payment that teachers used to receive for valuation of answer papers and accept the recovery. “The UGC has only stressed that paper evaluation is part of teachers’ responsibility. This clarification came against the backdrop of more universities adopting choice-based credit and semester system, which made the evaluation process more pervasive and continual. The situation become more complex since universities started giving sanction to any number of colleges in self-financing sector. Despite all difference of opinion, we will cooperate with the government efforts,” said C Padmanabhan, president, AKPCTA; a pro-Left association of aided college teachers.

Title: Shiv Bhojan thalis exhausted within 1 hour
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nashik: State government’s Shiv Bhojan thali scheme received an enthusiastic response across the district on Monday with the quota of 150 plates per centre getting exhausted within the first one hour at all the centres.

As per the operators of the Shiv Bhojan Thali centre, while the thali serving time was from 12 noon to 2 pm, people started queuing up from 11.30 am. When the designated quota of 150 plates was over in the first hour, hundreds had to return disappointed.

“There are a total of four centres in the district with three in Nashik city and one in Malegaon. The response to the Shiv Bhojan thali was overwhelming everywhere. All the thalis got exhausted at every centre. However, on the inaugural day, the thali centre in Malegaon could serve only 111 plates,” said Arvind Narsikar, the district supply officer.

Asked if the number of plates would be increased due to the huge response, Narsikar said the situation was same everywhere throughout the state. Therefore, if a decision has to be taken it would be taken only at the state level.

Rekha Gotise, who runs the Shiv Bhojan centre at the district collectorate premises, said, “There has been a lot of publicity for the Shiv Bhojan thali. People have been inquiring about its availability. On Sunday, even though it was a public holiday, the thalis got exhausted in a little over an hour. On Monday, people started lining-up from 11.30 am. We have space for 45 people to sit and eat at a time. Many people who came after 1pm had to be turned away.”

Nilesh Bacchav, a resident of Satana, who was at the district collectorate for some work, said, “The Shiv Bhojan thali was on my mind ever since I arrived at the collectorate. However, when I came to the Shiv Bhojan centre, I was told that the thali was over. The government should increase the number of plates and also the timing. It felt bad to miss the Rs10 meal and instead have vada paav for Rs 12.”

The operator said that they took the names, cellphone numbers and photos of the customer who purchased the thali from them. A person cannot order more than one plate.

Title: Stir against hydrocarbon project
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nagapattinam: Despite police denying permission to hold protest called by Anti-Methane Project Movement, against the Union government’s recent amendment to the Environment Impact Assessment Notification (2006) exempting hydrocarbon projects, farmers from Mayiladuthurai in Nagapattinam district staged protest here on Monday,.

Headed by the chief coordinator of the Anti-Methane Project Movement T Jayaraman, farmers, members of the movement and cadres from various political parties gathered at Chinna Kadai Street in Mayiladuthurai and raised slogans.

The Centre has exempted hydrocarbon exploration activities from the rigours of the Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) and public consultation through public hearings. It was issued in response to a request by companies including Vedanta Ltd for exemption from public hearing, Jayaraman alleged while addressing the protest.

He also condemned union government’s decision and warned that people would not allow any companies to explore natural gas and oil from their soil as he would carry out a series of protest across the delta. No project should be executed in the country without taking the consent of the people, he further stated.

They raised slogans and spoke about the ill-effects of the ongoing exploration projects at various places in delta region and the state of farmers who forgo their fertile lands for the projects.

Anti-methane project movement will hold such protest in Thanjavur, Tiruvarur, Mannargudi, Vedaranyam, Puducherry, Karaikal and Cuddalore continuously, protesters said.

Title: HC allows public meeting in memory of Palani Baba in Madurai
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Madurai: Madras high court has granted permission for a public meeting organised in memory of social reformer Palani Baba alias Ahammed Ali on his death anniversary near Goripalayam Dargah (mosque) at Madurai on Tuesday (January 28).

M Mohammed Rafiq moved the high court Madurai bench seeking to conduct the public meeting. Hearing the plea, justice A D Jagadish Chandira directed the petitioner to submit a fresh representation and an undertaking to abide by the conditions enumerated in the circular issued by the director general of police dated April 9, 2019. The judge directed that on receiving the fresh representation, the police shall allow the petitioner to conduct the meeting with certain conditions.

The judge directed the petitioner to ensure that the meeting is not conducted beyond the prescribed time and should not cause any hindrance to public and traffic. The volume of speakers should be at a minimum level and should not cause any disturbance to the residents in the area.

There should not be any speech that would affect the sentiments of other religions or caste or race and the speech should not affect peace and harmony. The judge also directed the organisers not to erect any digital banners or placards on arterial roads, platforms, walkways and any other roads. If a stage is erected, structural stability certificate should be obtained from the public works department.

The court further directed the petitioner to ensure that all conditions are strictly complied with and ensure that no law and order problem is created during the meeting. If the meeting is stopped or postponed by the police for any urgency, then the organisers shall cooperate with the officials, the judge said.

Title: APATA team reviews airport expansion work
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Andhra Pradesh Air Travelers Association ( APATA ) team met Visakhapatnam airport director Raja Kishore and reviewed expansion works taken up by the Airports Authority of India ( AAI ).

Construction work on the canopy, intended to shelter passengers, and expansion work on the terminal building are progressing well, said the APATA team.

The director of AAI had said that the new terminal, which is being taken up at a cost Rs 5.4 crore, will be ready by May 2020.

After commissioning the new terminal and N5 taxi track, the airport will be able to handle an additional two million passengers per year, said the director.

DS Varma, vice-president of APATA, said, “As Vizag is being considered as the executive capital, we expect air traffic to increase from current three million passengers to five million passengers in the next two to three years. In such a situation, there is a need to complete the work relating to parallel taxi track as early as possible.”

Title: BJP man hacked to death in busy Trichy market
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY/CHENNAI: A 38-year-old BJP functionary was hacked to death by a gang near the busy Gandhi Market in the heart of Trichy on Monday. F Vijaya Raghu, a resident of Pensioner Colony in Varaganeri and the party’s Palakkarai mandal secretary, died at a hospital later.

A cycle stand keeper at Gate number 6 of Gandhi Market, Vijaya Raghu was engaged in his work around 7am when two people arrived, hacked him on the head and sped away. He sustained grievous injuries and was rushed to the Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Government Hospital (MGMGH) where he died due to the injuries. One of the attackers was identified as Mohammed Babu, 20, of Uppu Parai, and the other a daily wager at Gandhi Market. While the police blamed previous enmity for the killing, the victim’s brother claimed that Raghu was threatened by some members of the Social Democratic Party of India for organizing a pro-CAA protest in Trichy.

BJP functionaries were quick to allege that the murder was committed by communal forces. A group of party cadre gathered in front of MGMGH and blocked the road demanding immediate arrest of the accused. A police team arrived and tried to pacify the protesters, but vehicular traffic was affected for more than an hour. A section of traders downed shutters in the Gandhi Market area following the incident. Police said Mittai Babu was a ganja addict with a history of petty offences and had come out on bail on January 11 in one such case. Police said preliminary inquiries revealed there was previous enmity between Raghu and Babu as the accused used to stalk the victim’s minor daughter.

“The murder happened due to some personal motive and no communal angle was involved in it. We have formed five special teams to nab the culprits”, Trichy central zone IG and city police commissioner in-charge A Amalraj told reporters. However, N P Senthilkumar, the victim’s younger brother, said in a police complaint that his brother had told him earlier that some members of the SDPI had threatened him for being actively involved in organizing a rally in support of the Citizenship Amendment Act in Trichy a few weeks ago. They also threatened to eliminate Raghu with the help of Mittai Babu, he said. Gandhi market police have registered a case.

Former Union minister Pon Radhakrishnan was among those who attended the funeral of the BJP functionary in the evening. Radhakrishnan raised apprehensions about the law and order situation in the state saying the government was losing grip over it and anti-social and extremist elements have taken charge. Police also failed to act against such forces and turned ineffective, he said. “Several BJP and Hindu organisations’ functionaries have been murdered. I call these murders pre-mediated and a declared war against Hindus,” said Radhakrishnan at Chennai airport. He claimed that collectors of certain districts were also feeling unsafe as police were not taking action against anti-social elements and Muslim extremists. Radhakrishnan alleged the DMK and Congress were supporting anti-social elements and remained mute when Hindus were killed.

Title: Uttarakhand health dept issues alert against coronavirus
Content:
Representative image

DEHRADUN: The state health department has issued an alert and advisory against Novel Coronavirus (nCoV), a cousin of the SARS virus, which has infected thousands of people in China since last month. With the state sharing land borders with China and Nepal, the health department has issued separate alert to border districts and extra ambulance and staff were deployed in local health centres as a precautionary measure.Director General (DG) health, Dr Amita Upreti, while briefing the media on Monday regarding the preparations of nCoV, said that though cases of the virus attack have been reported in Thailand, Japan and South Korea, “since China is our neighbouring country, India is taking all precautions from the same”. The health department has also ordered all the government hospitals to monitor every suspected case of the deadly virus and send daily reports to the concerned heads.“The integrated disease surveillance machinery has been put on alert as a usual readiness measure. Any suspected case would be taken straight to the isolation wards to be set up at government hospitals,” she said, adding that the common signs of infection include respiratory symptoms, fever, cough, shortness of breath and breathing difficulties. In more severe cases, infection can cause pneumonia, severe acute respiratory syndrome, kidney failure and even death.“We will also be creating awareness among the masses regarding the same and to alert people that one should not take the above mentioned symptoms lightly,” said DG health, adding that advisories have also been issued to Jolly Grant and Pant Nagar airports to ensure that if anyone is entering the state from countries or areas where the virus attack is prevailing, they should inform the health department and conduct proper health screening.A WHO note on nCoV states, “Coronaviruses (CoV) are a large family of viruses that cause illness ranging from the common cold to more severe diseases such as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS-CoV) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS-CoV). A novel coronavirus (nCoV) is a new strain that has not been previously identified in humans.” Coronaviruses are zoonotic which means they are transmitted between animals and people. Detailed investigations found that SARS-CoV was transmitted from civet cats to humans and MERS-CoV from dromedary camels to humans. Several known coronaviruses are circulating in animals but have not yet infected humans.

Title: WII survey team to hold in-depth river habitat assessment of Ganga basin with hi-tech tools
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Dehradun: In a unique in-depth study of country’s rivers, as part of river habitat initiative, a survey team will use state-of-the-art scientific tools and techniques such as laser-based distance measurement units for channel width determination, sonar-based channel depth estimator, doppler-based river flow determination, GPS and GIS technology in combination with the local traditional knowledge of the riverside communities for river conservation. The initiative will include 10 rivers and cover more than 4,000 km of rivers in eight states in the Ganga basin. The rivers to be mapped by Doon-based WII, including Ganga, Ramganga, Yamuna, Gomti, Ghagra, Gandak, Koshi, Son, Chambal and Rupnarayan — from source to their respective confluences.

Director-general of NMCH, Rajiv Ranjan Mishra, in the first national Ganga council meeting held recently at Kanpur had stressed on the need to safeguard the biodiversity of the important species of Ganga such as Gangetic dolphin, which is considered an important indicator of Ganga’s robust aqua system. This project has been assigned to WII for scaling up the aquatic species conservation in the Ganga basin.

Director of WII, Dhananjai Mohan, said that the convergence of state-of-the-art scientific tools, techniques and community involvement makes the assessment unique and one of its kind in the country. Project in-charge SA Hussain and Ruchi Badola said that the assessment will generate baseline data on river habitat conditions based on which a roadmap will be prepared for aquatic biodiversity conservation in Ganga basin for ensuring ‘Nirmal Dhara and Aviral Dhara’ of not only Ganga but also in its tributaries.

TOI had reported that a survey conducted by WII has revealed that around 49% of the Ganga River has high biodiversity value and species of conservation concern are reappearing as the river is getting cleaner. Hussain added, “We are confident that the present work will successfully address the biodiversity and river conservation issues in the Ganga basin, which will be a model for science-based river conservation in India.”

Title: Rodent alert delays flight by over 24 hrs
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Kolkata: A rat on a Dehradun-bound Air India Airbus 319 from Kolkata forced the airline to abort the flight at Varanasi on Saturday, de-board the passengers and accommodate them in hotels for 24 hours as airline staffers looked for the rodent. However, the rat could not be found. The flight finally left for Dehradun on Monday morning.

The incident happened on January 25, which also marked the onset of the Chinese New Year — the year of rats in Chinese zodiac.

According to aviation norms, an aircraft cannot be allowed to take off with a rodent on board. It could be catastrophic if it bit through an aircraft’s wiring, which can lead to loss of control. Airline officials fumigated the flight throughout Saturday night and Sunday while maintenance workers kept watch to ensure that the rat did not chew through any cable. The plane was certified to be rodent-free before it was allowed to fly again. Airline sources, however, were unable to say if the rat had entered the flight at Varanasi airport or had taken up temporary shelter in the flight for all of 85 minutes of the journey from Kolkata to Lal Bahadur Shastri International Airport in Varanasi.

“Necessary checks were done to ensure the flight was rodent-free and it was allowed to fly out of the airport on Monday morning,” said Akashdeep Mathur, director of Varanasi airport. The flight — AI691 — was scheduled to leave Kolkata at 3.55pm. But it was delayed by 80 minutes and it finally started for Varanasi at 5.15pm.

It reached Varanasi around 6.40pm. From Varanasi, the flight was scheduled to depart at 7.20pm, but just when the flight was about to take off, passengers and crew members noticed the rat scurrying around. The plane was taken back to the apron area from the runway and the flyers were offloaded as airline staffers began fumigation to sanitize the plane.

The aircraft finally took off for Dehradun on Monday morning. The delay made the passengers furious, some of whom took to social media to vent their anger. “AI691 on 25th Jan, 1stop to Dehradun from Kolkata via Banaras was late by 1.20 hr at Kolkata airport. We were de boarded at Varanasi airport due to a rat found inside the plane. We were made to stay in a hotel. After 24hrs we still don't know when will we fly,” (sic) Imran Ahmed, a flyer, tweeted on Sunday.

TOI tried to contact the airline for an official statement, but multiple phone calls and texts went unanswered till late on Monday.

Title: Minorities stage protest against CAA in Nagercoil
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Kanyakumari: Thousands of Christians and Muslims participated in the anti-CAA protest organised by Christian denominations, Muslim organisations and political parties in Nagercoil town on Monday.

They also sought speedy justice for the murder of special sub-inspector of police Y Wilson by extremists at the Kaliyakkavilai market road check-post on January 8. Police personnel were deployed in large numbers.

The mass protest organised in front of the Kanyakumari district collectorate in Nagercoil brought traffic to a standstill for a long time.

The protesters raised slogans against the Union government to withdraw CAA. Kanyakumari MP H Vasanthakumar, Congress MLAs S Rajesh Kumar (Killiyoor) and J G Prince (Colachel) and DMK MLAs N Suresh Rajan (Nagercoil) and S Austin (Kanyakumari) also took part in the protest.

Title: Man kills wife at Nanegaon village in Delolali
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nashik: A 30-year-old man has been arrested by Deolali Camp police for killing his 26-year-old wife following an argument at their home in Nanegaon village on Saturday night.

According to police, the suspect took a spade kept inside the house and hit it on the woman’s head, leading to her death. “We arrested the husband from the house on the same night. He was produced before a city court on Sunday and has been remanded in a day’s police custody,” a police officer said.

“The couple with their two children and the man’s mother stayed in the same house in Nanegaon village — around five-km from Deolali Camp. When the incident took place, the suspect’s mother was sleeping outside the house so that she could also guard their goats,” he added.

The suspect, his wife and their children were sleeping inside the house. “At around 10pm the husband and wife got into an argument. The suspect doubted his wife’s character. They were married for six years,” assistant police inspector Rahul More, the investigation officer, said.

“As the altercation got worse the man took the spade and hit her wife. The suspect’s mother came inside to check on the couple and saw the victim lying in a pool of blood. Soon, the villagers rushed to the house and caught the suspect. They later informed the police and a team soon reached the spot,” he added.

On the complaint of police patil of the village, the suspect was arrested by Deolali Camp police.

Title: Now, faceless assessment system at city port
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Visakhapatnam: To initiate transparency in tax collection, the customs department will introduce a faceless assessment system from the upcoming financial year. The system is making a trial run at the Visakhapatnam port for February and March 2019.

“In this trial run we are checking the efficiency and loopholes of the system. Indian customs will introduce the system at all ports across the country from the next financial year,” said DK Srinivas, during the international customs day programme.

Under this system consignments will be assessed by a virtual group irrespective of where the bill of entry is filed. A bill of entry is a document filed by an importer or an exporter that specifies the nature, quantity and value of goods that have landed or are being shipped out.

A customs official explained that if a bill of entry under this system is filed at one port and another port in country specialises in that specific cargo, the customs house of the second port would assess that bill no matter where it is filed.

“There had been complaints from trade bodies that seaports in India carry out assessment and examination according to their own method. Under this system there will not be any such compliant because customs house specialising in a particular cargo would asses bills for that cargo no matter at which port the entry is made,” the official said.

Title: Denotified tribes assn petitions dist collector
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Madurai: Members of the Denotified Tribes Welfare Association submitted a petition to the Madurai district collector demanding that the extension granted for the Justice Rohini Commission, which was formed to examine the distribution of benefits for sub-castes coming under the other backward classes (OBC) category, should not be given. They also demanded that the sub-categorisation of the OBC status be done immediately.

Treasurer of the association, Davamani Devi, said the central government has provided 27% reservation for the OBC category. The Justice Eswaraiah Committee, which took note of the fact that there was inequality in this categorisation, recommended that the OBC quota be sub-categorised into 9% of denotified, (DNT), 9% for nomadic tribes (NT) and another 9% for the semi-nomadic tribes.

The Justice Rohini Commission, constituted by the central government in 2017 was expected to submit its recommendations in two-and-a-half years but it has gone on seeking extensions, which were preventing these communities from getting benefits, that were long due to them. “We are the natives of this land, and our DNA is said to be 70,000 years old, but we are the most deprived, while communities that have 1% representation, enjoy more than 75% of the benefits in government jobs and other welfare measures,” she claimed. TNN

Title: Endobariatric surgery is newest weight-loss option
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Gastroenterologists from across the country participated in GPCON 2020

Nagpur: Obesity has become a public health crisis in India. Many of us are either overweight or obese. If dietary modifications, lifestyle changes and medicines (pharmacotherapy) fail, doctors go for bariatric surgery. But, such a surgery for weight loss is advisable only in highly obese people with body mass index (BMI) more than 35. Gastroenterologists from across the country and some foreign faculty discussed weight-loss surgery options for moderately obese people on Friday.

“Endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty is the latest minimally invasive weight-loss procedure. This process is emerging as a popular alternative to traditional bariatric surgery. Patients who don’t wish to undergo surgical interventions, prefer this option,” said Dr Saurabh Mukewar from Nagpur.

He said those who have BMI between 30 and 35 can also opt for this surgery to avoid further weight gain and health complications.

“Like any other weight-loss procedure, this surgery also requires commitment to a healthier lifestyle post-surgery. You need to make permanent healthy changes in your diet and exercise regularly to achieve long-term success,” he added.

Dr Kartik Sampath from New York said that endoscopic options can reduce complications while treating kidney stones, pancreas and intestine-related issues. Not only in bariatric surgery, advanced endoscopic procedures can be effective in treating problems in the pancreatic duct, large intestine (colon) and rectum,” he said.

Several pancreatic diseases, those that cannot be readily differentiated by non-invasive imaging techniques (CT scan/ultrasound etc) and conventional tissue sampling, can be diagnosed by endoscopy.

Leading gastroenterologist Dr Shrikant Mukewar was the conveyor of this event named as GPCON 2020. Dr Mukewar said that most advanced techniques to treat disorders regarding the digestive system are available in Nagpur now.

“We discussed the latest therapies on hepatitis B, irritable bowel syndrome (IRB), gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and such commonly experienced diseases related to the digestive system. More than 1,000 general practitioners from all over India participated in this conference,” he said.

WEIGHT LOSS WITHOUT CUTS

* Endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty is a minimally invasive weight-loss procedure

* This method is a middle path between medicines and traditional bariatric surgery

* A suturing device is inserted from the throat down to the stomach

* Doctors then place sutures in the stomach to make it smaller

* It leads to significant weight loss

* It’s minimally invasive and hence, the risk of operative complications are reduced

* A patient can resume daily activities quickly

Title: Cash, jewellery worth Rs 97k stolen
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nashik: Cash and articles worth Rs 97,000 were stolen from a house in the Bhadrakali area on Saturday morning.

According to police, the theft took place in Manikshaw Nagar near Kathe Galli close to Dwarka. The complainant was on his official duty on Saturday when some unidentified person broke the latch of the house and stole the cash and jewellery kept inside a cupboard.

The complainant said that the stolen articles included two gold chains, two gold rings, two earrings, gold coins, silver coins, and other jewellery, apart from the cash of Rs 10,000.

Meanwhile, in another house break-in, industrial articles worth Rs 48,000 were stolen from the Satpur industrial area between January 20 and January 21.

The complainant said that some unidentified person broke open the rear shutter of the industrial unit and decamped with two welding machines worth Rs 40,000, a drill machine worth Rs 5,000, a water motors worth Rs 2,000 and copper wire of Rs 1,000.

The Satpur police are investigating the case.

Title: First suspected case of coronavirus in Bihar
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: The first suspected case of coronavirus has been reported in Bihar. A 29-year-old research scholar, who returned from Tianjin in China, was admitted to the isolation ward of Patna Medical College and Hospital (PMCH) on Monday with symptoms similar to that of coronavirus.The woman from from Chhapra, doing PhD in neuroscience, had arrived at Kolkata on January 22 and reached home the next day. State health department principal secretary Sanjay Kumar said the woman had 102F fever and was taken to the government hospital at Chhapra Sunday night. On Monday morning, she was brought to PMCH, where her sample was collected and sent to a virology lab in Pune.However, the woman told a section of media that she did not have fever or any symptom of coronavirus and was completely fine. But symptoms, including breathlessness, fever and cough, were marked in the form signed by her and submitted in the virology lab of PMCH.State surveillance officer Dr Ragini Mishra , who has been made the state nodal officer for coronavirus, said she got to know about this case from a phone call from the woman’s family. “On Sunday, her brother told me over phone that she had fever, cold and breathlessness. We immediately arranged a mask for her and sent her to Chhapra sadar hospital, where she was kept in isolation throughout the night. She was brought to PMCH on Monday morning,” Mishra said.“As per the Centre’s protocol, any coronavirus suspect has to be kept in an isolation ward of the hospital. Her report will most probably come on Wednesday and if it is found to be negative, we will allow her to go home,” added Mishra.The state health department will keep monitoring the woman’s family members over the next 28 days. Officials, however, said none of them had developed any symptom till now.The Centre has alerted Bihar about three other students studying at Wuhan in China, of which two are natives of Sitamarhi and one is from Muzaffarpur. Mishra said of them, the 22-year-old Sitamarhi student had reached Danapur on January 19 from Kolkata and was under surveillance. But he has not reported any symptom yet.“We talked to the family members of another Sitamarhi native, who informed us that he is not coming to India. The one from Muzaffarpur has reached Delhi but will not come to Bihar. We are keeping a tab on their movement,” Mishra said.The state has already alerted the hospital superintendents and civil surgeons, especially in the seven districts near Nepal where one coronavirus case was confirmed.

Title: Pink party wins Karimnagar, BJP distant second
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Founder of TRS K Chandrasekhara Rao and KT Rama Rao. (File photo)

HYDERABAD: TRS continued its winning streak by romping home to victory in Karimnagar municipal corporation polls by a big margin. The result came as a shocker to Congress which did not win even a single division in the 60-member corporation. TRS won 34 divisions, BJP 12, MIM six, Forward Bloc three and independents won from five divisions.

For BJP MP from Karimnagar Bandi Sanjay, the polls were prestigious to demonstrate that Karimnagar was a stronghold. However, TRS dealt a blow by winning a substantial number of divisions as counting was taken up on Monday. The mayoral post will be bagged by TRS because of the numbers it has.

That Congress has drawn a blank in the polls in Karimnagar is a reflection as to where the party stands now. Not long ago, it was wielding control over the constituency with the likes of M Satyanarayana Rao, J Chokka Rao and Ponnam Prabhakar all winners.

Title: Social justice main criteria in selection of mayors and chairpersons: Telangana minister
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

TRS working president KT Rama Rao

TRS working president KT Rama Rao said the party maintained social composition in selecting the chairpersons and mayors. “We have given 58 chairperson and 45 deputy chairperson posts to backward classes...,” TRS working president said.

“Some castes under BC category such as Kummari, Patkari, Perika, Rajaka, Vadla, Vellapu, Reddika and Avusula which never enjoyed political posts were given a chance by TRS,” he added. In Suryapet, where the chairperson post was reserved for a woman candidate from general category, TRS allotted it P Annapurna who belongs to the Dalit community. Similarly in Medchal’s Pocharam which is a general seat, Redya Naik from the ST community was earmarked for the top post.

Title: Ben​galuru: Residents spend Rs 1,500 daily to get 50,000 litres of water sprinkled on dusty road
Content:
The one-km Gear School Road connects Panathur on Sarjapur Road to Marathahalli on Outer Ring Road

TimesView Desperate times, desperate measures. That’s the mantra Bengalureans are learning to live by, thanks to civic agencies which have hopelessly failed them. Doddakannelli is just another story that fits into a very predictable template — unending road works, missed deadlines and a suffering citizenry. The big picture is not very different. Sprinkling tanker-loads of water to fight clouds of dust could at best be a temporary solution. The permanent one lies in civic agencies walking the talk and upping their own game. If not for citizens, at least for the sake of restoring their own credibility.

BENGALURU: Close to half-a-lakh litres of recycled water is being sprinkled every day on Gear School Road of Doddakannelli , off HSR Layout, to mitigate the ill-effects of deteriorating air quality in the area. The road is bathed in dust, thanks to the digging work undertaken by the department of major roads and Bangalore Water Supply and Sewage Board (BWSSB).The one-km Gear School Road connects Panathur on Sarjapur Road to Marathahalli on Outer Ring Road (ORR). Residents are using eight tanker-loads of water daily to tackle the dust menace on the stretch.The drive was initiated on January 23 and residents are shelling out Rs 1,500 every day for this exercise. Famy Rasheed, a resident of Assetz East Point, said, “We are left with no choice but to do this ourselves and will continue doing this till the time we can afford it. Government officials need to step in and thoroughly complete the work.”Several months ago, the BWSSB dug up the road to lay water pipes and refilled the trenches. But the road wasn’t asphalted and the water board is now laying underground sewage pipelines. Plumes of dust rise from the road every time a vehicle passes by.Residents were told work would be over by December 15, 2019, but that didn’t happen. In another assurance, the MLA of the area, Arvind Limbavali tweeted that work would be completed by January 18, but this deadline too has lapsed.Four tankers sprinkle water at 4 in the morning and return 12 hours later for another round of the same drill. The water being used is the excess water from sewage treatment plants (STP) from two apartments — Assetz East Point and Adarsh Palm Retreat — on the road.Vasanthi Adarsh, a resident of Adarsh Palm Retreat said, “I have been living in this area for over 10 years now. Years ago, the road used to be in an excellent condition. Over the last two years, it has become pathetic.”Vasanthi says the road has three big schools and the dust kicked up by vehicles is threatening the health of children. “We realised there’s no point in waiting for the authorities to finish their work. It’s we who have to take care of our health. Hence, this initiative,” she added.A BWSSB officer said they are trying their best to finish work within the next one week. “Only installation of chambers is pending. Once that’s done, we will ask the BBMP to asphalt the road.”R Chandrasekhar, AEE, BBMP, said, “I agree there’s a slight delay in work. I know residents are facing a lot of trouble due to dust. As the road is comparatively narrow, the work has resulted in traffic congestion. But I’m also aware that BWSSB is sending three batches of labourers daily to finish work at the earliest.” Chandrasekhar said the BBMP is ready to asphalt the road as soon as BWSSB’s work gets over.

Title: Five dogs poisoned to death
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: At least five stray dogs were killed and four more were in critical condition after they consumed food suspected to be laced with poison at MS Ramaiah City in JP Nagar VII Phase on Monday morning.

The incident came to light around 8.30am when Aparna, a resident of Daffodils Apartment, came out with her dog for a walk and saw the strays lying unconscious on the roadside. She alerted her flatmates, who shifted the dogs to the hospital. She said five of the dogs died and four others were critically ill, including one pregnant dog.

Sources in Puttenahalli police said they suspect some residents who feared the stray dogs could harm them fed the animals food laced with poison.

Aparna said the dogs were being fed by locals and were friendly.

Title: Bengaluru: Hotel bouncers accused of attacking two partygoers
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: A criminal complaint has been filed against bouncers of a star hotel in central Bengaluru and two others for allegedly manhandling two youths during a late-night party on Sunday. The duo accused the managers of the hotel of not intervening during the scuffle.

Complainant P Bharghava, 21, of Papaiah Garden in Banashankari III Stage, said he and his four friends walked into the hotel’s party hall on Sunday night and had dinner. “We were enjoying DJ music when a few men fought with us for no reason and complained to the bouncers. Without hearing us, the bouncers pushed us out and in the melee, one hit me near my left eye. We approached one of the hotel managers, Biddappa, saying the bouncers should apologise to us. Some more men beat us again when we came to the parking lot,” read Bharghava’s complaint.

“Two men came out of a white car — KA 50-P-7719 — and attacked us. One of them pulled out a knife and attacked my friend Sankalp. No one came to our rescue. A little later, police, who arrived in a Hoysala vehicle, shifted Sankalp to a private hospital. We found that the DJ music and related events were illegal as the hotel management had no permission. The knife attack on us shows security is weak...” Bhargav added.

High Grounds police said they have issued notice to the hotel management and are looking for the accused mentioned in the FIR.

Title: Three more Punjab wetlands get Ramsar site tag
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Chandigarh: Giving boost to conservation of aquatic biodiversity in Punjab, three more wetlands have been declared as Ramsar sites of international importance by the Ramsar Bureau, Switzerland.

A total of 10 new sites from India have been given the prestigious tag, of which three are in Punjab, taking the total number of such sites to six in the state, highest in the region.

The development is significant as the inclusion of new sites will help the cash-strapped Punjab fetch more funds from the central government and different agencies for maintenance of the ecological character of its wetlands.

Of three new Ramsar wetlands, Keshopur-Miani community reserve in Gurdaspur is spread over an area 343.9 hectare and is is natural. On the other hand, 185-km stretch of the Beas conservation reserve, and Nangal wildlife sanctuary spread in an area of 116 ha in Ropar, are both man-made. The already existing Ramar sites include Harike, Kanjli and Ropar wetlands, covering a total area of 56.48 square kilometre.

The Ramsar Convention signed on February 2, 1971, is one of the oldest inter-governmental accord signed by members countries to preserve the ecological character of their wetlands of international importance. Wetlands declared as Ramsar sites are protected under strict guidelines of the convention.

Principal chief conservator of forests and wildlife Kuldip Kumar said that inclusion of three more wetlands would help the state government in carrying out the conservation of wetlands in more effective way. “Of total 12 wetlands in Punjab, six are now Ramsar sites. This was made possible due to hard work put in by the entire team involved in preparing the proposal in association with WWF-India,” said Kumar, who is also the chief wildlife warden of Punjab. He added that they were in the process of submitting proposal for declaring two more wetlands in the state as Ramsar sites.

WWF-India coordinator Gitanjali Kanwar, who was part of the team which prepared the proposal, said that the three new sites met more than three conditions required for getting the tag. Kanwar said wetlands conformed to the criterion of supporting the population of plant/animal conserving species important for maintaining the biological diversity of the area, and significant proportion of indigenous fish sub-species. They also fulfilled the condition of supporting vulnerable, endangered or critically endangered species, besides each wetland being home to more than 2,000 birds.

BOX:

Selection criteria

To be named as a wetland of international importance, the wetland must fulfil at least one or more of the nine conditions based on ecological characteristics, biodiversity which includes mammals, water birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish and other species.

Nine in the region

There are nine Ramsar sites in the region of which six are in Punjab and three in Himachal Pradesh. The wetlands in Himachal Pradesh with international tag include Chandra Taal, a high-altitude lake on the upper Chandra valley, which was declared a Ramsar site in November 2005. The other two are Pong dam lake and Renuka lake which got the tag in August 2002 and November 2005.

New Ramsar sites

Name | District | Area (in sq km) | Type of wetland

Keshopur | Gurdaspur | 3.439 | Natural

Nangal | Ropar | 1.16 | Man-made

Beas conservation reserve | Hoshiarpur, Gurdaspur, Amritsar, Kapurthala, Jalandhar, Tarn Taran

Title: TRS bags shot-calling rights in 119 urban local bodies
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Hyderabad: The Telangana Rashtra Samithi ( TRS ) has bagged chairperson and mayor posts in 119 urban local bodies (ULB) of total 127 in the state, indirect elections for which were held on Monday. They include 110 municipalities and nine municipal corporations .

The Telangana State Election Commission (TSEC) has postponed election in two municipalities —Neredcharla and Medchal. In Neredcherla, the election for chairperson was postponed as there was controversy over allowing ex-officio membership to Rajya Sabha MP KVP Ramchander Rao while in Medchal, the election was deferred to Tuesday as parties were yet to select their candidate for the post.

Elsewhere, Congress has secured the top post in four ULBs — Waddepally, Chandur, Manikonda and Turkayamjal while the BJP and AIMIM secured two each in Amangal, Maktal and Bhainsa, Jalpally respectively. The TRS was aided by ally AIMIM in securing the mayor post in Nizamabad. In other places, independents either joined or extended their support to TRS to get chairperson or mayor posts.

The TRS leadership deputed ex-officio members such as MPs, MLAs and MLCs to bag the top posts in the urban bodies. They also managed to draw support from other independents and party rebels. For instance in Meerpet, while the required number of seats for mayor is 24 wards (out of 46), the TRS managed only 19. However, the party managed to bring in all eight independents, including 3 rebels, to the party-fold in order to bag the mayor’s post.

In Kollapur, where several party rebels had demanded posts, the TRS gave its own candidates the posts to send a message that it will not tolerate “indiscipline.” Most rebels relented and extended their support to the party in elections for chairperson and vice-chairperson.

Title: There will be no power cuts this year: M M Mani
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Despite no substantial improvement in power generation, the state would continue to manage without power cuts this year as well, electricity minister M M Mani said. Arrangements were in place for managing power requirements of the state, the minister said on Wednesday adding that if need arises, more power would be brought from outside the state. “Water in major reservoirs would last till June. Kudankulam power highway would enhance the state’s capacity to bring more power from outside. Hence, the question of power cut doesn’t arise at all,” he said.

KSEB, meanwhile, is going ahead with the plans for setting up a second power generation unit in Idukki using the existing reservoir. Mani was talking to reporters after signing an agreement between KSEB and Tata Solar Power for generation of 35MW solar power from rooftop installations. Other two agencies that have been shortlisted by KSEB for setting up and operating roof mounted solar power generating units in the state include state government agency INKEL and Waarees, a solar panel manufacturing company. “With increasing public resistance to take forward hydel power projects such as Athirappally for which KSEB had already obtained necessary clearances from agencies concerned, we need to focus more on solar power generation,” he said. “Kerala is planning to scale up its solar power generation capabilities to 1,000MW. This presently is below 200MW. During the initial phase, the empanelled agencies together would ensure generation of 46.5MW solar power from rooftop solar units. Of this, 23MW would be from house rooftops, 14MW from other private rooftops and 9.5MW using government buildings. The target set for generation from roof top units is 500MW. The rest 500MW would be generated using floating solar panels to be deployed in reservoirs, including Idukki dam. The board had deployed floating panels in Banasurasagar dam on a pilot basis. Feasibility studies have proven that Idukki dam would be able to hold such panels that could generate up to 400MW solar power.”

Title: Coronavirus in Bangalore: People returning from China, neighbouring places throng hospital for coronavirus test
Content:
The isolation ward set up at Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Chest Diseases to treat suspected cases of novel Corona... Read More

Three patients in isolation ward

BENGALURU: People with travel history to China and other countries in its neighbourhood are knocking on the doors of Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Chest Diseases (RGICD), seeking clinical examination to ensure all is well. This despite the fact that they haven’t shown any symptoms of the novel Coronavirus (nCOV).Seeing the panicky reaction, the hospital on Monday called for an emergency meeting to set up a help desk to handle queries pertaining to the new virus infection. “Anyone with a doubt can approach us. However, there’s no need to panic. So far, there have been no positive cases,” doctors at RGICD said.Hospital sources said seven persons came to them with queries on Monday alone, but officials maintained there were just two such instances.“A man approached us stating his wife had recently travelled from Delhi to Bengaluru by air. Apparently, she sat next to a man who looked like a Chinese national. She has had fever for the last two days and the family is worried. We suggested he bring his wife for a check-up,” said Dr C Nagaraja, director, RGICD. In another similar instance, a person sought check-up at the hospital stating that he had recently travelled to Hong Kong.“Given the alarm, the number of such cases seeking clinical examination is likely to increase,” said health department authorities.Screening of passengers returning from China began at Kempegowda International Airport from January 20. Those reaching Bengaluru and Mangaluru from China are now being screened and a health surveillance team will be tracking them for 14 days.Currently, RGICD’s isolation ward has three patients with travel history to China. Two of them got themselves admitted on Sunday night with symptoms of cold and fever. The 37-year-old woman and the 22 year-old man, both working in Bengaluru, have been kept in the isolation ward.A 25-year-old Yelahanka man who tested negative for the deadly virus infection is yet to be discharged.The woman, a globalsourcing professional from Jalahalli, had travelled to Foshan in China between December 22 and January 11. “After that she went to Punjab. She may not have any infection. We just wanted to get her tested, as she was in China when the infection was spreading,” her family member told TOI.The 22-year-old man returned from China in January. Throat swab and blood samples of both patients have been sent to National Institute of Virology, Pune for testing and the results are expected in a couple of days.

Title: Jaganmohan Reddy seeks exemption from court appearances
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Andhra Pradesh chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy

HYDERABAD: Stating that CBI’s quid pro quo case against him was result of a quid pro quo arrangement between his political rivals, Andhra Pradesh chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy on Monday approached the Telangana high court urging it to dispense with the need to appear before the CBI court in Hyderabad regularly.

“Allow my lawyer to represent me at the trial court under section 205 of the CrPC,” he said. He filed 11 separate pleas urging the court to grant him the relief in all the 11 chargesheets CBI had filed against him.

The requirement of physical appearance is hindering the pace of his work as chief minister and hence, should be accorded an exemption taking into consideration the public interest involved, Jagan’s counsel said.

The case is likely to be heard by the high court on Tuesday.

Title: Telangana: Stone-pelting, lathicharge as Congress, TRS slug it out
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Choutuppal resembled a battle ground on Monday with supporters of political parties resorting to stone throwing and physical attacks during the election of municipal chairman and vice-chairman.

Police resorted to lathicharge to disperse the unruly crowds, while Congress workers staged a demonstration on the national highway alleging police highhandedness and bias in favour of the TRS .

Congress MLA from Munugode Komatireddy Rajgopal Reddy was arrested after he tore away the papers from the newly-elected councillors. In the 20-member council, TRS won eight divisions, Congress five, CPM three, while an independent bagged one division.

Later, two separate cases were filed against Congress workers for attacking two CPM councillors. A similar situation prevailed in Yadadri municipality as Raj Gopal, who went there also, objected to CPM elected councillors’ decision to support the TRS.

Title: Govt to train newly-elected members to boost accountability: KT Rama Rao
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

KT Rama Rao

HYDERABAD: All elected members in urban local bodies will undergo training on the new Municipalities Act, municipal administration and urban development (MA&UD) minister KT Rama Rao said on Monday. The move comes as the government now plans to focus on urban development, planned growth and corruption-free governance in municipalities. Around 43% of the of the state’s population resides in urban areas.

KTR said that the training will be initiated with an aim to increase accountability among elected members and will be on the lines of ‘Palle Pragati, Pattana Pragati’ (progress of urban areas). “Like gram panchayats, the government would release Rs 173 crore in the first week of every month towards matching grant of the central finance commissions grant of Rs 1,037 crore a year for development of infrastructure,” he said and added that the government was giving importance to green cover improvement in the state. “10% funds (of municipalities) should be earmarked for green cover improvement,” KTR said.

The TRS working president also said that Congress and BJP were “exposed” following developments where the two parties had helped each other secure posts in Turkayamjal, Manikonda and Maktal. “The unholy nexus between the two parties has been exposed now,” KTR said.

On using ex-officio votes, KTR said that the party had used the option granted by election commission in 1999.

Title: Congress & BJP join hands to deny TRS Manikonda pie
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

HYDERABAD: In a dramatic turn of events, Congress and BJP came together on Monday to pull the rug from under TRS’s feet to bag the chairperson and vice-chairperson posts in Manikonda municipality, which is predominantly a IT hub. Surprisingly, Congress had to eat humble pie in Nalgonda municipality and alleged that TRS won the municipal chairperson post thanks to the help it received from BJP with which it joined hands in Manikonda.

But, it was in Manikonda where all the drama happened with TRS trying to mobilise numbers to win the top post in the urban local body. But, Congress and BJP workers were two steps ahead of TRS by coming to an understanding and walked away with chairperson and deputy chairperson posts respectively.

Sources said former Congress MP from Chevella Konda Vishweshwar Reddy and Rangareddy district Congress workers played a big part in working out strategy with BJP. TRS working president and municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao termed it an “unholy alliance” of two national parties.

Vishweshwar told TOI that Congress and BJP came together in the interests of people of Manikonda. “There is an acute water problem in the municipal area and TRS has done nothing. Even members of Neknampur lake committee were in favour of Congress-BJP coming together to keep out TRS,” he said.

“I gave the go-ahead after an understanding was reached between local Congress and BJP leaders. We will continue to fight against each other in every other election. This understanding in Manikonda is for the welfare of the people and confined to Manikonda only,” he added.

BJP Telangana president K Laxman said local party leaders worked out the agreement with Congess for development of the municipality. “The BJP state-level leadership has no role in the Congress-BJP understanding in Manikonda. The BJP state leadership does not think on the lines of going along with Congress,” Laxman said.

In Narsingi municipality also, Congress and BJP tried to come together but TRS outwitted the two national parties by luring a BJP ward member. He had assured Congress of supporting it, but went missing. His supporters claimed he did not return after going out to brush his teeth early in the morning.

Title: TRS snatches mayor seat from BJP in Nizamabad
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

BJP workers led by MP Arvind Dharmapuri (right corner) at voting for Nizamabad municipal corporation mayor.

HYDERABAD: After intense politicking, Dandu Neethu Kiran of TRS on Monday got elected as mayor of Nizamabad municipal corporation with the support of AIMIM. BJP , which had emerged as the single largest party, winning 28 of the 60 divisions, declared that it was not interested in chasing its dream of winning the mayor post as it did not have the requisite numbers. Nizamabad MP Arvind Dharmapuri said they would rather be in the opposition since they did not have the numbers to bag the coveted post. The deputy mayor’s post was also won by TRS.

In the elections for the mayoral post on Monday, AIMIM, which emerged as the second largest party with 16 corporators, decided to support the candidature of the TRS nominee for the mayoral post, Neethu Kiran. TRS with 13 corporators was placed third in the corporation. Congress won from two divisions, while an independent won from one division.
