In addition to TRS and AIMIM numbers, the combine also had the votes of ex-officio members in their favour. Six legislators —3 MLAs and 3 MLCs, all from TRS —were ex-officio members. TRS Rajya Sabha MP D Srinivas, who fell out with TRS leadership, did not register himself to vote as an ex-officio member.

New mayor Dandu Neethu Kiran, who won from 11th division, said she would strive to ensure that the city was clean and also reduce use of plastic. She said for the last 15 years her husband was in politics and it was because of him she could get to the position.

“Health will be a top priority. Drainage systems needs to be improved. Garbage lifting has to be done on a regular basis,” she said, talking about her priorities as mayor. In the 2014 elections too, TRS took support of MIM for its candidate Akula Sujatha’s election as mayor. In this election, Sujatha lost the polls.

Title: Punjab gets 8 more additional DGPs, intelligence chief transferred
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Chandigarh: Already top-heavy, Punjab Police department on Monday got eight more officers in the rank of additional director general of police (ADGP) resulting in a reshuffle. DGP intelligence V K Bhawra has been transferred as DGP Punjab home guards and director civil defence in Chandigarh. Varinder Kumar has replaced Bhawra as ADGP intelligence.

The IG-rank officers of the 1994-batch who were promoted to the rank of ADGP are: Naresh Kumar Arora, Ram Singh, S S Srivastava, Praveen Kumar Sinha, B Chandra Sekhar, Amardeep Singh Rai, V Neeraja, and Anita Punj. Now, there are a total of 23 IPS officers in the rank of ADGP, and eight in the rank of DGP in Punjab.

Gurpreet Kaur Deo has now been posted as ADGP community affairs division, with additional charge of women and child affairs. S K Asthana is ADGP human rights; Shashi Prabha Dwivedi ADGP Lokpal, with additional charge of state police election cell; Naresh Kumar is ADGP crime; Ram Singh ADGP modernisation; Srivastava ADGP security, with additional charge of NRI affairs division; Sinha is ADGP prisons, B Chandra Sekhar is ADGP crime, with additional charge of ADGP internal vigilance cell; Rai is ADGP human resource development; Neeraja ADGP welfare. Mohnish Chawla has been transferred as IG Indian Reserve Battalion, Punjab, with additional charge of excise and taxation; S K Singh as IG crime, including crime against women; and Hardian Singh Mann is DIG Ferozepur range.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Congress election campaign yet to hit top gear
Content:
AICC general secretary in charge PC Chacko

NEW DELHI: While AAP and BJP have launched high-octane campaigns for the February 8 polls, Congress appears to be lagging behind. Though individual candidates have opened their elections offices and initiated door-to-door canvassing, the overall campaign has yet to pick pace with none of the top Congress functionaries seen on the ground.Displaced by AAP in 2013 after being in office for 15 years, Congress faces a tough electoral battle this year too, with AAP and BJP seen to be in a direct fight for a majority of the 70 seats. After a disastrous show in 2015, when it failed to win even a single seat, Congress’ vote bank — minorities, Dailts, slum-dwellers and those living in unauthorised and resettlement colonies — has gravitated towards AAP.To pose a real challenge, sources said, Congress required a concerted effort from its senior functionaries to convince people to again vote for the party. Some of the candidates TOI spoke to agreed that the central leadership could have stepped out and held group meetings even before the elections were announced.“AAP and BJP functionaries have been regularly addressing meetings and holding roadshows. With so little time left for polling, we have to cover a lot of ground,” said a candidate, requesting anonymity, adding that he had already requested for a roadshow or a big rally in his constituency, to be led by AICC general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra or former Congress president Rahul Gandhi.AICC general secretary in charge, PC Chacko , however, said all senior functionaries would soon be on ground addressing meetings and participating in roadshows. Chacko said the Congress campaign for Delhi polls would be in “top gear” in the first week of February. “There were some initial hiccups due of lack of resources and coordination. All our candidates have now opened their offices and started door-to-door canvassing. You will soon see our central leadership campaigning in Delhi too,” Chacko said.He added that 14 MPs and 70 MLAs from neighbouring states had already reached Delhi and taken over the responsibility of supervising the preparations at district and assembly levels. “The programme of our 40 star campaigners is being worked out to ensure that all constituencies are covered,” he said, adding that the party’s focus would more be on smaller meetings and roadshows than big political rallies that require a lot of manpower and time to organise. He said interim Congress president Sonia would also address some public meetings.Another party functionary said Delhi Congress chief Subhash Chopra and campaign committee chairman Kirti Azad had been addressing at least 3-4 corner meetings every day. “They have already held several interactions with district, zonal and booth-level party workers apart from addressing corner meetings in various constituencies. The Congress’ graph is only going up and that will reflect in the results,” he said.

Title: Float fest: Flag to be hoisted today at Meenakshi temple
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Meenakshi Temple

MADURAI: Flag hoisting ceremony will be held as part of the float festival of Sri Meenakshi Sundareswarar temple on Tuesday.

After 40 years, the Mariamman teppakulam in the city, where the festival is held has received water from the Vaigai river through its traditional water supply channels and is brimming. Hence this year is extra special for the festival as float would move in the brimming the tank.

For the past few years, the festival has been celebrated with a static float due to lack of water. The flag hoisting ceremony would be held in the temple premises on Tuesday morning and the deities, Goddess Meenakshi and Lord Sundareswarar would be taken around the streets of the temple in different vehicles on all the days of the festival. On the tenth day of the festival the deities would be brought to the tank, and special rituals would be performed when the float festival is celebrated on February 8.

Title: 400 volunteers to help fight forest fires in Kanyakumari
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Kanyakumari: Considering the vast forest cover and increasing incidents of fires, the fire and rescue department has started training youths from forests and adjoining areas as volunteers. They will help the fire and rescue services and forest department protect forests from fires.

“We are in the process of identifying at least 400 volunteers. They will be associated with four stations – Nagercoil, Kulasekaram, Kuzhithurai and Padmanabhapuram – as these stations have a major forest cover in their jurisdiction,” said Kanyakumari district fire officer (DFO) B Saravanababu after the first training programme on Monday.

“The programme was started on the directions of the DGP and director in-charge of the Tamil Nadu Fire and Rescue Services department C Sylendra Babu a couple of days back. As many as 90 volunteers were identified till Monday and the rest will be identified in a couple of weeks,” the DFO said.

It is learnt that the district with one of the largest forest covers in the state has seven fire stations with only 100 fire fighters, due to which not more than 50 personnel will be on duty in the district in each of the two shifts in a day. This presses the need for volunteers especially from the forest periphery. Fighting forest fires is difficult compared to fires in urban areas due to inaccessible terrain without roads and availability of fuel in the form of dry grass, bushes and wood.

Since fire tenders would take time for the fighters to reach the nearest accessible road that is at times 25 to 30 kms from the station, the volunteers will be the first to step into action. “The best way to fight a forest fire is to stop it early before it spreads,” he said. Identification was carried out on a war footing as the number of fire calls in the district increased from 22 in December 2019 to 57 in January. At least 15 calls this month were forest fires. This is due to heavy growth of bushes and grass facilitated by rains till last month. Training and engaging them in fire-fighting will be after verification of their background by the forest and police departments. On Monday training began for 25 students of Vins Christian College of Engineering at the foothills of Chunkankadai near Nagercoil.

Title: HSC question papers to come in small bundles of 25
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nashik: The Maharashtra State Board of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education (MSBSHSE) has decided to distribute question papers in bunches of 25 directly to all examination centres across the state this year for the HSC and SSC exams.

The board’s decision is aimed at reducing the risk of the question papers getting leaked.

“This is to be careful and avoid any instance of the question papers getting leaked. The board wants to ensure fair examination for all the students,” said Nitin Upasani, the divisional secretary, Maharashtra state secondary and higher secondary education office, Nashik division.

Till last year, the board used to send the question papers in bunches of 50s and 100s, which were kept in the custody offices of the board’s examination centres. “There is no way the papers can be opened mid-way between the printing press and the examination centres. But while at the examination centres, the big bunches of question papers had to be opened and segregated according to the required number of papers in the examination hall,” Upasani told TOI.

According to Upasani, the question papers will be kept in the board’s custody offices two days before the examination with ample security. For an exam scheduled between 11 am to 2 pm, the question papers will be brought to the respective examination centres by 10.30 am. By 10.40 am, the question papers will reach the examination halls where the sealed envelopes will be opened. By 10.50 am, the students will be allowed to read the question papers for 10 minutes and commence writing by 11 am.

The HSC examination is set to begin on February 18.

Title: ACS Khanna to probe felling of 24k trees along Bist Doab canal
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Bathinda: Punjab chief secretary Karan Avtar Singh informed the National Green Tribunal (NGT) on Monday that additional chief secretary (ACS) and financial commissioner (development) Viswajeet Khanna had been asked to inquire into the alleged felling of 24,700 trees along the Bist Doab canal here.

The state’s top bureaucrat, in an affidavit submitted to the tribunal, said the ACS would enquire into violations of the Forest (Conservation) Act, 1980, and fix responsibility.

The affidavit was submitted on the basis of NGT’s orders of January 10, when the matter of violations had come to the tribunal’s notice, but no one appeared to represent the Punjab chief secretary and secretary of irrigation. Then, NGT bench comprising Justice Raghuvendra S Rathore and Siddhanta Dass had directed the chief secretary to file a personal affidavit on January 27 to apprise why the matter had not been inquired.

The tribunal also directed the Punjab irrigation secretary to appear in person to explain why no one appeared on his behalf. Petitioner’s counsel, Saurabh Sharma, said Delhi resident Nishant Kumar Alag had filed the petition in 2018, alleging that 24,700 trees were felled around Bist Doab canal in Punjab in 2016 in violation of the Forest (Conservation) Act. “On August 16, 2018, NGT had directed Punjab through chief secretary to appoint an inquiry officer not below the rank of additional chief secretary to prove the matter and fix responsibility of officers. The forest department had claimed that trees were under jurisdiction and supervision of the state irrigation department. The Punjab irrigation department filed an appeal in the Supreme Court, which on January 11, 2019, had dismissed the appeal and upheld the NGT order,” he said.

Sharma said chief secretary informed the NGT that ACS M P Singh had been asked to inquire intp the matter on September 2, 2019, with direction to complete the probe in two months. “The officer could not complete the inquiry and retired on December 31, 2019. Now, the CS has appointed ACS Khanna to inquire the matter and complete probe in two month. An affidavit in this regard was filed in NGT today and principal secretary (irrigation) A Venu Prasad appeared in person. The tribunal has adjourned the matter to February 10,” Sharma said.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Congress election campaign yet to hit top gear
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

AICC general secretary in charge PC Chacko

NEW DELHI: While AAP and BJP have launched high-octane campaigns for the February 8 polls, Congress appears to be lagging behind. Though individual candidates have opened their elections offices and initiated door-to-door canvassing, the overall campaign has yet to pick pace with none of the top Congress functionaries seen on the ground.

Displaced by AAP in 2013 after being in office for 15 years, Congress faces a tough electoral battle this year too, with AAP and BJP seen to be in a direct fight for a majority of the 70 seats. After a disastrous show in 2015, when it failed to win even a single seat, Congress’ vote bank — minorities, Dailts, slum-dwellers and those living in unauthorised and resettlement colonies — has gravitated towards AAP.

Complete Coverage on Delhi Elections

To pose a real challenge, sources said, Congress required a concerted effort from its senior functionaries to convince people to again vote for the party. Some of the candidates TOI spoke to agreed that the central leadership could have stepped out and held group meetings even before the elections were announced.

“AAP and BJP functionaries have been regularly addressing meetings and holding roadshows. With so little time left for polling, we have to cover a lot of ground,” said a candidate, requesting anonymity, adding that he had already requested for a roadshow or a big rally in his constituency, to be led by AICC general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra or former Congress president Rahul Gandhi.

AICC general secretary in charge, PC Chacko , however, said all senior functionaries would soon be on ground addressing meetings and participating in roadshows. Chacko said the Congress campaign for Delhi polls would be in “top gear” in the first week of February. “There were some initial hiccups due of lack of resources and coordination. All our candidates have now opened their offices and started door-to-door canvassing. You will soon see our central leadership campaigning in Delhi too,” Chacko said.

He added that 14 MPs and 70 MLAs from neighbouring states had already reached Delhi and taken over the responsibility of supervising the preparations at district and assembly levels. “The programme of our 40 star campaigners is being worked out to ensure that all constituencies are covered,” he said, adding that the party’s focus would more be on smaller meetings and roadshows than big political rallies that require a lot of manpower and time to organise. He said interim Congress president Sonia would also address some public meetings.

Another party functionary said Delhi Congress chief Subhash Chopra and campaign committee chairman Kirti Azad had been addressing at least 3-4 corner meetings every day. “They have already held several interactions with district, zonal and booth-level party workers apart from addressing corner meetings in various constituencies. The Congress’ graph is only going up and that will reflect in the results,” he said.

Title: AAP, BJP did ‘jumlebaazi’, we do not believe in lip service: Subhash Chopra
Content:
Subhash Chopra

After a disastrous 2015 assembly poll when it failed to win a single seat and its vote share plummeted to below 10 per cent, Congress this time is fighting a battle for survival in Delhi politics. Atul Mathur spoke to Delhi Congress Pradesh Committee president and former MLA

on the party’s poll agenda and why it believes people will vote for his party this time. Excerpts.

Congress lost the 2013 and 2015 assembly polls and 2014 and 2019 Lok Sabha elections badly. Why do you think people would vote for Congress this time?

What are you promising Delhi this time?

Congress has openly supported the anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) protests in Delhi. While the BJP has turned it into an election plank, do you think your party will also get support from those opposing the law?

The protest at Shaheen Bagh is causing a lot of inconvenience to commuters. Would you request the protesters to end their sit-in?

Whenever Congress has forged an alliance with a regional party in any state, its own vote base has shrunk. What prompted your party to ally with RJD in Delhi?

Congress has always been criticised for promoting dynastic politics. You have given ticket to children of several former MLAs including your own daughter.

In the 2013 and 2015 assembly polls, people voted for a party which was born out of a movement started by Anna Hazare and promised a corruption-free society and Jan Lokpal Bill. But then its founder-members started leaving because they realised that those who talked about a corruption-free society were themselves indulging in it. Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal, who sat on a dharna at Rail Bhawan in 2014 to get three policemen suspended, didn’t have time to go and meet the students who were assaulted at Jamia Millia Islamia and JNU. And he is the same person who called Sheila ji a helpless chief minister. A government which can’t provide safety to women and children, can’t prevent people dying by inhaling polluted air, cannot provide clean water, can’t check price rise and take action against hoarders but blames the Prime Minister and lieutenant governor for not allowing them to work for four-and-a-half years can’t be remain in power. It was our government that introduced CNG-run public transport, privatised discoms, gave Rs240 crore to the Haryana government to build a water canal, expanded Delhi Metro and bought new DTC buses. We started the Laadli scheme to give education to the girl child. People realise that and they will vote for Congress this time.The voters were influenced by big promises made by AAP and BJP. But Delhiites have now realised that it was all ‘jumlebaazi’ (just words). Congress does not believe in lip service. We do what we promise.Congress started the monthly pension scheme for senior citizens and widows in 1998 with Rs 200 and increased it to Rs 2,500. We have now promised a pension of Rs 5,000 per month now. While Kejriwal says he will open more old-age homes, we want to empower senior citizens with more money. Their children will also be able to take better care of their parents. Water has become scarce now. We want people to save water. We will not only give 20,000 litres of water free but also give an incentive of 30 paise for every litre they save. We want to give free travel to senior citizens, students and people below poverty line. We will soon bring out our manifesto, which will have several schemes for Delhiites.I don’t think CAA is a local issue and should become an election plank. This is a national issue. Any movement which turns violent becomes weak and we are not in favour of that. But it is surprising that AAP has suddenly taken a stand on it. It realised it was not getting support of the youth and women associated with protests and that Congress was coming back to power. AAP is a creation of BJP and it is their conspiracy.I bow my head in front of the women sitting on dharna. The LG had called a meeting with these women and they have agreed to leave a lane for traffic. Their intention is not to create problems for anyone but only to save their future generations. I leave it to them to decide their course of action. It is their democratic right to stage a protest.There are a lot of Poorvanchalis in Delhi who have contributed in the development of the city. Since we have an alliance with RJD at the national level, out of respect we have given them four seats to contest.They have been given tickets on merit and not by the virtue of being children of former MLAs or ministers. Daughters of (former Delhi Speaker) Yoganand Shastri and (former MLA) Kunwar Karan Singh are active workers of Mahila Congress. My daughter has worked closely with Martin Luther King III. and travelled with him to several countries, promoting peace and working with the youth. She is highly educated and had worked in Karnataka elections for one month. She is working with All India Congress Committee’s research department. I never pushed her name and she is here by virtue of her work. We want the young generation to come forward and join politics to serve society.

Title: Punjab CM Amarinder Singh to throw open youth fair in Mohali
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Amarinder Singh

CHANDIGARH: Punjab chief minister Amarinder Singh will inaugurate the two-day Punjab State Youth Fair at a private university in Mohali on January 30.

State sports, youth services and NRI affairs minister Rana Gurmeet Singh Sodhi on Monday said around 25,000 students of the state would participate in the fair. Sodhi presided over a meeting in this regard here. He asked officers to develop a dedicated mobile app for the event to apprise people, especially the youth, of activities planned for the event.

The minister said they needed to involve drug abuse prevention officers (DAPOs) and buddies from educational institutes for the event’s success.

Title: ‘Crimes dipped after installation of CCTV cams in Jaihindpuram’
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Madurai: Closed-circuit television (CCTVs) installed in Jainhindpuram, one of the areas notorious for crimes in the city, have helped bring down the crime rate drastically, city commissioner of police S Davidson Devasirvatham said on Monday. More than 70 CCTVs were installed in the area resulting in the crime rate coming down when compared to the previous year, he added.

Speaking at a function organised to dedicate 56 more CCTVs in Jaihindpuram on behalf of Suryan Friends Group Devasirvatham recalled how his earlier stint in Madurai in 2005 when the city was prone to severe crimes. In 2018, when he assumed charge, the crime rates had come down. There used to be a time when several murders used to take place in the city, but that has come down. The commissioner said that the co-operation of the people has helped bring the crime rate down, and now the centre medians and barricades on roads have helped reduce accidents. If people also came forward to wear helmets that could further help reduce accidents and loss of life, he added.

Residents who spoke at the event agreed that incidents of petty thefts and chain-snatching have come down in Jaihindpuram after the installation of CCTVs.

Title: Over 500 lawyers protest Justice Haq’s transfer
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nagpur: Over 500 lawyers on Monday signed a petition protesting the sudden transfer of Justice Zaka Haq to Aurangabad by Chief Justice Pradeep Nandrajog.

While demanding cancellation of the transfer order, the lawyers said the signed petition would be sent to the President of India, Chief Justice of India , Chief Justice of Bombay High Court and Maharashtra chief minister . Earlier, the High Court Bar Association (HCBA) had passed a resolution in this regard.

According to the protesting lawyers led by Sudip Jaiswal, Justice Haq was one of the upright and honest judges in the judiciary, who had taken up various PILs on issues like potholes. Due to his stringent directives to the Nagpur Municipal Corporation in this PIL, civic officials had to work overtime to fill up potholes which had become a death trap on every road after monsoon, they said.

The lawyers hailing from various courts also apprehend threat to the judge’s life due to a slew of directives passed by him while hearing various cases related to alleged mysterious death of former judge BH Loya in the city. They added that he had directed the authorities to protect all documents and records related to the judge’s death from last 10 years in original form.

Title: Nitish Kumar launches Rs 187 crore exam board schemes
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nitish Kumar

PATNA: CM Nitish Kumar on Monday launched a series of projects of Bihar School Examination Board (BSEB) worth Rs186.74 crore. The projects included examination hall-cum-administrative buildings at nine divisional headquarters in Patna, Munger , Gaya, Purnia, Saharsa, Chhapra , Bhagalpur , Muzaffarpur and Darbhanga. Each examination hall has a seating capacity of 4,000 to 5,000 examinees at a time.

Nitish also inaugurated a new administrative building of the BSEB at its headquarters, its enterprise resource planning system and a new data centre. He also announced that the ‘Unnayan Bihar’ scheme would be extended to Classes XI and XII. Under the scheme, students of Classes IX and X are taught through online and offline methods and smart television sets.

The CM lauded the role of BSEB officials in erasing the “blot of mass cheating” from the state’s forehead by holding fair examinations and publishing results of matriculation and intermediate examinations on time. He said the BSEB was doing so well that officials from other countries (read Nepal) and states (Chhattisgarh) were visiting its headquarters to learn how to hold fair examination and publish results before the stipulated time. “I am really happy over the recent improvements in the board. I thank the officials of the board and the education department for their achievements,” Nitish said.

Recalling the infamous mass cheating incident at Hajipur in 2015, Nitish said the picture showing relatives scaling a four-storey school building to pass notes to matric examinees had gone viral and brought a very bad name to the state’s board. “Every newspaper across the country had carried that photo. Also, a board topper had brought bad name by giving an unsatisfactory reply to media people. Then, we had lodged FIRs and took stringent action against all those involved in such acts,” he said.

“But now, the board has improved its efficiency and maintains transparency by use of technology in holding examinations and publishing results,” Nitish said.

He asked the board officials to be “extra careful” in use of technology because “wrongdoers” could go to any extent to defame the board by misusing the technological advancements.

The CM urged media persons to publish reports if any irregularities are found in the BSEB works. “Had you not published that school picture, we would not have initiated such action. So, you must publish any irregularities in the board’s functioning,” Nitish told the media.

State’s education minister Krishna Nandan Prasad Verma , chief secretary Deepak Kumar, additional chief secretary (education) R K Mahajan and BSEB chairman Anand Kishor also spoke at the event.

Title: Political process must for resolving water woes: Experts
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Aurangabad: Water management experts have underlined the need of a “political process” to resolve the water issues being faced by Marathwada.

“Water experts, lawyers, retired government officials and media have been doing their best to highlight the water problems of Marathwada, but their efforts have obvious limitations. Resolution of water problems is a political issue,” water management expert Pradeep Purandare said.

Activist Abhijit Dhanorkar said it was the collective responsibility of different stakeholders to join hands for waging a battle for the just share of the region in equitable water distribution. The stakeholders have also stressed that political parties, peoples’ organisations and political activists should study and understand the socio-economic-politico-legal complexities involved before arriving at informed decisions for framing water policies, strategies and programmes.

Coinciding with the fresh political agitation with a lead from BJP functionary Pankaja Munde, experts have released an indicative list of demands that could offer the desired relief for Marathwada.

“Top most priority needs to be given to soil conservation and river rejuvenation. There is a dire need for measurement of water and carrying out water audit. Such a measure can ensure development of resilience towards climate change,” Purandare said.

He added that the authorities concerned must prepare rules of equitable distribution of water at river-basin level and create an institutional as well as legal arrangement to implement those in letter and spirit.

“The rules should address only equitable distribution of available water. It should be left to the individual projects to decide purpose-wise distribution of water once they get their share of water,” Purandare said.

Strengthening of Maharashtra Water Resources Regulatory Authority and effective implementation of the Integrated State Water Plan are some of the key remedies the experts have pressed.

Among other demands, experts have laid emphasis on completing the operative part of Irrigation Acts by framing rules, issuing notifications and committing agreements.

“It is advisable to convert Irrigation Development Corporations into River Basin Authorities and promote water users’ associations by dissolving the Canal Advisory Committees. We have to bring lift irrigation under the purview of Irrigation Acts. It is completely un-regulated now,” Purandare said.

Title: NMSCDCL: Smart road is uneven at some stretches
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Done

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Smart City Development Corporation Ltd (NMSCDCL) on Monday admitted that the construction of city’s maiden smart road is “improper”.

“The riding quality on the smart road is not as per the set standard. It is uneven at some stretches,” chairman of NMSCDCL and senior bureaucrat Sitaram Kunte said after a meeting of NMSCDCL in which CEO of NMSCDCL Prakash Thavil and municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game were also present.

“It is not possible to rectify this shortfall at this juncture as construction of the road is complete. We cannot dig up road to set things right. So we have taken a decision to rope in experts from IIT-Bombay,” Kunte said.

“The experts from IIT-Bombay would examine the road and come up with the best possible solution to deal with this problem to ensure that the problem is rectified,” he added.

The 1.1-km stretch of city’s first smart road — from Ashok Stambh to Trimbak Naka — has been constructed at a cost of Rs 20 crore. The work for the project began in March 2018.

The contractor of the project missed five deadlines and has been penalized by the NMSCDCL for the same. Many elected representatives of the civic body and local residents have been questioning the quality of the road following which the NMSCDCL carried out a quality check of the entire stretch and the problem was detected.

“Although we have opened the road for traffic, work to set up the bus shelters, high mast lights, underground cable work of MSEDCL, installation of e-toilets, is still remaining. The NMSCDCL will ensure that these works are completed within the next one month,” Kunte said.

A visit to the road on Monday revealed that the traffic signals at CBS chowk and Mehar junction are yet to be made operational.

Title: Bail plea of Childline activist rejected
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Kottayam: A special court for Pocso cases at Thodupuzha in Idukki on Monday rejected the anticipatory bail plea of a Childline activist, who is accused in a crime registered by the Munnar police for the offence of giving false information of sexual assault on a minor boy.

The accused threatened the Class IX student to file a false complaint against a woman counsellor who was acquainted with the boy.

The accused John S Edwin of Ikka Nagar, Munnar, had moved a complaint through the childline to the police.

On preliminary complaint inquiry conducted by the police, it was revealed that it is a false complaint and certain disputes existing between the school teachers added fuel to filing the complaint. Special public prosecutor P B Wahida pointed out that filing false complaint is punishable under Section 22 of Pocso Act.

Justice K Anilkumar, special judge for Pocso cases, rejected the anticipatory bail plea citing that granting bail will give the wrong message to the society as the probe is in progress.

Title: Punjab wrestler caught stealing from ATM in Bengaluru
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

The Punjab wrestler and his aide had cut through an ATM by the time police landed at the kiosk

BENGALURU: A wrestler and his associate from Punjab , who entered an SBI ATM kiosk in southwest Bengaluru early on Sunday and cut open the cash-vending machine, were arrested after blank visuals from the kiosk were noticed by the bank’s control room in Mumbai.

Harsh Aror, 36, a wrestler in Jalandhar, and his associate, Samarjoth Singh, 32, from Sri Muktsar Sahib city, had removed Rs 13 lakh cash from the ATM and stuffed it into a bag, when police arrived and arrested them. The cops were alerted by the bank.

Ramesh Banoth, DCP (west), said the incident took place between 1.20am and 1.50am on Sunday at the SBI kiosk opposite BHEL.

“The two masked CCTV cameras installed outside the ATM with chewing gum. After entering the ATM, the miscreants, who wore helmets, blackened the cameras inside. But SBI’s control room staff in Mumbai noticed the visuals going blank and suspected something amiss. Officials alerted the Bengaluru police control room, but we were not told which kiosk had been targeted. We asked night patrol cops to verify all SBI ATMs from JJ Nagar till Rajarajeshwari Nagar,” Banoth said.

Chandra Layout inspector Brijesh Mathew, who was on night patrol, and three Hoysala staffers zeroed in on the kiosk near BHEL. “Our men found its shutter rolled down and could smell something burning,” Banoth said.

The duo inside the kiosk, however, put up a fight. According to Brijesh’s complaint, they hit head constables Basavaraj and Anand with an iron rod on the leg and hand, respectively.

“We nabbed the duo red-handed and seized the stolen money, a gas cutter, cylinder, oxygen masks, pipes, a car and other material from them,” Banoth said.

Duo were fourth-time unlucky in robbery

Harsh Aror and Samarjoth Singh had planned to loot ATMs to clear the debts they had incurred after suffering loss in their cloth business. Aror and Singh were staying in BTM Layout, southeast Bengaluru. for six months. They failed to loot ATMs in their first two attempts but succeeded the third time and took away Rs 23.5 lakh from a kiosk at Parappana Agrahara on the night of December 28.

They learnt tricks from online videos

“They initially watched videos about looting ATMs on online platforms, including YouTube. They realised a gas cutter would help them open the metal kiosks,” an investigating officer said. The suspects were produced before the court, which remanded them in police custody for 14 days. Police said Harsh was a wrestler and car driver, while Samarjoth ran an apparel business, in which he lost huge sums of money.

Title: Subhash Chopra: AAP, BJP did ‘jumlebaazi’, we do not believe in lip service
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Subhash Chopra

Title: Pathetic state of roads, pavements irks city folk
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Madurai: Bad roads, uneven pedestrian paths and damaged or encroached pavements are what residents witness every day leaving all sorts of mobility at risk in the city.

Encroachment of the pavements in the four Masi Streets around Sri Meenakshi Sundareswarar temple makes it extremely difficult for the commuters. “The vendors pick up a quarrel if we walk in front of their roadside shop, or stand in front of them. They try to make it look as though we are violating the rules,” said K Kannan of Chinthamani.

It is not just one part of the city that is facing this problem but almost all the roads. In West Veli Street near the Madurai railway junction, vehicles are parked on the pavement, forcing people to walk on the road amidst fast moving traffic where vehicles tend to rub against the pedestrians as the centre median has narrowed the road, said S Shanthi, a commuter.

Window shopping is a strict no in Anna Nagar, a dream destination for shoppers where many shops like textiles, ice cream, sweets, shoes, and jewellery dot the surroundings. “However, one cannot walk without watching every step as the pavement is full of gaping holes, into which a child could fall,” said Thangaraj, a shopkeeper. “A paver block pedestrian path could do wonders to the business in Anna Nagar, but the corporation has not been paying attention in spite of representations to repair the pavement,” he said.

Kamarajar Salai, which has shops on both sides, also sees vehicles being parked haphazardly. The problem becomes worse when marriage halls are booked as cars are parked for nearly a km. Pavements on this stretch are also unusable.

City engineer S Arasu said that the repair works of the pavements would be taken when the roads are re-laid for which funds have been sanctioned. Encroachments are also being removed by the authorities regularly, he added.

Title: Panel to decide on Smart City consultant’s penalty
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nashik: The directorial board of the Nashik Municipal Smart City Development Corporation (NMSCDCL) on Monday expressed concerns over the poor consultancy services provided by Project Management Consultant (PMC). The board set up a committee to decide whether to levy a penalty on the consultant and reduce its consultancy fees.

The committee includes municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game and Uddhav Nimse, the chairman of the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) standing committee.

The Smart City administration had tabled a proposal in this connection at the board meeting of the NMSCDCL. “We have reported our disappointment for the inefficient staff provided for the Smart City projects by PMC. The total consultancy charges for the projects amount to Rs 31 crore, and the NMSCDCL has paid Rs 5 crore so far,” said NMSCDCL chairman Sitaram Kunte.

“The PMC did not prepare proper estimates for the Smart City projects and we had to make frequent changes due to its inexperienced staff. Therefore, there is an issue over making payment to PMC. We have set up a committee that will decide on whether to reduce its consultancy fees,” said Kunte. “PMC is a well-known consultant, but it did not provide qualified staff. We have told the company to provide experienced and qualified staff,” he added.

A PMC had been appointed to support NMSCDCL in developing, planning, designing, managing, implementing and monitoring the Smart City proposals/projects. However, the quality of work, quantity and timeliness of services were not to a satisfactory level.

Title: Subsidy to equip 2 lakh properties with waste disposal units
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Owners of 82,000 properties have applied for and benefited from the PMC ’s property tax discount of 5% and 10% if their building, society or bungalow has a compost pit, rain water harvesting or solar powered systems. The civic body now wants to increase the number of beneficiaries up to two lakh.

The PMC now also offers a subsidy to citizens and housing societies if they buy composting or waste processing machines for disposal of wet waste instead of compost pits.

A subsidy is given for promoting segregation at source. Individual citizens and housing societies can avail the subsidy. Citizens can get financial aid up to Rs 1,200 per house, while societies can get up to Rs 1.2 lakh.

The funds are to be used for setting up a processing plant. The two-bucket vermi-compost unit can be installed on private properties especially in flats, while the electrical composting machines can be used by housing societies.

The civic body will empanel traders to sell the garbage processing units . The traders have to demonstrate their machines and provide training about their usage and maintenance to the buyers. An exhibition of these options was organised at Ganesh Kala Krida Manch on Saturday and Sunday .

“Those who have availed the subsidy will have to ensure that they keep their units maintained and use them. These units will be monitored by a team,” Dnyaneshwar Molak, head of PMC’s solid waste management department, said.

More and more people can set up the processing units on their properties. Smaller and old housing societies will benefit from the move for 100% disposal at source and improve Pune’s Swachh ranking for the cleanest city.

Title: TRS eyes independents to bag top posts in urban local bodies
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Hyderabad: Eyeing urban local bodies where TRS did not perform well, the pink party is reportedly wooing independents as they have become decisive factor in getting mayor and chairpersons posts.

TRS working president and MA&UD minister KT Rama Rao has asked local leadership to talk to independents to bring them into party fold. On Saturday evening, two independents had joined TRS in Khammam district. In Kollapur and Ieeja municipality, TRS rebels, who won on All India Forward Bloc tickets, reportedly expressed their willingness to join TRS.

Party leaders said the TRS working president has begun the exercise of selection of chairpersons, mayors and deputy chairpersons and mayors on Saturday evening and continued on Sunday morning by talking to the ministers and MLAs. Sources said the incharges of the respective civic bodies have been asked to give names and preferences for the posts. TRS president K Chandrasekhar Rao might take a decision on the names on Sunday night and communicate them to the ministers and MLAs by Monday morning.

Indirect elections to posts of chairpersons, mayors and deputy mayors would be held on Monday morning. The Telangana State Election Commission can issue whip to the elected corporators to prevent defections. “TRS will be in power for the next four years and they can serve to the people in the party. Ninety per cent of independents have come forward to support TRS,” TRS leaders claimed. The ex officio members of the civic bodies MPs, MLAs and MLCs have already given their preferences like at Meerpet corporation, where the party requires more number.

In the election of chairpersons and mayors, social composition is also likely to be taken into consideration and also other factors like leaders who are loyal to the party and participated in the movement.

As there was a chance of illegal practices in election of mayor and chairpersons posts, Telangana State Election Commission said bribery, exertion of undue influence on the elected representatives (ward members) and camps were seriously and also it was in violation of the Model Code of Conduct.

“No political party or candidate shall offer any post to the electors as an incentive or bribe for defying their party whip while exercising their voting rights. They candidates or party shall not organize any camps with elected members either directly or indirectly,” SEC commission V Nagi Reddy said.

“Bribery or influencing ward members in the indirect elections are punishable under Section 234 of the Telangana Panchayat Raj Act and Section 226 of the Municipalities Act and the responsible persons would be prosecuted,” Nagi Reddy said.

Title: Saudization in online taxi sector to affect Malayali drivers
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Jeddah: Ministry of labour has ordered to localize jobs in the online taxi sector to Saudi citizens, banning employment of foreign workers. Online taxis, introduced two years ago, are very popular. Thousands of Malayalis work in this sector.

For many Malayalis, it’s an additional source of income. They work during evening hours as part-time job after finishing routine work. Uber, Kareem and Easy taxis are available options. Suneer from Kayamkulam in Alappuza, a Kareem driver said that it was a good source of income. On an average, he used to earn Rs 38,080 (SR 2,000) monthly by doing this as part-time job. Like Suneer, many expats with cars do the same job to earn extra money.

Commuters prefer to hire online taxis as the entire service is controlled by gadgets. Passengers need not bother about route or destination. Khaled Abu Al-Khail, spokesman from ministry of labour and social development, confirmed the decision regarding limiting work in online taxi cars to Saudi nationals. He said joint inspection teams will monitor online car companies for any violations. Fines will be imposed on violating firms depending on the number of expat workers employed in jobs restricted to Saudis.

Meanwhile, Saudi authorities decided to make regular taxis to go green. The colour change began at King Abdulaziz International Airport as an experiment. Very soon all online taxis will go green. Private cars cannot run as online taxis official sources said.

Title: PMC draft budget takes up traffic challenge
Content:
File photo of huge traffic jam in Pune

Activists not on the same page

PUNE: Municipal commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad has plans to find some method in the traffic madness.On Monday, along with the proposal to streamline traffic in the city, he also announced a review of the Bus Rapid Transit System project, dedicated lanes for two-wheelers and introduction of solar or electric vehicles in the congested areas.While presenting the draft civic budget, Gaikwad said streamlining traffic in the city was his top priority to ensure a hassle-free commute.“The city has more than 36 lakh registered vehicles of which 80% are motorcycles. A proper plan to deal with movement of two-wheelers is necessary,” he said.The civic chief said he was looking forward to solutions, which would enable the two-wheeler riders to traverse the entire city in 35-40 minutes. “It is a challenging task, but a solution needs to be worked out to avoid hassles in the future. Like freeways for cars in Mumbai, we can have dedicated lanes for two-wheelers to ensure faster movement,” Gaikwad said, while speaking with the media after tabling the draft civic budget.He said the existing BRTS corridors were only meant for buses, but could also be utilized for movement of two-wheelers.“At some stretches, especially in the congested areas, BRTS lanes can be opened for two-wheelers. On lanes where the frequency of buses is less, the corridor can be opened for two-wheelers as it remains vacant for a longer period. However, before implementing the scheme, we will conduct a detailed study and also seek the help of organizations. All the stakeholders will be consulted before any decision,” Gaikwad said.Gaikwad said smaller solar-operated and electric vehicles in the congested areas were needed. PMPML vehicles face problems to operate in such areas and smaller e-vehicles or those operated on solar energy can be introduced on such routes for the benefit of the people, he said, adding that the initiative can be rolled out with the help of the industries under their corporate social responsibility initiatives.Gaikwad said there was a need to reset traffic movement on narrow lanes by introducing one-ways for barrier-free movement. “Also, development of parking lots in the government-owned plots to minimise roadside parking is an option,” he said.The civic chief also expressed the need to prepare a comprehensive plan for extension of Metro services, while considering the requirements of the next 50 years. “Factors like inclusion of new villages in the city limits, development of new industrial areas, IT hubs and proposed airport have to be considered while coming up with the Metro plan,” he added.On the opening of BRTS lanes to two-wheelers, activists said the civic authorities should first execute the BRTS project properly. “PMC has failed to execute the BRTS project, which is the reason for the prevailing chaos. BRTS should primarily handle public transport buses. Introduction of private vehicles, including bikes, will defeat the very purpose of introducing the dedicated lanes of BRTS. The bikes or private vehicles can be allowed only in exceptional cases,” an activist from the Satara Road area said on condition of anonymity.

Title: NMC to clean 3 Godavari tributaries using robotic tech
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has decided to clean three tributaries of the Godavari river — Waldevi, Nandini and Waghadi — on its own using robotic technology.

Earlier, the civic body had planned to clean these three rivers manually through private contractors. The NMC had also floated tenders for the purpose. However, it did not receive a good response from contractors.

Following demand from civic body office-bearers, the NMC has decided to clean the rivers on its own. In fact, it has already started the cleaning process using a robotic machine in three tributaries.

Water hyacinth, sewage, moss and plastic waste have been causing obstacles to the free flow of water in Nandini, Waghadi and Waldevi. The obstructions also make the water stagnant in many places. Stagnant water is neither good for the health of the river nor for people. In addition, a lot of pollution is being caused by local residents living by the rivers.

“Earlier, we had plans to rope in private contractors or agencies to clean the rivers by removing water hyacinth, plastics, garbage and other waste from the waterbodies. We had invited bids to clean the three tributaries of the Godavari, but did not receive a good response,” said the NMC officials.

“We had then invited bid for the second time, but we received bids from only two-three contractors. Even they did not qualify. We had plans to float fresh bid again,” they added.

However, there are limitations to cleaning rivers manually. Therefore, the civic body has decided to clean the Godavari’s tributaries on its own. The NMC has a robotic machine and the manpower is to be provided by the robotic company concerned, said the municipal officials.

“In fact, we have already started cleaning the three tributaries on our own,” said officials. The robotic cleaning operations will also be faster than the manual method.

Title: PMC draft budget seeks 12% hike in property tax
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A 12% hike in property tax proposed by municipal commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad in the draft civic budget for 2020-2021 is expected to bring an additional income of Rs 150 crore.

Gaikwad tabled a Rs 6,229-crore budget for the next fiscal before the standing committee on Monday, an increase of Rs 144 crore from last year's Rs 6,085 crore.

The proposed increase includes a 5.5% hike in general tax, 1.5% in water benefit tax and 5% in sewage treatment charges. The budget has to be approved by the standing committee and the general body before its implementation.

Citizens will also have to pay an additional 15% in water tax which has already been approved as a part of 24X7 water supply project.

Gaikwad said steps have been planned to increase tax collection to boost the civic body's income. “The civic administration may start revenue generation by imposing tax on properties which are not in the ambit. They include properties which were in the gram panchayat limits but are now part of the PMC, and the newly constructed buildings in such areas,” he said.

He said many properties under the PMC have got occupancy certificates but have not been added in the tax net. A special drive to identify and include these properties will follow, he added.

“We will cross verify the OCs issued in the last few months and their property tax status. The civic body will make sure that each and every property with OC is registered with the property tax department and the owner pays tax,” Gaikwad added.

The stumbling block may be the standing committee which may reject the tax hike as it has done in the past. The civic panel gives the final touches to the budget and presents it.

“The hike is not justifiable and I want to reject it. The civic administration has to ensure that the tax dues are recovered. All the senior leaders in the PMC will take a final call, but the hike is very likely to be rejected,” standing committee chairman Hemant Rasne said.

The panel had rejected the 12% property tax hike proposed in the 2019-20 budget by then commissioner Saurabh Rao. The civic administration was expecting an additional tax revenue of Rs 110 crore from such a hike that was applicable to residential properties, cellphone tower companies, IT and ITES companies.

Civic activists said the hike was unfair to those paying tax regularly. “Recovery of around Rs 3,500 crore is pending. The civic administration should not increase property tax until they recover such dues,” Vivek Velankar of Sajag Nagrik Manch, a citizens’ group, said.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Two people killed in clash near Theni
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Two people were killed in a clash between two groups at Kailasapatti near Periyakulam in Theni district on Monday prompting relatives of one of the victims to block the road with his body disrupting traffic on the Theni - Dindigul highway. Police said that members of a particular community had lodged a complaint with the Thenkarai police against the activities of a man from another community, a ganja peddler, at Kailasapatti near Periyakulam about two months ago. The ganja peddler and his relatives attacked members of the other community on coming to know about the complaint leading to tension in the village. Subsequently, another complaint was filed by the affected people with the police demanding that the police take action against the man selling ganja. Tension prevailed in the village and there were frequent quarrels between the two groups since then.

On Tuesday evening, a clash erupted and seven people including a woman were attacked with deadly weapons by the other group. Jayabal who was injured died at Theni government hospital. Perumal, 70 from the other community who sustained grievous injuries died a little later. Jayabal’s relatives staged a protest on the road with his body. Theni district superintendent of police E Sai Charan Tejaswi and other officials visited the village and a large number of policemen have been posted there.tnn

Title: IPR scientist moves Gujarat high court against chargesheet
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A suspended scientist from the Institute of Plasma Research (IPR) has approached the Gujarat high court challenging a departmental chargsheet issued against him last month.

Petitioner Subrata Pradhan is a former head of the Steady State Superconducting Tokomak – 1 Mission, (SST-1). He was instrumental in getting it commissioned and operational in 2013. This was achieved for the first time in India. He was suspended in August 2018 by IPR director, Shashank Chaturvedi. He has been fighting a legal battle in the high court since then.

Pradhan has approached the HC once again through advocate Rahul Sharma and Utkarsh Dave after he was served with a chargesheet last month. He has questioned the validity of the chargesheet on various grounds. He has contended that the chargesheet is without jurisdiction since the mandatory First Stage Advice of the chief vigilance commission (CVC) was not taken.

Pradhan has also claimed that some of the charges mentioned in the chargesheet are required to be looked into by the CVC and not by the department. He has claimed that he has been singled out by the director for decisions that were taken by a committee more than a decade ago. He attributes the alleged malice on part of the director to his own chances of becoming the institute’s director in 2015.

Besides quashing of the chargesheet, Pradhan has also urged the HC to direct the government to consider his request for increasing his subsistence allowance to 75% in accordance with law.

The HC is likely to hear Pradhan’s plea in the coming days.

Pradhan’s petition challenging his suspension is pending in the HC. He claimed in the petition that he was suspended without being given an opportunity to respond to accusations or irregularities levelled against him.

The scientist has been contending that as soon as Chaturvedi became IPR director in 2016, he began harassing him and narrated the series of events that ultimately led to his suspension and filing of chargesheet.

Title: Gujarat government makes U-turn on helmets, tells high court it hasn’t relaxed the rule
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Pull out your helmets as the state government took a U-turn over its “temporary relaxation” of the mandatory helmets rule, and told the Gujarat high court on Monday that it had not issued any notification relaxing the rule regarding safety headgear for two-wheeler riders.Not only did the government assert that it had not relaxed the compulsory helmets rule, its advocate pointed out that in 2015, it amended the state rules and made helmets mandatory for pillion riders as well.The state government made this clarification after the much touted announcement by the state cabinet on December 5, that the mandatory helmets rule was “temporarily” relaxed in municipal areas. The bench headed by Chief Justice Vikram Nath asked for an affidavit from the transport department in this regard from by the end of the month.The government’s claim that there was no relaxation on paper came in response to a PIL filed by one Sanjeev Ezhava from Surat, who complained that making helmets temporarily optional for two-wheeler riders in municipal areas was a violation of Section 129 of the recently amended central Motor Vehicles Act. Ezhava claimed that Gujarat government’s decision to relax this rule was a negligent omission.The PIL submitted that the state government had earlier made pillion riders in women and children the exception to mandatory helmet rule , which was also against provisions of the MV Act.The petitioner cited a press note published on the Gujarat government website, as well as a circular issued on December 5, 2019 by the transport commissioner to all RTOs and assistant RTOs, asking them to grant exemption to two-wheeler riders in municipal areas from the mandatory helmet rule.In response to the petitioner’s claim of exempting women and children form wearing helmets while riding pillion, the government cited its 2015 amendment, by which it made helmets mandatory for them.The petitioner argued that the central government law in August 2019 went a step ahead to protect the lives of riders, and any move to make wearing helmets optional was a regressive step. He cited figures of two-wheeler riders killed in road accidents. In 2017, 35,975 people died in the country and the deaths witnessed a 9.1% rise in 2018, with 43,614 deaths reported.Ezhava further submitted that in Gujarat, 209 persons riding two-wheelers were killed in accidents in 2016 and 1,546 people were killed in 2018. The number was even higher in 2017, with 1,912 deaths. Gujarat is eleventh in the country in the number of road deaths of two-wheeler riders.Ezhava also cited the high court’s directions in a suo motu PIL to the state government, to make helmets mandatory for two-wheeler riders in 2005-06.

Title: Civic chief proposes review of all schemes
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Pune: Municipal commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad on Monday proposed a review of the civic body’s existing schemes to check their necessity and efficacy.

Gaikwad said he would immediately initiate steps to start reviewing the schemes. He said, “The schemes that are not useful or effective can be suspended. Besides curbing unnecessary expenses, this will also help administration introduce new schemes that are more effective.”

The municipal commissioner said he was not in position to provide details of every scheme since he recently took charge of the office.

“The review will be comprehensive in nature. I also appeal to the elected representatives to come forward with suggestions on the review and implementation of the schemes. A joint study by the administration and corporators will help eliminate lapses and achieve a realistic outcome,” Gaikwad said, adding that no scheme would be suspended without prior review.

The civic chief said he was in favour of a supplementary budget from the next financial year. Gaikwad said, “The concept is being implemented at the state level, where the elected representatives submit their demands or revised estimates. A similar concept can be introduced at the civic body.”

He added, “The elected representatives can submit proposals for diversion of funds under the supplementary budget. Currently, all such proposals are tabled throughout the year which poses a challenge for the administration.”

The civic chief said the supplementary budget exercise could be executed in December-January. “It is an ideal period because the administration by the time gets a fair idea about revenue collection and also about spending of allocated budget for projects,” Gaikwad said.

Title: Telangana: Anything can happen, BJP MP D Arvind warns TRS
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

HYDERABAD: A day after chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao came down heavily on BJP leaders and the Union government, Nizamabad MP D Arvind on Sunday said that BJP getting good results in Nizamabad civic polls is a warning for TRS .

Addressing the mediapersons, Arvind said, “If BJP take things seriously anything can happen.” He alleged that the state government is encouraging religious conversions and involving children also.

Title: Piyush Goyal calls for a national register of traders & workers
Content:
While the Delhi assembly polls have seen a lot of debate over freebies, Goyal said he doesn’t believe in subsi... Read More

NEW DELHI: Union commerce and industry minister Piyush Goyal , while addressing a traders’ conclave in Delhi on Monday, suggested the idea of a national register for traders that would have a database of the merchants, their families and workers “You say there are seven crore traders and many families are associated with you as workers. It is my suggestion that there should be an accurate database of names, family members, workers, type of trade, locations and mobile numbers. It is unfortunate that while a (national) population register is being considered, people are carrying out mischievous propaganda against it,” Goyal said.At the Dilli Vyapari Mahasammelan organised by Confederation of All India Traders (CAIT), Goyal argued that for any welfare scheme to be effective, the government should have accurate data. “We wanted to bring an amnesty scheme for pending cases of traders and industrialists, but we needed data to gauge its effectiveness. It would have shown us how much revenue we would have to forego,” he added.The minister said that the national database would benefit both the trading sector, by giving them more power, and the government, by effective policymaking. “Every forum throws different numbers. Every sector, be it the mobile industry, retail trade, grain trade, etc, claims to have a large number of people associated with it. Sometimes, the overall number becomes more than the entire population of the country,” Goyal added.Goyal clarified that his remarks were non-political. “You have taken permission from Election Commission for this conclave by stating that it is a non-political forum. So, I will say things within my maryada (dignity). I am not here as a politician seeking votes. The government wants to work on improving financing and digitisation,” he added.While the Delhi assembly polls have seen a lot of debate over freebies, Goyal said he doesn’t believe in subsidies. “This government doesn’t give subsidies on one hand and cause injury on the other. We believe in structural reforms,” he added, while giving the example of the LED bulbs programme to support his argument.“Before 2014, a government company used to purchase 6 lakh LED bulbs in a year. After subsidy, the bulb was sold for Rs 400-500. Subsidy was limiting the capacity. The subsidy and the problems highlighted by the industry were removed. Against the target of 70 crore bulbs, we sold more than 150 crore and the price came down to as low as Rs 38,” Goyal said.CAIT general secretary Praveen Khandelwal said they have accepted the minister’s challenge and a database on traders will be created in six months.

Title: Motera to get a facelift ahead of stadium opening
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Civic sources add that a detailed survey of underground lines is also being done simultaneously, to clear bloc... Read More

AHMEDABAD: Residents of Motera and Chandkheda have reason to cheer. In anticipation of US president Donald Trump’s possible visit to the city for the Motera cricket stadium inauguration, the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) is giving 16 stretches of road around the stadium a makeover, as well as laying new alternative routes to the world’s largest cricket stadium.

A senior AMC official denied any intimation about Trump’s visit, “Neither the US or the Union government has confirmed Trump’s visit to the city,” said a senior AMC official.

Some of the main roads that will be widened and resurfaced are Chimanbhai Patel Bridge to Visat junction and Visat to Zundal junction. Another stretch that will be repaired will be between Visat junction and Tapovan Circle. The access road to the Motera stadium from Janpath Hotel will be widened to 24 metres, along with two other parallel roads. Two new roads are be made, from Bhat and Koteshwar to Motera. Most internal roads from residential societies to the ONGC and Motera stadium roads under TP 28 will be spruced up in the current drive, AMC officials claimed.

“We have to get the roads ready ahead of the stadium becoming functional, keeping in mind the traffic jams that the area may witness as 1.10 lakh spectators turn up at the venue,” says municipal commissioner Vijay Nehra.

Civic sources add that a detailed survey of underground lines is also being done simultaneously, to clear blockages or shift lines.

Title: Piyush Goyal calls for a national register of traders & workers
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

While the Delhi assembly polls have seen a lot of debate over freebies, Goyal said he doesn’t believe in subsi... Read More

NEW DELHI: Union commerce and industry minister Piyush Goyal , while addressing a traders’ conclave in Delhi on Monday, suggested the idea of a national register for traders that would have a database of the merchants, their families and workers .

“You say there are seven crore traders and many families are associated with you as workers. It is my suggestion that there should be an accurate database of names, family members, workers, type of trade, locations and mobile numbers. It is unfortunate that while a (national) population register is being considered, people are carrying out mischievous propaganda against it,” Goyal said.

Complete Coverage on Delhi Elections

At the Dilli Vyapari Mahasammelan organised by Confederation of All India Traders (CAIT), Goyal argued that for any welfare scheme to be effective, the government should have accurate data. “We wanted to bring an amnesty scheme for pending cases of traders and industrialists, but we needed data to gauge its effectiveness. It would have shown us how much revenue we would have to forego,” he added.

The minister said that the national database would benefit both the trading sector, by giving them more power, and the government, by effective policymaking. “Every forum throws different numbers. Every sector, be it the mobile industry, retail trade, grain trade, etc, claims to have a large number of people associated with it. Sometimes, the overall number becomes more than the entire population of the country,” Goyal added.

Goyal clarified that his remarks were non-political. “You have taken permission from Election Commission for this conclave by stating that it is a non-political forum. So, I will say things within my maryada (dignity). I am not here as a politician seeking votes. The government wants to work on improving financing and digitisation,” he added.

While the Delhi assembly polls have seen a lot of debate over freebies, Goyal said he doesn’t believe in subsidies. “This government doesn’t give subsidies on one hand and cause injury on the other. We believe in structural reforms,” he added, while giving the example of the LED bulbs programme to support his argument.

“Before 2014, a government company used to purchase 6 lakh LED bulbs in a year. After subsidy, the bulb was sold for Rs 400-500. Subsidy was limiting the capacity. The subsidy and the problems highlighted by the industry were removed. Against the target of 70 crore bulbs, we sold more than 150 crore and the price came down to as low as Rs 38,” Goyal said.

CAIT general secretary Praveen Khandelwal said they have accepted the minister’s challenge and a database on traders will be created in six months.

Title: Explain poll remark: EC to BJP’s Thakur
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

New Delhi: The Election Commission on Tuesday asked Union minister of state for finance Anurag Thakur to respond to a complaint over the inflammatory slogan that he allegedly used at an election rally in northwest Delhi’s Rithala on Monday. He has been given time till noon on January 30 to explain his statement.

EC issued the notice to Thakur after the Delhi chief electoral officer submitted a report to the poll panel on the “provocative” language used by the minister. After lashing out at anti-Citizenship Amendment Act protesters the BJP MP had egged on the election rally crowd to raise an incendiary slogan — “shoot the traitors”.

In its notice to Thakur, EC said it prima facie found his slogan had the potential to “disturb communal harmony” and “aggravate the existing differences” between social and religious communities. Referring to sections 123 (3A) and 125 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, the EC said: “You have violated… the provisions of Model Code of Conduct and Representation of the People Act, 1951. The Commission gives you an opportunity to explain your position in making the above said statement on or before noon of 30 January, 2020 (Thursday), failing which the Commission shall take a decision without any further reference to you.”

EC also asked the Delhi CEO to furnish details on the controversial statements made by BJP’s West Delhi MP Parvesh Sahib Singh Verma regarding the protests at Shaheen Bagh.

Earlier on Tuesday, the Delhi CEO issued a press release saying that it had submitted reports to EC on “suspected” violation of Model Code of Conduct by BJP’s star campaigners Thakur and Verma. The office of the CEO took suo motu cognisance of the two men’s statements.

Aam Aadmi Party and Congress also complained to EC against the two BJP leaders. The former complained that Thakur’s speech was a “blatant violation of the model code of conduct” and sought an FIR against the central minister. Delhi Congress urged EC to ban Thakur and Verma for making “provocative statements to incite communal violence” in the campaign for the assembly elections.

Ajay Maken, senior Congress functionary, said, “BJP’s star campaigners Parvesh Verma and Anurag Thakur have used objectionable language. Top BJP leaders, including home minister Amit Shah, are making provocative statements in Delhi’s lanes and bylanes to polarise people and incite communal violence. The BJP is doing this out of frustration.”

Title: Congress will study TRS poll run success: Sangareddy MLA Jagga Reddy
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Sangareddy MLA T Jayaprakash Reddy

HYDERABAD: Sangareddy MLA T Jayaprakash Reddy on Sunday said he was unable to understand why people were voting for TRS in election after election despite the ruling party not fulfilling a substantial number of promises made by it.

“We need to study the reasons behind people voting in favour of TRS. One of the factors that worked in favour of TRS is its distribution of money and liquor, but this alone would not be enough to win over 100 urban local bodies,” the Congress MLA said.

Stating that the resolve of Congress gets strengthened with every election, he said the grand old party would work hard to come to power in the 2023 Assembly elections. “The Congress has given a tough contest to TRS in a large number of ULBs. TRS won with small margins in many municipalities,” he added.

Jayaprakash Reddy popularly known as Jagga Reddy, congratulated municipal minister KT Rama Rao for leading TRS to huge victory in the municipal polls and lauded finance minister T Harish Rao for winning both municipalities in Sangareddy, an Assembly constituency represented by him.

Title: Telangana: TRS conquers bastion it never won
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

HYDERABAD: Khammam, once the stronghold of CPI, CPM, Congress and TDP, has gone to the TRS this time. Firming up its hold over entire Telangana , the ruling party has won all the five municipalities in Khammam and Bhadradri-Kothagudem districts.

While BJP has no representation in the five urban local bodies of the two districts, the TRS has decimated the Congress, TDP and Left in Khammam. In 2014 municipal polls, TRS could barely manage to win only 4 wards in urban local bodies of Khammam and Bhadradri-Kothagudem, but, this year, it won 94 wards in all in the five municipalities.

In Kothagudem municipality of Bhadradri-Kothagudem distict, TRS won 25 of the total 36 wards, followed by CPI (8 wards), two independents and a single ward won by Congress. In 2014 municipal polls, TRS had managed to win just one ward in Kothagudem municipality with Congress leading with 12 wards, followed by CPI 8 wards, TDP 4, YSRCP 1 and independents 6. This year, TDP has failed to win a single ward in Kothagudem.

The TRS also swept the polls in Yellandu municipality by winning 19 of the total 24 wards. The Congress failed to win a single ward, while CPI managed to win one and independents 4 seats. In 2014 polls, TRS had won just 3 wards in Yellandu with Congress 8 and CPI 3, among others.

In Khammam district , TRS made a clean sweep by winning all the 23 wards in Sathupalli municipality, including an independent supported by the party. In 2014 polls, TRS had failed to open its account in Sathupalli.

The victory margins have been huge for TRS in the remaining two municipalities of Khammam district. TRS candidates romped home in Madhira ULB, which falls under Madhira assembly constituency represented by Congress leader Mallu Bhatti Vikramarka. In 2014, TRS had failed to win even a single ward in Madhira. In Wyra too, TRS won 15 out of the total 20 wards. The CPM managed to win one ward each in Madhira and Wyra.

Title: Madurai: Boy loses arm as school bus topples
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

A hospital source said the boy who lost his arm suffered a lot of blood loss and was critical

MADURAI: A boy’s arm had to be amputated while 18 other students and the driver escaped with minor injuries after a school bus skidded off the road and fell into the bushes at Poonjuthi village in Melur on Monday. Police blamed the driver’s negligence for the accident.

According to them, the school bus belonging to a private school in Sivaganga district was picking up students including those from Poonjuthi village in the morning. The accident occurred when the bus driver bent to pick up a fallen packet of curd and tried to throw it out. He lost control of the vehicle in the process leading to the accident.

Veerapandi R, a Class III student, lost his left arm in the accident while the others sustained minor injuries. The students were being treated at the closest government hospital and private hospitals in Melur and Madurai city. Hospital authorities said Veerapandi’s condition is critical. “We had to amputate his left arm. The boy also suffered a lot of blood loss. He has to be monitored closely for the next 24 hours,” they said.

Melur police registered a case against the driver under sections 279, 337 and 338 of IPC dealing with rash driving and endangering lives of others. Probe is on and the accused is yet to be arrested. “There was no other factor involved. The accident could have been avoided had the driver been careful and stopped the bus before trying to pick up the curd packet and disposing it,” police added.

Title: Two-finger test for rape survivors unconstitutional: Gujarat high court
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Gujarat high court

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat high court has held that the two-finger test to check the virginity of rape victims is unconstitutional. It directed the trial courts and doctors to bear this in mind because “it violates the right of the victim of sexual assault to privacy, physical and mental integrity and dignity”.

The HC observed so on the aspect of consent by rape survivor in a “unique appeal” filed by the state government. The HC convicted one Rameshchandra Panchal from Kadi town for rape nearly 25 years after he was exonerated by a trial court “by mistake” in 1995. The victim was a minor, but the court by mistake counted that she was above 16 and recorded Panchal’s acquittal on the basis that the sexual relations between Panchal and the victim were with her consent. Panchal, however, was punished with a seven-year jail term for abduction of the girl under sections 363 and 366 of IPC.

However, after recording the acquittal, the sessions court at Mirzapur rural court campus realized that the victim was below 16 years, and a minor, and her consent was immaterial and the offence amounted to statutory rape. Since the trial court had recorded its verdict, it could not review its own order. The HC corrected the mistake 25 years later in response to an appeal filed by the state government. The HC declared Panchal guilty of rape and ordered him taken into custody. The court has summoned him on December 31, when it is likely to sentence him for rape.

The ‘two-finger test’ also known as the PV (Per Vaginal) refers to an intrusive physical examination of a woman’s vagina to figure out the laxity of vaginal muscles and whether the hymen is distensible or not.

Calling upon courts and doctors to do away with the “archaic and outdated” practice, the bench of Justice J B Pardiwala and Justice B D Karia cited various orders by the Supreme Court and recommendations by the International Covenant on Economic Social and Cultural Rights 1966, a UN declaration in 1985 and planning commission’s orders and recommendations to this effect that medical procedures should not be carried out in a manner that constitutes cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment for victims of gender-based violence.
