The HC said that the Indian Evidence Act does not permit character assassination of a witness and two-finger test is also “one of the most unscientific methods of examination used in the context of sexual assault and has not forensic value”.

The court further said that since the apex court is considering the issue of ‘two-finger test’, “Our endeavour is to remind the trial courts as well as the medical fraternity that the ‘two-finger test’ is unconstitutional, as it violates the right of the victim of sexual assault to privacy, physical and mental integrity and dignity. If the trial court comes across any such medical certificate, wherein, there is a reference of such test, then it should take cognizance of the same and do the needful in the matter.”

Title: Bareilly: Two arrested with 15kg opium; third incident reported this month
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Besides opium, police also seized three mobile phones and seven ATM cards from their possession and impounded ... Read More

BAREILLY: Two drug peddlers were arrested with 15kg opium worth several lakhs of rupee in the international market on Monday, said police.

This is the third incident of drug peddling reported this month in Bareilly . Earlier, police had arrested three drug peddlers and seized 4.9kg opium from their possession.

Police said after receiving a tip-off that a white car coming from Alampur Gajraula will be carrying opium stashed in two sacks, a police team erected a barricade on the road in Bithri Chainpur area and started checking suspected vehicles.

“We have been waiting for the white car at the barricade, but when the accused saw police, they tried to escape, but we waylaid the car. When asked to come out of their vehicle, the accused again tried to flee the spot, but police thwarted their attempt,” said police.

The accused identified themselves as Tahir and Rashid, both native of Urala village under Bithri Chainpur police station, said police.

Station house officer of Bithri Chainpur police station Ashok Kumar Singh said, “During interrogation, the accused told police that they are mainly gamblers, but peddle drugs only when they need some extra money. We seized 15kg opium from their possession, which would be to the tunes of several lakhs of rupees. We are, however, yet to ascertain its actual price in the international market.”

Apart from opium, said the SHO, police also seized three mobile phones and seven ATM cards from their possession and impounded the car. An FIR was registered and the accused were sent to jail, said the SHO.

According to data available with police, 141 drug peddlers were booked under the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (NDPS) Act in Bareilly in 2017. The number, however, increased to 237 in 2018 and 252 in 2019.

On January 3, the Special Task Force (STF) arrested two inter-state drug peddlers in Bareilly and seized 4kg opium worth Rs 40 lakh from their possession. According to STF officials, the accused had come to Bareilly with a consignment of opium from Jharkhand. The accused had tied opium around their legs and were travelling in air-conditioned coaches of a train to dodge police. They had bought opium in Jharkhand at a price of Rs 60,000 and were supplying in Bareilly for Rs 1 lakh.

Similarly, a drug peddler was arrested in Quila area on January 2 with 900gm opium worth Rs 6 lakh.

Title: Maharashtra: Order on verification of seized e-data on February 3
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Special UAPA judge S R Navander on Monday posted for February 3 an order on a joint application of the nine arrested accused in the Elgar Parishad case raising doubts over the veracity of cloned copies of the seized e-data provided to them by the state.The copies are crucial for the accused to prepare their defence in the case that largely rests on the e-data seized by the police. The case is at the stage of framing of charges.The accused have questioned if the hash values of the copies provided to them were matching with that of the original data at the time of seizure of their electronic devices. They insisted that there was no clarity yet either from the police, the prosecution or the Forensic Science Laboratory (FSL) over how the hash values were matched.The Pune police’s investigating officer, ACP Shivaji Pawar, told the court that the cloned copies given to the accused had been prepared by the FSL experts from the seized original hard disks just like the copies were provided to the police for investigation. He said the original hard disks continue to be with the FSL authorities. Pawar said the hash values of original hard disks had been mentioned in the chargesheets.Pawar sought to clarify the argument by the accused that the police had claimed in their earlier remand reports of having retrieved 25 terabyte (1 TB = 1,000 gegabyte) of data from seized e-devices, but the actual data given to them was far less. He told the court that the earlier reports made only an “estimate” and never claimed an actual figure as the data analysis was then in progress before the FSL. He insisted that all copies provided to the accused had been made by the FSL from the original hard disks.Special prosecutor Ujjwala Pawar explained the procedure followed by the police before the copies were given to the accused. She submitted that the entire search and seizure operations on the premises of the accused were videographed and panchanamas of seizures was drawn. The seized e-devices were immediately sent to the FSL, which made their cloned copies from the originals and gave the copies to the police for investigation. The investigating officer then sent a detailed questionnaire to the FSL seeking information on when the files were created, who were the owners of these files and the date and time of last access, among other details, she submitted.

Title: Congress will walk out of Maharashtra government if statute, CMP violated: Ashok Chavan
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Ashok Chavan, former Maharashtra chief minister (File photo)

MUMBAI: Ashok Chavan , former Maharashtra chief minister and at present the public works minister, has said that Congress will walk out of the newly-minted Maha Vikas Aghadi government if the Constitution and Common Minimum Programme (CMP) are violated.

He made these remarks at a Congress workers’ rally on Sunday as part of Republic Day celebrations. “I made it clear to our workers and prominent citizens who were present that the new government will adhere to the Constitution and CMP. If there is any deviation, Congress will withdraw,” Chavan told TOI.

The comments come days after CM Uddhav Thackeray re-emphasised the Shiv Sena’s “saffron colour” and Sena mouthpiece Saamna wrote that “illegal Pakistani and Bangladeshi Muslims should be thrown out”. Chavan added that when the Agahdi was being formed, Congress members had had a meeting with party president Sonia Gandhi. “Sonia Gandhi agreed to join the Shiv Sena-led government only on the condition that all constituents of the Maha Vikas Aghadi would adhere to the Constitution and CMP. We had then assured her that if there is deviation, Congress will pull out of the government,”he said.

Title: Onion prices crash by 35% at Lasalgaon
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nashik: The average wholesale price of onions dropped by 35% to Rs 2,300 per quintal due to an increase in the supply of kharif variety at the Lasalgaon APMC on Monday.

The average price was recorded at Rs 3,500 per quintal at the AMPC, the country’s largest wholesale onion market, on Friday.

An APMC official said the Lasalgaon market has been witnessing price fluctuation for the last two months. “Only a week ago, the average wholesale price had shot up by Rs 950 per quintal to Rs 4,400 per quintal. The price trend, however, reversed last week and the wholesale price has crashed to Rs 2,300 now.”

The average wholesale onion price had recorded an all-time high of Rs 8,625 per quintal at Lasalgaon on December 16 last year. However, it dropped to Rs 4,500 per quintal in the next 15 days.

“Markets are witnessing an increase in supply of fresh produce. Hence, the price trend in wholesale markets will be downward,” the APMC official said.

In the retail market, good quality onions are being sold in the price range between Rs 40 and Rs 50 per kg. But the crash in in average wholesale price is likely to reflect in retail markets in a couple of days and the price is expected to come down to around Rs 30-35 per kg.

Around 20,000 quintal of onions was auctioned at Lasalgaon on Monday, and the minimum and maximum prices were recorded at Rs 1,000 and Rs 2,751 per quintal.

“Usually, the arrival of fresh kharif onions begins by mid-October, but unseasonal rainfall badly affected the kharif crop across Maharashtra. Around 75% of the onion plantation was damaged due to the rain, leading to scarcity and price rise,” the official said.

“However, at around 45,000 hectare, the acreage of late kharif onions has increased in the district. The harvest of late kharif crop has increased in the past three weeks, leading to drop in prices,” added the official.

Title: Dara case: Court quashes FIR order against Rathore, others
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Jaipur: The district and session court on Monday quashed the order of lodging FIR against BJP leader Rajendra Rathore and others including the police officers in connection to the Dara Singh encounter case.

The court sets aside previous order of metropolitan magistrate court which had ordered to lodge an FIR against Rathore and others .

Metropolitan Magistrate no 17 had ordered an FIR at Bani Park police station on January 7 after a legal complaint through Istegasa was filed by Dara Singh's son Amit Kumar Beniwal. The complaint named BJP leader Rajendra Rathore, Jat Samaj leader Rajaram Meal, Sher Singh Poonia and accused police officers. Some lawyers and Sushila Devi, the wife of Dara Singh were also been implicated for turning hostile.

On the other hand, advocate Roshan Singh, one of the accused in the case, filed a re-inspection petition, saying that the complainant Amit Kumar had cheated the court by concealing important information

Accepting the revision filed by Singh the district and session judge held that the lower court did not examine the complaint properly and ordered to lodge an FIR. “The complainant cleverly concealed name of district judges in the heading of the complaint, but levelled allegations against them in the body of the complaint copy,” said Ajay Kumar Jain, counsel for the petitioner in the court.

Advocate AK Jain argued that the complaint was filed with oblique motive to extort money.

Title: Government Rajaji Hospital is fire-safe, old structures to be demolished soon: Dean
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) dean Dr Sangumani J said that the hospital is well-equipped to prevent and handle fire accidents. The dean was speaking in the wake of Saturday’s fire accident at Kanyakumari Medical College Hospital , where an old building used for storing scrap and packing material was gutted.

“Fire safety measures are in place in both old and new buildings at GRH. The fire department has also been continuing to hold periodical checks to see if all the buildings are well-equipped to prevent and handle fire accidents.

“All employees are also being given awareness and training programs in fire safety by the fire department,” Dr Sangumani told TOI. Notably, a minor fire broke out last year in September at the plastic surgery department in GRH reportedly due to a live beedi left behind by someone.

Hospital sources said that several of the old structures at GRH are not being maintained properly as many of them are leaking and developed cracks. However, there is no specific threat that could result in a fire.

“Though maintenance has been poor, electric circuit boards and wiring, which is capable of causing fire, have all been replaced. Previously, we had aluminium wiring but now they have all been replaced with copper wiring,” said a hospital staff. Dr Sangumani further said that the few old structures at GRH, which have been left unused, are also going to be demolished soon. “Around 5% of the old structures are currently not in use but soon, they will all be demolished for the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) project, which plans to set up a seven-storey building on the GRH main campus near Goripalayam junction,” he said.

One of the concerns raised by some of the patients’ attenders and hospital staff was the dumping of garbage in the bins near the mortuary. “A huge amount of waste, including plastic, paper, dust and dead plants are being dumped inside and outside the bins kept there. A live match stick or a cigarette or beedi can set off fire,” said a staff.

Title: Ahmedabad passport office to send reminders for renewal
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The regional passport office, Ahmedabad, following direction from the ministry of external affairs has commenced a new service to reach out to people whose passports are on the verge of expiry. The RPO has decided to send SMSs on their registered mobile numbers and send them emails to remind them of renewal dates.

Passport officials said that a majority of countries insist on a minimum of six months validity of passport for travel. If passports are not renewed in due time, passengers may not be able to travel.

Under the new service, the RPO will send two SMSs. The first SMS and email will be sent nine months before and the second, seven months before the expiry date. The message will contain the passport number and the date of expiry and will also have a link for online renewal.

Title: Gujarat: Cops asleep, victim’s husband steps up
Content:
Nizamuddin Ansari and Salmabano

AHMEDABAD: A vegetable vendor from Ganeshnagar saw his wife die of the burns she had suffered after falling on a heap of hot sand a year and a half ago. He rounds of several government offices to learn more about her mysterious death. As he did not get justice, he turned crusader and began helping victims who suffered burns in similar circumstances. Nizamuddin Ansari , 52, who travels 30km a day selling vegetables to make a living, said that he now monitors the Ganeshnagar area to know if anyone is dumping chemical waste there.“Some four months ago, two girls, 9 and 10, suffered burns when they went to defecate in an open area. Their parents were so scared by the incident that they had left and returned to their native place in Uttar Pradesh,” said Ansari who also helped Parvati Sarkar , 35, a resident of Ganeshnagar, who suffered similar burns on Monday morning, get medical help.Ansari’s wife, Salmabano , died on July 17, 2018, after she fell on a the mysterious heap of sand while riding pillion with Ansari on June 22, 2018. They were on their way to Narol when he had lost control of his scooter while trying to avoid colliding with a truck.She fell on to the heap of sand. Moments later, she started screaming in pain. When Ansari stepped on the heap to pull her out, he felt as if his legs were on fire. Salmabano suffered 57% burns and her husband, 15%.“It took me five months to walk. Even though I had the cops several times to know about my wife’s case, nothing has happened,” said Ansari.DCP Zone VII Bipin Ahire said Narol police had registered an application of complaint. “The FSL had also taken samples of the sand. At that time (Salmabano’s case), no one had paid much attention to it. Now police will try to get CCTV footage and if any negligence is found, a complaint for negligence will be filed,” said Ahire. Gujarat Pollution Control Board (GPCB) member secretary N M Tabhani told TOI, “We have sent a team to investigate the site (Ganeshnagar) for dumping.”

Title: Battle down south: Old guards, new allegiances & a fresh face
Content:
Narayan Dutt Sharma is the sitting MLA from Badarpur

NEW DELHI: Badarpur, the largest assembly constituency in south Delhi in terms of the number of voters, has seen many a twist and turn ever since the parties started declaring their candidates.While AAP was the first to announce its candidate, the decision to replace sitting MLA Narayan Dutt Sharma (47) with Ram Singh Netaji (64), who had only recently switched over from Congress, didn’t go down well with the former. Netaji has previously won the seat twice, first as an independent in 2003 and, then, as a Bahujan Samaj Party candidate in 2008. In 2013 and 2015, he contested on a Congress ticket, but lost on both occasions.Snubbed, Sharma went on an all-out attack, claiming that AAP had sold the ticket to Netaji. A few days later, he joined BSP and was promptly given a ticket.BJP, on the other hand, has kept its faith in veteran Ramvir Singh Bidhuri (66), who has won the seat thrice — once each as a Janata Dal (1993-1998), Congress (2003-2008) and BJP (2013-2014) member.Amid this game of musical chairs, Congress has gone for a fresh face in the form of Pramod Kumar Yadav (46). Yadav dismissed the idea that this could prove to be a disadvantage. “I am a local and, so, understand the issues well. Neither AAP nor BJP have done any work here. I know the needs of the schools and colleges here and I will work towards them,” he said.Bidhuri alleged that development had come to a standstill in the five years under AAP. He said: “The DTC buses I had started were stopped and so was Ganga water supply (referring to the water drawn from Sonia Vihar). They haven’t been able to lay sewer lines. Where are the new schools and colleges they are talking about?”Bidhuri claimed that if BJP won the election, together with the party’s government at the Centre, it could build new schools, colleges and hospitals. “The area is heavily populated and needs schools and colleges. The land here comes under the Centre’s purview. So, it’s clear that if the same party is in office at both state and Centre, it will be good for development.” Like in the rest of the city, BJP is betting big on Citizenship Amendment Act here too. “Our stand on CAA is clear. We are explaining to the people that it (CAA) has nothing to do with Indian Muslims.”Netaji, on the other hand, believes that all issues will pale in significance in front of the “Kejriwal wave”. He said: “AAP government has worked really hard. People are only going to vote for development. I have been working as a politician for 25 years.”Residents, however, aren’t so keen on passing a clear verdict already. Ram Kumar, who irons clothes for a living at Molarbandh village, said: “It’s clear that the MLA (Sharma) didn’t work and that’s why he didn’t get a ticket again. I’ve been running from pillar to post for over a year for senior citizen’s pension, but to no avail.” He was, however, quick to add that “Netaji is here this time and he’s very good”.Vimal Kumar, who owns a grocery shop at Badarpur, said in a similar vein: “Anyone can walk up to Netaji’s house. He is always ready to help people out.” Manoj Bindal, a resident of Molarbandh village, differs: “Bidhuriji is a little arrogant, but he has done a lot of work. No development has taken place here in the last five years. Whenever it rains, dirty sewer water enters our houses.”

Title: ‘Over 3,000 CCTV cams will be installed through CSR project’
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Smart City Development Corporation (NMSCDCL) on Monday said the city requires 4,000 closed-circuit television (CCTV) cameras and 800 of them are to be installed under the smart city project by May this year.

The remaining 3,200 CCTV cameras will be installed through private companies under the Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) funds and also through funds from MPs and MLAs.

The project of CCTV cameras, Wi-Fi and Information Communication Technology (ICT) is being implemented by the Maharashtra Information Technology Corporation (MahaIT) at a total cost of Rs 169 crore. Of this total amount the contribution of NMSCDCL is Rs 45.43 crore.

The MahaIT will install 800 CCTV cameras under the project. Moreover, the command and control room is also being set up by the MahaIT for monitoring different projects.

“The requirement of CCTV cameras for entire Nashik city is over 4,000 cameras, but it is not possible to cover the entire city under this project. Only 800 CCTV cameras are to be installed under the smart city project, but we have chalked out a business model to install the remaining CCTV cameras in the city,” NMSCDCL chairman Sitaram Kunte said.

“We have plans to install other remaining cameras through private companies under the CSR. Moreover, funds from MLAs, MPs along with District Planning Development funds can also be used,” Kunte said.

The NMSCDCL chief also said that they will provide the technical specification of the cameras and locations to install the CCTV cameras.

“Earlier, MahaIT had sought the NMSCDCL to release its contribution of Rs 45.43 crore in one go, but we had decided to release the funds as per the progress of the work. We have given approval to release all the funds in order to give momentum to the project work,” Kunte said.

Title: Medaram Jathra: CM K Chandrasekhar Rao wants plan for crowd management
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

CM K Chandrashekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao instructed officials to make all necessary arrangements for devotees visiting Medaram Jathra .

“Lakhs of devotees visit Medaram Jathra. There should not be any negligence with regard to drinking water supply and sanitation. Plan a proper strategy for queue lines, smooth flow of traffic. Depute IAS and IPS officers who earlier worked in Warangal or those who have experience of organising jathra in the past. All departments should be on high alert,” he said.

He said two helicopters would be made available in Hyderabad for chief secretary, DGP and other senior officials to visit Medaram to review arrangements between February 5 and 9. Ministers and people’s representatives have given invitation for Medaram Jathra to be held next month to CM on Sunday.

In a separate meeting, the CM instructed officials to increase number of Basti Dawakhanas, which were catering to the health needs of the poor, to 350. He said that 118 Basti Dawakhans in the city have been functioning well and people were happy with the services rendered by them.

Title: Three Class VI students held for thrashing classmate to death over ‘buying a guava’
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Bareilly: A 15-year-old school boy was allegedly thrashed to death by his classmates over a petty issue at a government upper primary school in Amirnagar village of Lakhimpur Kheri district on Monday. The deceased, identified as Farmaan Qureshi, was a student of Class VI. He had a quarrel with his three friends over purchasing a guava after school hours on Saturday.

Basic Shiksha Adhikari’s (BSA) Budhpriya Singh, when contacted, told TOI, “Police have taken appropriate steps in this case while we have called a probe to ascertain whether any negligence was shown on the part of any school teacher.”

On Monday morning, after the weekend, when Farmaan reached school along with his cousin Tauheed, all three of them thrashed him mercilessly which reportedly led to his death. Police have sent the boy’s body for autopsy. All the three boys of same age group were detained by school staff and handed over to police.

An FIR has been registered against under IPC section 302 (murder) against all three of them on the complaint of Farmaan’s father. However, police later claimed that Farmaan was thrashed by only one of the accused.

After getting the information about the shocking incident, SSP Poonam along with DM Shailendra Singh also rushed to the village and spoke with the aggrieved family. They had a word with the main accused who had allegedly punched and kicked Farmaan. The accused claimed that he never intended to kill Farmaan and only punched him in his stomach.

Farmaan’s father Saimur said, “My nephew Tauheed, who studies in the same school, told me that Farmaan was thrashed by three schoolchildren in the presence of a school teacher. The accused sat on his chest and repeatedly thrashed him to death.”

BSA’s Budhpriya Singh also said, “The incident occurred around 9.30am when the schoolchildren had started arriving and most teachers were yet to arrive. The school starts at 10am. It was indeed an unfortunate incident as one of the children died during a quarrel in the school in Mohammadi block.”

SHO Mohammadi police station Sanjay Tyagi told TOI, “We have registered an FIR against three school children as per the complaint lodged with us but initial investigation suggests that the deceased had a quarrel with only one of them. We have recorded the statement of schoolchildren who witnessed the fight between both the boys and it seems like it was an accidental death. We are waiting for autopsy report to ascertain the main cause of death. The accused will be sent to juvenile home.”

Title: Pune: Polytechnic student found dead in Mutha valley, police claim suicide
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A 19-year-old polytechnic student was found dead in the Mutha ghat section of Pirangut-Lavasa Road, about 25km from the city, on Saturday. The police said it was a case of suicide.

His father (49) had lodged a missing person’s complaint with the Airport police station on January 20. “The boy had sent a text message to his father on his cellphone before ending his life. The message read ‘Sorry Dad. Because of me you were troubled’,” inspector Ashok Dhumal of the Paud police said.

He said the student’s body was found partially burned, while his motorcycle was gutted completely. “The grass at the area where his body was found was burnt too. After reviewing the spot, we think that the student rode his motorcycle at high speed in the Mutha ghat section and drove it over the railings of the road before plunging into the valley,” Dhumal said, adding, “He was the only child of his parents.”

He said after falling into the valley, the student might have lost his consciousness and his motorcycle might have caught fire.

According to the Airport police, the student was pursuing his studies at a private polytechnic college in Wagholi. “On January 20, he attended his morning classes. He informed his classmates that he was going to Regional Transport Office (RTO) in Pune for some work and left the college around 12.30pm,” the police said.

The student used to return home by late afternoon usually. When he did not return home till evening on January 20, his family members started searching for him, but to no avail. They then filed a missing person’s complaint with the Lonikand police before approaching the Airport police.

“The Pune city police tracked down his location on January 25 after he sent a text message to his father. They then informed us about his location, following which our team reached the spot,” Dhumal said.

“We will conduct an inquiry later on to ascertain the reason behind the suicide. For now, we have registered a case of accidental death in this regard,” he said.

Title: Congress leader threatens fast unto death over statue
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

AICC secretary V Hanumantha Rao

HYDERABAD: All India Congress Committee (AICC) secretary V Hanumantha Rao on Sunday said he would take up fast-unto-death if TRS government fails to re-install Ambedkar statue at Punjagutta before February 5.

“I will sacrifice my life for the cause of re-installation of Ambedkar statue. The TRS government has no respect for Ambedkar. They removed the statue and shifted it to a police station,” Rao said after unfurling the national flag at Gandhi Bhavan on the occasion of Republic Day.

Stating that he would also submit a representation to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Union home minister Amit Shah seeking their intervention into the matter, Rao said he had spent lakhs of rupees to get the statue sculpted.

Title: Jaipur divided into 11 zones
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Jaipur: The newly created municipal corporations in Jaipur have further been divided into 11 zones in total. As per the notification issued on Saturday, in Jaipur Municipal Corporation (Heritage) there will be four zones and in Jaipur Municipal Corporation (Greater) there are going to be seven zones.

Earlier, Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC) was divided into eight zones. The division made in both the zones have been done on the basis of the legislative assembly area.

In both JMC Greater and Heritage, there are five legislative assemblies which have been further divided. The decision to divide the zones of the municipal corporation on the basis of legislative assemblies was taken in the fifth board meeting of the JMC earlier. The proposal was passed in the board meeting and sent to the government for approval.

Meanwhile, JMC got divided into two parts before the approval from the government albeit the division of zones was done on the basis of legislative assembly areas.

With the division of JMC officials will now be given a choice to opt between the two JMC very soon. A senior JMC officer who does not wish to be named told TOI that they have sent the proposal to the government for approval.

“We have sent the proposal to the government and just waiting for their approval. The government may introduce some amendments as well. We need more staff for both the corporations and further transfer will be needed,” said the official.

One of the revenue officers of JMC said that most of the shops in JMC (Heritage) are smaller than 100 yards outside the purview of the taxable properties.

Title: PMPML official equates old, rickety bus with ageing parent
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

The PMPML has in the past two years scrapped 300 old buses. RTO guidelines state that a bus has to be scrapped... Read More

PUNE: A PMPML official ’s justification of not to scrap a worn-out bus in its fleet by equating it with an ageing parent has left a transport activist flummoxed.

Transport activist Sanjay Shitole had in a WhatsApp message drawn the Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited ’s (PMPML) attention towards an old, rickety bus carrying passengers from Shivajinagar to Aundh.

The answer from the PMPML, Shitole said, was: “The PMPML has a minimum life expectancy of between 12 and 15 years for around 40% of the buses. It is because of this reason that the body of the bus is in a bad condition. Considering the less manpower, we are doing our best. How can you call a bus, which has plied for close to 18 hours for more than 12 years, a ‘bhangar’ (scrap)? Do you call parents and relatives, who have completed 70 years and have taken care of us, as scrap?”

Shitole said, “I was travelling in a can on Friday morning when I saw the bus. It was very old and in a bad condition. I thought that plying such buses was risky for passengers. I sent the PMPML a WhatsApp message on its complaint number...I was expecting a professional answer, but got something else.”

The transport activist said after he got the PMPML’s reply on Saturday, he forwarded it to the transport utility’s chief engineer.

PMPML joint managing director Ajay Charthankar told TOI, “The reply to Shitole’s message was not professional”. “I will have to check this and also see which official had sent the message and why.”

The PMPML has in the past two years scrapped 300 old buses. According to the Regional Transport Office’s guidelines, a bus has to be scrapped once it has completed 7 lakh km of running and/or has been in service for 10 years.

Title: Pune: It’s only January, but the air around feels like June
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

PUNE: Day temperatures in Pune have touched the season's highest with Shivajinagar recording a high June-like temperature on Sunday at 32.8 degrees celsius and 33 degrees celsius in Lohegaon, making it the warmest Republic Day in the last three years.

Humidity levels were high in all the three locations in Pune at Shivajinagar, Lohegaon and Pashan on Sunday. Humidity levels touched 90% and more late in the night and morning hours with the city's real feel temperature seeming at least a degree or two higher than the actual day temperature.

Past Republic Day temperature records showed that January 26, 2017, 2018, 2019 had day and night temperatures much below what they were this Sunday.

Night temperatures on the Republic Day in the last few years were at a cold 8.3 degrees celsius and 9.9 degrees celsius in 2019 and 2018 respectively, while day temperatures then was at least 2-5 degrees lower than Sunday's maximum.

Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather, IMD Pune, told TOI that the current day temperatures are quite unusual because January is a winter month.

If only Republic Day temperature data for over a decade is considered, Republic Day this year was the second warmest since 2010. On January 26, 2016, the maximum temperature in Shivajinagar was only a decimal point higher (32.9 degrees celsius ) than Sunday’s 32.8 degrees celsius.

Sunday’s day temperature in Lohegaon was the warmest Republic Day for the location since 2010 as the maximum temperature had peaked to a warm 33 degrees celsius.

“There has been increased humidity lately, but it has not been enough to cause cloudy skies during the day, which is what happened on Sunday. While the clear skies ensured that maximum solar insolation reached Pune’s atmospheric surface, the high levels of humidity pushed up the city’s real feel temperature, giving the air a June-like feel. The high amount of humidity in the air is currently making day temperatures feel at least 1-2 degrees C more than what they actually are. This means that the city’s heat index has risen,” Kashyapi said.

Citizens have also been feeling the heat during noon time. “We were back to turning on the fan on Sunday and Monday for the first time this January,” city-based event manager Saurabh Arora said.

Title: More rain, snow in store for Himachal Pradesh, chill set to return
Content:
A view of the snow-covered area after fresh snowfall at Jakhu in Shimla on Tuesday (File photo)

SHIMLA: After witnessing dry weather conditions in the past few days, Himachal Pradesh is likely to receive rain and snow on Tuesday and Wednesday, which will intensify cold conditions in the state, the Shimla meteorological centre has predicted.Fresh snowfall is also going to hamper the snow-clearing exercise from roads in the snowbound areas. In the coming days, heavy rainfall and snowfall are likely to occur in Shimla, Kinnaur, Lahaul-Spiti and upper parts of Kullu, Mandi, Chamba and Sirmaur districts.Shimla meteorological centre, director, Manmohan Singh said a fresh feeble western disturbance is likely to affect Western Himalayan region from January 31. He said on account of arrival of fresh western disturbance, the state is likely to receive light to moderate rainfall and snowfall with effect from Monday and at most places on Tuesday.He said on Wednesday, precipitation is likely to decrease and will occur during day time. Weather is likely to be clear after Wednesday evening.In Himachal Pradesh, 204 roads, including four national highways and one state highway, are still lying closed after the previous snowfall. In the tribal districts of Lahaul-Spiti and Kinnaur districts, an operation to clear snow from roads has been hampered due to avalanches.Read the story in Bengali

Title: Gujarat: Two steal ornaments worth Rs 56 lakh from jewellery store
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Two men on Monday afternoon stole ornaments worth Rs 56 lakh from a jewellery shop in the Ramdevnagar area in Satellite after spraying some chemical which left the jeweller unconscious for about two hours.

In his FIR with Satellite police, Bhaumik Shah, 30, resident of Vasna, said that he has been running RS Jewellers for around seven years in the Ramdevnagar area.

On Monday morning, he went to his shop at around 10.30am and started work.

“At around 1.15pm on Monday, when he was about to take his lunch after locking the glass door of his shop, two men knocked on the door. I opened the door and they came inside,” states the FIR filed by Shah.

“Later, they asked for some rings for men. They saw some rings for a while and then told me to show gold chains. When I was showing them gold chains, suddenly I felt an unusual smell and then I fell unconscious,” adds the FIR.

At around 3pm on Monday, another jeweller Viral Akhiyania, who runs a store near Shah’s, came to meet Shah. He found Shah unconscous and tried to wake him up. After a while, Shah woke up and saw that the ornaments in the display counter were missing.

Shah states in the FIR that ornaments weighing 1.4 kg worth Rs 56 lakh were stolen from his shop.

Shah called up police control room and filed his complaint. Later, Satellite police registered a complaint under charges of causing hurt by means of poison, theft and abetment.

Police have begun recovering CCTV footage of the area to identify the accused person.

Title: Two sisters allege gangrape in UP’s Sambhal
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Bareilly: A family in Uttar Pradesh’s Sambhal has alleged that a few men “who came in khaki” barged into their house late on Saturday, took away their two daughters and gangraped them at a secluded spot.

In his complaint to police, the girls’ father has alleged that four men wearing khaki barged into their house to “enquire about some liquor smuggling”.

“After I denied any role in liquor smuggling, they started misbehaving and thrashed me. Later, they took us at gunpoint to some deserted location on the outskirts where they took turns to rape our two daughters,” he said.

One of the daughters told TOI, “My father was thrashed and we were later dragged by the men who took us to the vehicle parked outside. They took us to some deserted place and raped us by turns. They let us free after around two hours and fled the spot.”

Sambhal superintendent of police Yamuna Prasad said, “The family is unable to reveal the identities of the persons accused of the crime. The written complaint lodged by the family didn’t mention gangrape but a medical examination has been initiated and the report is awaited. An inquiry in the case is currently underway.”

Local police said that an FIR has been registered against unidentified men for ‘assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty’ under IPC’s section 354, among others. Investigation is on.

Title: ED attaches Rs 69 lakh FD of ex-fire officer in graft case
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Jaipur: The Enforcement Directorate (ED) on Monday attached moveable property in the form of fixed deposit (FD) amounting to Rs 69.13 lakh, including the interest, of Dinesh Kumar Verma, the then chief fire officer, Jaipur in a corruption case.

In an official release on Monday, the ED stated that investigation under Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA) was initiated on the basis of an FIR and chargesheet filed by Anti-Corruption Bureau, Jaipur. Verma, the then chief fire officer, Nagar Nigam, Bani Park and others for offence under Section 7,8,12,13(1)((d),13(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act, 1988 and Section 120B of Indian Penal Code for receiving bribe of Rs 1.50 lakh for allegedly issuing fire NOC to a hospital.

“The investigation conducted by ACB revealed that the accused had adopted modus operandi to demand and receive bribe money through middlemen for issuance of NOC only after receipt of bribe money. During search operation carried out by the ACB at his residence, unaccounted currency worth Rs 69.13 lakh, including more than Rs 41 lakh in newly introduced currency of Rs 2000 were found. Since demonetization was introduced, ACB with the orders of the trial court had deposited the seized money in a FDR in December, 2016,” said an officer of ED. Prior to this attachment, bribe money worth Rs 1.5 lakh had been attached under the PMLA, besides seizure of FDRs worth Rs 2.86 lakh and incriminating documents seized by the ED under Section 17 of the PMLA from the residence of Verma on April 6, 2017.

Title: Coronavirus scare: 436 under observation in Kerala
Content:
Representative image

'Hospitals equipped to handle emergency'

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The state, which has taken utmost care on Coronavirus surveillance , has been free from any threats so far. Of the seven blood samples that had been sent for testing to the National Virology Institute in Pune, two have tested negative for Coronavirus.As many as 436 people who have come from China to the state in the past few weeks are under the strict radar of the state health department. Of them, five people have been admitted to isolation wards of various hospitals in the state. The rest, though allowed to remain at their homes, are under the department’s observation.Meanwhile, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan has written to Prime Minister Narendra Modi , urging him to operate a special flight to bring back the Indians, including Keralites, who have been stranded in the virus-hit regions of China. The chief minister also assured of all help, including the services of the health experts from Kerala, if the people are evacuated from China and are brought back to India.The state has been put on high alert since hundreds of people are travelling to Kerala from the virus-hit regions. “On an average, 90 people are reaching the state per day from China. All the airports are under strict vigil and are screening all passengers. So far there is no threat for the state as none of the patients here has been found in the high-risk category,” said Dr Amar Fettle, state nodal officer on public health emergency.“At present five people are put in isolation wards in different hospitals of the state. The two patients who were admitted in Ernakulam have tested negative. The results of the five are expected in a day or two. Since they are having fever, they have been kept under constant monitoring by the health team,” he added.The health department has directed public to maintain personal hygiene in the wake of the spreading of virus globally. People should strictly maintain personal hygiene and keep their surroundings clean. Everyone must cover their nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing. Hands must be washed with soap and water frequently, said a bulletin issued by the state health department.The health department has also issued specific directive to tourism department to keep a close tab on the tourist destinations if the tourists from the virus-hit regions are arriving. “All hotels have been issued specific directive on the steps and precautions they have to take if they receive any tourist from these virus-hit regions,” said Dr Fettle.Health minister K K Shailaja said that there is nothing to panic about the coronavirus (Wuhan) outbreak and the hospitals in all districts in the state are equipped to handle any emergency.“We should join hands to identify the people coming from the virus-infected areas, and the information should be regularly passed to the health workers to strengthen the preventive measures,” Shailaja said.The minister also said that monitoring has be strengthened atall the airports. People arriving from abroad at Kannur and Kozhikode airports will be screened. Even in the cases in which the laboratory report is negative, the monitoring would be continued to make sure there is no spread of the disease. At the same time, it is for the central government to bring the Indians from the affected areas, said the minister.

Title: Tourists throng Solang to see snow, jam road
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

A view of the snow-covered area after fresh snowfall in Manali (File photo)

MANALI: With thousands of tourists trying to reach Solang valley to enjoy snow and snow-related activities, the traffic movement has almost come to a halt on the stretch between Solang and Kulang village. Hundreds of vehicles have been stranded as they are not able to go beyond Palchan village, where the road is partially covered with snow.

The tourist vehicles are slipping on the ice. Many tourists have parked their private cars on the highway, adding to the chaos on the highway.

Many tourists, who were unable to reach Solang, are enjoying snow near Kulang and Palchan villages. Many are reaching Solang after walking for 3km from Palchan and others are hiring four-wheel drive vehicles or all-terrain vehicles. Upset with jams and slippery condition of the road, tourists can be seen parking vehicle anywhere near the snow on Manali-Solang highway.

As authorities did not clear snow from the highway on time, it turned ice. The workers are now removing ice with help of iron bars. Not just tourists, but local residents of Palchan, Ruar, Solang and Kothi villages are also upset over traffic jams.

Amar Thakur, a local resident, said sometimes it is taking more than five hours to cover 10-km distance to Manali . “We feel helpless during medical or other emergency. The highway is narrow at several places and tourists make multiple lanes that choke traffic. We need big parking places at Palchan and Solang. A special plan to manage traffic is the need of the hour,” he said.

Solang valley is still covered with over 75cm of snow, which has otherwise proved to be boon for the hoteliers, local traders and taxi operators.

Title: Primary schoolteacher with fake degrees booked, expelled
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Bareilly: A primary schoolteacher posted in Fatehganj East was on Sunday booked for securing the teaching job based on alleged fake degrees.

After the matter came to light following an internal probe conducted by the basic education department, the teacher was expelled .

According to police, Deep Karan, a resident of Mathura district, was posted as a teacher at a primary school in Chatiya Chatanpur in Bareilly. He had joined the government school as an assistant teacher on March 18, 2016. However, an internal probe conducted by basic shiksha adhikari Tanuja Tripathi found Deep Karan’s two degrees — BSc and Bed — obtained from Bundelkhand University “fake”.

Officials also contacted the university, which “confirmed both degrees fake”.

Station house officer of Fatehganj East police station Ashwani Kumar said, “Based on a complaint lodged by basic education department officials, an FIR was registered against Deep Karan under sections 420 (cheating), 466 (forgery of record of court or of public register, etc), 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating) and 471 (using as genuine a forged document) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC). The education department has expelled him. The teacher is absconding and effort is on to nab him.”

Title: Paramour sets woman on fire after she returns to her husband
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Bareilly: A 30-year-old woman was set on fire by her beau, in a village in Subhash Nagar of Bareilly on Sunday evening, after she refused to live with him and returned to her husband.

Meenu Devi had eloped with Vinod Kumar in February 2019, leaving her two children with her husband Chandra Pal. On January 23, she returned to Chandra Pal, claiming Vinod used to regularly beat her and that she was missing her children. On Sunday evening, when Chandra was out on work, Vinod barged into their house, poured petrol on her and set her on fire. She was admitted to district hospital by her mother-in-law Parwati Devi with the help of police, where her condition is reportedly critical. Doctors have advised Chandra Pal to take her to a higher facility, as her condition is deteriorating rapidly. Police have filed an FIR against Vinod and are searching for him.

According to sources, Meenu was living with Vinod in a rented house in Rampur, where she even gave birth to a daughter. Vinod often used to return home drunk and thrash her mercilessly, which is why she left him and her newborn daughter in Rampur and returned to live with Chandra Pal, who happily agreed to let her back after she apologised for her mistake.

When Vinod realised Meenu was back with Chandra Pal, he was filled with vengeance. Chandra Pal told TOI, “Vinod was my friend and used to often come to our house. Last year, he gave something to my wife to eat, after which she started following his command and eloped with him. She returned home after her illusion broke and she saw Vinod’s real face. I forgave her for the sake of my children, but Vinod attempted to kill her and my children when I was out on work. My family is being threatened by Vinod, so I’ve requested police to arrest him ASAP.”

Subhash Nagar SHO Harishchandra Joshi told TOI, “We’ve filed an FIR against Vinod and are searching for him. The victim is admitted at district hospital and doctors are trying to save her life.”

Title: HC restrains Punjab from taking coercive action against Bharti Singh
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Bharti Singh

Chandigarh: Punjab and Haryana high court on Monday restrained the Punjab government from taking any coercive action against popular television comedian Bharti Singh in a case related to hurting religious sentiments. The HC has also issued notice to the state government and the complainant in the case, asking them to file their replies on the petition filed by Bharti.

The case would now come up for hearing on March 25 along with the previous petitions filed on the same issue by director-choreographer Farah Khan and Bollywood actor Raveena Tandon.

On December 25, 2019, Bharti, Farah and Raveena were booked by Ajnala police under Section 295-A of the IPC for deliberate and malicious acts intended to outrage religious feelings of any class by insulting its religion or religious beliefs. They had allegedly made some comments about ‘Bible’. The FIR was registered on the complaint filed by Sona Masih alias Sonu Jaffar. The allegations against Bharti are that in a web-show, she made a joke of the word ‘Hallelujah’.

In her plea against the FIR, Bharti has submitted that she was one of the guests of the show. Counsel appearing for Bharti, advocate Abhinav Sood submitted that even if the issues/discrepancies pointed out by the complainant are taken on the face of it, there was nothing to perceive that it was intended to hurt the religious sentiments of the Christian community or remotely qualify to constitute an offence under section 295-A of the IPC.

“Just because the petitioner being the participant guest in the show was trying to spell the word "Hallelujah" and further because of the profession of the petitioner being stand-up comedian the words uttered by the petitioner unintentionally are now being used to arraign her,” counsel told the HC.

It was also submitted that the show was not being telecast for discussing anything about Christian or Christianity, but it was a show for entertaining people.

In her plea before the HC, Bharti Singh has sought directions to quash the FIR number 200 dated December 25, 2019 registered at police station Ajnala, district Amritsar rural and not to take any action against her till the matter is pending before the HC.

Title: Gujarat: When artisans read seasonal colour forecast!
Content:
Prakash Vegda, a quilt (dhabla) weaver from Balej, 40km from Veraval in Gir Somnath district, had not heard ab... Read More

AHMEDABAD: Prakash Vegda, a quilt (dhabla) weaver from Balej, 40km from Veraval in Gir Somnath district , had not heard about colours such as Sugar Almond, Dark Cheddar, Bluestone or Eden before he came to National Institute of Fashion Technology (NIFT) at Gandhinagar earlier this month.“We work predominantly with brown or white with primary colours such as red, blue and green with geometric patterns. For us, weaving with seven to eight different colours was challenging at first — but was exciting as well. We had never done something like that,” said Vegda.He was among the 25 artisans picked by INDEXT-C from six clusters of Gujarat to revamp their weaving and boost their sales and visibility both in and outside Gujarat. The participants included patola weavers from Rajkot and Surendranagar, khadi weavers from Amreli and quilt weavers from Porbandar and Gir Somnath among others.Shubhangi Yadav, associate professor at NIFT and coordinator for the project, said that the primary objective of the training programme was to help the artisans think out of the box.“Artisans often work with the same materials and same designs over the years. While on one hand it makes the designs unique, on the other it does not motivate customers to buy more than one piece in their lifetime,” she said. “Thus, we worked with the artisans closely to introduce them to a new colour palette, new fabric and new design while retaining the soul of their art,” she said.Ketan Makwana was among the single-ikat patola (Rajkot patola) artisans in the training.“One cannot imagine patola out of traditional colours, but this workshop has introduced us not only to new colours while retaining the weaving style but also taught us how to photograph the final product using mobile phones and introduced us to online platforms for artisan products to improve our international reach,” he said.Sunita Agarwal, assistant professor at NIFT, said that the move could give a new lease of life to artisans. “We often get demands to organize workshops on techniques such as jacquard, which they believe have more demand in the market. We thus showed them ways in which they can also weave stories around their craft,” she said.

Title: Pune: Mercury may dip to 10 degree Celsius on Wednesday
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Day and night temperatures in the city continue to climb, but a gradual dip is likely from Wednesday. (File ph... Read More

PUNE: The day and night temperatures in the city continue to climb, but a gradual dip is likely from Wednesday, India Meteorological Department (IMD) officials told TOI on Monday. The dip will be significant but short-lived, officials said, when night temperature could reach around 10-12 degrees C in the city.

Night temperatures have been high in the last few days ranging from 14-15 degree Celsius. It was only twice this month and this winter, that Pune’s night temperature plunged lower than 10 degrees C—on January 17 when the mercury fell to 8.2 degrees C in Shivajinagar and the next day on January 18, when the location had recorded 9.6 degrees C. Since then, the minimum temperatures have been rising constantly.

Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather, IMD Pune, said, “The passage of a western disturbance over northwest India around January 27-28 is likely to bring a drop in night temperatures in parts of the state, including Pune from January 29. The minimum may rise again slightly in the city on January 31, but will come down once more on February 1. But this will be followed by a gradual rise in night temperatures from February 2,” he said.

Meteorologically, minimum temperatures rise when a western disturbance approaches but fall after it passes due to the reduction in moisture in the air and also due to cold, northerly wind flow. Also, the induced cyclonic circulation over southwest Rajasthan and neighbourhood is likely to shift its position with time, which will help cold northerly winds to re-enter partially into the state, especially north Maharashtra.

Title: Poonia targets Rahul for not fulfilling poll promises
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Jaipur: State BJP president Satish Poonia has sought an apology from former Congress president Rahul Gandhi, a day before his scheduled visit in Jaipur, for not fulfilling promises made during the assembly polls.

In a presser held in Jaipur, Poonia asked Gandhi to disclose the number of farmers benefitted out of the loan waiver, number of youths registered for unemployment allowance in his proposed rally and what his government has done for locust-hit farmers.

“I wanted to remind Rahul Gandhi of promises made by him during the assembly polls. He had announced a loan waiver for farmers within 10 days of his government formation. The total outstanding loan sum is Rs 99, 995 crore on 60 lakh farmers. However, over a year the party has able to waived loan of 20.26 lakh farmers. The total sum waived is just Rs 7,689 crore. Will he apologise for the lie he made to the voters of the state,” said Poonia.

He didn’t stop here. Sharpening his attack on the another promise of unemployment allowance, Poonia said, “The time Congress made the promise, state had 27 unemployed youths and they could able to provide allowance to just 1.58 lakh beneficiaries.”

Title: Jaipur: Traffic diversions for Rahul Gandhi rally today
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Deputy CM Sachin Pilot, Avinash Pande on Monday inspect preparations for the rally at Albert Hall

JAIPUR: City traffic police made elaborate arrangements for traffic diversions as Congress leader Rahul Gandhi to address Yuva Akrosh rally at Albert Hall in Ram Niwas Bagh in Jaipur on Tuesday.

Deputy commissioner of police (traffic) Rahul Prakash said that they have made diversions and other arrangement for smooth traffic flow.

Traffic flowing on MI Road from Government Hostel crossroad will be diverted from Panch Batti towards Bhagwan Das road. Vehicles moving on MI Road should take the route of Government Hostel crossroad, Sanjay Circle, Chhoti Chauper, Badi Chauper, Ramganj Chauper and Galta Gate.

Vehicles moving from Badi Chauper to Sanganeri Gate will be diverted towards Ramganj Bazaar. Traffic flowing from Chhoti Chauper to Ajmeri Gate will be diverted towards Chand Pole and Tripolia Bazaar.

Vehicles moving from Rambagh to Yaadgaar will be diverted from Prathiviraj T point to move towards Statue Circle to reach Chomu House.

Traffic coming from JLN Marg towards Albert Hall will be diverted from Trimurti Circle towards Narayan Singh T-point. Traffic flow from Dharam Singh Circle heading towards MD Road will be prohibited.

Traffic flow from TP Nagar crossroad to MI Road will be diverted from T P Nagar crossroad and diverted towards Delhi road and Jawahar Nagar byepass.

Traffic coming from Agra road tunnel will be diverted from Goner mod Agra road to reach Kho Nagoriyan road, Jagatpura and Hanuman Tiraha. Vehicle coming from Suchna Kendra Tirahi, Tonk Road to Arogya Path will be diverted towards Heerabagh to reach JLN road.

Buses coming from Government Hostel crossroad MI road to reach Ajmeri Gate will be diverted from Government hostel towards Sardar Patel Marg and Sansar Chand road. Parking will be remain prohibited on MI road, MD Road, Yaadgaar to Ghat Gate, Govind Marg, JLN Marg, Tonk Road, Prithviraj Road, Bhagwan Das Road, Sardar Patel Margm Sansar Chand road, Chand Pole market, Tripolia market, Ramganj market and Suraj Pole market.

Title: 70-year-old killed in clash at function to celebrate great grandson’s birth
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

FATEHABAD: An 70-year-old old man was killed in a clash during a prayer function to celebrate the birth of his great grandson in Bhattu town of Fatehabad district on Saturday night. The victim has been identified as Ramanand, a resident of Pratap Nagar in Fatehabad town, while Sonu of Bhodia Khera village of the district was injured in the brawl.

Police said a case of murder, rioting, unlawful assembly and causing hurt had been registered against accused Rahul, Dholu, Monu, Dheeraj, Surendra, Vikas, all residents of Bhattu Kalan, on the complaint of Kamal, grandson of the deceased.

In the complaint to the police, Kamal said his father Ramnivas died almost 25 years ago, after which he has been living with his maternal grandfather Ramanand. Kamal stated that on January 25, there was a prayer and a musical programme to celebrate the birth of his son. He said the celebrations went on till 10.30pm, after which guests started leaving.

He said at that time Rahul, Dholu, Monu, Dheeraj, Surendra and Vikas came and stood outside their house. “When we objected to their standing there, they started quarrelling with us and attacked us with bricks, stones, sticks, poles, iron pipes and swords. As our relatives started crying for help, my grandfather went out to the street to convince them to stop. Rahul attacked him with a brick on the chest and he fell headlong in the street,” he alleged.

After Ramanand fell unconscious, his sons Omprakash and Rajendra admitted him to the general hospital for treatment, where doctors declared him dead.

Title: NRC, NPR will not affect Maharashtra residents: Deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Maharashtra deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar

PUNE: Deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar on Monday iterated that the residents of the state would not be affected by the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Register of Citizens ( NRC ) or the National Population Register ( NPR ) because no one can force their implementation.

Addressing a press meet, he said as a tripartite government, there were discussions among the parties over these. “Our chief minister has assured that citizens in our state will not be affected by the NRC or NPR,” he said.

The deputy chief minister said states like Rajasthan, West Bengal, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh, Jharkhand and Chhattisgarh — all ruled by single parties — had announced that they would not implement NRC.

Commenting on the depleting funds of the state government as the finance minister, he said even as the registration department was among the departments generating high revenue, he had steered clear of either increasing or decreasing the Ready Reckoner rates and had called for a realistic value.

On the forthcoming expectations of the state from the central budget in the weekend, he said the state was keeping a close watch and would take a call after the budget was tabled.

The deputy chief minister on Monday cleared 1990.84-crore budget for the Pune division — an increase of Rs354.02 crore. Pune district was sanctioned Rs625 crore, Satara Rs325 crore, Solapur Rs424.32 crore, Kolhapur Rs331.52 crore and Sangli Rs285 crore for the 2020-21 financial year.

Title: Gujarat trader duped of Rs 11 crore in ‘biggest’ online fraud
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: In what police say is the biggest cyber fraud on an individual in the country, cheats teased out Rs 11,06,71,824 from a 62-year-old textile businessman, Prataprai Avtani, a resident of Asavari Towers in Satellite. Avtani lodged a complaint in this regard on January 24.According to cyber cell officials, the cheats first lured Avtani into ‘buying’ various insurance policies and then entering other investment schemes, with promises of high returns. They later told him to pay more money towards fees and charges to redeem his investments, which they told him had grown to Rs 30 crore.Avtani paid them the money into 186 different accounts, between June 2016 and December 2019. He has named 96 persons as accused.Avtani lives with his family at Asavari Towers in Satellite and owns various textile companies operating from the Kalupur area of the city. According to the FIR, in March 2016, he bought two insurance policies worth Rs 50,000 each from a private bank, for his granddaughters.The FIR states that in the same month, he got a call from one Kaushik Desai, identifying himself as being from the bank Avtani had bought the policies from. “Desai told Avtani that he got his details because of the two policies he had bought earlier. He told Avtani that the bank offered several other policies, which would give him double the returns,” said a cyber cell official.The FIR states that Avtani paid first Rs 1,98,000 on March 15, 2016 and then through various transactions till 2018, ‘invested’ more than Rs 50 lakh.According to the FIR, Desai then told Avtani and said that as his investment had crossed Rs 50 lakh, his case would be handled by Sadanand Mishra from their Hyderabad office. “Mishra then induced him into ‘investing’ more money. When Avtani sought to redeem his investments, Mishra told him that Jagdish Kute of their Chennai office would handle his case,” a cyber cell official said.In August 2018, Mishra called Avtani and said Kute was out of station and he would get his ‘file cleared’, but Avtani would have to pay some charges and taxes.“Avtani paid the money Mishra demanded into various bank accounts. In November 2018, one Vikas Dangar called, saying he was from the Delhi office and Avtani would have to pay Rs 1 crore to have his file cleared. Avtani paid the Rs 1 crore into various bank accounts as instructed by Dangar and waited for his ‘file to be cleared’,”One Premkumar Shaswat then called Avtani, saying he was calling from the from Hyderabad office. “He told Avtani that if he followed his instructions, his investments would be cleared in 15 days,” said a cyber investigator.From June 2019 to July 2019, one Ashok Ravat called Avtani, saying he was from the Delhi office. He told Avtani that he was to get Rs 30 crore but permission from the Reserve Bank of India and finance ministry was needed, and Avtani would have to pay more money. Avtani stated in his FIR that between August 2019 and October 2019, several people called him and made him pay, purportedly to get his ‘investments’ released.

Title: Miffed Middha leaves grievances meeting, minister brings him back
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Jind: BJP’s Jind MLA Krishan Middha walked out of the district grievances committee meeting here on Monday after his seat was occupied by an official. The meeting was being presided over by minister of state Anup Dhanak of Jannayak Janta Party (JJP) who too had to face local BJP member’s ire on the issue.

The MLA was already at the meeting while Dhanak reached the venue later. When Middha stood up from his seat to welcome the minister, a police officer sat in his seat. While initially, Middha pulled another chair from behind and sat, after a few moments he stood up and walked out from the meeting.

Local BJP functionary Ramphal Sharma stood up from his seat, along with other party members, and asked the minister why the MLA was insulted. “We can’t attend the meeting any longer as our MLA didn’t get his place to sit, which is an insult to everyone. Therefore we are going from the meeting as a mark of protest,” he announced.

BJP members and Dhanak then had an arguments over the issue. Later, the minister assured them to bring Middha back and stopped the meeting. Dhanak went out to call the MLA back to the meeting and managed to bring him back after half an hour. It was only then the meeting, in which complaints of local residents, were being heard started.

Sources claimed that Anup followed MLA Middha till Pindara village and appealed to him to attend the meeting. From there, they returned together and held the meeting.

After the meeting, the minister addressed the mediapersons but Middha refrained from speaking on the issue. Dhanak only said, “We have no differences with the BJP MLA. He had some work so he left the meeting, but came back along with me.”

Title: Chief of sanitation workers’ association joins AAP
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

New Delhi: Promising that the AAP government will fight for the rights of sanitation workers , chief minister Arvind Kejriwal welcomed former BJP leader and Akhil Bhartiya Safai Mazdoor Sangh chief Sanjay Gehlot into the party fold on Monday. Gehlot, on the other hand, blamed BJP for their plight.

Kejriwal described Gehlot as the man at the forefront of the sanitation workers’ fight. “Gehlot was a victim of misunderstandings, he stood against our party for he believed that Delhi government had not been funding the corporations adequately. Later he realised that they were suffering because of the inadequate funding by the Centre. It was then that he decided to join AAP,” he said.

Gehlot said Kejriwal had assured regularisation of the sanitation workers employed before 2017. “I want to assure him that the Valmiki community would participate in AAP’s door-to-door campaign,” Gehlot said. Kejriwal has also promised to fight for unifying the three corporations, he claimed. TNN

Title: Suspecting illicit relationship, man hacks wife, his brother in Kheri
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Bareilly: Suspecting that his wife was having an affair with his younger brother, a 40-year-old man allegedly hacked both to death in Lakhimpur on Monday morning. His parents who tried to intervene to save their son and daughter-in-law were also injured and have been admitted at district hospital. The accused, a father of three children, has been detained by police.

After getting information about the murders, SSP, Lakhimpur Kheri, Poonam also arrived at the spot to take stock of the situation.

According to police, on Sunday night, Mohammed Shakeel, a resident of Naurangabad locality, had an argument with his wife Shabkun (30) after he allegedly caught her with his younger brother Mohsin (28) in a compromising position. On Monday morning, Shakeel woke up early, took out an axe kept in the storeroom and went towards his brother’s room. When his parents saw him carrying an axe in his hand, they tried to intervene. But he allegedly killed his brother who was sleeping. He then went to his bedroom and killed his wife. He also injured his father, Noor Mohammed, and chopped off his mother, Shabrunisha’s fingers.

After the murderous assault, Shakeel attempted to escape from the spot but was caught by residents with the help of a homeguard deployed in the area. He was handed over to police and an FIR under section 302 (murder) was registered against him at Sadar Kotwali police station.

Ajay Mishra, SHO, told TOI, “We have detained the accused who suspected that his wife and younger brother were cheating on him and killed both of them with an axe. We have also recovered the murder weapon. Forensic experts have collected the evidence from the house. Both bodies were sent for an autopsy. His father told us that his son was mentally ill and was not even going for work for a while.”

ReplyForward

Title: ‘CM not sincere in fight against CAA’
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala said he would press for the notice issued to move a resolution in the assembly to recall governor Mohammad Arif Khan.

While responding to minister A K Balan’s statement that there was no issue between the government and the governor, Chennithala said, “LDF is not genuine in its protest against the governor.”

He said the opposition was forced to move a resolution as the government was not ready for it. “The governor had flouted all democratic values of the position he holds and he made a mockery of the Kerala legislature which we hold in high esteem. But the state government is unmoved despite the harsh criticisms made against the assembly and the resolution passed by its members. As a responsible opposition, we cannot remain a mute spectator when our supreme constitutional body is being targeted by a governor,” said Chennithala.

The governor is continuing his tirade against the assembly and humiliating the resolution passed unanimously by the members, he said. “The governor is infact ridiculing the people of the state through his statements,” he added.

“It is unfortunate and strange that the leader of the House was not ready to utter a word despite the governor making harsh criticisms against the assembly. His silence was dubious. It has to be understood that he was not sincere in his words against the CAA. The chief minister has the moral responsibility to register a protest against the comments made by the governor. Since the chief minister was silent, the opposition was forced to come out with a notice in the assembly against the governor,” he said.

Chennithala alleged that the state government and BJP had an unholy nexus and the chief minister’s silence signals it. “This was the reason why the governor showered praise on the chief minister in his Republic Day speech. This has raised several suspicions,” he said. On Republic Day, the chief minister and other ministers had attended the At Home reception organized by the governor at Raj Bhavan while the opposition boycotted the event as a mark of protest.

Title: IIT-MIT to find ways of cutting use of chemicals in agriculture
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Chandigarh: The Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) at Ropar has tied up with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, USA, for research to make agricultural practices safer and sustainable. The research will focus on Punjab and Haryana.

Sloan School of Management senior lecturer Chintan Vaishnav is collaborating with IIT Ropar’s department of humanities and social sciences assistant professor Parwinder Singh. They will use ethnography-based system and dynamics modelling to determine the conditions that would be most supportive to the transition from conventional to organic farming.

The research and modelling will focus on the regions of Punjab and Haryana in India, where the problem of chemical overuse in agriculture is most acute. At the close of the project, the team will have a check list-based advisory that smallholder farmers in India can use to guide their risk perception and actions during their transition from conventional to organic farming.

In another research initiative, MIT department of environmental engineering Professor Dara Entekhabi and IIT Ropar department of civil engineering assistant professor Reet Kamal Tiwari are developing a remote sensing device that can draw information on vegetation and soil using active and passive microwave systems.

Title: 5 hurt in clash over CAA in Kota, 2 held
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Kota: At least five persons sustained injuries late on Sunday night following a clash over CAA between two groups at Bhistipara under Gumanpura police station area.

Police reached the spot to control the situation and registered cross-cases against eleven identified persons of both groups. Two persons, one each from the two groups, were arrested for breach of public peace.

“Two groups, one against CAA and another for CAA, clashed with each other late on Sunday night in Bhistipara at Chawani area. Three persons of a group, identified as Mubarak, Mustakim and Azij, and two persons of another group identified as Pawan Kumawat and Satish, sustained injuries in the clashes,” said Manoj Singh Sikarwal, SHO, Gumanpura police station.

“On reports submitted by Mubarak and Kumawat, police have registered cross-cases against eight identified persons of the minority group and three identified persons of the other group under IPC Section 307 (attempt to murder). Investigation in the matter is underway,” the SHO said.

Police later arrested Mubarak and Kumawat under Section IPC 151 (breach of public peace), the police officer added.

The anti-CAA protesters allegedly also pelted stones at the police check post in Bhistipara at Chavani area.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: 1 more person admitted to Ernakulam medical college
Content:
A team of doctors deputed by Union health ministry with the officials of Cochin International Airport Limited ... Read More

KOCHI: One more person was admitted to isolation ward at Government Medical College, Ernakulam , on Monday morning. With this, the total number of people admitted due to suspected symptoms of Coronavirus in the district is four, with three admitted to the government college and one to a private hospital in the city.“On Monday, a man with symptoms of fever and throat infection was admitted to the hospital. He had returned from Hong Kong.“The condition of two other people admitted to the isolation ward is now better. But we are waiting for reports from NIV, Pune,” said an official with the health department.The total number of people who are quarantined at home in the district is 85.Meanwhile, a central team of doctors deputed by the Union ministry of health and family welfare visited Cochin International Airport Limited (Cial). The team expressed satisfaction with the arrangements in place at Cial. They examined the passenger manifests of 178 flyers who were screened by airport health officers. They also conducted awareness classes for immigration officials.Later, the team comprising Dr Pushpendra Kumar Verma, pulmonologist, Lady Hardinge Medical College, Delhi; Dr Ramesh Chandra Meena, internal medicine specialist, Safdarjung Hospital, Delhi; and Dr Shoukathali, National Centre for Disease Control, Kozhikode, visited the medical college here. “They checked the control room and isolation facility in the college. They also ensured that all preparations were in place, in case anyone tests positive for the Coronavirus that has killed at least 80 people,” a health official said.

Title: Locusts enter Jaisalmer city, spark fear in public
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Swarms of locusts hover over Jaisalmer city on Monday

JAISALMER: After destroying the crops in villages, the locusts on Monday swarmed into Jaisalmer ’s city area. They hovered over the sky for more than an hour in the evening. This sparked panic among the people. Insects were seen flying over Sonar Fort, bus stand, Patwa Haveli, etc.

At Jaisalmer Airforce station, all flying operations were suspended for an hour as a precautionary measure. Efforts were made to clear the locusts from the runway. The district administration has informed the locust control department. They have assured to destroy them in one or two days.

At 4.45pm on Monday, large groups of locusts were seen entering Jaisalmer city . The groups were several kilometres long. People came out on the roads and there was a situation of fear. The insects hovered over the city till 6pm. Jaisalmer witnessed a change in weather conditions on Sunday. Cloud cover and light rain were reported at several places. Possibly, due to the change in wind direction, the locusts reached Jaisalmer city. District collector Namit Mehta said that Fatehgarh village had reported fresh locust attack two days ago. Possibly, the remaining locusts reached Jaisalmer. Meanwhile, fresh locust attacks were reported in Gudamalani and Dhorimanna areas of Barmer district on Sunday and Monday, adding to farmers’ woes.

Title: Govt offices to get trained officers
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Thrissur: For the first time in the country, government offices in Thrissur district will extend a helping hand to people with disabilities.

The district administration will appoint sign language trained officers in the front offices of each government offices soon. In the first phase, officials trained in sign language will be appointed in the revenue department. The initiative to appoint the sign language trained officials in the government offices was started by district collector S Shanavas.

A special training will be given to selected 50 revenue officials at Thalappilly taluk office on Sunday at 10am. In the first phase, the sign language trained officials will be appointed in the offices in the first week of February, said officials.

“As per the primary data there are nearly 5,000 hearing and speech impaired people in the district. Many of them visit various government offices every day. But the officials can’t provide proper service to them, due to them not knowing sign language. The special initiatives aim to provide a helping hand to them”, district collector S Shanavas told TOI.
