“The NGOs will be giving sign language training to selected revenue officials. In the first phase the trained officials will be appointed to the revenue offices like village and taluk offices. In the second and third phase we aim to appoint sign language trained officials to banks, panchayat, police and other offices. We plan to appoint sign language trained officials in all government offices in the district soon,” said the collector.

“If sign language trained officials are appointed in government offices hearing and speech impaired individuals can share their complaints and requests to the officials in their own language. By knowing the actual details through sign language, the officials can provide proper service to them. As part of the initiative we also aim to give sign language training to auto, taxi and bus drivers,” said the collector.

Title: All three accused of gang-rape & murder of minor arrested after encounter
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Rampur: Three people, including a juvenile, were arrested after an early morning “encounter” on Monday at Himmatpur village under Shahabad Kothwali police station. Police later said they are accused of the rape and murder of a minor girl on January 18, whose body was found two days later in a sugarcane farm in Mittarpur village.

Police also claimed two of the suspects, Babu Beig and Israr-ud-din, both in their late twenties, suffered bullet injuries in their legs from retaliatory firing by police. One constable also suffered injuries during the encounter.

The arrested injured duo was admitted to a nearby hospital for treatment, and later referred to Meerut Medical College. Cops had to chase the third accused, a minor, till Badagaon, to arrest him.

Each of the three was carrying a reward of Rs 25,000. Rampur SP Santosh Kumar Mishra had set up three police teams to go after the culprits. Speaking with TOI, Mishra said, “The juvenile, who is 17 years of age, was sent to a juvenile home. The other two accused were sent to Meerut Medical College for treatment.”

“The three had together kidnapped and gangraped the minor girl, before strangling her with her dupatta for resisting them. At 4.45am on Monday, when the accused were tracked down to Himmatpur village, they fired on police and tried to escape on a bike, but were arrested. One of our constables suffered a minor injury in the encounter,” he added.

Police recovered country-made weapons of caliber .315 and .12, along with cartridges, from the accused. The Rampur SP announced that all police personnel who were involved in the operation will be rewarded with cash rewards of Rs 20,000 each.

Title: HC stays recovery of cops’ salary
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Granting relief to the police constables, a division bench of Rajasthan High Court stayed the recovery order of their salaries and have also issued notices to the additional chief secretary, home, principal secretary of finance, director general of police and Jaipur police commissioner.

A bench comprising Chief Justice Indrajit Mahanty and Justice AK Gaur gave this interim instruction on the petitions of Vikram Singh and others.

Advocate Dharamvir Tholia said that the applicants are entitled to get the benefits of grade pay after serving for 9, 18 and 27 years in police. “The state’s finance department issued a circular on October 30, 2017 through which the government reduced the existing grade pay of policemen from 2800 rupees to 2400 rupees for those constables who had served in police for 9 years, from 3600 to 2400 for those served in police for 18 years, and 4200 rupees to 3600 rupees by the revised order of 31 October 2017. Also, government implemented this order with retrospective effect from July 1, 2013, thus recovery of salary was issued,” said Tholia.

Tholia further stated that the amended order is illegal, arbitrary and thus recovery of salary paid to them should be stayed.

Title: Himachal Pradesh: Lahaul-Spiti residents help save Tangrol from poaching
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

The species had almost disappeared from the area a few years back

SHIMLA: Strict vigil of local tribal residents, along with the wildlife officials of state, against poaching has ensured an increase in the number of Himalayan Ibex, locally called Tangrol in Lahaul-Spiti district .

Increase in their number is a matter of relief as Himalayan Ibex, though listed in International Union for Conservation for Nature (IUCN) Red Data Book with status of least concern, had almost disappeared from the area a few years back. A subspecies of the Siberian Ibex, Himalayan Ibex is found in the areas of Trans Himalayas region of Ladakh and Greater Himalayas and Pir Panjals of Jammu & Kashmir and Himachal Pradesh .

It was the residents of Lahaul-Spiti district who had stepped forward to save Himalayan Ibex from becoming extinct by joining hands with the state wildlife department. Many panchayats had decided to take action against those found involved in the hunting of Tangrol, especially during winters, by socially outcasting them. No surprise then, in last seven years not even a single case of Ibex hunting has been reported in the district.

Head of Tabo panchayat, Dechen Angmo, said before winters, a general house is called in their panchayat where people are asked to take oath not to killed wild animals during winters.

Langja panchayat head Sher Singh said they have banned hunting due to which rise in the number has been witnessed. Dozens of other panchayats too have taken similar steps.

According to officials, the eastern limit of Ibex’s roaming ground seems to be Bara Lacha La Pass on the north and Satluj Gorge south of the Great Himalayan Range in Himachal Pradesh. The southern most populations may occur south of the Pir Panjal Range in Manali Wild Life Sanctuary in Himachal Pradesh.

Wildlife range officer at Spiti Devender Singh Chauhan said people of entire valley are protectors of wildlife. “We have not seen a single case of poaching here. The Buddhist people here consider killing of Ibex a sin. They do not allow outsiders to harm them either,” he said.

Chauhan said, “We have noticed Kibber wildlife sanctuary had almost no Ibex a few years back but now the animal has made Kibber sanctuary their habitat.” Spiti is known for good number of snow leopards and availability of natural prey like ibex and ghoral is responsible for this, he added. Himalayan Ibex is generally found in steep crags above the tree line in the Himalayas up to 5,500 metres.

Title: Udaipur: Triple talaq case against man, kin
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

UDAIPUR: A 20-year old woman has lodged a police complaint against her husband and in-laws for mental and physical harassment as well as forcing her to leave their home by uttering triple talaq . Asma Siddiqui, wife of Ahmed Raza , resident of Dholi Bawri in Udaipur city gave the complaint to IG Binita Thakur which has been lodged at the Dhanmandi police station on Monday.

Asma told the police that she lived with her husband and his family in Salumber town and was ill treated by them. She said she hailed from a poor family and her parents could not afford the dowry demands of her inlaws. They wanted to get rid of her so that Ahmed could remarry. Asma said that her sister-in law and her friends connived a plan to tarnish her image.

Title: Lucknow University finalises CBCS, offers more options to PG and PhD students
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Lucknow University

LUCKNOW: Lucknow University will implement choice-based credit system ( CBCS ) in all its post-graduate and PhD programmes from new academic session to give more learning options to students in interdisciplinary subjects.

The structure of CBCS was finalized at a meeting of all heads of departments and deans on Monday.

LU spokesman Durgesh Srivastava said, “Under CBCS, students will be offered non-credited courses, which will be for learning purpose only and no examination will be held, and credited courses where a student will be evaluated. It will offer two types of electives – frozen and open. In frozen elective, a student will have to select a subject from his or her stream while there will no such compulsion in open electives.”

He said postgraduate courses would have a total of 96 credits, including an internship which should be completed in the third semester (wherever applicable) and a dissertation (200 marks) to be completed in fourth semester. Srivastava said each student would be guided by a teacher-mentor.

“Introduction of CBCS will give a major boost to quality of education at university level. It will offer more learning options and greater flexibility to students. They will get an opportunity to learn an extra subject apart from their core courses,” said Srivastava.

The system will also offer Massive Open Online Courses (MOOC) which is an online learning and knowledge testing system made available by the Union ministry of human resource development.

The university students will have interdisciplinary and intra-disciplinary learning options as well. For example, in inter-disciplinary choice, a student of science can learn a subject from humanities while in intra-disciplinary option, a PG student of zoology can study botany as one of the subjects.

Title: Nurses stage sit-in outside Cong office
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Jaipur: Hundreds of nurses have begun an indefinite dharna outside state Congress headquarters on Monday. The incident comes a day ahead of Congress leader Rahul Gandhi’s visit to the city on Tuesday.

The nurses are demanding recruitment of candidates selected during the earlier tenure of the Congress government in 2013 which was denied by the former BJP government.

In 2013, state Congress government had invited applications for posts of 15,773 nurse grade II and 12,278 ANMs.

Voted out of power in 2013, Congress could not initiate the recruitment.

After coming to power, the former BJP government had curtailed the number of posts for nurse grade II by 4,514 posts and ANM by 6,719 posts. tnn

Title: Disciplinary committee to nip dissent in KPCC soon
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: KPCC president Mullappally Ramachandran has talked tough against the growing indiscipline in the party where the leaders are coming out against the appointment of new party office bearers.

“However senior the leaders be, those who are making public comments against party decisions will have to face severe disciplinary action,” said Mullappally Ramachandran in the first meeting of the newly-appointed party office bearers. He was indirectly referring to the open statements made by the senior leader K Muraleedharan against the revamp.

Mullappally said the party will soon have a disciplinary committee which will deal with all such disciplinary issues. “No one will be allowed to misuse the social media against the party. All leaders in the party have the freedom to raise their opinions and comments. But it should be made only in the party forum. All the leaders are given enough freedom to air their opinions in the party meetings,” he said.

AICC general secretary K C Venugopal said that AICC has decided to take strict action against those defying party decisions and making comments in the public against the party or its leadership. “The new office bearers have been selected by the AICC leadership to equip the party in Kerala for the ensuing local body elections. The aim of the party now should be to register an impressive victory in the civic body elections. The AICC will not tolerate any other issues,” he said.

Congress working committee member A K Antony who was also present in the meeting said that the party had no time to waste and everyone should stand united to work for the victory of the party in the local body and next assembly elections.

The KPCC president said that the Congress had the tradition of including leaders who were willing to come back to the party. “The inclusion of Mohan Shankar should be seen only in this direction. The party collectively took the decision to give him a new responsibility in the party,” said Mullappally, on the criticism raised by Muraleedharan against including Mohan Shankar as the new general secretary of the party. On complaints that women have not been given enough representation in the new list, Mullappally said there were grievances and they would be rectified when the new secretaries were appointed.

Title: Rajasthan: Black buck case hearing deferred to March 30
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Salman Khan

JODHPUR: Hearing on the state government’s appeal challenging the acquittal of co-accused in black buck poaching case will now take place on March 30. After the counsel for the co-accused sought time to argue the case, the court deferred the hearing on Monday.

Salman Khan was sentenced to five years imprisonment by the trial court on April 5, 2018 for poaching two black bucks in Kankani on October 1-2, 1998, while the co-accused Saif Ali Khan , Sonali Bendre , Tabbu, Neelam and a local Dushyant Singh had been acquitted by the court giving all of them the benefit of doubt. The state government had moved the session court filing a Leave to Appeal against the acquittal of all the five co-accused.

Title: Delhi elections: Roadshow rolls on in garments hub
Content: NEW DELHI: Despite it being a weekly off , the Gandhi Nagar main market saw a flurry of activity on Monday evening. Hundreds of Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) supporters had gathered to participate in a roadshow , which was also attended by chief minister Arvind Kejriwal . The procession started from Gandhi Nagar-Pusta Road intersection around 5pm, half an hour after the scheduled time.Kejriwal was campaigning for Navin Choudhary (Deepu), the AAP candidate from Gandhi Nagar assembly seat. “Thousands of people participated in the mega road show at Gandhi Nagar. AAP is getting unprecedented support in city,” tweeted Kejriwal later.Besides cars and two-wheelers, hundreds of e-rickshaws joined the cavalcade from nearby areas, including Seelampur.As soon as the roadshow entered the main market, traders welcomed the leaders by showering rose petals. However, due to the weekly bazaar, vehicles were finding it difficult to cross the stretch smoothly.The constituency, which is known for the biggest readymade garments wholesale market, is affected by problems of encroachment, unregulated traffic and congestion. “While the shopkeepers have encroached over 5-6 feet of area for displaying their items, hawkers occupy the roads on Mondays,” said a resident of the area.From Gandhi Nagar, the procession moved to congested lanes of Ragubarpura, Shanti Mohalla and East Old Seelampur, where people showered flower petals from their balconies to welcome Kejriwal.“We had urged for organising the roadshow on a Monday when all shops remain closed. Had it been any other day, it would have been impossible to take out the procession here,” said a local trader.“We have high expectations from Choudhary. He understands the local issues and had shifted from Congress sometimes back. AAP is doing well for development of the city,” the trader added.Choudhary will be contesting against former AAP MLA and now BJP candidate Anil Bajpai and four-time MLA from the area, Arvinder Singh Lovely, of Congress.The constituency was a Congress bastion for years until Anil Bajpai won it in 2015.

Title: No organ donation committee, yet GMC declares patient brain dead
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

BHOPAL: In a serious breach of protocol for organ donation, doctors at Gandhi Medical College (GMC), Bhopal assuming a 41-year-old patient as brain dead permitted the patient to be transferred to private hospital cum transplant centre. The patient was declared brain dead when there is no active ‘organ donation committee’.

Now, GMC and Hamidia hospital officials are not taking responsibility for the breach of protocols.

Cadaveric organ donation of the 41-year-old woman captured national headlines when her 10-year-old son opted for the noble deed on Saturday. On ventilator, the patient was shifted to a private hospital and 13 hours later declared dead on Sunday. Only her eyes were donated. The cremation was conducted in Bhopal Sunday. The deceased suffered a brain injury and was admitted in Hamidia hospital since January 23.

Patient was considered fit for organ donation to declared unfit for organ donation within matter of hours. Interestingly, private hospital final report stated patient ‘declared brain dead in Hamidia hospital surgical ICU at 5 pm on January 25’. In the same page, it notes ‘patient underwent cardiac arrest at 8.42 am on January 26.’ No sooner, a post mortem and funeral took place on a holiday.

The private hospital is an authorised centre for organ transplant. Hamidia hospital does not have organ transplant facility. “I am understanding the situation and have taken charge only recently,” said GMC dean Dr Aditya Agrawal.

Hamidia hospital medical superintendent, Dr AK Shrivastava said, “Appointed committee should declare the person as brain dean. Concerned doctors should clarify how the body was sent to private hospital, else it is illegal.” However, GMC organ donation committee awaits an approval from directorate of medical education (DME), admitted GMC HoD ophthalmology Dr Kavita Kumar.

Patient was being treated under GMC department of surgery, Dr SS Pal. When contacted on who gave authorisation for the patient to be declared brain dead and shifted to private hospital, he said, “Do write, I did not respond to your queries.” The goof-up is expected to impact, proposal for start of organ transplant at Hamidia hospital. GMC nephrologist Dr Himanshu Sharma too also did not comment.

Organ donation society representative, Dr Rakesh Bhargava who was point person during the entire case said, “There are certain criteria for declaring a person brain dead. It takes time for person to be stabilised, parameters checked before organ donation can begin.”

For Dr Bhargava’s own prognoses, he admitted that patient’s urine and BP was normal when checked at Hamidia hospital, indicating that her body organs were in acceptable state. “Test reports in private hospital transplant centre were negative for organ donation,” he said.

GMC dean has recently taken charge, he is not aware of the basics, said Dr Bhargava. “Only government recognised doctors can declare a person brain dead,” he admitted.

The family of deceased was asked to submit a written application to Hamidia hospital for shifting of patient ‘suspected brain dead’ to private hospital. As per NOTTO rules, hospital competent authority should have authorised transfer of patient and informed Regional Organ and Tissue Transplant Organisation (ROTTO).

Title: A third of voters ‘unsure’, BJP to plan outreach
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: With an internal party survey concluding that almost one-third of Delhi is still unsure about whom to vote for in the assembly polls, Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has decided to launch a mega outreach programme covering every single household in the city.Senior party functionaries said that booth-level committees and on-ground workers have been told to ensure that every household is visited with the party’s symbol, photo of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the list of works done by the Centre as the chunk of about 30% voters still sitting on the fence have the capability of swinging the poll either way.BJP believes that it enjoys a fixed vote share of 32-33%. With campaigns generating heat and polling less than two weeks away, senior party functionaries said that the survey has indicated that their vote share is steadily rising.“This clearly points towards an anti-incumbency factor. These undecided voters can easily be tapped and convinced to vote for BJP,” said a senior party functionary, who is part of the core committee supervising the elections.Sources said the focus is more on A and B-level constituencies, which had always supported BJP but went with AAP in the 2015 polls. In C-level constituencies — dominated by minorities or reserved segments — the party has decided to target those pockets that supported them in the 2019 Lok Sabha election.About 250 party functionaries, including BJP national president JP Nadda, Union home minister Amit Shah, cabinet ministers and Delhi MPs, have been holding close to 400 public meetings and direct dialogue with voters every day. In the next 12 days, more than 10,000 hyperlocal meetings have been planned.Apart from over one lakh ground-level BJP workers, thousands of RSS activists have also been holding corner meetings and visiting door-to-door.Shah, who is micro-managing the campaign, has been in regular touch with the coordinators at the parliamentary constituency and assembly segment levels by taking regular updates and sending instructions. In a meeting of social media volunteers on Saturday, he had urged them to bring maximum voters on polling day. A massive social media campaign is also being launched to influence fence-sitters.After hectic campaigning, which includes addressing at least 2-3 public meetings and leading roadshows, the top functionaries get into a huddle, review the day’s campaign and work out the strategy for the next day, said party sources.“Since the survey report, the central leadership is keen on continuing the momentum and mobilising workers and sympathisers to garner support. The party’s focus is on smaller interactions with target groups instead of huge public rallies,” said a party functionary.

Title: Union govt failed to contribute: HC
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Kochi: The central government failed in contributing its share to the project for treating children with rare diseases even when the state government set apart funds for three years, the high court said in an order.

Though the policy introduced by the central government in 2017 to provide treatment for children with rare diseases was withdrawn in 2018, a division bench comprising Chief Justice S Manikumar and Justice Shaji P Chaly ordered the government to deposit Rs 1.5 crore in the state corpus within 15 days. The court pointed out that such amount was due as per the policy that existed and that the state government had deposited its share in 2017, 2018, and 2019.

In order to create a national and state-level corpus, National Policy for Treatment of Rare Diseases was introduced in July 2017. The central government was to provide 60% of the funds whereas the state government had to provide 40%. State government had deposited Rs 50 lakh during the three years since then. The central government had kept the implementation of the policy in abeyance through a notification issued in December 2018.

Noting that the central government should have contributed Rs 75 lakh each for 2017, 2018, and 2019, the court said in the order, “Having regard to the prompt treatment which is required for the above said rare diseases and the number of death of children, we are of the view that there is a failure on the part of Union of India in contributing 60% of the share as per the National Policy. Therefore, we direct respondent No.5 (central government) to deposit a sum of Rs 1.5 crores in the State Corpus which is due, as per the then existing National Policy, within 15 days from the date of receipt of a copy of this order.”

Title: ‘It’s soul, not body, that makes life complicated’
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Dr. Sunil Prakash, the CEO of California Hypnosis Institute, Gurgaon, talked about the connection between body and soul at the JLF on Friday.

Prakash has been teaching and practicing clinical hypnotherapy since 2008.

“Life has been made extremely complicated, not by our body, not by our will, but by our soul. Soul is the real culprit. A lot of times people ask me what is the connection between body and soul as well as about past life. Hypnosis has helped me in answering few of these questions,” said Prakash.

Prakash said a human body was just being used as a mere bank account by this accountant called the soul. He said the soul maintained the karmic accounts of not only current life, but also of all its previous as well as future lives.

“The soul keeps the karmic account to manipulate all information for its own selfish motive of experiencing everything before finally evolving and becoming one with the super consciousness that is the Creator. In this process, it grossly exploits and tarnishes the body. Sadly, as soon as the soul’s plans are accomplished and desires fulfilled through our body, it leaves the body lifeless, just like a useless piece of machinery, closes the account, further moving on to start a new a journey thereby assuming another physical body to fulfil its next set of objectives,” said Prakash.

Title: Action against Mishra was disciplinary: Bhatkhande VC
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

BMIDU VC Shruti Sadolikar Katkar at the press conference

Lucknow: The vice chancellor of Bhatkhande Music Institute Deemed University (BMIDU) on Monday denied allegations of harassment levelled by the family of deceased sarangi player Pandit Vinod Mishra against her.

In a press conference, VC Shruti Sadolikar Katkar claimed that Mishra’s retirement benefits were held back by Uttar Pradesh culture department and that he was sent on compulsory retirement by the management council of the university as disciplinary action.

Mishra, who worked in the university for 34 years as an accompanist, died on January 23, seven days before his 62nd birthday, during treatment at SGPGI.

Mishra’s daughter Preeti (29) had claimed that her father had been continually harassed since 2018 after he went to attend a concert abroad on the invitation of the Indian Council for Cultural Relations (ICCR). On his return, Mishra was suspended from the university and had to approach court to get reinstated. Next year, after Mishra returned from cataract surgery, he was given “compulsory retirement”, Preeti said.

Because of that, the family slumped into economic crises as the university had allegedly also held back his retirement benefits. The family claimed that because he didn’t receive his monetary dues, he was depressed, leading to death, they said.

Preeti has submitted a complaint to Kaiserbagh police station, alleging harassment. However, no FIR has been lodged so far.

In the press conference, Katkar said that in 2018, Mishra had applied for leave for a concert but it was rejected because the university had assigned his duty in a seminar at the time. Despite that, Mishra went on leave. When he returned, disciplinary action was taken against him. However, when asked for the date or document of assigning the duty to Mishra, the VC was not able to provide it. Katkar continued that next year, Mishra went on unplanned leave for which the university council sent him on compulsory retirement. The VC also claimed that laxity in releasing his dues was on the part of the culture department.

Title: Man found dead in water-filled quarry
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Pune: A 43-year-old missing man was found dead in a water-filled quarry near Kakade City housing complex along Karve Road on Saturday afternoon.

The Warje Malwadi police have identified the deceased as Nilesh Kanase of Gujarat Colony in Kothrud. Ashok Kadam, senior inspector of the Warje Malwadi police, told TOI, “Prima facie it is a case of suicide. Kanase’s brother told us that he was mentally disturbed for the past five years.”

Kadam said after Kanase’s brother had lodged a missing person’s complaint with the Kothrud police. “His brother was also searching for him. On Saturday afternoon, he noticed Kanase’s motorcycle near the quarry, following which he alerted the police. Kanase’s body was taken out from the quarry by the firemen,” Kadam said.

He said Kanase, who was undergoing medical treatment, was unmarried.

Title: FIR can be filed at any police station: Behera to officers
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

T’puram: The public can file an FIR registered in any police station across the state irrespective of jurisdictional limits where a particular crime or incident that led to the registration of the FIR has occurred.

State police chief Loknath Behera instructed all police officers to allow any aggrieved citizen to allow registration of FIR in this manner. An FIR registered in such a manner will be forwarded from the police station where it has been registered to the police station concerned where the incident falls. In case any police officer refuses to register an FIR despite knowing about a cognizable offence, such an action from the officer can earn him imprisonment up to two years and a fine.

He also said that departmental action will be initiated against such officers. The instruction will help citizens especially if they are travelling to report and get a case registered about any incident during their travel irrespective of where the incident occurred.

Title: Secunderabad Cantonment Board takes up road repair works, commuters relieved
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Potholes on roads between Safilguda Railway Junction and AOC tracks filled with bitumen.

SECUNDERABAD: Roads under the Secunderabad Cantonment Board (SCB) have finally been repaired, much to the relief of commuters who travel through these stretches daily.

Over a lakh commuters pass through the roads that connect residential areas such as Safilguda, Mallikarjuna Nagar, Dayanand Nagar, Neredmet, Yapral, Balaji Nagar and adjoining areas. Even the roads near Safilguda Railway Gate and Army Railway Tracks are busy throughout the day.

The United Federation of Residential Welfare Associations (UFERWAS) had filed several complaints with the garrison engineer (north), SCB, urging the authorities concerned to repair the potholes to avoid accidents.

“Traffic congestions during peak hours have become a daily affair on Ordnance Road near Safilguda Railway Gate. Vehicles often get damaged as vehicles move slowly and it put a lot of pressure on the engine and brakes,” UFERWAS general secretary BT Srinivasan told TOI.

The Residential Welfare Associations (RWAs) had appealed to the army authorities several times, but no action was taken. Last monsoon, many motorists met with road accidents and were badly injured due to the bad roads especially beside the army railway tracks, Srinivasan said.

“Finally, the garrison engineer (north) took note of our complaints and initiated repair of the roads. The workers filled up all the potholes with bitumen,” Srinivasan pointed out.

“The patchwork is a temporary fix and the SCB authorities should take up complete re-carpeting works. This will ensure a smoother ride for commuters,” said a resident of Safilguda, P Kamalakar.

Title: International flyer movement up in Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

SVPI Airport

AHMEDABAD: Improved connectivity, more direct flights to newer destinations from Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International (SVPI) airport in Ahmedabad, has led to a significant increase in international passenger movements. According to data given by Airport Authority of India (AAI), international tourist arrivals at the SVPI airport in Ahmedabad went up by 16% in 2019, with some 24.09 lakh international passengers moving in and out of the city airport during the year. The number of international passengers handled at the SVPI airport in Ahmedabad stood at 20.6 lakh in 2018.

“The connectivity to international destinations has tremendously improved from SVPI airport. We now have direct flights to destinations such as Turkey, whereas direct connectivity to existing destinations has increased significantly. Moreover, some of the airlines have upgraded with higher seating capacity aircraft and others plan to do so. As a result, the overall passenger movement has increased significantly and will further go up,” said Manoj Gangal, director, SVPI airport.

Travel experts also attribute the growth in passenger movement to the heritage city status conferred upon Ahmedabad; in addition to a slew of foreign investments that have taken shape.

“Several foreign companies have invested in Gujarat and most of them are in and around Ahmedabad, as a result of which, movement of international business delegates has significantly increased at the city. This number is growing year on year and is visible with several hotels in the city hosting international guests,” said a city-based tour operator.

“At the same time, increased frequency of flights to popular tourist destinations coupled with affordable and competitive airfares has led to an uptick in the number of passengers taking international trips,” said Anuj Pathak, secretary, Tour Operators and Travel Agents Association (TAG).

Even domestic passenger movement at SVPI airport showed a promising 8.4% growth in 2019, with 93.1 lakh domestic passengers travelling from the airport against 85.8 lakh in 2018.

Title: Hill Highway plan may take off soon
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Kozhikode: The Hill Highway project in Kozhikode is likely to take off soon after getting rid of all the stumbling blocks.

Out of the four stretches of the hill highway through Kozhikode, three stretches have already received financial sanction.

The PWD officials are expecting to start the work of the fourth stretch in the district in the first phase as the detailed project report for the work has already received technical sanction. Though e-tender for the work also was started, the tender could not be allotted as only one bidder turned up to take up the project.

“We are now planning to re-tender the work of the fourth stretch, Kodenchery- Kakkadampoyil stretch, of the proposed alignment in the first phase,” said R Sindhu, executive engineer PWD (roads). We are also hoping to get technical sanction for the other stretches soon, she said.

The total length of the Kodenchery-Kakkadampoyil stretch is 34.4km and the issues related to the alignment and land has already been settled for the stretch. According to the figures, land possessed by 987 land owners is being used for the fourth stretch of the hill highway from Kodenchery to Kakkadampoyil.

The PWD has also started the utility shifting on the first reach of Hill Highway in the district connecting Vilangad and Thottilpalam. The total length of the stretch is 28km.

On the other hand, the preliminary work of the second stretch of the Hill Highway connecting Thottilpalam with Thalayad is progressing at a slow pace owing to legal hurdles and opposition from land owners. There has been rift between the residents and the PWD regarding the alignment of the 37.6km stretch.

The third stretch, which is the shortest reach in Kozhikode district, has received financial sanction. The work of the road extending to 17.8km will be completed spending Rs 48.75 crore.

Apart from the road construction activity, the fund for reconstructing the compound walls of those who hand over their land for the road, will also be earmarked, said MLA Karat Razak. Tender process for the stretch will begin immediately after getting technical sanction, said the MLA.

The hill highway stretch in Kozhikode is part of the 1332km-long Hill Highway connecting Nandarapadavu in Kasaragod district with Parassala in Thiruvananthapuram. The total length of the hill highway in Kozhikode is nearly 120km.

Title: Municipality withdraws letter related to NPR
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Malappuram: Manjeri municipality has withdrawn a letter regarding the updation of National Population Register ( NPR ), issued to some schools in the municipal area on Monday, after it kicked off a controversy.

The letter was issued to schools in the area seeking details of teachers who are ready to participate in the NPR works. Earlier, the same municipality had passed a resolution objecting to the central government’s move to implement CAA, NRC and NPR.

The municipal secretary had sent the notification to 12 schools in the area. When the letter drew criticism from various corners, the municipal authorities on Monday withdrew the notification. The municipal authorities explained that it was a clerical mistake from the part of some officials.

Meanwhile, district collector Jafer Malik said he would take strict action against the officials who sent out letter to the schools. “The state government has already made it clear that it will not cooperate with the enumeration works related to the NPR and NRC. Even after knowing the government stand, the officials who made the mistake will face action. The works related to the NPR and NRC, which is against the stand of the state government, has not begun in the district,” Malik said.

Title: Jaipur Literature Festival: Rajasthan exploits only 20 per cent of tourism potential, says Vishvendra Singh
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Vishvendra Singh

Rajasthan has exploited only 20% of its tourism potential, said state tourism minister Vishvendra Singh while speaking at Jaipur Literature Festival on Monday.

Singh said tourism has immense potential in Rajasthan, much is being done and much more needs to be done if we are to truly exploit it. “The state has only exploited 20% of its tourism potential. There is need to focus on ethical and sustainable tourism by way of which we leave minimal impact on the places we visit.”

He was speaking at ‘Sustainable and Responsible Tourism’ session along with Dr Rashmi Dickinson and Dr Edward Dickinson.

Singh said, the desert state has the maximum number of heritage hotels in the country. “We gave and are giving special concessions to heritage properties which have contributed to this large figure. Smaller interventions can take us a long way towards practicing responsible tourism. Without losing money and making heavy duty investments, we can make a conscious effort to source food locally, employ locals and involve the global community,” he said.

Singh also spoke about formulation of new tourism policy and said that the state government is in the process of formulating a ‘New Tourism Policy’ taking initiative to maximise, socialize and economise benefits to the local communities, conserve natural resources, protect heritage and begin awareness in a campaign mode.He also touched upon recycling of waste and said by recycling waste, valuing our water and electricity, reducing plastic waste, we can keep culture and environment at the heart of our businesses.

Title: ‘Getting data on occupational health still an issue in India’
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates the impact of occupational health on global GDP at 3-4% annually. In a country like India, where about 90-92% of the workforce is in informal sector, the figure could be higher, said experts who gathered at the Indian Institute of Public Health , Gandhinagar (IIPH-G) as part of an international workshop on occupational and environmental health.

Prof Dileep Mavalankar , director, IIPH-G, said the workshop was held to understand global best practices and how to implement them in the Indian context. D

r Shyam Pingle , senior occupational health specialist from IIPH-G, said that the initiative to improve occupational health should start from the general physician’s level. “Studies show that MBBS students learn about occupational health only for about 20 hours in their entire course. Data collection is a major issue while assessing the impact of a person’s occupation on his/her health and cause of death,” he said.

Prof Gert van der Laan, from the Netherlands, said that regulations and implementations are stricter in several European nations. “When it was found that pesticides were causing illness among the Dutch farmers, rules about procurement and use of pesticides were introduced and the chemicals were made expensive. The move brought desired results,” he said.

“In Italy, the occupational healthcare professionals have powers of an enforcement officer who can visit industrial areas and can also take legal action. Data collection is also stringent where it can point towards major hazardous factors in time,” said Prof Claudio Colosio, University of Milan, Italy.

Title: CAA/NRC won’t affect even one Indian Muslim, assures Rajnath Singh
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Defence minister Rajnath Singh (File photo)

MANGALURU: Defence minister Rajnath Singh asserted on Monday that not a single Muslim in India would be thrown out of the country due to the proposed National Register of Citizens and that the Bharatiya Janata Party would throw its might behind the community if a single member of this community feels persecuted by the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. This is in line with Prime Minister Narendra Modi ’s motto of “Sab Ka Saath, Sab Ka Vikas aur Sab Ka Vishwas”, he added at a pro-CAA rally here on Monday.

Assailing Congress for spreading fear among Muslims regarding a law that both Houses of Parliament debated and passed, Rajnath addressed the mammoth rally organised by the BJP district unit here. He said BJP has merely fulfilled a wish that Mahatma Gandh had directed Congress to do post-Independence. This was also in the resolution adopted by the Congress Working Committee on November 25, 1947, he said.

Asking the crowd if government discriminated based on religion in implementing its various flagship programmes such as Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana, Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana and Ayushman Bharat or in providing various infrastructure works, Rajnath wondered how the same government could discriminate with CAA. “How can the opposition accuse us of being discriminatory with this step their leaders wanted?” he asked.

Reminding Congress that it implemented the NRC based on a Supreme Court directive, Rajnath said, “NRC naam ki chidiya hum (BJP) logon ne nahin laya tha!” CAA is a balm the government is using to apply to the souls of persecuted minorities from India’s theocratically ruled neighbours and is not to hurt any Indian citizen, he said, adding that Congress, seeped in hatred for the ruling government, can’t see anything good it does.

Noting that there is a concerted attempt on the part of Congress to drive a wedge between Hindus and Muslims using the CAA, Rajnath said it wouldn’t be surprising if foreign powers were behind it. The former BJP national chief exhorted the party’s rank and file to explain to Muslims that their citizenship was not under threat and they would continue to enjoy their rights as any other citizen.

Rajnath said the opposition should not forget the “national dharma”. Let the opposition question the continuing persecution of minorities in neighbouring Pakistan, he said. While CAA is only to accommodate persecuted minorities from Afghanistan, Pakistan and Bangladesh, the majority of whom are Dalits, why should anyone have any objection to it, he asked.

Noting that as home minister in the Modi government’s first innings he had given citizenship to over 600 Muslims, including Pakistani singer Adnan Sami , Rajnath said Muslims from India’s theocratic neighbours wanting to become Indian citizens are still able to do so under CAA provisions. Even with the NPR that Congress introduced in 2010, no one will be forced to give their personal details, such as their father’s name or date of birth, he said.

Title: Fire at heritage Taj Mahal palace damages frescos, roof; none hurt
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: Amid reports of the 150-year-old Taj Mahal palace going back under the state government control, a major tragedy was averted at the heritage palace after a fire broke out at the gate of the palace towards Bara Mahal late on Sunday night. Though the 20-feet tall ceiling, precious fescos and other decorative parts were partially damaged, no one was injured in the fire, BMC fire brigade officials said.

Local residents spotted the fire and alerted the emergency services. “The fire was doused within about half-an-hour. It was reported at 11:51 pm on Sunday night. No one was injured in the incident,” confirmed BMC fire brigade officials.

The fire was triggered in blankets and pillows of homeless people who have occupied the gate of the palace. Dial 100 was alerted and the police informed the fire brigade.

“The gate has been has been completely cordoned off,” said a representative of private group in charge of Taj Mahal. Meanwhile, senior MPT official confirmed that notices to the private group has been issued.

Local resident, Junaid Kidwai alleged that Taj Mahal agency was alerted about the possibility of such incidents and its impact on the heritage property. Earlier too, there was a homeless family living along the old heritage gate towards, Bara Mahal, he claimed. The family was removed about a month back. The belongings including pillows and blankets were left behind.

Police have registered a case and have initiated investigation in the case.

For over a decade, various heritage conservationists have called for restoration and protection of the palace, considered one of the best examples of 18th century architecture in India. In 2011, the palace was de-notified as a protected heritage by the state government and since then, the property has been under Madhya Pradesh tourism (MPT) which has given it to a private group on a 96-year lease.

The move follows, a ‘ Bhopal Vision Statement’ released during the general elections, which called for protection of all heritage properties in the city. Value and historicity of the place has been valued in crores. Dozens of encroachments along the Motia Talab and Bab-e-Aali side of the Taj Mahal palace that have cropped up in the last six months, have gone unnoticed by the government.

Title: Govt should answer all questions by MLAs: Khaunte
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Porvorim: The debate over questions raised in the assembly going missing or being clubbed with others refused to die down, with Porvorim MLA Rohan Khaunte on Monday saying that deliberate attempts were being made by the government to hinder public accountability.

Khaunte met speaker Rajesh Patenkar at the assembly complex to discuss his concerns that several questions raised by him had been clubbed with questions raised by other MLAs. “The government should realise that it is answerable to the questions we are asking, and it is our privilege to get replies,” he said.

The meeting did not appear to be fruitful with both sides claiming that the other was wrong. After the meeting, Patnekar told reporters that as per rules and procedure of the House, the legislature secretariat could club questions from multiple MLAs.

Opposition leader Digambar Kamat, Khaunte and Goa Forward Party president Vijai Sardesai have claimed that some of the questions raised by them have been omitted by the legislature secretariat to ensure that the government does not face fire in the upcoming budget session.

Title: LMC officials skip duty, taint city’s swachh bid
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Lucknow: Laxity of Lucknow Municipal Corporation zonal and beat officials may cost the city its ranking in the ongoing Swachhta Survey. According to LMC, its zonal officials of Gomtinagar were found missing from their allotted duties on Sunday, which included supervision of garbage collection in the areas between 6am and 10am every day.

“Both the zonal and beat incharge have been blacklisted and action will be taken against them for skipping their duties,” said additional municipal commissioner Amit Singh .

The officials’ absence resulted in no garbage collection in zone-4 on Sunday. Their absence coincided with third party inspection by the ministry of housing and urban affairs which is awarding marks to civic bodies under Swachhta Survey. Since the central authorities are conducting surprise inspection in various parts of the city till January 31, the officials’ absence on Sunday is being seen as a lapse on LMC’s part. During inspection, if the central team finds littered garbage in open it can deduct as many as 350 marks from Lucknow’s total marking.

Lucknow has been performing poorly in swachhta surveys for the past three years. City was ranked 269th out of 408 cities in 2017. Its ranking improved to 118th rank in 2018, but slipped to 121 among 425 cities last year.

Title: Hyderabad Metropolitan Development Authority plans to install elevators at Oliphant Bridge
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

SECUNDERABAD: The Hyderabad Metropolitan Development Authority ( HMDA ) officials have taken up a detailed study on the feasibility of installing escalators at Oliphant Bridge near Secunderabad Railway Station.

Though the study was initially proposed by the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC), North Zone, the project was finally initiated by HMDA.

Hundreds of pedestrians walk under the Oliphant Bridge daily and the escalators will help them cross the bridge easily.

The authorities concerned have also proposed to construct skywalks in the area connecting four sides of the main junction at Oliphant Bridge (towards Bhoiguda side), for the convenience of those travelling from Secunderabad Railway Station Terminal-II (Bhoiguda) towards either Tarnaka, Sitaphalmandi, RTC X Roads and Rathifile bus stand or Secunderabad Metro Rail East.

“The study of this important junction has been entrusted to the civil engineering wing of Osmania University,” sources in HMDA told TOI.

Meanwhile, officials of Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWSSB) have repaired the leaking sewage pipe under the bridge. Now, pedestrians do not have to walk on dirty water.

“Once the escalators are installed under the bridge, it will benefit hundreds of pedestrians who cross it daily, said T Shankar Das, a resident of Sitaphalmandi.

Title: Lucknow: Teacher booked for hitting, threatening Class 4 student
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: A teacher of a private school in Gomtinagar Extension was booked for assault and criminal intimidation for allegedly beating a 9-year-old girl, a student of Class 4, and threatening to kill her if she dared to inform her parents about the incident.

The incident took place on Thursday last week while the FIR was lodged by the girl’s mother on Saturday.

The girl’s mother informed police that the class teacher hit her daughter with the edge of a book on Thursday. “My daughter fell on the floor due to the impact and started crying. The teacher threatened my daughter that she would kill her if she informed us about the incident,” she said.

However, the girl mustered courage and informed her parents.

Spokesman of the school, Rishi Khanna, said: “We have issued a notice to the teacher and asked her to give an explanation. If her answer is not found satisfactory, she will be dismissed. Physical assault on students is strictly prohibited in the school.” In her complaint, the girl’s mother claimed that other students of the class were traumatized and her daughter was also in pain since the incident took place.

The complainant said she sent her daughter again to the school on Saturday but the school administration informed her that her daughter was complaining of headache and she should take the girl home.

“I reported the incident to school authorities but they took no action,” she informed cops.

Investigating officer in the case, sub-inspector Baleshwar Prasad, said an FIR had been lodged and statements of the accused teacher and the complainant would be recorded on Tuesday.

Title: Jaipur Literature Festival: Overwhelmed, but a tad intimidating for a first-time speaker
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Visitors at Diggi Palace, the venue of Jaipur Literature Festival, in the city on Monday

Unless you see it with your own eyes, the scale and magnitude of Jaipur Literature Festival is quite difficult to imagine. As a first-time author, I had the good fortune of being invited to speak at this prestigious event, considered the Mecca of all literature festivals. And I was overwhelmed.

Held at the Diggi Palace Hotel , and we hear for the last time before it moves to another venue, it’s a festival in every sense. The dinner on the opening night itself, held at the Rambagh Palace, was itself quite a grand spectacle and a harbinger of the things to come. Food of all types and suited for different palates was there. But what attracted my attention were the traditional Rajasthani food counters. One had women making different types of rotis (the bajra roti turned out to be everyone’s favourite) on chulhas, the traditional Indian stove made of mud. Another was a chutney counter where men with stylish moustaches ground various spices and herbs on a mortar and pestle and gave you the tangy and spicy flavours of Rajputana. Everything about it was royal. And why not, after all it was held at the palace of the former royals of Jaipur.

But for me, it was a tad overwhelming too. Every attendee there was a somebody. And I had so many fanboy moments, seeing some of my favourite authors and celebrities for the first time in real life. But thankfully, I bumped into award-winning author Annie Zaidi who turned out to be an amazingly down-to-earth and forward-looking person. I met Prof Anisur Rahman of Jamia Millia Islamia who is one of the key figures of Rekhta Foundation. I also met historian S Irfan Habib, publisher Atiya Zaidi and author and translator Dr Rakshanda Jalil. Together, they became my comfort zone.

The following morning, on January 23, the festival officially opened. My session was from 12.30pm-1.30pm at the front lawn. I was invited to speak on Mughal Emperor Akbar due to the fact that I wrote a biography of the emperor, which came out in October last year. My co-panellist was historian Supriya Gandhi who teaches at Yale and who has recently authored a biography of Mughal prince Dara Shukoh. We both were to be in conversation with festival co-director and celebrated author, William Dalrymple.

I thanked my stars for being on a panel moderated by William, but I was also nervous because, well, it’s supposed to be a big thing at a big venue. William made me feel very comfortable, and eventually, I lost my stage fright. It also helped that Supriya Gandhi turned out to be a warm and friendly person while being such a formidable historian. Our conversation before the event had steadied my nerves quite a bit, so the conversation on stage went quite well.

The session was called ‘Akbar and Dara’ and was a thorough discussion on the relevance of the Mughals and why they are so reviled today. Supriya outlined Dara’s princely exploits and his wish to be a model sovereign. I spoke about how our understanding of the past is shaped by our present and that brings in biases. That explains why a BJP spokesperson had equated Akbar with Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler. That also explains why the term ‘secular’ is often used retrospectively to describe these two Mughals.

We discussed all this and more and the audience received it favourably. During the Q&A session that followed, a young woman asked Supriya if she would ever consider joining politics (she’s the daughter of Rajmohan Gandhi). Supriya said that she does academic interventions with her scholarship but it’s tough for people with her surname to be in politics in India today. Her response was cheered by all and sundry.

The rest of the day I hopped different venues to catch different sessions. I also managed to sign quite a few copies at the JLF bookstore there. The masala chai served on kulhads at the venue were quite something.

But despite all the charms of JLF, I was there only for the first day. I returned to Delhi on January 24, carrying back tonnes of cherishable memories, and the hope to be back.

Title: Government in no position to bail out stressed banking sector, says Abhijit Banerjee
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nobel economics laureate Abhijit Banerjee during a session at Jaipur Literature Festival on Monday

Arguing against the belief that authoritarian regimes are better positioned to drive economic growth and deliver on promises, Nobel economics laureate Abhijit Banerjee said the success of China or Singapore owes much more to the decentralisation of power than otherwise.

Speaking at the Jaipur Literature Festival (JLF), the India-born American economist said, “You can easily argue that Singapore had a successful dictator and can easily come back and talk about Zimbabwe. We can talk about this ad nauseum… At some level authority is an illusion.”

To the TOI journalist’s question as to what are the stress points of the economy, the MIT economist, who with his wife Esther Duflo and Harvard professor Michael Kremer jointly won the 2019 Nobel Economics prize, said, “We also know that due to a demand deficit in the economy, cars and two-wheelers are not selling, and those things are signs of a general fact that people lack confidence that the economy is going to grow fast so they are holding back, they are not spending.”

While he said that some economic indicators in recent months have shown signs of revival, it is not to easy to reboot the economy quickly.

“We are in a deep cycle. It will take some time to fix things, particularly the banking sector. We don’t have the money to do what China did which was to put the money in the banking sector, write off the loans. We cannot really afford that right now,” he said.

The author of “Good Economics for Hard Times” said that the slowdown in the economy will also adversely impact poverty alleviation in the country as urban and rural sectors are interdependent.

“Poverty alleviation has been happening mostly on the strength of the fact that urban sector creates low skill jobs, and a lot of rural sector works in the urban sector and sends money back. That's the peak source of transmission of growth from urban sector to rural sector. And as soon as the urban sector slows down the rural sector, the people in construction work don't have as many jobs. All of that will feed back on the rural sector,” said Banerjee.

Growing cynicism of the government is also not good for the country, Banerjee said explaining why this will not help people in electing the people on merits.

Referring to one of his projects in Uttar Pradesh covering 200 villages some years ago, he said, "As part of the experiment, we told the people to vote on development issues and not on caste lines. That was the message delivered through a set of puppet shows, posters and songs. We did not talk about who to vote for; all we said was vote well. We found that 10% people were less likely to vote on caste lines."

He said excessive cynicism pf the politicians will force people to lose trust in them even though all of them are not corrupt. Banerjee said if people believe that all the politicians are corrupt then they will fall into the same trap of casteism because a known candidate from the community will be preferred one even if he does not deserve that trust on merit.

Title: Oppo, IIT-Hyderabad sign MoU to develop AI for smartphones
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Premium global smartphone brand OPPO has signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) to collaborate with the Indian Institute of Technology , Hyderabad ( IIT-H ), to promote research in the field of science and technology.

The MoU will facilitate the exchange of ideas and state-of-the-art research in advanced and emerging technologies. It envisages joint research on multiple projects over a period of two years for the development of new technologies in areas specific to camera and image processing, battery, 5G networks, system performance and Artificial Intelligence (AI), among other areas.

“We will carry out research on computer vision and AI to make phones smarter. Our studies will try to address issues like blurring effect to ensure that good quality pictures can be taken even when the lens is zoomed in or see how the handset works when connected to 5G network,” said Krishna Mohan, a professor from IIT-H, who will be in the research team.

The researchers said that the partnership is aimed at developing solutions and bridging the gap between academic excellence and business requirements as well as to help create an industry-ready workforce.

“IIT-H is known for excellent work in the field of science and technology. Our collaboration is in line with our vision to enhance R&D and innovation capabilities at OPPO India as we continue our endeavor to build localised solutions for the Indian market,” said Tasleem Arif, vice-president and R&D head, OPPO India.

“This collaboration with OPPO will help in the development of indigenous solutions to cater to the dynamic needs of the Indian consumers,” Sumohana S Channappayya, dean (R&D), IIT-H.

Title: Six more arrested in Kattakada murder case
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Police have arrested six more alleged land mafia members for the murder of Sangeeth, 37, of Kattakkada. The six were identified as Linu, 30, of Kuzhivila Veedu, Kollamkonam near Peyyad; Mithun, 25, of Koovalassery near Maranalloor; Stalin John alias Saju, 48, of Thoongampara near Maranalloor; Uthaman alias Manikandan, 34, of Keezhumachel near Ambalathinkala; Lal Kumar alias Unni of Chemboor near Ottasekharamangalam; and, Vineesh alias Thenga Aneesh, 26 of Vellangal near Ottasekharamangalam.

Vijin, 24, who operated the earthmover which was used to fatally injure Sangeeth was arrested earlier and remanded into judicial custody on Saturday. One more accused, identified as Baiju, is still absconding. The accused were presented in court on Monday evening and subsequently remanded into judicial custody.

Speaking at a news conference at Kattakkada on Monday evening, Thiruvananthapuram Rural SP B Asokan said that while Vijin, Linu, Saju, Uthaman, Mithun and Baiju were present at the crime scene, Lal Kumar and Vineesh were arrested for aiding the accused. “A probe is on to track down Baiju. Investigations have revealed that both the tipper and earthmover hit Sangeeth. The accused revealed that they killed Sangeeth after he confronted them and warned them of imminent police action. Fearing arrest and confiscation of their vehicles, they tried to flee. Sangeeth was murdered as he had blocked their path. The tipper first hit him but he stood his ground. The earthmover’s rear bucket was then used to crush Sangeeth against the compound wall,” he said.

The tipper, which was driven by Linu, is owned by Uthaman. Vijin operated the earthmover which is owned by Saju.

Nedumangad DSP Stuart Keeler said the postmortem report revealed multiple injuries to Sangeeth’s ribs and head. “Three ribs on both sides of his body had multiple fractures which were caused when he was crushed between the earthmover and the compound wall,” the DSP said.

SP Asokan said that a probe, by DSP Keeler, will also go into negligence on the part of the police, who had allegedly arrived more than an hour after Sangeeth had alerted them. “The Nedumangad DSP is already probing the alleged apathy. Strict action will be taken against officers who were on duty if the report confirms any sort of passivity. The gang had moved around five loads of earth on the same day, ahead of the murder. A truck owned by Saju had been confiscated by SHO Bijukumar in December for mining without a permit. They will also be booked for theft, along with murder,” he said.

The JCB which was traced to Saju’s old stone quarry at Kuzhalar near Mulayamkodu, Kattakkada and the tipper which was found inside a cement brick factory at Mepala in Tamil Nadu have been confiscated. Finger print and scientific analyses revealed that both vehicles were used to to hit Sangeeth. Lal Kumar and Vineesh arranged the hideouts for the vehicles and also booked the lodge rooms at Thriparappu where Uthaman, Linu and Midhun stayed after the crime.

Title: CM seeks probe, compensation
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan has sent another missive to external affairs minister S Jaishankar to persuade Nepal government ‘to order a thorough inquiry ’ into the tragic incident which killed eight tourists from Kerala and ‘to provide a suitable monetary compensation to the families of the victims’.

The CM had sent a letter in this regard to the Union minister on January 20. “It is now reported that the deaths have happened due to malfunctioning of equipment in the room where these persons were staying. Their untimely death has been a severe blow to their families. Prima facie, it is clear that there has been negligence on the part of the service providers and there appears to be failure of regulatory mechanisms which ought to have been in place,” the CM in his letter sent on Sunday.

Meanwhile, tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran said on Monday that the attitude of the Indian embassy in Nepal and the management of the resort where the ill-fated holiday team from Kerala stayed was ‘shocking and very disturbing’.

“The attitude of the Nepal government too has been very disturbing. The government (Nepal) hasn’t started any probe into this tragedy and the resort management has not even considered about compensating the families of victims,” the minister told reporters here on Monday. What was even more disturbing was the stand taken by the Indian embassy in Nepal which wasn’t ready to bear the expenses of transporting the mortal remains, he said.

Citing the Nepal tragedy and the recent Alappuzha houseboat accident, Kadakampally stressed the need for a proper regulatory mechanism.

Title: Every effort on climate change counts
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

UN Goodwill Ambassador Dia Mirza

Climate emergency was one of the inaugural sessions of the last day of the Jaipur Literature Festival which touched upon some important issues, including that climate change is a reality and human induced environmental change.

The session had a panelists comprising of author Shubhangi Swarup, United Nations representative Renata Dessallien, reformist Sonam Wangchuk , Chief Executive at Aga Khan Rural Support Programme Apoorva Oza, novelist Namita Waikar and UN Goodwill Ambassador Dia Mirza in conversation with moderator Samir Saran.

While Mirza was visibly emotional on the dias and could not hold back her tears over a personal grief, the other panelist spoke at length about the reality of climate change. “The seriousness of climate change is too important for it to be not believed and though UN is not a global police, we try to bring the nations together to address this issue but it appears that we are failing miserably. We are getting to the point that the scientists are telling us that it might actually be too late. We are also a long way away from reducing human induced climate change”, said Dessallien.

The panelist also lamented that political borders are ‘ridiculous’ and there is ‘unbearable inequality’ in this world today which also lends to climate change. Environmental representation was also a topic which was talked about during the session.

“We should have seats reserved for ‘nature representatives’ in the parliament and a look at our education system also needs to be taken as at present, though the system teaches about the deforestation, it does not teach the other way around,” added Wangchuk.

The panelists also emphasised on the fact that every small effort to curb climate change counts which has to be done continuously along with the fact that ancient wisdom and practices go a long way in teaching and helping to prevent climate change.

Title: Adapt & reform: The guide to climate-change survival
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Navroz Dubash

The fact that this year’s Jaipur Literature Festival had three panels on or around climate change demonstrates how this issue has finally begun to preoccupy everyone, the public and governments included. Now, however, comes the hard part – doing something about it. Because, civilisation now comes with a sell-by date.

In the session, ‘Uninhabitable Earth’, on day four of JLF, panelists spoke about the policy, politics and psychology of climate change. “We’re all living in unprecedented times. For as long as humans have walked the earth, the planet has never been as warm as it is today,” revealed David Wallace-Wells , author of a work (‘Uninhabitable Earth’) that has injected urgency into the conversation on climate change. “It’s like we’ve landed on a new planet, with a new climate.”

In other words, humans must accept that much of the life of old can no longer be saved, and that a new world would have to rise from the ashes of the old – literally, in the case of Australia. “We need to have a sense of urgency but our actions shouldn’t result in a global, North-South blame game.”

According to Navroz Dubash , a professor at the Centre for Policy Research who has researched and written extensively on climate change, what is different today is the pace and scale of the changes, which very few had predicted. “We have to think of development in the context of a warming world,” he informed.

Of course, climate change is also impacting our psyches; some of us would rather not think about it. “There is a paralysis at the level of policy makers and citizens. And there’s also a defensive pushback, where people are saying, ‘It’s not a problem of our making, we don’t have to deal with it’,” explained Wallace-Wells, who admitted he’s happy to be alarmist.

“We need to focus not on climate denial but on climate complacency. I woke up to this issue out of fear, and we can use this language to talk about climate change.”

Yet, hope floats. Through its wind farms, Texas, a traditionally conservative state, is playing its part in promoting sustainable initiatives. “There has to be innovation, in how people move and how they live,” shared Marcus Moench, who has for 38 years spoken and written on adaptability to climate change.

It is, stressed Wallace-Wells, about making the right choices today, so that future generations can live in a world that’s more inhabitable than the one we are leaving behind. “We’re at a consequential hinge point in humanity, and we must take dramatic action both in terms of decarbonisation and creating a resilient social infrastructure.”

It is also about encouraging behavioural change, at the level of individuals and, also, of institutions. “It’s not about changing the trajectory of development, it’s about a deeper change; how we live, what our footprint is,” maintained Moench. Maybe we could start by handing over charge to women. For, as Moench asked: What has an all-male dialogue achieved in the last four decades?

Title: Coronavirus in India: Coronavirus pushes up demand for N95 face masks from India
Content:
People wearing masks as a preventive measure at Incheon airport in South Korea. Due to the outbreak of coronav... Read More

CHENNAI/MUMBAI: The demand for N95 masks in China, where people continue to walk with the nose and mouth covered to protect themselves against the coronavirus , is making Indian manufacturers and dealers of the special safety gear smile. It has also led to an increase in cost by at least 50%.With common disposable surgical masks considered ineffective against large, infectious particles, experts are asking people at risk — health workers and care givers — to use the N95. “But many in China are wearing it. N95 offers better protection by filtering out small particles,” said Manoj Vakharia, treasurer of Scientific and Surgical Dealers and Manufacturers Association (SIDMA). “Now, instead of importing from China, many dealers here are exporting them to that country.”With China limiting exports, many Asian countries are now approaching Indian dealers. “We are sending boxes of masks we bought from China. Apart from this we are procuring fresh ones directly from manufacturers here,” said Anil Gupta of Mumbai-based Avishankar International Private Limited.On Monday, several Indian manufacturers hiked prices. “Dealers here used to buy N95 masks at Rs 25 a piece. Now, it is at least Rs 38. Some other varieties such as N95plus are sold at a much higher price. Manufacturers are also demanding that we pay 100% money in advance,” said Chennai-based J Jayaseelan, chairman of Indian Drug Manufacturers Association.Corporates placing orders have just two demands — the masks should be National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health-certified and delivered in a week. Dealers say this may not be possible as Indian manufacturing units don’t have large capacities. “China is the largest manufacturer of masks and India would be 4% - 5% of it. This is first time we are getting orders from there…,” said Nikunj Kedia, director, Bellcross Industries. “A mask costing Rs 25-Rs 30 a unit is being exported at Rs 60-Rs 70 a unit,” he said. His company manufactures wide range of disposables such as disposable cap, gloves, masks and surgical drapes, among others.Shiv Kumar Mangal, CEO of Faridabad-headquartered Manglam Medikits which has received orders from Hong Kong and Europe, said, “There is a bit of panic due to which existing supplies are being bought even at higher prices.”Customers are not hesitating to order the consignment via air , he said. “We have flown a couple of consignments to Hong Kong.”

Title: A new panel to overlook Sita Mata temple construction: Kamal Nath
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Kamal Nath

BHOPAL: Chief minister Kamal Nath, on Monday, reiterated his government’s commitment to build a grand ‘Sita Mata Temple’ in Sri Lanka.

Nath said, a committee will be set up soon to finalise the plan. “Madhya Pradesh government is committed to construct a grand temple of Sita Mata in Sri Lanka. A committee comprising officers of MP and Sri Lankan government will be constituted soon for construction of the grand temple in Sri Lanka. The committee will also include members of Maha Bodhi society,” said Nath talking to a delegation of Maha Bodhi society led president Banagla Uptisa, at Mantralaya on Monday. State minister for public relations PC Sharma, who had recently visited the temple site in Sri Lanka, was also present.

Nath said that the committee will constantly monitor the construction of the temple to stick to the stipulated time. “The design of the temple and necessary funds required for the project should be made available in the current fiscal year to build the temple at the earliest possible,” said the CM.

Nath also directed the officials to prepare a plan for the construction of Boddh museum, study and training centre of international standard in Sanchi. He said allocation of fund and land for the museum, study and training centre will be done forthwith.

“An action plan be prepared to finalise the museum project. The president of Maha Bodhi Society, several companies of Japan and other countries, apart from institutions, have offered financial assistance for the construction of various projects in Sanchi,” he said.

Title: Delhi voters hold town halls to demand better air
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

The campaign aims to mobilise people to push political parties beyond manifesto promises.

NEW DELHI: Ahead of the February 8 elections, hundreds of people gathered in various parts of the capital on Monday to demand action for clean air from political representatives.

Under the banner of NGO Chintan’s Safai Sena and #DilliDhadakneDo by My Right to Breathe, a civil society movement, people from several assembly constituencies have started a series of town halls to make political parties accountable. On Monday, Jangpura, Matia Mahal, Badli, Karawal Nagar, RK Puram and Delhi Cantonment were covered and each town hall was attended by representatives of AAP, BJP and Congress.

The campaign aims to mobilise people to push political parties beyond manifesto promises. The events at RK Puram, Karawal Nagar and Delhi Cantonment were followed by a march and a rally of around 300 e-rickshaws for cleaner technologies.

Chitra Mukherjee, head of programmes and operations at Chintan, said they had been receiving positive responses from the parties. At Jangpura, sitting AAP MLA Praveen Kumar promised, “We will strengthen public transport more. We also need to clamp down further on garbage burning.”

Vighnesh Jha of Federation of Rickshaw Puller Association said at Karawal Nagar, “We are most exposed to air pollution and urge our members to vote for those who will work to improve Delhi’s air.” Rekha Jhingan of NGO Sahaj Sambhav said at Delhi Cantonment, “Women, especially young mothers like me, demand parties take concrete steps to safeguard the health of younger generations.”

Title: Gajendra Singh Shekhawat does a U-turn, targets AAP on water quality
Content:
Gajendra Singh Shekhawat

NEW DELHI: Union water resources minister Gajendra Singh Shekhawat mocked Delhi’s deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia for giving reasons why people get bad quality water in the capital.In a tweet, Shekhawat tagged a video in which Sisodia was seen explaining why people get dirty water when they switch on booster motors, particularly during the ‘no-supply’ period. “When questions relating to bad quality water were asked to the education minister, he started referring to physics. This is beyond anyone’s understanding. He started talking about the timing of switching on booster motors and the science of drawing water when he was confronted with questions. The CM had promised to ensure supply of good quality water within a year of coming to power,” Shekhawat tweeted.In September, he had claimed that Delhi’s water quality was better than European standards, which had kicked off a controversy within Delhi BJP. CM Arvind Kejriwal, who is also the DJB chief, had welcomed the statement. But in November, Union consumer affairs minister Ram Vilas Paswan had announced the test results of water samples collected from 21 cities which showed that Delhi’s piped water was the worst on quality parameters. “Now people of Delhi also accept that the water supplied by DJB is unsafe for drinking...I wish that every household receives water by 2024 under Jal Jeevan Mission, which complies with BIS norms,” Paswan said.

Title: St Thomas school pupil bags Bal Shakti Puraskar
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Siddharth Kumar Gopal is on cloud nine! Following his successes at the National Science Olympiad, the Geo Genius Geography Olympiad and the Raman Young Science Innovator Awards last year, the 11-year-old was recently conferred the Pradhan Mantri Rashtriya Bal Shakti Puraskar by the women and child development ministry. He received the award from President Ram Nath Kovind at an event held at the Rashtrapati Bhavan on Wednesday.

Siddharth also met Prime Minister Narendra Modi on January 24 and attended the Republic Day parade as a special guest.

“It was almost a dream come true for me and my family. I have always watched the Republic Day parade on television, but never did I expect to view everybody and everything from close quarters. This was my lucky break. The speeches of President Kovind, PM Modi and minister for women and child development Smriti Irani were inspiring,” said Siddharth.

Siddharth, the eldest son of Dr Kumar Gopal and Vandana Rajendran of Kaithamukku, is a Class VI student of St Thomas Residential School here.
