As many as 50 children aged between 5 and 18 were awarded the Bal Shakti Puraskar, instituted to recognise children with exceptional abilities and outstanding achievements in the fields of innovation, scholastic achievement, social service, art and culture and sports.

From Kerala, Richard Joseph of Kochi also bagged the award, carrying a purse of Rs 1 lakh, a tablet, a medal and a citation.

“Siddharth started attending competitive examinations at the age of five. We are thankful to the principal and teachers at STRS who have been an immense support,” said Vandana.

Title: Oppn to corner govt in House

He said Congress will coordinate with other opposition parties and MLAs for effective “floor management” in order to demand detailed discussions on the issues listed above. tnn

Title: Coronavirus in India: Coronavirus pushes up demand for N95 face masks from India
Content:
People wearing masks as a preventive measure at Incheon airport in South Korea. Due to the outbreak of coronav... Read More

CHENNAI/MUMBAI: The demand for N95 masks in China, where people continue to walk with the nose and mouth covered to protect themselves against the coronavirus , is making Indian manufacturers and dealers of the special safety gear smile. It has also led to an increase in cost by at least 50%.With common disposable surgical masks considered ineffective against large, infectious particles, experts are asking people at risk — health workers and care givers — to use the N95. “But many in China are wearing it. N95 offers better protection by filtering out small particles,” said Manoj Vakharia, treasurer of Scientific and Surgical Dealers and Manufacturers Association (SIDMA). “Now, instead of importing from China, many dealers here are exporting them to that country.”With China limiting exports, many Asian countries are now approaching Indian dealers. “We are sending boxes of masks we bought from China. Apart from this we are procuring fresh ones directly from manufacturers here,” said Anil Gupta of Mumbai-based Avishankar International Private Limited.On Monday, several Indian manufacturers hiked prices. “Dealers here used to buy N95 masks at Rs 25 a piece. Now, it is at least Rs 38. Some other varieties such as N95plus are sold at a much higher price. Manufacturers are also demanding that we pay 100% money in advance,” said Chennai-based J Jayaseelan, chairman of Indian Drug Manufacturers Association.Corporates placing orders have just two demands — the masks should be National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health-certified and delivered in a week. Dealers say this may not be possible as Indian manufacturing units don’t have large capacities. “China is the largest manufacturer of masks and India would be 4% - 5% of it. This is first time we are getting orders from there…,” said Nikunj Kedia, director, Bellcross Industries. “A mask costing Rs 25-Rs 30 a unit is being exported at Rs 60-Rs 70 a unit,” he said. His company manufactures wide range of disposables such as disposable cap, gloves, masks and surgical drapes, among others.Shiv Kumar Mangal, CEO of Faridabad-headquartered Manglam Medikits which has received orders from Hong Kong and Europe, said, “There is a bit of panic due to which existing supplies are being bought even at higher prices.”Customers are not hesitating to order the consignment via air , he said. “We have flown a couple of consignments to Hong Kong.”

Title: Live near Defence Expo venue? Get a pass to enter home
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Preparations for Defence Expo in progress at Vrindavan Yojana

LUCKNOW: Residents living within 1km radius of sector-15, Vrindavan Yojana , will have to register themselves at their local police outpost for obtaining access cards to enter the locality.

The drill is being followed due to safety precautions required for the 11th edition of Defence Expo which will be held in the city for the first time from February 5-8.

Preparations for the mega event are on in full swing. The venue will be handed over to the ministry of defence on January 28, following which the 1km area will be sealed from February 1-10. While residents will have to obtain passes from the local outpost, visitors or guests invited for a wedding or other social functions will also have to get themselves registered and follow the drill.

The person hosting the function will have to first get permission from the administration and then get their number of guests registered with the local police outpost.

SHO of SGPGI and nodal in charge of the expo Anjani Pandey said that the verification process for the passes will begin soon.

“The process is underway and will begin a day or two ahead of the exhibition. Each and every resident will have to present their identification proof at the police outpost for verification and passes. Visitors will also have to follow the same for security purposes,” said Pandey.

For visitors to the expo, five entry-exit points will be paved where police personnel will be deployed. Entry for the public will be free of cost on February 8 and February 9.

Title: One more held in online fraud case
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Officers of the Cyber Crime police station arrested a 49-year-old man from Visakhapatnam in connection with an alleged case of online fraud and cheating of a businessman.

The accused has been identified as Kurmana Kameshwara Rao of Jalari Peta of Visakhapatnam. The prime accused in the cheating case, identified as Vadalamani Ravi Sankar, was arrested back in December 1, but Rao was on the run until he was tracked down by a team of officers led by Cyber Crime station house officer DSP Jeeji N on Friday. The accused was presented before the court and subsequently remanded into judicial custody on Monday.

According to an officer attached to the Cyber Crime police station, the investigation based on mobile tower location revealed that the accused was in Visakhapatnam.

“The complainant, who is the owner of Naveen Agencies in Alappuzha, noticed an online advertisement offering steel bars at low prices and approached the accused. He then placed an order worth Rs 9,80,425 after contacting prime accused Vadalamani Ravi Sankar. After receiving the money, Sankar sent contact numbers of Rao who was introduced as the driver of the truck carrying the load. But, the shipment failed to reach the complainant. The complainant then contacted Rao, who further demanded and took Rs 75,000 for fixing the damages of the truck and Rs 35,000 for treatment of the co-driver who had allegedly fallen to dengue. The complainant paid the money,” the officer said.

Even after several days of making the payment, the load failed to reach Alappuzha, prompting the businessman to file a complaint at the Cyber Crime station here.

The officer also said that probe is still on to track down others who are involved in the online scam. “Sankar was tracked down from his hideout near Nishita Complex, West Bengal, on December 1 and was subsequently presented to the court and remanded in judicial custody. Enquiry about Rao has also revealed that there were several other cases registered against him in various police stations of Vishakapatnam. We have also recovered bank account books, sim cards and phone, with details of transactions from the accused,” he said.

The team under DIG Sanjay Kumar Guruddin, led by DSP Jeeji N, also comprised of Cyber Crime inspector Roj R, sub-inspector Bijukumar, civil police officers Sabarinath and Sreeraj. They travelled to Visakhapatnam and made the arrest.

Title: All-woman crime investigation teams to come up in all ranges
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Giving thrust to more women-centric policing initiatives as part of observing 2020 as the year of women safety, state police chief Loknath Behera has asked all range DIGs to set up at least one all-women crime investigation wing and entrust them with investigation of some major crime cases, in which women victims are involved.

In his circular issued last Thursday to all the district police chiefs, range DIGs and zonal IGs, the state police chief asked the DIGs to draw a competent woman inspector from a unit in their range and form a team of women officers under the officer. They will be entrusted with some serious cases registered for atrocities against women and children in the jurisdiction. “According to the workload, the size of a range team should be fixed. DIG shall be the motivator and supervisor of the team. Continuous training for them will be required and should be ensured by the DIG concerned,” the circular said. For such teams, the training will be provided either at the Kerala Police Academy at Thrissur or police training college in the capital.

A state-level committee led by ADGP (training) B Sandhya has also been set up to supervise all women-police related projects and initiatives. The team also includes SP (ICT) Divya V Gopinath, DCP (Kochi) R Poonguzhali, commandant (women’s battalion) D Shilpa and ASP (Shanghumugham) Aishwarya Dongre. The committee has been asked to monitor and supervise all programs and furnish a monthly progress report to the state police chief.

As the police also feels that visibility of women police in public spaces will have a telling effect on the safety of women, a team of two women police officers should visit busy public spaces where there is presence of women, like bus stops, bus stands, market places, school and college premises etc., four times in the day especially in the morning and evening hours. In the night, such visits should be accompanied by one male police officer too, the circular said. The team should interact with school and college girls about sexual harassment, stalking or threatening, so as to ensure their safety and instil confidence in them. A group of 30 women officers should be trained and deployed for each district, the police chief instructed.

Title: Delhi elections 2020: Fewer aspiring MLAs have gone to college
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: The candidates fielded by the three major political parties for the February 8 polls may be richer in terms of wealth compared with the 2015 assembly elections, but they are certainly poorer when it comes to education. In 2015, as many as 48 of the 70 candidates fielded by AAP had a graduation degree or higher. This time, the number of such candidates has come down to 39. Also, 31 AAP candidates were graduates and 17 had a Master’s degree in the previous election. This time, there are 20 graduate candidates and 19 post-graduates.Similarly, the number of BJP candidates who are graduates or have a higher qualification has come down from 47 to 39. In 2015, there were 28 graduates among BJP candidates, apart from 14 who had a post-graduation degree. Five were PhD holders. This time, there are 27 graduates and 12 Master’s degree holders among the candidates fielded by BJP and its allies LJP and JD(U).Complete Coverage on Delhi ElectionsCongress, however, has bucked the trend. The number of its candidates and those of its ally, Rashtriya Janata Dal , who are graduates or higher, is 45 against 39 in 2015. They include 26 graduates, 19 with a Master’s degree and four PhD holders. In 2015, Congress had fielded 28 graduates, nine PG degree holders and two who had PhD.On the other hand, the number of AAP candidates who have studied up to Class X or less has gone up from eight to 12. The number of XIIth pass candidates has gone up from 13 to 19. In case of BJP, the number of candidates who have studied up to Class Xth or less has gone down from 18 in 2015 to 11. But number of Class XIIth pass candidates has gone up from four to 18. In case of Congress, the number has gone down from 20 to nine in the former case and is up from 11 to 15 in the latter.The information provided by candidates in their affidavits throws up some interesting facts. Humanities appears to be the stream of choice for most hopefuls. As many as 45 have a Bachelor of Arts degree. While most have opted for a “Pass” course, those who have done “Honours” have largely gone for political science.Commerce is the second most preferred stream with 13 candidates having a Bachelor of Commerce degree, followed by just six candidates who are science graduates and have done BSc. Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal and AAP chief spokesperson Saurabh Bharadwaj have engineering backgrounds.Law is another favourite subject. There are seven who have done Bachelor of Law (LLB) and four Master of Law (LLM). Nine candidates pursued graduation or post-graduation in different streams, but later went on to earn an LLB degree too. Among those who have a Master’s degree, most (20) have pursued humanities, followed by nine with a Master of Business Administration degree. Six candidates have completed MSc and three others MCom. Four PhD holders are in the fray this time compared with seven in 2015. There are also six doctors, including three with a Master of Surgery degree.The title of the most qualified candidate may go to Naresh Kumar (58) of Congress. Kumar, an advocate by profession and contesting for the Mundka seat, completed his graduation and Master’s from Meerut University in 1987. In 1991, he did his LLB from Delhi University and later pursued PhD in sociology from Chaudhary Charan Singh University, Meerut, in 2003. Kumar also holds a diploma in pharmacy and a postgraduate diploma in journalism.Interestingly, while the three richest candidates are not graduates and two are not even Class Xth pass, two of the poorest candidates have done Master’s.AAP’s Dharampal Lakra, (61), the richest candidate with assets worth over Rs 292 crore, has trained as a diesel mechanic from ITI Pusa, Delhi. Pramila Tokas, AAP candidate from RK Puram is the second richest candidate with assets worth Rs 80.8 crore and has passed Class XII. The third richest candidate with assets worth Rs 80 crore is Class VII pass. On the other hand, Rocky Tuseed, the Congress candidate from Rajinder Nagar is the poorest with assets worth Rs 55,574 and has done Master’s. Rakhi Bidlan, AAP candidate from Mangolpuri, is the third poorest with assets worth Rs 76,421 and has done Master’s in mass communication.

Title: Which other areas in Sec'bad are in need of improvement works?
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Secunderabad: With GHMC constructing eight FoBs in Secunderabad zone, TOI asked readers to suggest other areas that needed measures to reduce the traffic snarls

Secunderabad junctions are choking due to excess traffic and poor management. Every junction including Jubilee bus stop, Patny, Paradise and NTR statue need improvement works. The poor placement of bus bays, inaction on auto rickshaws parked illegally, unwanted speed breakers, lack of footpaths, complete absence of subways in the city, improper streetlights and dysfunctional signals and unclean urinals are just some of the issues that need to be tackled.

The GHMC and Secunderabad Cantonment Board needs to work together corporation to address these issues. There is a need for a complete overhaul of the road and sewage in the city. We need more public transport to bring down the traffic. Authorities and citizens need to work together to solve the civic issues in the city.

Deepesh Surana

The road from Yellareddyguda Saibaba temple cross road towards Anuraag Special school, Janapriya Silver Crest villas and Kapra lake is in very bad condition. Many school buses and ambulances pass through this road that is full of potholes. Is GHMC not responsible for the proper upkeep of roads. We will be highly grateful if the road is repaired. Hope GHMC wakes up and give instructions to the concerned officials to take up this issue at the earliest before any untoward accidents happen on the road.

Dakshina Murthy Shanker

The density of traffic is very high near Sangeet crossroads, Patny, Paradise and Chilakalguda junctions making it is difficult to cross the road. Invariably, women and senior citizens are seen taking help from police to cross the road. Due to continuous movement of vehicles throughout the day, people are constantly worried about crossing the road. Authorities must take up construction of skyways at these junctions on priority. Similarly, FoBs must be constructed at accident prone junctions at New Bhoiguda and Boats club junction. Authorities must conduct a survey and decide the exact spot for construction of skyways.

K.R.Srinivasan

It is indeed a great news that GHMC is planning to construct FOBs and skywalks for the convenience of the public. There are many roads which need this facility. Begumpet Khairatabad, Rajbhavan, Irraum Manzil, Punjagutta and Masab Tank road need improvement works. FoBs and footpaths are also needed in Basheerbagh and Himayat Nagar. Footpaths are being encroached and this needs to be addressed.

Dr GV Kumar

At Suchitra junction, pedestrians are facing lot of difficulties due to heavy traffic at junction point and needs FOB to mitigate public sufferings. Initiate action for a FOB at Suchitra junction early -- Simhadri Ch

Thank you for proposing a FOB at Neredmet cross. Much needed. Please consider a FOB on Karkhana road near Mcdonalds. Crossing that road is a suicide mission. @KTRTRS @CommissionrGHMC @greensainikpuri @molfe2000 -- Deepa Shailender

Title: IUML cadres join LDF’s human chain
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Kozhikode: Embarrassing the UDF leadership, a section of IUML workers participated in the human chain formed by the LDF against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ) on Republic Day.

To make matters worse for the UDF, the E K faction of the Sunnis, who are the traditional vote bank for the Front, also took part in the programme.

Prominent among the IUML cadres was K M Basheer, vice-president of the party’s Beypore mandalam. He told media persons on Monday that he joined the protest as the LDF was showing more sincerity in agitations.

Basheer said that the Left parties succeeded in understanding the importance of the issue and acted accordingly. The Congress thoroughly failed in this regard, he said.

He added that in the present scenario Congress cannot become an alternative to the BJP at the national level. A joint fight by the secular forces, including the Left, is the need of the hour. Basheer also praised chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan for leading the anti-CAA agitations. “The declaration the chief minister made that CAA will not be implemented in Kerala is a great relief for the Muslim community,” Basheer said, adding that KPCC president Mullappally Ramachandran is speaking in the language of an ordinary politician about a crucial issue.

E K group sources told TOI that they have announced that they would join anyone in the fight against the CAA.

The feeling that at least a section of the Muslim community is cozying up to the Left has given heartburn to the UDF leadership. There is already a buzz in the Muslim community that something is lacking in the UDF agitations against the CAA.

K Muraleedhran, MP, said the IUML cadres participating in the LDF programme is a serious issue. He said he had spoken to the opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala on the issue. “The programme UDF organised in Kozhikode last week was a grand success. We need more such programmes in future,” he said.

IUML has sought to downplay the development, saying that it is a non-issue and cautioning that such trivial controversies will only help the BJP.

In a statement issued here, IUML state general secretary K P A Majeed said it was the decision of the coordination committee of Muslim organizations that everyone should participate in common programmes against the CAA.

But it was difficult for the UDF to join the human chain because the programme was unilaterally announced by the LDF, Majeed said.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Rs 3 lakh can get you a doctorate without research
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Who says you need critical thinking and academic acumen to earn a PhD? You can order a doctorate with just a phone call. The cartels that employ ghost writers no more operate on the sly. They’ve set it up like restaurants – there’s a menu and what you pay depends on what you order.

Tamil Nadu produced the maximum number of PhDs in the country, 5,844, in 2018, according to All India Survey for Higher Education 2019. There is a renewed interest among faculty members to publish research papers and complete doctorates due to the Union HRD ministry’s decision to make PhD mandatory for the entry-level post of assistant professor from July 2021, and give more weightage for research work in National Institute Ranking Framework rankings and National Assessment and Accreditation Council ratings.

The spike in research interest has made the ground fertile for ghost writers and agents who have branded themselves consultancy services. Scholars and research guides TOI spoke to said they received calls from unknown people offering ‘help’ in doing research. TOI picked the trail of one such message to uncover how a racket has been functioning in a sophisticated but brazen manner.

Posing as a faculty member from a private engineering college, this correspondent called the agent. He promptly asked about the area of research and topic before quoting a price. He offered to do engineering research, analyse data and publish a paper in an annexure-1 journal for Rs 1.2 lakh. For converting research into an article and publishing it in the journal he quoted Rs 80,000.

“If you can do research and only need help in publication, it will cost Rs 45,000. But, your research should be complete research with analysis, data and graphics. You should take responsibility if the paper is rejected or needs clarification from journal editors,” he said.

Asked about outsourcing thesis work, the agent said, “If you have the literature review, research work, article, output and analysis, we will charge `65,000 to write the thesis. If you have nothing, then it would cost around Rs 3 lakh. We will do the research, get the article published and write the thesis.”

The agent said a team of professors does the research for money. His ‘agency’ is helping scholars across universities. “The rate will be finalised after seeing the university guidelines. We collect the highest rate for Anna University PhDs,” he said.

The payment is in installments. “We will collect registration fee initially and take full payment after the acceptance by the research journal. For example, we will take Rs 10,000 as initial payment for publication and update you about the research. You can make corrections. We will take the next installment after your corrections,” he said.

Faculty members TOI spoke to confirmed that outsourcing research work is a trend thriving in arts and science colleges, and technical colleges.

“It has become mandatory to publish research papers for increments. Journals take up to a year to accept an article or even to respond. So faculty members opt to publish research papers by paying money. When we pay money, even some of the listed journals respond within a day confirming publication without any proper peer review,” said a faculty member from an arts and science college in the city.

Professors from University of Madras said one of the reasons why such rackets flourish is because students without research aptitude enrolled for PhDs.

Professor M K Surappa, vice-chancellor of Anna University, said the practice was “unethical and devoid of all morality”. “Research is a passion and not a routine degree. This is perhaps one of the reasons why our country is not able to produce high quality research publications in sufficient numbers,” he said. To deter such PhDs, Anna University has introduced minimum eligibility marks in entrance exam for aspirants. This brought down the number of PhD candidates from 2,527 in 2018 to 908 in 2019.

University of Madras has introduced measures to enhance the quality of PhD thesis in the past two years. “All theses have to pass through a plagiarism detecting software. There is a new online system to trace the progress of research work very closely. A first year candidate has to present a paper in at least one national-level conference and in the second year one conference and one publication, and it continues for the third year also. If the candidate meets these requirements then he or she can prepare the thesis,” said P Duraisamy, vice-chancellor.

Title: 2000 homeguards stage protest, booked
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Homeguards stage protest on Monday

BHOPAL: Around 2,000 homeguards reached homeguard Lines near Police Control Room in Jehangirabad on Monday morning and staged a protest to press for their demands. Heavy police force was deployed in the area and barricading was done to divert the traffic. Senior officers, including DIG Irshad Wali and district collector Tarun Pithode, reached the spot and monitored the situation from control room.

After talks failed between the protestors and district administration and the former refused to withdraw their agitation, police filed FIRs against them for obstructing road traffic.

Several attempts made during the day by senior police officers to persuade the protesters, failed. The jawans did not even allow any senior homeguard official to enter the protest area. They were demanding that the word ‘volunteer’ be removed from their post and they should be provided the facilities given to state government employees. Jawans also demanded that the process of enrolment after every three years should be abolished and the mandatory medical examination by medical board after every 10 months be stopped. They also demanded that rotation system, which includes two months’ compulsory end to service after every 11 months, should also be stopped.

The protest ended around 7.30 pm when the senior homeguard officers called a 10-member delegation of protesters and counselled them to file a proper application, stating their demands so that higher authorities can look into the matter. The officers instructed the jawans to reach their respective duties on Tuesday without fail, else disciplinary action will be taken against them. The delegation handed over six memorandums to the officials, later the jawans dispersed.

Title: No reason to succumb to social media: Makarand Paranjpe
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Panelists during a session at the festival on Monday

The Jaipur Literature Festival 2020 ended with an uncertainty over the venue for the next year and the dates for the same which were announced previously are also likely to be changed.

The festival ended with a debate about whether the social media has divided the society or not with panelist comprising of senior journalists including Siddharth Varadarajan, Rana Ayyub, Faye D’Souza, Nilanjana Roy and others in conversation with Sonia Singh

“It is not social media but PM Narendra Modi who has divided the society. If a person is to be indentified with his clothes then how is social media playing a divisive factor. In fact we should this medium to fight those dividing the society,” said Varadarajan while disregarding that social media has divided society. Another panelist, giving an opposing view also said that social media is killing journalism.

“There is no reason to succumb to social media which can also be a great unifier. We are all unified in becoming so called addicts to this medium and but we can always choose,” said Jawahar Lal Nehru University profressor, Makarand Paranjpe .

While the debate touched over various pros and cons of the social media, the audience also pitched in with their views and talked about various aspects of this form of interaction which could both harm and benefit the society as a whole.

Title: Schoolboy falls unconscious at Republic Day parade, dies
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: A 12-year-old child, who refused to back out of a Republic Day parade despite being unwell, fell unconscious after the march past and died on the way to hospital.

Ayush Pandey studied in Class VII in a government school in Umaria’s Birsinghpour Palli town. The cause of death isn’t known, and may never be known because the doctors who declared Ayush dead did not inform police about the need for an autopsy. The child was cremated on Sunday night.

Police have found that Ayush was feeling unwell on Sunday morning but insisted on going to the event because he was the parade commander of his school. Ayush held himself together until the parade at the town stadium was over, and then collapsed, say sources.

His family took him to Shahdol district hospital, about 40km away, but he was declared dead on arrival. Police say the body was handed over to his parents without autopsy as no case was registered.

Shahdol civil surgeon Vikrant Baria said, “The child was dead when brought here from Umaria. The parents took away the body.” Asked if post-mortem was conducted, he said: “It was not done here. I am not aware if it was done in Umaria.”

Pali police station in-charge Rajesh Chand Mishra said, “We investigated the incident and found that the child was sick that day. Even his teachers asked him not to participate in the parade, but since he had prepared for it, he insisted. After participating, he fell unconscious and was taken to Shahdol by his parents, but since the autopsy wasn’t done, no case has been registered.” Police will take action if they get a complaint, he added.

Title: Chennai: 19 scholars under him, ex-VC broke Anna University rules
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Anna University

CHENNAI: Anna University regulations in 2013 allowed a professor to guide up to 12 research scholars at a time (the number is 11 now). But M Rajaram guided 19 research scholars simultaneously from 2013 to 2016 when he was holding office as vice-chancellor, according to a reply to an RTI query .

Anna University’s PhD regulations do not bar a vice-chancellor from guiding research students, but there is conflict of interest, say academicians. The vice-chancellor chooses the examiners to evaluate thesis and conduct viva-voce for doctoral candidates.

This is just the tip of the iceberg, say professors, asking how it’s possible to guide 19 research scholars while holding a top academic post in a university?

“It is unethical to guide research scholars after becoming a vice-chancellor. Besides, he wouldn’t have time to guide so many research scholars while heading a large technical university,” said E Balagurusamy, former vice-chancellor, Anna University.

Professor Rajaram denied all allegations. “There is no bar on a vice-chancellor guiding researchers. I have not taken any student after becoming vice-chancellor. All my PhD students completed research after proper publication,” Rajaram told TOI. He said some of his students had published papers in top journals like IEEE.

On allegations that he guided scholars in other streams such as computer science engineering and held a closed viva-voce for his students, Rajaram said, “As a professor in electrical and electronics engineering, I can guide students from all circuit branches. My students have defended their thesis in public viva voce and university has records for attendance of public.”

But his critics are not convinced. They say even a full-time research guide cannot supervise more than 10 scholars. According to UGC’s shodhganga website, Rajaram conducted viva voce for 43 students as guide between 2013 and 2019. The data shows Rajaram had more than 12 Anna University research scholars, which is a violation of university rules.

Raising doubts about the research data and originality of the theses, several professors demanded a committee be set up to investigate the issue.

“If there is sufficient proof and evidence of plagiarism, fake data in theses submitted by his research scholars, the university will initiate action,” said M K Surappa, vice-chancellor of Anna University.

Title: Polythene banned in 21 UP districts on Ganga Yatra route
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Local bodies have also been directed to put in place permanent/temporary measures to stop discharge of sewage ... Read More

LUCKNOW: While chief minister Yogi Adityanath kicked off the Ganga Yatra on Monday, the state urban development department has pushed in a slew of measures, including total ban on the use of polythene in local bodies through which the yatra would pass.

As per the directive issued by the department, Ganga Yatra would cover 21 local bodies in 26 districts. These would include three municipal corporations, 12 nagar palika parishad and six nagar panchayats.

The notification issued by principal secretary, urban development, Manoj Kumar Singh directed all local bodies to ensure the ban on use of plastics. Directives have been issued to ensure strict enforcement of ban on single use plastics, Singh told TOI.

“The idea is to ensure that no plastic flows into the Ganga during the yatra,” said a senior official in the urban development department. Ganga Yatra would be kicked off simultaneously from Gram Sabalgarh in Bijnor and village Kondhara Naubrar in Ballia, close to Bihar border.

The government had issued a notification in July 2018 banning use of polythene with thickness less than 50 micron. The ban on polythene comes after the department directed local bodies to be made open defecation free (ODF) during the course of yatra which would cover 205km every day. Local bodies have also been directed to put in place permanent/temporary measures to stop discharge of sewage and drain water into the Ganga. At the same time, management of solid waste will also have to be ensured till the conclusion of Ganga Yatra on January 31. Also, local bodies will have to identify suitable points where cultural programmes could be organised during the five days.

Title: Shared-auto scheme: Two mobility corridors mooted
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Two shared-auto mobility corridors are being considered by Smart City Thiruvananthapuram Ltd (SCTL) ahead of the launch of the city’s first shared-auto scheme under the Smart City project.

As many as 15 e-rickshaws will ply to and fro along the Thampanoor-Overbridge-Secretariat-Legislative Assembly-Museum-Public Office-Manaveeyam stretch and Thampanoor-Overbridge-Gandhi Park-Pazhavangadi-Sree Padmanabha Swamy Temple stretch. The corridors are being analysed for possible demand for commute from railway station and bus stand to offices and places of tourist attraction and religious significance.

The city corporation has submitted a list of 14 women licence-holders to be part of the e-rickshaw scheme. Both e-autos and e-rickshaws will be driven by women beneficiaries.

The corporation and SCTL have also reserved one slot for a transgender beneficiary. Vanchiyur P Babu, chairman, development standing committee, said that the corporation is yet to receive any application from transgender persons for the e-rickshaw scheme. He said that the slot will be left open for transgender beneficiary. Babu also added that the initial list was compiled from applications received from nine wards and more applications are being submitted from other wards.

The e-rickshaw with four seats will have two passengers on each side, sitting face-to-face. The minimum rate has been tentatively fixed at Rs 10. The e-rickshaws will be rolled out with a special colour theme in sync with the city’s heritage and history. The design of the theme is expected to be finalized within a week. E-rickshaws will be brought to the city from the showroom in Kollam. The shared auto scheme is expected to be implemented in wards under coming under ‘area-based development’ (ABD) to ensure connectivity between minimum distance points within central wards.

SCTL has mandated that e-auto and e-rickshaw shall be operated with Lithium battery and that charging cable should be fast-charging enabled. Besides, it should have real time GPS tracking system with emergency request buttons. The officials said that the vendors will be tasked with the responsibility of ensuring additional features in vehicles procured through ‘Government e Marketplace’ (GeM).

SCTL is planning to procure e-autos from Kerala Automobiles Ltd. The vehicles should also have the facility for generating printed bills for commuters for greater transparency and acceptance. The supplier will be responsible for registration of vehicles with the Kerala motor vehicles department. E-rickshaws are expected to ply at a speed below 35km/h while e-autos can move at a speed above 35 km/h.

The ownership of vehicles will rest with SCTL for the first one year and after that it will be transferred to respective beneficiaries. E-autos will ply within the limits of wards under ABD, but relaxations will be made for plying outside ABD areas as well.

Title: Muneer: Won’t act against IUML workers
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Kozhikode: IUML leader and deputy leader of opposition in the assembly M K Muneer said there was no need for IUML to take action against party workers for attending the anti-CAA human chain organized by the LDF on Sunday.

Muneer said on Monday that though the IUML had decided not to participate in the programme, it had not issued any directions asking people not to participate in the programme in their individual capacity.

“Some people might have participated in it in their individual capacity. Those who are part of religious organizations have dual membership making them members of both IUML and the organisation concerned. For example, Kerala Nadvathul Mujahideen (KNM) had decided to participate in the human chain and many IUML workers are part of the organization,” he said.

Muneer said that Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad will take part in the anti-CAA protest to be held at Kozhikode Beach at 3pm on Friday.

Title: Chackai flyover opened for one-way traffic
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Motorists were in for a Republic Day surprise when the Chackai flyover was opened for one-way traffic on Sunday morning. The National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) opened the stretch to facilitate movement of vehicles in the Kovalam-to-Kazhakoottam direction.

Vehicles can now enter the flyover immediately after Enchakkal Junction. A slip-road access has been provided at Chackai Junction for vehicles coming from the airport or city and heading to Kollam side to enter the flyover.

With construction progressing on the slip road at the opposite end, NHAI plans to have the flyover fully functional in 10 days. This slip road will enable vehicles from Chackai or the airport heading in the direction of Kovalam to access the flyover.

NHAI is operating the flyover’s streetlights using a generator as differences with KSEB over cost has delayed electrification. After quoting an exorbitant Rs 1.75 crore for lighting the stretch, the electricity board agreed to relook the number. It is expected to submit a revised estimate soon.

The over bridge allows motorists to bypass Chackai Junction and thus reduce travel time. However, some motorists are concerned over increased congestion at Enchakkal Junction. And this is expected to worsen when the flyover becomes fully functional. Vehicles taking the bridge come to a grinding halt at Enchakkal Junction, which has direct access to vehicles coming from East Fort and Beemapally. Moreover, KWA’s manhole renovation work at the intersection can only add to the woes.

With the Chackai flyover readied, the Kazhakoottam-Mukkola NH stretch is nearing completion. NHAI is currently engaged in the construction of the underpass to Akkulam bridge. The authority has envisaged a pedestrian underpass with access to light motor vehicles. “On the Kuzhivila side, the level of the underpass has been raised by 1 metre to solve the issue of water logging,” sources said.

Title: Goa: TCP takes up 36 cases for zone change under Section 16B
Content:
Representative image

PORVORIM: Hearing applications for change of zone, the Town and Country Planning (TCP) board took up 66 fresh petitions for change of zone under Section 16B of the TCP Act, of which 36 were considered for provisional approval, while 10 were deferred and 20 were rejected outright, said deputy chief minister and town and country planning minister Chandrakant Kavalekar on Monday.Under Section 16A, which is solely for government projects, the TCP board approved the change of zone for establishing the permanent campus for the Institute of Information Technology at Sattari.A total of 179 cases for change of zone were taken for consideration, of which 143 cases were given provisional clearance in 2019.“We have only given provisional approval, nobody has received final approvals,” said Kavalekar.At the board meeting, six projects came up for approval under 16A, which included change of zone for construction of a bus stand at Quepem, multi-purpose hall at Nagoa, integrated office complex at Dharbandora and an indoor stadium at Pernem.Kavalekar said that clearance for change of zone for the integrated office complex and indoor stadium has been withheld till other departments give their approval.The town & country planning (TCP) Act was amended in 2018 by adding Section 16B, empowering the TCP board to change the zone of an applicant’s land in the regional plan.The amendment has been challenged in the high court by Goa Bachao Abhiyan and Goa Foundation .Around 5,300 applications for change of zone were received by the TCP board.“95% of all these cases are below 500sqm area. And if any of the cases fall within irrigation command areas or no-development zones, they have been deferred, and if any proposal falls within forest area, we have rejected them,” said the TCP minister.

Title: Nirbhaya case: Tihar conducts another mock hanging, asks for new ropes
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

NEW DELHI: Tihar Jail authorities on Sunday conducted another mock hanging of the four Nirbhaya case convicts as they are likely to be hanged on February 1. Sources said the hangman, Pawan Jallad , has been asked to report to Tihar on January 30.

The authorities have asked for a dozen new manila ropes from Buxar prison, which would be lubricated and left to dry for two days. Sources said a mock drill is a mandatory procedure before every hanging since the body weight of the convicts tends to change. The dummy hanging was conducted using four sacks filled with sand and gravel that had similar weights as the convicts to check the strength of the ropes that would be used for the actual execution. The sacks were left suspended for three hours after which an expert checked the condition of the ropes.

Jail sources said the wardens and doctors of Tihar have been asked to ensure that the body weight of the four convicts remains constant till they are hanged. The authorities have taken the measurements of the necks and heads of the four convicts. The hangman will prepare the noose according to the measurements.

On Monday, the family members of convict Akshay Kumar Singh were allowed to meet him. In the emotional meeting, he discussed about the legal recourse with his parents. He, Pawan and Vinay have the option of filing a mercy plea before the President.

The families of the other inmates will be allowed to meet them twice a week as per their schedule. During the meeting, the family members will be allowed to take the personal belongings of the convicts and record a will in the presence of a superintendent. The convicts have refused to give the last date of their meeting to the jail authorities despite several reminders. They have also refused to prepare a will. A red notice will be sent to the families about the execution so that they can make preparations to take back the bodies.

Title: Stagecraft’s play has audience in splits
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Artistes in a scene from the play staged at Chatterton Hall, All Saints’ Cathedral Ground, Sadar, on Sunday

Nagpur: Like every time, director Vikash Khurana of Stagecraft Theatre came up with a hilarious play ‘Karan Kumar Khanna Ke Khatarnak Karnamon Ka Kaatilana Kissa’ (K9) that was staged at Chatterton Hall, All Saint’s Cathedral Ground, Sadar, on Sunday.

The play depicts a story of a rich resident of South Delhi, Karan Kumar Khanna who has his wedding around the corner. When girlfriend’s mother (Jaee Jog) pesters him to get his fortune read, he relents — like any other son-in-law.

The fortune teller, Guruma (Sanskruti Bajoria) tells him that he has blood on his hands and that he will commit a murder in his lifetime. Being the ‘proper gentleman’ and wanting to save his future wife, Dimple (Dimple Anandani) from humiliation, Karan decides to get the dirty deed done with before his wedding.

He teams up with his manager Natwar Singh (Samson Aiyub) and a terrorist Al-Kabzz (Shubhankar Mishra) and what follows is a hilarious series of mishaps as they try to commit a murder.

Rahul Bhojwani shines as Karan as he goes to great lengths to murder someone. Aiyub’s performance as an incompetent ‘Sardaarji’ who is Karan’s manager shows brilliance.

Mishra who plays the constipated terrorist Al-Kabzz makes the audience laugh without fail every single time with his spectacular comic timing and dialogue delivery. Karan’s family comprising of ‘chachi’ Aarti Khanna (Anurima Chakraborty), ‘mama’ Vishnu Dewan (Ashwin Shukla), ‘bua’ Preeti Malhotra (Shweta Kewalramani) all make up the perfect ensemble of an entertaining Indian family.

Adapted by Nitish Chandra, the play is based on Oscar Wilde’s short story — Lord Arthur Saville’s Crime.

The play was produced by NV Sharma and Nirmalya Sinha.

Sound and lights were done by Onkar Ghare, Rajat Rajani and Nirmalya Sinha.

Title: Sargam’s ‘safar’: A musical journey worth remembering
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nagpur: To mark 50th birthday for MV Unnikrishnan, organizer of the Sargam musical group, a musical programme ‘Sunhara Safar’ was organized at Sai Sabhagruh, Shankar Nagar, on Sunday. It was an amazing musical experience for the audience as old and new hits were presented by the talented artistes.

The event began with felicitation of Unnikrishnan. Anchor Manish Nair shared Unnikrishnan’s connection with music and retro songs. Since, it was Republic Day, Isbabul Hasan and Rashmi Deshpande kick-started the event with the patriotic song ‘Aye watan tere liye’. Bina Chatterjee charmed the gathering with her performance on ‘Aye mohobbat tera anjam’. Other songs like ‘Taaron mein sajke’, ‘Khuda bhi aasman se’, ‘Tum aaye toh aaya mujhe yaad’, ‘Solah baras ki’ set the mood right for the evening.

All time hit songs like ‘Tu iss tarah se meri’ by Nandu Andhare, ‘Morni baga ma bole’ Purnima Joshi, ‘O re majhi’ Arvind Raje added element to the programme. The list of total 30 songs also had some new hits like ‘Main jahaan rahoon’, ‘Sun raha hai na tu’, ‘Channa mereya’, ‘Ae kaash ke hum’, ‘Ruk jaana nahi tu kahi’ that gave a twist to the event.

‘Gori tera gaon bada pyara’ was the concluding song sung by MV Unnikrishnan, who also organized the event. Other singers who made the evening memorable included Brejbhushan Sharma, Shreekant Sapre, Ila Dua, Sugandha Garway, Parvathi Nair, Vilas Dandge, Swaminathan Iyer, Devika Nair, Ashok Bagul, Rajiv Yashroy, Suresh Iyer, Hemant Balekar, Nishikant Lokhande, Pravin Ghadole, Vijay Sonarkar, Dinesh Barnase, Mohit Jaitha, Arvind Uprit and Abhilash Somkuwar.

Music arrangement was done by Pankaj Singh. Pramod Bawne on tabla and Ghanshyam Barman on dholak complimented the singers.

Title: State issues advisory on management, prevention
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Aurangabad: In the wake of suspected coronavirus cases in Mumbai, the state government has issued an advisory to the district public health department and the Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) on the prevention and management of the infection caused by the virus.

Though no patients or suspected cases of coronavirus have been identified in Aurangabad, in particular, and Marathwada, in general, the state government has alerted the district health officer, zilla parishad, district civil surgeon at the civil hospital, medical officer of Aurangabad Municipal Corporation and the GMCH dean to take necessary steps to prevent the outbreak of the infectiom caused by the virus.

The advisory lists the symptoms, the diagnosis that needs to be followed, preventive steps, the treatment and quarantining patients, if necessary, and health education associated with coronavirus infection.

When asked, head of GMCH’s medicine department Meenakshi Bhattacharya said that the hospital had taken full-fledged preparations as per the instructions in the advisory. District health officer Amol Gite said that the health department was prepared to contain the possible outbreak of coronavirus infection.

Director of Aurangabad airport D G Salve said that they have received the advisory. “However, since the airport does not directly receive international visitors, no screening is being done here.”

Title: More app-based cabs at Chennai airport likely from next month
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Chennai Airport

CHENNAI: Passengers landing at Chennai airport may have multiple cab operators to choose from starting next month. Now, only one app-based cab service is allowed to pick up passengers from arrival terminals .

Airports Authority of India is looking to bring in more cab services to offer pick-up from the airport as there have been many complaints from passengers who said that they were forced to book vehicles from only one app if they wanted to get picked up from arrival terminals. A majority of the passengers prefer to board cabs from the lane in front of the terminal and do not want to go the parking lot to board other cabs.

A meeting was held in New Delhi with representatives of cab operators to work out a way to have more operators run their service from the airport. For now, Ola is the only operator.

“We are trying to give contracts to multiple operators. The existing contract system allows for one prime operator and two secondary operators. But the two other operators who had counters inside the terminals have withdrawn,” said a senior AAI official.

He said the meeting was to “understand what changes will be needed in the contract procedure to ensure that there would be more than one cab service at the airport. The current procedure is not friendly to all.”

Since Ola was paying a high licence fee, its cabs are allowed to pick up passengers from the terminals. Other cabs are allowed only to pick up from parking lots or pick-up points farther from the terminals. This led to chaos and entry points were barricaded and men were posted to prevent cabs of other companies from entering the pick-up lane along the terminals.

An official said the system invited too much criticism because passengers were not getting cabs on time.

“The wait time at the arrival terminal gate for cabs extends to more than 20 minutes during peak hours at night. International passengers with three to four heavy bags suffer the most. This is because the cab aggregator does not have enough vehicles and passengers cannot book any other cab. The cab service that can be booked from inside the terminal is expensive,” he said.

Title: ‘Don’t link PhD and NAAC accreditation’
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Former vice-chairman of University Grants Commissionm professor H Devaraj, spoke to TOI on why there is a rush to publish papers and getting PhDs, how the UGC intervened to discontinue the part-time PhD programme in Bharathiar University and the measures taken to end outsourcing of PhD.

Why is there a rush to get PhDs and to publish in journals?

We should not ask PhD or research papers for NAAC or NBA accreditation. It causes inbreeding PhDs and paid publications. Clearing NET/SLET is tougher than getting PhDs. But UGC adopted a wrong policy when it decided to give increments for faculty members who completed PhD. MHRD also announced that PhD would be a minimum qualification for assistant professors in universities from 2021.

Too many papers being published ...

We need to be careful while allowing colleges to do research work. Many colleges do not have the infrastructure or resources to do it. Yet they are publishing papers due to the prominence given in accreditation for research publications. Part-time PhD (category B) is another major reason for the dilution in quality of PhDs. Unless there is a collaborative research by industry experts and academia, we should not allow any part-time PhDs.

What can be done to ensure quality?

Candidates with JRF or project fellowship alone should be allowed to do PhD. PhDs are not required to teach in colleges. Candidates who clear National Eligibility Test will be competent to do research and write thesis. If we ensure these steps, then there will not be any need for outsourcing research work.

UGC once intervened to stop part-time PhD programme in Bharathiar University. How should UGC deal with outsourcing PhD and ghost writing?

Bharathiar University once admitted thousands of PhD scholars under part-time PhD (category B) programme. A student from anywhere can register for the PhD and a guide from anywhere can supervise and they can submit theses. It was horrible. In 2015, UGC had called then vice-chancellor to Delhi and ordered him to stop the programme. Later, university discontinued the programme. UGC should evolve new mechanisms to identify and prevent outsourcing PhDs and ghost writing. They should enhance the punishment for such practices.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Holding fort against the sands of time
Content:
The road to Alamparai Fort, the crown jewel of the fishing village of Kadapakkam, about 100km from Chennai, ha... Read More

CHENNAI: For more than a year now, the road to Alamparai Fort, the crown jewel of the fishing village of Kadapakkam, about 100km from Chennai, has been shut. Access to the hauntingly picturesque Mughal-era fort overlooking the Bay of Bengal , was cut off after incidents of gang war and murder of local fishermen.Now, the department of archaeology, Tamil Nadu, is inspiring fresh hope among villagers and a new lease of life into the disintegrating walls of the once bustling trade centre, as Alamparai gets restored as part of a multi-crore project covering 12 archaeological monuments across the state."We spent two months just clearing thick vegetation that had cracked open the walls and covered the complex," says the assistant engineer at the site. "We’re rebuilding the foundation of the wall facing the sea from scratch and also using boulders from the ruins to build a structure to keep the sea from reaching the walls," he says.Historians attribute the earliest construction of the fort, to Sambuvarayars – feudatories of the Cholas — who find a mention in Kalki’s ‘Ponniyin Selvan’. "It was rebuilt several times after that, until it came to the Nawabs and the Mughals. It finally went to the French, who lost it to the British in the Carnatic wars," says historian R Venkatesh.Perhaps proof to this are the granite cannon balls that workers found inside the fort’s walls in the course of the restoration. The most recent damage incurred by the structure was following the 2004 tsunami that eroded its sea-facing walls and piled up large heaps of sand against it. The fort as it stands today, covers an area of 14.5 acres, with a 7m wall, a 9m bastion and 12 watch towers. Inside the complex are smaller run-down rooms that experts suggest could have been soldiers’ resting places or stables. It also has a tomb, which locals believe to be a sacred shrine and worship.According to the state department of archaeology website, excavations at the site have unearthed copper, iron, glass and lead objects, porcelain wares, spindle whorl, terracotta lamps, coins, and smoking pipes, revealing rich trade activity during 17th-18th century. "This area was one of the Chola provinces and called Edaikazhinadu, a name it continues to have. It was also a centre for weaving, so a lot of muslin could have been exported," says Venkatesh. Reports also suggest that the fort was a hub of salt, silk and ghee trade for the Arcot Nawabs.Till a few years ago, the ruins of Alamparai were a favourite shooting spot for filmmakers, and to this day, fishermen reminisce about the tea breaks and catamaran rides they had with popular actors. Joyrides on the catamaran and a delicacy of fried fish dished up from the day’s catch, are a few of the unofficial attractions for tourists visiting the fort. While some fishermen feel its renovation and regularisation of tourism may disrupt these impromptu earnings, other villagers are looking forward to the business opportunities it could bring."If word spreads about the fort, it will attract more people, and the women, who usually are at home when the men are fishing, can set up shops of their own to sell fish and refreshments. It will also help clear the image of our village that had so far been in the news for the violence. Alamparai could make us known for the right reasons," says Saranya, a fisherwoman.In Video: Restoration work to infuse new lease of life into TN's Alamparai Fort

Title: Nainital’s crumbling roads are crying for attention
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nainital: Overflowing drains, pothole-riddled roads and frequent jams have become the defining features of the roads of Nainital, one of the most famous tourist destinations of Uttarakhand.

Locals say that while most of the focus of the administration has been on developing the crumbling Mall Road, the secondary roads and roads in the upper areas have been completely left out. “The roads leading up to almost all the major residential areas of the hill station are riddled with potholes, openly flowing drains and garbage strewn all around. Though the administration has focused much on maintaining the Mall Road and roads frequented by tourists, several roads in the old part of the town are completely damaged,” said Alok Tiwari, a resident of Tallital area.

Another resident, Shubham, added, “If one travels to roads in upper areas of the town, they become very slippery during rains and snowfall. The sewage lines laid right in between and damaged after rains pose a greater danger in those conditions.”

The condition of roads in Haldwani isn't any better. In fact, in many of the areas, locals say that roads have not been repaired for years and they have to drive through these potholes each day because the administration hasn't taken any steps to repair them.

Rashid Khan, a resident of the Banbhoolpura area in Haldwani said that the roads in the area have not been relaid for over a decade now. "The authorities built the road almost ten years back. Since then, they have been damaged beyond repair, still nothing has been done," he said.

He added that overflowing sewage in the city further adds to the misery of the locals.

When queried on the steps being taken to address the issue, Nainital district magistrate Savin Bansal said, “We have been building and repairing the major roads of the district, and this includes the secondary roads as well as the smaller streets as well. However if any street has been left out, they, too, will be repaired soon.”

The state Public Works Department (PWD) also chose to claim that “all is well.” State PWD chief Hariom Sharma said that “the department keeps taking stock of the damaged roads and that the road-repairing work has already started in several areas.” “We keep repairing the damaged roads before and after the monsoons. The repair work is going on in several areas and the damaged roads in Nainital district, too, will be repaired soon.”

Title: Antony bats for joint protests
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Veteran Congress leader A K Antony has called for a joint protest without divisions such as LDF and UDF against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. Inaugurating the ‘Kaval Yatra’ organized by KPCC Samskara sahiti here on Monday night, Antony said those who now stay away from protest should realise that more damaging legislations are in the pipeline. “The CAA is a part of the RSS agenda to destroy our Constitution,” he said.

Antony said the biggest protest mobilization in the country after Quit India protest is happening now under the leadership of students and youth. “I have taken part in the protest amidst chilling cold in Delhi. When I come here, I am only happy to join the protest here,” he said after handing over the flag of the rally to captain Aryadan Shoukath.

The Kaval Yatra will tour the state with a message to save the Constitution and conclude at Kasaragod on February 13. On Tuesday, the yatra will pass through Kollam district.

Meanwhile, in Kozhikode, INTUC state president R Chandrasekharan said that Congress and UDF should have carried out a joint agitation along with LDF against the CAA. The joint stir against the controversial Act at the national level under the leadership of Sonia Gandhi had the participation of CPM general secretary Sitaram Yechury and other opposition leaders, he said at a news conference on Monday. “INTUC thinks that Congress should work for taking all opposition parties together on the issue,” he added.

Title: Amazon, PwC top IIM-L recruiters
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Lucknow: American e-commerce giant Amazon, consulting firms Accenture, Deloitte India, PricewaterhouseCoopers, and Boston Consulting Group extended 13 offers each to the post-graduate programme students of 2018-20 batch to share top recruiter spot at the final placements of Indian Institute of Management, Lucknow (IIM-L). For the first time, IIM-L released salary packages, with the highest domestic remuneration pegged at Rs 54 lakh per annum.

Consulting firm Deloitte US was second top recruiter with 12 offers, while Reliance Jio and management consulting firm Bain & Company shared the third spot with 11 offers each. Among other big firms, Mastercard offered 10 jobs while Flipkart and JDA Software handed out nine job offers each. In all, 483 students were placed.

Seven offers each were made by American Express, Avendus Capital, Citi, EXL Services, Landmark Group, and RPG Group. Asian Paints, ICICI Bank, McKinsey and Company and Royal Bank of Scotland extended six offers each to figure in the list of top recruiters.

Consulting, with 32% placements, was the highest recruiting domain like last year, with operations/IT pipping general management to claim second slot with 24% share.

With a 3% increase over last previous year, finance remained third highest recruiting domain and offered 19% jobs. Remaining 13% jobs came from general management sector, followed by sales and marketing with a share of 12% jobs, a dip of 4% over last year.

As many as 16 job offers were international, with the highest seven from Landmark in Dubai followed by three each from Apparel Group and RPG Group in Dubai, Africa and US, respectively. Ernst & Young made two international offers in Qatar. The highest international salary was Rs 58.5 lakh per annum.

Chairman, students’ affairs and placement, IIM-L, Prof Rajesh K Aithal said, “The results show IIM-L has excellent pedagogy, and speaks volumes about the competencies and values which students acquire here.”

Title: To boost innovation, govt offers mentorship to school students
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Porvorim: Aimed at identifying and rewarding talent in innovation and product design, the Goa State Innovation Council (GSInC) on Monday announced awards for school students who come up with solutions to critical challenges that society faces.

Aside from a cash prize, the Goa government is also offering mentorship, training and incubation.

“We want to encourage young students to take up something different, something related to technology. They have to bring the project and showcase it,” minister for science and technology Michael Lobo said.

The Goa Young Innovator Award 2019-20 is open to all Goan schools, and students will compete under two categories — Classes V to VII and Classes VIII to X. The schools have to submit all entries by February 22 and the winners will be announced in March, Lobo said.

Students can submit their ideas to their schools and, after vetting, the school will submit the product or innovation to GSInC along with a description of the technology used, sketches of the project and details of the students, GSInC chairman Jose Manuel Noronha said.

Three winners will be picked from each category and they will receive mentorship and, if found viable, the state is ready to finance the patent process.

“We want to give a platform for youth on how to innovate, commercialise a product, and get patents. We are giving an award under this scheme. We are also giving them mentoring and space at the incubation centre,” Noronha said.

Title: 73 couples tie the knot in mass wedding
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nashik: A total of 73 couples got married in a colourful mass wedding ceremony organised by Sant Nirankari Mission at Thakkar ground in Borgad on Monday.

The couples had come from various parts of the country including 29 grooms and 28 brides from Mumbai. There were also 38 grooms and 35 brides from other parts of Maharashtra, said organisers.

They further mentioned that six grooms and 10 brides belonged to Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Karnataka, Chandigarh and New Delhi. One bride also came from the United Kingdom.

“All the brides and grooms are eligible to get married. Many of them are graduate, postgraduate, engineers and pharmacists. Interestingly, 10 bridegrooms and 14 brides came from outside the Sant Nirankari Mission,” said the organisers.

The ceremony was attended by parents and relatives of the couples. There was also no barrier of caste or religion in the ceremony. After the ceremony, all of them were served langar food on behalf of the mission.

Title: Set up skills devpt varsity in city, Jaleel urges CM
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Aurangabad: City MP Imtiaz Jaleel has urged chief minister Uddhav Thackeray to set up a skills development university in Aurangabad.

According to a statement issued by the MP, he also discussed several other issues with the CM during a meeting in Mumbai on Monday.

Pressing for the need for vocational training and addressing the issue of unemployment, the MP asked the CM to establish a skills development university in Aurangabad. “There is enough Waqf land in possession of dargahs or religious trusts and the same should be used for establishing the university,” he said.

Terming drinking water as the biggest problem of his constituency, Jaleel urged the chief minister to personally look into the problem. “The state government should issue work order for the Rs 1,680 crore water project for Aurangabad,” the MP said.

Jaleel also demanded that urgent measures must be taken to create nearly 400 jobs at the Government Medical College and Hospital in the super-specialty block. He also brought the issue of delay in procuring medicines though Haffkin to the GMCH.

The MIM state president also sought land acquisition for expansion of Aurangabad airport runway which would pave way for bigger aircrafts. “Farmers and other land owners should be immediately compensated for their lands which have been kept on hold since 2016,” Jaleel said.

Thackeray held a meeting with MPs from across the state in Mumbai in wake of the upcoming budget session. NCP president Sharad Pawar, state cabinet ministers and secretariat staff were also present at the meeting.

Title: Residents throw dirty water on Republic Day festivities
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Aurangabad: The office-bearers and officials of the civic body, who had gathered at the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation headquarters to celebrate Republic Day on Sunday, were greeted by the residents of Gadiya Vihar with jars of turbid water that was being supplied to their areas by the civic body.

Residents of Kasliwalpuram society in Gadiya Viharhave have been receiving contaminated water for the past six months. Initially, the AMC had taken up the work of repairing the damaged pipeline that supplied drinking water to the society. However, the work has not yet been completed and the 100 families living in the society continue to receive contaminated water. The water is murky and blackish in colour and contains impurities visible even to the naked eye.

On Sunday, around 20 residents of the society gathered near the headquarters to attract the attention of the office-bearers and the officials to the issue of contaminated water supply.

They brought along transparent jars containing the murky water.

Mayor Nandkumar Ghodele, the standing committee chairman, corporators and municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey, who were among the officials present there to hoist the flag had to face the angry residents. The residents showed the dirty water to the authorities and explained their concerns.

Subhash Kadam, a resident, said, “Consumption of this water can cause sickness among the people, especially children. We knew the officials will be there for the function so we took up the issue on Sunday,” Kadam said.

He said the ignorance of the civic officials is responsible for the delay in work.

Mayor Nandkumar Ghodele directed the civic officials to complete the repair work of the pipeline promptly. He assured the residents the work will be completed and their issue will be resolved within 2-3 days.

Title: 2nd edition of higher edu survey launched
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Unmindful of the poor response of non-governmental institutions to the first edition of state higher education survey , the Kerala state higher education council ( KSHEC ) has launched the survey for 2019 -20.

Modelled on All India Survey on Higher Education and named as AKHES (All Kerala Higher Education Survey), the survey intends to collect data pertaining to higher education institutions in the state covering government, aided, autonomous, unaided colleges and universities. Only less than 400 among the 1,400 odd higher education institutions in the state participated in the 2018-19 survey.

AKHES 2019-20 survey is an attempt to set up and update an authentic and reliable database on higher education institutions in the state, lack of which, say experts, has taken a toll on policy formulation for qualitative improvement of the sector. Following the request of the council, the state government has now made participation in higher education survey mandatory for institutions for seeking State Assessment and Accreditation Council (SAAC) accreditation. The government plans to use SAAC accreditation as a yardstick when considering requests for new courses and batches in colleges. The last date for uploading data of the institutions is Feb 29, 2020.

“KSHEC is planning to release a statistical booklet (annually) based on the data consolidated from the higher education institutions that have participated in the survey. The booklet, besides including data on the above parameters, will also include the list of programmes offered by the institutions in the state,” council member secretary Rajan Varughese said.

Data is being collected on several parameters such as the institution’s basic information, details of faculty and non-teaching staff, programmes conducted under various faculties/schools & departments/centres, students’ enrolment, examination, financial information such as receipt and expenditure under various heads — funds, scholarships, loans, infrastructure.

Title: Madurai schools fight phone addiction among students
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: It has become rare to see an urban child without having access to smart phones these days. It is a blessing to have the whole world at your fingertips through internet, but along with it comes an addiction problem.

"Addiction to smart phones is similar to drugs or alcohol. It’s all the same chemicals in the brain. What starts off simply using the device to take care of one’s needs, ends up escalating to developing dependency on the device. The only difference is that there is no additional substance that goes inside the body, which makes it less intense," said Dr Kumanan T, a psychiatrist.

Many private schools in the city, where children from middle class and upper middle class families are studying, find an increasing number of students addicted to smart phones.

"Initially, it was the odd student who would misbehave and bring smart phone to the school without the parents’ knowledge. But now we have to conduct raids in classrooms and seize phones. Students have hiding places or use it in washrooms. Though many tell us that it is to contact their parents after school, they still do use it during school hours," said the principal of a private school.

Peer pressure is often one of the major reasons for children attempting to sneak smart phones.

"Just like putting your collar up, wearing special wrist bands or any other fashionable and cool thing done by school kids, there is a fascination about smart phones. By showing off their smartphones or taking selfies, they are garnering their peers’ attention and sometimes this leads to jealousy or even theft," said a counsellor and teacher at a private school in KK Nagar.

Children mostly use smart phones for social media and playing games such as PUBG. "Children are becoming frustrated quickly these days and are having low tolerance to boredom. All they are thinking about is instant gratification. I want to post something or play game at this moment and it should be done immediately. I can’t wait. That is the thinking they are developing," observed Dr Kumanan.

Title: R-Day celebrations: Delhi-like display at Cambridge school
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

The students of Nashik Cambridge School presented a tableau of performances replicating the culture of different states on Sunday. The parade included a display of various plays and aerobics depicting social and historical aspects of various states. The display of the three forces waving the 15x15 meters, tricolour earned a thunderous applause from the crowd.

Flag hoisting at Ryan International

Ryan International School, HAL, Ojhar, and DGP Nagar began the Republic Day celebrations with the flag hoisting ceremony followed by the national anthem. The students performed patriotic fusion dance and skits depicting different national movements during the special assembly. The students, who won various cultural and literary competitions held during the month, were felicitated by the eminent guests.

Duties recalled at Wisdom High International School

The 71st Republic Day was celebrated with great pride and nationalism at Wisdom High International School. The chief guests gratified the audience as they hoisted the flag and recapitulated one’s duties towards the nation. The students presented songs, dances that elevated the patriotic spirit of the audience.

Saplings planted at St Francis High School

St Francis High School, Rane Nagar hoisted the Indian tricolour followed by the singing of the national anthem. The students recited the national pledge and planted the saplings to mark the occasion. A cultural programme was presented including patriotic songs and a historical skit based on great freedom fighters. The winners of various activities and sports were felicitated by the dignitaries.

Songs and speeches at Delhi Public School

The celebration of the 71st Republic Day incepted with the hoisting of the national flag followed by the national anthem and national song. The celebration accentuated the significance of the day through patriotic songs and speeches by the students in English and Hindi. The chief guest addressed the students to uphold the values and culture of the rich nation.

Q&A at UWCEC

The significance of a democratic republic was conveyed to the students of United World Child Enrichment Centre (UWCEC) through their class vocabulary file. The kids were shown the pictures of flag hoisting and were asked questions related to it. The students attempted to answer the questions with enthusiasm. The nursery students made a collage of national symbols such as the peacock, the banyan tree and the lotus.

Classical patriotic medley at St Lawrence

There was a rendition of patriotic songs, national anthem and national song at St Lawrence High School and Junior College. The school dance troupe presented a classical patriotic medley and students of different classes expressed their views and opinions on the needs of the country and duties as a citizen. The programme ended with students joyfully pledging to be catalysts of change for the betterment of the country.

Choir at Fravashi Academy

Fravashi International Academy hoisted the national tricolour and recited the Preamble. The programme included an inspiring conversation by the junior college students about the significance of discipline in life and a melodious rendition of the patriotic songs by the school choir which touched the patriotic chord in each and every heart.

Title: Archaeology department approaches NMC again
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nashik: The civic administration is likely to allow the archaeology department to use the space near Sunder Narayan temple to keep its equipment.

Now that the site near Sunder Narayan temple will be taken over by Nashik Municipal Smart City Development Corporation Ltd (NMSCDCL) for undertaking projects under the smart city mission, the archaeology department will have to look for an alternate space to keep its equipment.

“We discussed the issue with civic officials on Monday. They have allowed us to use their space to keep the materials,” said officials from the archaeology department.

The archaeology department has already started shifting its material and equipment from the garden to the roadside.

Assistant director of the department of archaeology, Virag Sontakke, said, “We repeatedly requested the smart city authorities to allow us to complete the first phase of restoration before we shifted the materials. We may face problems in the new space as it is not big enough to design the stones to be used for restoration.”

“NMSCDCL has been asking the archaeology department to vacate the space for nearly two months. We have started shifting the equipment to the roadside,” said Sontakke. The archaeology department will take a week’s time to shift their material from the garden, but that has not hampered their work.

According to Sontakke, the temple from the Peshwa era needs to be restored as it was and minute intricacies have to be carved upon the stones. The labourers need their time and space to work.

The archaeology department had set the deadline of completing the restoration works by March this year.

Title: Play ‘What’s done is done’ tickles funny bones
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nagpur: The highly acclaimed play ‘What’s done is done’, a satirical adaptation of William Shakespeare’s ‘Macbeth’ was staged on Saturday at Centre Point School, Amravati Road Bypass (Dabha), commencing the celebrations for the 70th birth anniversary of Aruna Upadhyaya, the visionary and founder of Mothers’ Pet Kindergarten and Centre Point Group of schools. The play was staged on Sunday as well.
