Written and directed by actor and director Rajat Kapoor, the play features Bollywood stars and theatre artistes like Vinay Pathak, Ranvir Shorey, Aadar Malik, Suraj Tomer, Waris Ahmed, Chandrachoor Rai, Mantra, Mallika Singh, Anna Ador, Vaishali Malhara and Nikhil Murali. The play was presented by Cinematograph group and produced by Sachin Kamani and Hussain Zaidi. The technicians are Sameer Sheikh (sound operator) and Asmit Pathare (light designer).

Having received rave reviews in India and abroad, the play is Kapoor’s reimagination of the character Macbeth. It unfolds the original play’s bold themes of greed, power, lust and betrayal by transforming the characters into eccentric clowns and presenting a different take with improvised humour and Pop culture references.

Two clowns named Julio (Pathak) and Pedro (Malik) claim to be the producers of the play and unravel the story of Macky B (Shorey). Macky B and his friend Banquo set out on an adventure in the forest where they meet three witches who give them three impending prophecies. The two are then sent on a journey that leads to tragic consequences and the original theme of the play comes to the fore.

(Reportig by Manshika Vaikkath)

Title: Deolali to spend Rs 2.5 cr on road repairs
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nashik: The work of repairing nine internal road in the Deolali cantonment area has begun and is expected to be completed by the end of this month.

Ajay Kumar, chief executive officer, Cantonment Board, Deolali, said “We have released the work order of over Rs 2.5 crore and started repairs of the internal roads damaged. The work shall be complete by the end of this month.”

The nine internal roads that are being repaired are Belatgavhan Road, Coral Garden Road, More Bungalow Road, Mahalaxmi Mandir Road, Sansari Lane 1, Sansari Lane 2, Nagjira Road, Station Wadi, Deolali High School Road and Development Area Road.

Asha Godse, a corporator of Deolali, said “We have been requesting the board since long time to repair the roads. The residents had to go through a lot of inconvenience. Good roads are the basic amenity for the residents.”

The internal roads are full of potholes and needed urgent repairs. Local residents said the board’s move would resolve their problem.

Popat Dhurjad, a milkman, who stays at Kahan Nagar Road, said “I have seen people falling off their bikes, especially after dark, while trying to navigate through the potholes on the road. A man skids even when they are not speeding. The roads are in such bad shape that our vehicles require servicing every month.”

The CBD had filled the potholes of the 2.1 km long Lam Road, which is the main road of the Deolali area, with a fund of Rs 2 crore in December.

Title: Goa budget on February 6, CM Pramod Sawant seeks people’s suggestions
Content:
CM Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: Chief minister Pramod Sawant , who will present his first budget on February 6 , on Monday launched a web portal inviting ideas and suggestions from citizens towards preparing the Goa Budget 2020-21 .In a first of its kind in the state, the portal is available on the government website.Suggestions and ideas can be sent to the government till January 31, the chief minister said at press conference on Monday after chairing a meeting of the Business Advisory Committee (BAC).Stating that in the past people would give their ideas on the budget in writing to the government, he said that there are a lot of people out there, most importantly, the youth, who would have brilliant ideas to contribute. “This is another step towards participative and transparent governance,” Sawant, who also holds the finance portfolio said.While this time the public gets only five days to submit their ideas, in the future, they will be allotted more time, he said.The 5-day budget session that commences on February 3 will see Sawant presenting his first budget after assuming charge as Goa chief minister on March 19, 2019, following the demise of former chief minister Manohar Parrikar.On January 30, 2019, Parrikar had presented the budget, and had taken a vote on account, but was unable to read the full budget due to his ill health.Asked if his budget will have anything specific towards job creation, he said, “Job creation cannot be the focus of the budget. The focus will be sustainable development. All inclusive development of the state is what I want.”He said that emphasis will be laid on rural development and that the budget is being prepared accordingly. He, however, did not give any details.Traditionally, as part of the pre-budgetary exercise, the finance minister meets various stakeholders and industry stalwarts and receives their representations on how the budget should be and their expectations.The chief minister said the exercise of meeting industry representatives and other stakeholders is underway. On Monday, he met with representatives of the mining industry.To a question, Sawant said he has also been holding meetings with various heads of departments to assess if the previous budgetary targets have been fulfilled.An action taken report on the budget will also be tabled in the House, he said.

Title: Ravi Kannan: Padma Shri doctor from Chennai who is saving patients in Assam
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Dr Ravi Kannan (in white shirt) has subsidised medical costs and helped poor patients’ kin have an additional ... Read More

CHENNAI: Bomb blasts and floods were the two things that came to mind when senior surgical oncologist Dr Ravi Kannan got an offer to head a hospital in facility. A weekend at the hospital in 2007 changed his opinion about the state. The 13 years he spent taking cancer treatment to the doorstep of poor patients, improving follow-up care and subsidising medical costs, earned him the Padma Shri this year.

It started with a visit to the Cachar Cancer Hospital in Silchar on request. As he was going around the wards of the hospital, his wife Seetha mingled with the community. He quit his practice in Chennai and joined the hospital, while his wife, Seetha, quit her job for voluntary service.

"I thought if we offer low cost many people will come," he said. But he soon realised that the needs of patients in Silchar were far more than those of patients in south India.

Most of the people there lived in poverty. So, when he saw a child eating puffed rice soaked in water with chillies, he spoke to the management and opened a free kitchen. "I thought with free food and shelter people will be happy to receive treatment. In many cases treatment was free too. So it was good. Or so I thought," he said.

In 2011, results of an in-house study crashed all hopes. "We found only 58% of people who tested positive for cancer didn’t return for treatment. Only 28% completed treatment. People were dying in pain and agony. If they have to come for treatment, they need to be accompanied by a family member, who will have to lose their wages and the family will starve," he said.

That’s when the hospital decided to offer jobs to patients and their attenders. Initially, it was planning jobs like tailoring and candle making, but found that people also needed training.

"So, we offered them jobs that required unskilled labour. They could clean wards or water plants for Rs100 a day. Some would do plumbing and carpentry," he said.

Hospital social workers were given cellphones to remind people of follow up schedules. Some patients paid an annual fee of Rs500 for consultation with multiple specialists and some paid nothing. If they did not return, medical teams were sent for free homecare. Soon, compliance went up to 70%.

But there is one thing that hasn’t changed since 2007 — the weekly calls he has been having with his mentor Dr Shanta to discuss the disease, treatment and problems. "Medical schools don’t teach you service, but teachers like her and Dr S Krishnamurthi do. Like her, I give away the cash I receive as awards so poor can benefit," he said.

Read the story in Bengali

Title: Keralites lead CAA protests in Finland
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: As thousands joined human chain protest against Citizenship (Amendment) Act in the state on Republic Day, its ripples reached as far as Finland. Indians and locals in three cities of Finland held a peaceful protest in solidarity with the protests across India. Interestingly, many youths from Kerala were active in organizing the Finland protest.

More than hundred people participated in protests held in Helsinki, Tampere and Turku where they read the Preamble of the Constitution and organized speeches explaining CAA and NRC and on the importance of safeguarding India’s Constitution.

“I see the passing of the CAA and current political atmosphere as an imminent threat to our constitutional values and secularism. If our country slips into a theocratic state (religious), India may never be a safe haven for millions of its religious minorities,” said Thiruvananthapuram-based Indu who is pursuing higher studies in international law and human rights in Finland.

Shameer from Thrissur who works as an IT consultant in Helsinki said, “I want India to support all refugees fleeing persecution irrespective of religion. Having seen the Holocaust memorials in Germany and Poland, I am afraid of genocidal consequences of statelessness to many Muslims in India.”

Holding placards with slogans against CAA and NRC written in English, Hindi, Tamil and Malayalam, the group staged dharna near popular places in their respective cities.

In Helsinki, the protesters conducted a silent march through the centre of the city accompanied by police vehicles.

The protesters also said instead of imposing CAA, the central government should focus on reviving the economy and developing the country.

Title: Only few places for kids to play outdoors safe
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Madurai: Though psychiatrists and counsellors insist that good physical activity outdoors can help children reduce their dependency on smart phones, parents question its practicality in the modern city landscape.

"There are only a few places outside, which are safe to play these days. Children are scolded for running around or playing on streets. Even for playing proper games such as cricket or football in a safe place, we have to go to sports facilities and pay membership fees, which are not affordable. Isn’t it cheaper to educate and entertain children with smart phones?" asks Ramya R, a parent.

Senthilnathan M, president, Private Schools Correspondents Confederation, also echoed similar concerns and called for private schools to be more responsible in providing increased physical activity for students. "There is no place or time for children to do some physical activity outside school. After school, they are forced into going for extra-curricular classes, and if both parents are working, there is no one to take care of the child’s needs. Our community and residential areas are also not having proper recreational spaces for children. So, private schools should try to include mandatory physical activity for the students every day," he said.

Several parents and children felt that using smart phones in kid safe modes is enough and enjoy the fun during leisure time. Psychiatrist Dr Kumanan T also encouraged the practice of self-control to reduce addiction to smart phones. "Smart phone addiction is a less intense form of addiction. By restricting usage at an early age and practising proper self-control, children can make the best use of smart phones and stay safe," he added.

Title: Nod for hotels to serve tipple till 4am in Uttar Pradesh
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: Nightlife is set to get enhanced in UP with the excise department now allowing restaurants and bars to serve liquor up to 2am. Starred hotels can take that a step further and serve liquor up to 4am. In order to promote tourism in the state, UP government’s new excise policy has eased rules for serving liquor, but has restricted the change to only big cities.

“We are now giving bars the option of serving liquor till 2am and to hotels up to 4am, but on certain conditions. Firstly, the option is only open to bars located in metro cities like Lucknow, Agra, Moradabad, Kanpur etc, apart from Noida and Greater Noida.

For all bars located in these areas, time can be extended up to 2am. Three, four and five star hotels can open bars up to 4am,” said Sanjay Bhoosreddy, principal secretary, excise.

Serving liquor under a temporary bar licence can also be extended by one hour, from midnight to 1am, but with special permission of the district magistrate and additional fees. The licence will be available for a six hour bracket, starting from 8am.

Service time in bars was 12am earlier and could be extended till 1am on payment of additional fees.

The new excise policy says that bars will have to pay an additional Rs2.5 lakh in licence fees for each two hour extension.

The excise policy has also allowed for an increase in areas in which liquor can be served in hotels. From the existing limit of five spots, areas for serving liquor can be added on the payment of Rs50,000 for each additional point.

Stressing on the need to making liquor available in special trains, cruises and airports as a means of encouraging tourism, with a special focus on foreign tourists, the excise department will also be giving licences for serving liquor at such locations. While a train licence will cost Rs10 lakh annually, it will be Rs3 lakh for a cruise and Rs5 lakh for airport bars.

However, while the rules come as a bonus for consumers, the Liquor Traders’ Association of UP is not very happy with the government’s refusal to allow them to open retail shops from 9am to 11pm, against the current time of 10am to 10pm.

“The rules are not friendly for retail shops. There has been an increase in licence fees but no increase in maximum retail price of liquor. Timings have also not been extended for retail shops even as hotels are being allowed to serve for longer,” said KL Maurya, secretary of the association.

Title: Exchange of fire between cops, Maoists
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Maoists received series of blows within 24 hours as their camp at Niyamagiri hills forest was busted by security personnel on Sunday night. Security forces seized a huge cache of ammunition and other material from camp in in Rayagada district, close to the AP Border. According to sources there were no casualties on either sides.

Earlier, a Maoist was killed and another was injured when villagers of Janturai village in Malkangiri district in Odisha were asked to observe Republic Day as a Black Day by the Maoists on Saturday night. There was an exchange of fire incident in Rayagada district on Sunday night.

Acting on a tip-off, after Maoists had stopped a road construction work in Niyamgiri on January 22, security forces were pressed into action in the area. A joint team of security forceshad gone for combing operations.

The cops busted a Maoist camp running in Niyamgiri hill forest. After seeing the cops, Maoists detonated three IEDs (Improvised Electronic Devices). Luckily, cops escaped and retaliated with gunfire.

Title: Join Shaheen Bagh stir, get biryani: Kerala jobseeker gets email
Content:
Anti-CAA protesters during 71st Republic Day at Shaheen Bagh in New Delhi on Sunday.

Screenshot of the email

KOCHI: The mobile phone of Abdulla S S, a Thiruvananthapuram native currently in Bur Dubai on visit visa hunting for jobs, has not stopped ringing ever since the screenshot of reply email he received from a prospective employer that asked him to join anti-CAA protests at Shaheen Bagh in Delhi went viral.Hours after Abdulla, a mechanical engineer, send out the mail with a desparate header ‘Willing to work without salary for training period’, he got a reply from a person identified as Jayant Gokhale.“Just a thought. Why u need a job. Go to Delhi and sit in Shaheen Bagh for protest. Every day you will get Rs 1,000, free food i.e biryani, unlimited amount of tea and milk, sometimes sweets also,” the mail said. Several people who shared the post on social media criticized the sender of the mail for harassing a job seeker on the basis of religious identity and suggesting that Shaheen Bagh protesters are paid, an allegation levelled by those supporting CAA.Abdulla said he had been sending numerous job applications. The reply referring to the Shaheen Bagh protest was for one of the many mails he had sent. “I had sent a screenshot of the mail to my brother’s friend and I think it was he who posted it on social media. Now, many people are calling with offers of help. I am also getting abusive calls thinking I am the employer,” said Abdulla over phone from Dubai.Some want him to move legally against the person who sent out the mail. “I don’t want to file any legal complaint. My only concern is securing a job,” said Abdulla.

Title: Trichy model to keep slums open defecation-free a hit
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

TRICHY: The sanitation model introduced in the slums in the city in 1999 by roping in self-help group (SHG) women to maintain community toilets continues to be an effective mechanism even in 2020 in prevent open defecation. The successfully-demonstrated model, emulated by various local bodies, has been acknowledged as one of the achievements of Trichy City Corporation in its 25 years of existence. The model, which established 398 community toilets, has helped Trichy become the state’s first open defecation free (ODF) city in 2016.

In August 1999, Trichy City Corporation along with three NGOs namely Gramalaya , Scope Trichy and Sevai identified 186 slums in the city that are prone to open defecation. To tackle the situation, a plan was chalked out by the local body to make the slums ODF. The state government agreed to construct and revamp toilets in 75% of the city’s slums, whereas the NGOs were allotted the remaining 25% of the slums to build community toilets. Supported by international charity organisation Water Aid, community toilets were constructed by the NGOs across 25 slums at an outlay of Rs 4 crore. The corporation facilitated land and water and drainage connections for the community toilets in all the slums. "Slum-dwellers were consulted right from the designing of community toilets. By inducing the ownership attitude, SHG women were told to maintain the toilets and educate neighbours not to defecate in the open," S Damodaran, founder, Gramalaya, said.

Instead of handing over the maintenance of community toilets to the corporation, ‘She’ (Sanitation and Hygiene Education ) teams comprising SHG women from the slums were formed to maintain the toilets in 1999. A minimum of 50 paise was collected as user fee. The She teams were given bank accounts to maintain records. Kalmandhai slum near Gandhi Market became India’s first 100% sanitised slum in 2000, earning state government’s appreciation. The same model was gradually emulated in all 186 slums by the end of 2005. "Periodical and proper maintenance of community toilets by SHG women helped us maintain the open defecation-free status. The sanitation model made our slums unique," a corporation official said.

SHGs maintaining the community toilets were classified under a rigid mechanism of She teams (ward level). The She teams were brought under a pan-city level Wave federation (Women’s Action for Village Empowerment ) for an effective audit. Cross-subsidisation model was introduced to maintain the community toilets. The revenue from operating toilets close to commercial streets were utilised to maintain free or low-cost toilets in areas vulnerable to open defecation.

Title: ‘CAA not against Muslims in India’
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nagpur: Minorities from the Islamic countries like Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan have migrated to India due to persecution. Since they do not have citizenship of India, they are unable to avail several facilities. Thus, Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) has been introduced to grant them citizenship but false rumours are being spread that the Muslim community are under the threat of being driven out of the country, said Captain (retd) Smita Gaikwad of Indian Army, on Saturday.

She was delivering the keynote address on ‘Understanding CAA and working of Maoist front organizations’. The lecture was organized by Yuva Aayam at Kalpataru Sabhagruh, Gorewada Road.

Unravelling facts about CAA, Gaikwad said, “Every country has different rules for citizenship. India came up with a set of such rules in 1955 with the Citizenship Act that grants citizenship by birth, descent, registration and naturalization. Muslim migrants from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan can be granted citizenship if they have stayed for more than 11 years in India, by naturalization. Even today, that clause remains the same.”

She added, “There have been countrywide protests opposing CAA. Not only Maoists but people from the Muslim community, several NGOs and certain celebrities among others have joined the protests. This is a result of the lies and rumours that are being spread against the Act. Many of the people participating in protests have not even understood the concept of CAA. Maoist organizations take advantage of such situations and try to incite violence.”

Addressing the backlash against CAA, she said, “People have labelled the Act as unconstitutional. In India, there are some laws that are applicable to women and not men. This is because they were framed for protection of women after considering the social experience. Laws against caste atrocities were formed to counter discrimination. A law cannot be tagged unconstitutional for protecting minorities.”

“Even if the Act is unconstitutional, the democratic way to handle it is to approach the Supreme Court. There are a number of petitions filed and people are still taking to the streets and giving way to violence,” said Gaikwad.

She spoke at length about the objectives of the banned Communist Party of India (Maoist) functioning in urban areas, like mass mobilization, party building, building the United Front and military tasks.

(Reporting by Manshika Vaikkath)

Title: Rs 10 Shiv Bhojan launched at district civil hospital
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Aurangabad: The state government’s Shiv Bhojan scheme, to provide affordable lunch for the people, was launched at the district civil hospital at Chikalthana on Sunday.

It was inaugurated by the district guardian minister.Subhash Desai.

The meal, which costs Rs 10, is a boon to people coming from different areas of the region to the hospital.

The Shiv Sena-led Maharashtra government launched the scheme in the state on an experimental basis.

The scheme will be available in at least one centre in each district of state.

During the inaugural programme, Aurangabad district guardian minister Subhash Desai said that Rs 6.47 crore has been allocated for the scheme by the state government for the remaining quarter of the current financial year. “The scheme will be implemented at bus stands, railway stations, markets and government offices,” he said.

Desai directed the hospital administration to implement the scheme so that people can get healthy food at an affordable rate. For now, the meal will be available from 12pm to 2pm at the hospital. As many as 75 to 150 plates will be distributed each day at the centre.

MLC Ambadas Danve, district collector Uday Chaudhari, district civil surgeon Sundar Kulkarni and additional district civil surgeon Archana Bhonsale were present during the inauguration. The meal includes rotis, dal, vegetable curry and rice. At district civil hospital, a room has been dedicated where the people can sit and eat the Shiv Bhojan lunch. The guardian minister served the first few thalis to the people.

The scheme was part of the common minimum programme of the Maha Vikas Aghadi government.

Title: Goa Medical College ward identified for coronavirus cases
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: The task force which was constituted for monitoring coronavirus cases , will hold its first meeting on Tuesday.On the instruction of health minister Vishwajit Rane, the task force was constituted to closely monitor all activities related to coronavirus.State epidemiologist Dr Utkarsh Betodkar said the Union ministry of health and family welfare held a meeting with all states on Monday over their preparedness to deal with if any cases of coronavirus. “The meeting was held to check our preparedness,” he said.A ward at Goa Medical College (GMC) and hospital has been identified to keep coronavirus patients in isolation. Samples of suspected cases will be sent to the National Institute of Virology, Pune, for testing, he said.GMC dean Dr S M Bandekar held a review meeting on Monday, and issued a “call for vigilance” regarding the virus.Bandekar said while cases will be treated in the isolation ward that has been identified at GMC, the hospital pharmacy has enough stock of the required medicine.

Title: NMC illegally uproots 8 trees, expedites works on playground
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nagpur: Violating its own norms, Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has expedited construction of walking track on Kukde Layout playground by uprooting trees. The garden department said the Tree Authority had not given permission to remove these trees.

A resident of Kukde Layout, Naresh Pandey, also alleged the ongoing works are unauthorized and also against the norms for playgrounds.

TOI had, on January 23, highlighted that the district court imposed a stay on NMC’s plan to develop garden on one of the playgrounds (No. 392) situated at Kukde Layout, because playground cannot be converted into garden. Also, it was highlighted that NMC started execution of the works on another playground (No. 225) in the same layout, where too residents opposed it.

Pande told TOI, “Staffers of NMC Dhantoli Zone on January 24 reached the playground (No. 225) and uprooted eight trees. Shami tree was one of those uprooted and very rare in the city. Among other trees, teak, like shami, cannot be uprooted without forest department permission. All trees were four-eight years old.”

He added that NMC is constructing a walking track in an unauthorized manner. It was sanctioned along with garden and green gym for playground (No. 392). After stay from district court, NMC shifted the works to this playground without revising the proposal.

A green gym has already been installed on the playground. NMC norms say only 15% construction, with 10% on ground floor and remaining 5% on first floor is allowed, that too only for sports purposes.

“NMC constructed compound wall and there was no need for walking track and green gym. All playgrounds, gardens and schools situated within 200 meter radius have green gym and walking track. I have lodged a series of complaints but NMC is not paying heed,” he said.

NMC Dhantoli Zone assistant commissioner Kiran Bagde said trees were uprooted with consent of NMC garden department. “Trees were uprooted and planted in another part of the same playground for construction of walking track,” she said.

As per norms, trees cannot be uprooted without Tree Authority’s permission. Even transplantation of trees requires Tree Authority’s approval.

NMC garden department denied it had given any permission from Tree Authority for uprooting and transplanting trees at the playground.

On the other hand, Bagde accused Pandey of creating problems by storing cow dung in the playground. “Pandey did not remove cow dung despite repeated reminders. Our staff cleaned the playground,” she said.

NMC garden department officials said works of garden and storm water drain have been dropped. They did not comment on works of green gym and walking track carried out in the playground without proper process and against norms.

Each and every playground excluding no. 392 has one or other construction, like library building and religious structures, in Kukde Layout, which is one of the biggest localities in South Nagpur.

IAN

* NMC approved works of garden, walking track and green gym on playground no. 392 of Kukde Layout

* A resident filed a petition in district court, which imposed stay since playground cannot be converted into garden

* NMC garden department started executing works on adjoining playground no. 225 in same layout without revising proposal, and still going against playground norms

* Residents raised objections

* Department dropped garden and storm water drain works, installed green gym and started construction of walking track

* Still, residents continued opposition

* NMC Dhantoli Zone team uprooted eight trees and planted four in another part of the playground, while status of remaining trees unknown for continuing construction of walking track

* Trees uprooted without mandatory permission of Tree Authority

Title: NIT to fill 25k tonne fly ash in sewage-logged basement
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nagpur: Around 722 families have been residing in fear for the last 15 years due to Nagpur Improvement Trust’s (NIT) mistakes, at its housing scheme at Nandanvan in East Nagpur. The lower basement parking of the schemes has been filled with sewage water of Nag river for over a decade. Now, as a mitigation measure, NIT plans to fill the basement with 25,000 metric tonne fly ash.

The frightening situation came to fore from the tender issued by NIT on January 24 to fill the basements of seven towers with 25,000 metric tonne fly ash. NIT has sought fly ash from Koradi, Khaparkheda or Mauda thermal power stations. The contractor has to supply fly ash only with bulkers and unload it in basements through compressor pump.

Brick kilns used to operate in Nandanvan along Nag river. NIT constructed 13 towers of one BHK and two BHK flats on the area in 2002. NIT’s contractor constructed lower basement parking, upper basement parking and three floors of flats in each building. There was some problem in lower basement parking, so it was abandoned since auction of flats. Flat owners did not have any idea about the lower basement parking when they started residing in the flats between 2002 and 2005.

A former resident of the buildings, Subhash Ghate, told TOI his family is one of those who sold out and left the housing scheme due to the threat to the buildings. “In one of the rainy seasons, water from Nag river submerged the upper basement parking. During inspection, it came to fore there is a lower basement parking filled with sewage water. Then, people realized this was the reason for the permanent problem of foul smell and mosquitoes. Before that, people used to blame the foul smell and mosquitoes on Nag river,” he said.

Ghate added many engineers believe the buildings can collapse anytime as the basement has been filled with sewage for so long. “So, many people like me sold the flat and left,” he said.

BJP city vice-president Suraj Singh Thakur, who is following up on the problem at NIT and state government level, sent a copy of NIT’s report to TOI. In the note written after inspection, NIT admitted water logging in basement of buildings. “NIT appointed M/s PT Mase and Associates to conduct structural audit of all buildings and suggest works to repair and strengthen all structures in 2017. Chances of damage to foundation of buildings cannot be ruled out due to water logging in basement,” the report said.

In January 2018, Thakur and residents met the then CM Devendra Fadnavis and requested directions to NIT to repair and strengthen the buildings. Accordingly, the state’s urban development department (UDD) directed NIT to take up works immediately.

In October 2018, NIT planned various works, including filling all basements with cement concrete at a cost of around Rs3 crore. Thakur said NIT did not give administrative approval to the works citing lack of funds.

“We requested the government to provide the funds but nothing happened. During winter session, we met CM Uddhav Thackeray and explained to him the problems of 722 families. Also, Union minister Nitin Gadkari wrote a letter to the CM. UDD again directed NIT to begin mitigation measures with immediate effect,” he said.

Accordingly, NIT has now floated a tender for filling the basements with fly ash. Ghate said filling fly ash will not solve the problem. “Problem is likely to aggravate, NIT is not taking the issue seriously,” he said.

Thakur said the plan to fill fly ash is likely to work. “NIT can’t do much as it does not have funds. Government should approve funds for a solution,” he said.

NIT officials said plan for filling basements with fly ash was prepared only after detailed study. “It will resolve the problem,” the official said.

IN A NUT SHELL

* NIT constructed 13 towers of 722 flats with lower basement parking, upper basement parking and three floors

* Lower basement parking flooded with sewage water from Nag river

* People started living in flats between 2002 and 2005, but lower basement parking was totally hidden

* During rains, Nag river water submerged upper basement parking

* People found lower basement parking was full of sewage water

* Foul smell and mosquitoes due to sewage water in basement

* NIT admits water logging, and possibility of damage to foundations

* UDD directs NIT to execute mitigation measures in 2018

* NIT plans to fill basement with cement concrete, works to strengthen buildings

* NIT drops plan citing lack of funds

* CM again directed NIT to take up works in 2019

* NIT plans to fill basements with fly ash

Title: CAA is extremely misunderstood: Journalist
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Uday Nirgudkar at the event

Nagpur: “The Muslim community in India needs to be told that the CAA is not against them,” said Dr Uday Nirgudkar, journalist on Saturday at Dr Hedgewar Blood Bank’s Hall, Dharampeth. He was speaking on the topic ‘CAA and NRC’. Former MP Hansraj Ahir presided over the function.

He said, “It is our responsibility to tell at least one person from the community that CAA is not against them and that it is extremely misunderstood. There is a big potential in bringing harmony in religions. It cannot be left in the hands of religious fanatics and clerics.”

Nirgudkar informed the audience about the history which led to the enactment of CAA. “Over a period of time, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan were declared Islamic states. In case of Afghanistan, their law clearly states that all religious practices should be as per Sunni laws. So much so, the Shiya sect of Muslims are not welcome there.”

He further spoke about the religious persecution faced by many non-Muslim communities in these countries. “Jinnah had promised equal rights for Hindus in Pakistan. In the end, nothing was done about it. If a Muslim accused a non-Muslim of insulting the Quran (normally the burden of giving proof lies on the accuser), but in those places the non-Muslim has to prove his innocence. It’s totally bizarre.”

He also told the audience about a law, according to which if a Muslim kills a non-Muslim and that non-Muslim has died during conversion, he cannot be held liable for any crime. Nirgudkar gave many such examples of religious persecution.

“There has been a significant drop in the percentage of Hindu population in Pakistan and Bangladesh. So, they are either killed, converted or have migrated to India and are living without respect, identity or even any documents. This has been happening since 1971,” he said.

“Pakistani Constitution discriminates by law, the Indian constitution does not discriminate and even provides remedies in cases of discrimination. It is 100% false idea that Indian-born Muslims will be thrown out of the country.”

Title: CAA Protest Mumbai: Hundreds stage Shaheen Bagh-like stir in Nagpada
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Women protesters stage a sit-in

MUMBAI: From the intervening night of January 26 and 27, hundreds of women occupied a section of Morland Road-Thandi Sadak near Nagpada in a protest like Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh against the Citizenship Amendment Act, National Register of Citizens and National Population Register.

The protesters are mainly from Nagpada, Jhoola Maidan, Madanpura and Agripada. Despite police’s attempt to persuade them to not stage a sit-in as they didn’t have a permission, they refused to budge.

Seated on the under-concretisation road, the mostly burqa-clad, slogan-chanting women said they would not move till CAA is repealed. “Almost all protesters are locals. We have come on our own and not at the behest of anyone. Thousands of Shaheen Baghs will come up in the country till the divisive and unconstitutional CAA is repealed,” said Sadia Shaikh, a protester.

Police tried to stop them, saying the protesters had not taken written permission; two police vans were stationed. “They didn’t seek permission for the dharna. Some outsiders too were seen here and our priority is to maintain law and order,” said DCP Abhinash Kumar.

MLAs Rais Shaikh, Amin Patel and NCP leader Naseem Siddiqui visited. The leaders said the protest would be peaceful and should not be stopped.

Some were seen holding cutouts of India’s map while one placard read: “Main Bharat ki beti hoon (I am a daughter of India).”

Title: 21 years on, BMC reclaims 1.6-acre Cuffe Parade plot
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Trust that had the park in its possession has called BMC action illegal. Wall around plot was bulldozed on Mon... Read More

MUMBAI: Twenty-one years after the BMC ’s licence agreement with a private trust to develop a 1.6-acre recreation ground in the prime Cuffe Parade ended, the civic body finally took possession of the plot on Monday morning. Civic officials, accompanied by local residents and municipal councillors, bulldozed the wall around the plot. Residents have called it a major victory and are hopeful the civic body will develop and maintain it.

Officials said the trust had kept the space in its possession though after its agreement ended back in 1999. The trust’s managing trustee, though, said the matter was sub judice in the Bombay high court and the BMC had arbitrarily taken possession of the plot by not following due process of the law.

Maria Chico, a local, said she used to take her son to the park almost almost three decades ago and back then it was maintained well. “On Monday, when I accompanied BMC officials who were to take possession of the plot, I was shocked to find only wild grass everywhere. I am happy the garden will be revived to its former glory. I have fond memories of a beautiful pond within the space too.”

Harshita Narwekar, local corporator who was present on Monday, said a notice was served to Suraksha Trust on January 24. According to the notice, a copy of which is with TOI, a licence agreement between the trust and the BMC dated September 30, 1994, expired five years later in 1999. Terms of the agreement stated that Suraksha Trust must develop the ground within six months from the date the BMC handed it over. The BMC notice has alleged the trust failed to do so, depriving residents of a recreation facility. “Even though the licence period has expired, the trustees are holding out the said ground illegally and unauthorised,” stated the notice.

Chanda Jadhav, assistant municipal commissioner, A Ward, said the trust was informed on January 27 at 10.30am that the BMC would take possession of the ground. Corporator Makrand Narwekar said the trust repeatedly got a court stay to avoid handing it over.

When contacted, Jaikumar Jain, chairman and managing trustee, Suraksha Trust, said, “The BMC was restrained from taking action even by the city civil court without following the due process of law. They then approached the high court where the matter is sub judice. Despite that, they have taken possession of the garden today. They have clearly taken law into their hands. The BMC did not provide water and electricity. How was it possible to maintain the space in such a situation? I had repeatedly requested them to inform me how they wanted me to maintain the space as well. I will approach the court now.”

Title: More trees on the block: Greens plan protests
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nagpur: Disapproving the civic administration’s decision of chopping down 139 trees for Smart City Project roads, environment activists in the city are filing objection letters demanding protection of the existing green cover.

TOI reported on Sunday that Smart City Project special purpose vehicle Nagpur Smart and Sustainable City Development Corporation Limited (NSSCDCL) has sought permission to cut 139 fully grown trees in different areas of East Nagpur. This, when a recent study done by the Indian Space Research Organisation’s (ISRO) Regional Remote Sensing Centre (RRSC) had highlighted significant absence of green cover in that part of the city.

NMC sources told TOI that most of the trees proposed to be cut are fully grown. “Some are on the road while others are inside residential properties. The trees belong to different species including subabul, mango, neem, raintree, Ashoka etc,” they said.

Calling the decision an “unsmart move for a smart city”, greens have decided to file maximum objection letters with the garden department of Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC). “We can’t make a city smart at the cost of environment. It is evident that protection of trees continues to be overlooked during the planning stage of any developmental project. The authorities should modify plans instead of compromising on green cover,” said Kaustav Chatterjee, founder of environment NGO Green Vigil Foundation.

The members will be filing an objection letter on Tuesday. Honorary wildlife warden of Nagpur Jaydeep Das has appealed to citizens to come forward and give their objections. “If we think that the smartness quotient of the city will increase by cutting existing trees and planting new ones, the project itself becomes questionable. In spite of the city feeling the impact of climate change and public movements like Save Bharat Van, authorities are turning a blind eye to the environment conservation,” said Das.

In the case of Bharat Van and Empress Van too, thousands of objection letters were filed by citizens. However, violating the Maharashtra (Urban Trees) Protection and Preservation of Trees Act, NMC did not conduct the mandatory public hearing.

While the proposal of felling trees at Bharat Van has been dropped, activists have demanded that a joint public hearing should be held for Empress Van and Smart City cases.

“What is the point of publishing public notices in a newspaper as it often goes unnoticed? NMC should involve all stakeholders and then decide the need for cutting trees,” added Chatterjee.

Title: Civic chief absent, NMC GB meet on NIT issue adjourned
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nagpur: The urgent special general body meet of the Nagpur Municipal Corporation had to be postponed due to the absence of the municipal commissioner. The meeting on Monday was called by mayor Sandip Joshi to discuss the issue of guardian minister Nitin Raut wanting to reinstate the powers of the Nagpur Improvement Trust. It will now be held on February 4.

While the NMC is BJP dominated, Raut is from the Congress. The Devendra Fadnavis-led BJP government had earlier taken a decision to dissolve the NIT but could not complete the process during its term.

The BJP was hoping to pass a resolution to maintain NMC as the sole planning authority. Now, the Congress-led opposition group has claimed it is due to the Fadnavis government that three civic agencies function in the city.

While ruling party leader Sandip Jadhav asked Joshi to postpone the meeting, leader of opposition group Tanaji Wanve said discussions can be held and a decision be taken by additional municipal commissioner Ram Joshi. Outgoing municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar was in Mumbai to attend a meeting organized by speaker Nana Patole. Bangar’s replacement Tukaram Mundhe is likely to reach city on Tuesday.

Wanve told TOI that BJP is misguiding people on NIT. “It has not been dissolved. The NIT continues to execute works,” he said.

Wanve added that the Nagpur Metropolitan Region Development Authority (NMRDA) is the third civic agency in the city. “It came into existence over a year ago. The NIT had transferred many projects to NMRDA. Also, NMRDA got some projects from the state government,” he questioned.

Fadnavis government had approved a decision to amend the NIT Act as per which the NMC was supposed to get all assets and liabilities of NIT. Through the amendment, the past government had started the process to make provisions to distribute NIT’s assets and liabilities between NMC and NMRDA. With this it becomes evident that the two agencies will continue exist even after NIT is dissolved.

Title: People should follow only Constitution: Mishra
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Khwaja Rabbani speaks at the event

Nagpur: People should follow only the Constitution which states that people are free to practice any religion regardless the state or other factors, said chancellor of Krishna Institute of Medical Sciences, Karad, Dr Vedprakash Mishra, during a programme title ‘Rashtra va Dharma — Vicharmanthan’, organized by Yashwantrao Chavan Pratishthan, at Dhanwate Hall, on Saturday.

The other speakers of the programme were Jain Darshanacharya Vipin Jain Shashtri, social worker Jagjit Singh and former director of archaeology department Khwaja Rabbani.

Highlighting the recent developments, Mishra said, “India as a country does not to promote any particular religion and is a sovereign nation.”

In his address Rabbani highlighted the teachings of Islam and mentioned that it promotes the ideology of being true towards the land where we live. “Muslims will always spread love irrespective of any particular region. Speaking on behalf of Muslims of India, I can assure that we will be true to the nation and its culture,” he said.

Singh said, “No religion has ever promoted the idea of hurting other humans or indulging oneself in ill practices.” He added, “Scientifically we are all the same. Religion is just a concept that humans have made and have been manipulating it according ot their wish.”

Raising an important question, Shastri said, “We need to ask ourselves — is religion contributing to the betterment of India or is it acting as an obstacle?”

“All the religions are same as their teachings are same. It is humans who have given it different titles of Hindu, Muslim, Jain, Sikh, and others.”

(Reporting by Janhavi Dave)

Title: Mumbai: Cruelty-free items seen at Ahimsa Fest 2020
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

MUMBAI: That several Mumbaikars are aware about veganism was evident at Ahimsa Fest 2020 organised in Andheri (East) on Republic Day .

Hundreds thronged the festival to check out over 200 stalls showcasing vegan products, from food to footwear.

“As dairy products involve animal cruelty, we ask people to opt for milk-free butter made from peanuts and almonds. Vegans also avoid leather footwear and wallets; eco-friendly fibre and cork material are available,” said activist Darshana Muzumdar of Ahimsa Land NGO. Activist Shweta Savla of United for Compassion NGO said, “Our volunteers regularly hold awareness drives and vegan potluck events.” “Most believe it is difficult to go vegan. This is what Ahimsa Fest strives to disprove,” said activist Anand Siva. Vegan athletes like Kuntal Joisher who had climbed Everest were present. “The fest shows it is possible to live a life of compassion,” said Atul Doshi of the core committee. “Conserving water is key too,” said the committee’s Saroj Choudhary.

Title: Coronavirus in Hyderabad: Coronavirus looms, but no labs in Telangana to test samples
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: While the fear of a possible outbreak of the highly contagious Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) is escalating with reports of suspected cases in parts of the country, the state is not prepared to carry out tests for the virus at existing facilities.Over one-and-a-half years ago, the outbreak of the Nipah virus and the subsequent epidemic scare had prompted authorities to plan the upgrade of the laboratory at the Institute of Preventive Medicine ( IPM ) to biosafety level 3(BSL 3) from the existing BSL level 2.Nearly 18 months later, the plan is still stuck in red tape.The existing facilities continue to be of a level which does not permit testing for highly contagious and emerging viruses such as Nipah virus, Ebola virus, Zika and Corona.Currently, only National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune is equipped to test for Coronavirus and other such highly contagious viruses. The need for high level of biosafety is pertinent to prevent the onset of a bio hazard. A bio hazard in this regard is an outbreak of the disease that can be caused if bio waste released during testing is not disposed properly.The BSL 3, meanwhile, entails having a negative pressure room that is temperature controlled with fabricated roofs, sophisticated laboratory apparatus. The air that escapes the room will be highly filtered along with regular cleaning of all lab materials. BSL 3 provides highly restricted entry with requirement of cleaning the area every time a person enters the lab.The plan for upgrading the lab was approved at a meeting in June 2018 and Rs 3- Rs 3.5 crore was estimated to be cost for upgrading the lab. When asked about the facility, Dr K Shankar, director of Institute of Preventive Medicine (IPM), “The upgradation work is under process, currently. The decision has been taken but some civil works are pending,” adding that although testing equipment currently available at the lab can test for Coronavirus and other viruses, a minimum level of BSL 3 is required to conduct tests for Coronavirus and Nipah virus.

Title: Rahul Gandhi: Congress leader Rahul Gandhi to lead long march on Thursday
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Congress leader Rahul Gandhi

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Rahul Gandhi , MP of Wayanad, will carry out a long march to protest against the implementation of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) in his constituency on Thursday. As per KPCC decision, all party MPs are carrying out long marches in their constituencies against the CAA.

“In the meeting with Rahul Gandhi in New Delhi, we decided to convene a long march in Wayanad,” said KPCC president Mullappally Ramachandran. Though we were a little hesitant in Gandhi leading such a march, he himself came forward for organizing such a march, he added.

“Rahul Gandhi was of the opinion that since KPCC had decided to organize marches against CAA in all constituencies under the leadership of the respective MPs, he would also do the same in Wayanad,” said the KPCC president.

Ramachandran said the party has launched its campaign against CAA in all districts and the district presidents are now holding padyatras. “Only Congress is sincere in its campaign against CAA. Whatever the CPM has been doing is a gimmick or a political stunt,” he said.

While flaying the chief minister for remaining silent against the governor, the KPCC president said, “The chief minister is a prisoner of uncertainty. He is clueless as to what stand he should take on the criticisms by the governor against his government.”

The chief minister has the responsibility to clarify his stand on the criticisms made by the governor against his government, he said. “He should open his mouth and comment. It is nothing but a hide and seek game played by our chief minister. On the one hand, he wants to appease the Centre and on the other side he wants to exploit the vote bank too,” said Ramachandran.

Title: State BJP brass throngs Pankaja’s hunger strike venue in show of unity
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Aurangabad: Senior BJP functionaries, including former chief minister Devendra Fadnavis, made their way to the Aurangabad divisional commissionerate to extend their support to the token hunger strike launched on Monday by former rural development minister Pankaja Munde. The move was seen as a way to send out a message that everything was alright within the party.

Recently, after the core committee meeting, the party had declared that the BJP would agitate for Marathwada’s water demands under the leadership of Pankaja Munde, who incidentally has been critical of the party’s leadership since she lost the assembly election.

Despite the BJP trying to portray it as a party agitation, the banner put up on the podium claimed that the agitation is being organised under the aegis of ‘Gopinath Munde Pratishthan’, an NGO named after the late BJP stalwart and father of Pankaja and MP Pritam Munde.

Interestingly, the pandal was set up barely 10m from the place being dubbed as Aurangabad’s Shaheen Bagh, where around-the-clock anti-CAA/NRC/NPR agitation is underway for the past 20 days. The agitation and speeches continued peacefully at both the pandals, without making comments on each other.

For the water agitation, all BJP MLAs from across Marathwada — except a couple who cited personal reasons — reached the venue and shared the stage with the Munde sisters. Former assembly speaker Haribhau Bagde, Union state minister Raosaheb Danve, leader of opposition in legislative council Pravin Darekar, MLAs Atul Save, Narayan Kuche, Abhimanyu Pawar, Pasha Patel, Suresh Dhas, Prashant Bamb were amongst those present. Most attendees, however, were Pankaja supporters who shouted slogans hailing Pankaja during party functionaries’ speeches.

Fadnavis, who has been appointed as the leader of the opposition, appreciated Pankaja’s move of organising the hunger strike. Fadnavis also warned that if the state government stops the water-related schemes started by the previous government, the BJP will take to the streets.

While recalling his efforts to address Marathwada’s water woes, he appealed the Maha Vikas Aghadi government in the state to let Jayukt Shivar (the former CM’s pet project) continue even if its name is changed. He maintained that Rs 4,000 crores were given for diverting river water from the Konkan towards Godavari and said that the government should ensure completion of the work, which is in the last phase.

The token hunger strike concluded with Pankaja’s speech, demanding addressing of the water issues of the region, apart from holding cabinet meeting in Aurangabad. Going soft on the Maha Vikas Aghadi government, she maintained that she does not have anything against the government and she is hopeful that it will do well. She made an emotional appeal to her followers by asking them to ignore those making statements against her and said that she is staging the protest for people, and not for any post. She said that if need be, she will not hesitate to opt for an indefinite hunger strike.

Title: Govt auctions manganese mine in Ramtek tiger den
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur forest division is in a quandary as the state mining department has auctioned manganese mines in tiger-bearing areas in Gugaldoh block under Ramtek range.

The Central government amended the Mines & Mineral (Development & Regulation) Amendment Act, 2015, which has been implemented from January 12, 2015. The amendment relaxed norms and allowed mining even in notified areas and asked states to auction such mines through competitive bidding process.

Accordingly, the contract for prospective mining lease in compartment number 293 of Gugaldoh (Manegaon beat) has been bagged by Raipur-based firm Shanti GD Ispat & Power Private Limited, which was the highest bidder.

SK Pande, president and CEO of Sharda Ispat, confirmed the firm has bagged contract for mining. “We are in the process of obtaining forest, environment, and wildlife permissions,” he added.

Nagpur forest officials said, of the 105 hectare area auctioned for mining, 99.95 hectare falls in reserve forest while 5.05 hectare is with revenue department. The area was auctioned in 2018.

They said the area has old history of manganese mining in 1950-55. Now, the abandoned mines have developed into rich forest and wildlife habitats as the mining pits have turned into good water bodies.

The proposed mine area is a reserve forest and hence project proponent needs forest, environment as well as wildlife clearance. As the area is sensitive, Nagpur deputy conservator of forests (DyCF) Prabhunath Shukla had asked forest officials to submit a survey report.

Ramtek forest officials conducted a survey and had also installed camera traps for one month between December 7, 2019, and January 6, 2020. The camera trap survey recorded images of scheduled animals like tigers, leopards and rattle, porcupines, wild dogs, jungle cats, nilgai, deer, sambar, wild boars, peacocks and hares.

On December 7, a full-grown tiger was found dead in one of the abandoned mine pits in the same area. “We have submitted a negative report and the forest area should not be handed over for mining at any cost,” said forest officials involved in the survey.

Nagpur district honorary wildlife warden Kundan Hate says, “As tiger numbers in Pench tiger reserve are increasing, the proposed mine area is being used by tigers and wildlife to settle down. If the area is allotted for mining, conflict will be inevitable. We will oppose the move.”

Title: Youths inspired to follow their passion
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Sukhada Chaudhary at the Indian Youth Conclave 4.0, held on Saturday

Nagpur: Interactive sessions and workshops raised the curtain for the youth fest Indian Youth Conclave (IYC) 4.0, organized by IIM Bangalore-incubated start-up at Chitnavis Centre, Civil Lines, on Saturday. The two-day event celebrated being young and passionate as personalities from various walks of life interacted with the youth and spoke about their life journeys with a view to inspire them to follow their passion.

On the first day, IYC featured nearly 20 events including sessions on start-up, blogging, filmmaking, culinary arts, leadership, marketing and music among others.

Co-founder of Chaos Theory, a co-working space, Sukhada Chaudhary spoke at length on the theme ‘Do what you love’. In order to help the youth navigate their options, she said, “If there is an idea that refuses to leave your mind for 10 days or more, it is the first sign that you should put in efforts and acquire it.”

She added, “It is completely fine to not have an idea. Talk to people, explore several options and wait for it to come to you and convince you to work for it.”

Speaking about the challenges, Chaudhary said, “You need to know that you are opting out of the rat race. Don’t compare yourself to your contemporaries as it is essential to have a personal definition of success.”

Rishab Joshi, a dentist turned into an award winning filmmaker, shed light on his contrasting professions and motivated the youth to follow their passion wholeheartedly. He advised, “Instead of aiming for perfection, keep working on your passion without even worrying about the outcome. Everyone has their own journey but they need to start somewhere. Try to make mistakes because that is how you will learn to be better next time.”

Co-founder of The Climber, Ruhan Naqash, held a workshop on digital marketing where he addressed the two sides of the area — good and bad. He emphasized on how social media uses information entered by people to pedal fake news and targeted advertisements.

DIY artist Vibha Harish gave a talk on ‘How to give your passion a start’. Parth Bajaj unfolded his journey from being an engineer to a famous food blogger. ‘How to be sellable’ was tackled by brand chief of Thinking Birds, BK Mehta.

(Reporting by Manshika Vaikkath)

Title: Congress & Sena to head 2 Ytl ZP sub-panels each
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Yavatmal: Congress and Shiv Sena members will chair two sub-committees each in the Yavatmal Zilla Parishad.

Accordingly, Ram Deosarkar and Jayashree Pote of Congress have been elected as chairperson of B&C committee and women and child welfare committee, respectively, while Shiv Sena members Vijay Rathod and Shreedhar Mohod will head social welfare and education committee, respectively.

Swati Yende has been designated as group leader of Congress in the 61-member House.

Earlier, Shiv Sena’s Kalantibai Pawar was elected as president of the ZP while the post of vice-president was given to NCP’s Balasaheb Kamarkar. Both were elected unopposed.

Title: Madhapur accident: BMW driver loses licence forever
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Regional Transport Authority (RTA) has permanently suspended the driving licence of a businessman who reportedly drove his BMW car in an inebriated condition and hit a motorist resulting in his death in Madhapur on November 24. Incidentally, it was the second suspension in less than a week.

Recently, RTA had cracked the whip against actor Rajasekhar and software professional P Abhilash, whose negligent driving reportedly caused the death of two motorists on Biodiversity flyover in November last year, and suspended their driving licence.

Cyberabad police, in a press release, said K Ashwin Rao on November 24, after consuming alcohol at a star hotel in Madhapur, hit two motorists travelling on a bike while driving on wrong side.

The bike rider died on the spot, while the pillion rider suffered major injuries. Since police found that Ashwin had committed the offence, driving under the influence of alcohol, for the third time, they moved a proposal with the RTA concerned recommending suspension or revoking his licence.

“In December, a proposal was sent to RTA, Rangareddy, for taking action to suspend/revoke the driving licence of the said person as he is unfit to drive any kind of vehicle on public roads,’’ Cyberabad deputy commissioner of police (Traffic) Vijay Kumar said in a press note .

A criminal case has already been registered by Madhapur police against Ashwin as his blood alcohol count was 185 mg/100 ml (permissible: 30mg/100ml) when he was caught after the accident.

Cyberabad police have been recommending suspension of licence of motorists driving under the influence of alcohol and causing accidents.

Title: BBMP health officer assaulted while clearing footpath shops
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

BENGALURU: A BBMP officer clearing footpath encroachments was allegedly assaulted in HSR Layout on Saturday.

Vinod G, 32, a senior health officer, Bommanahalli zone, was waiting on 18th Cross around noon for his men and machines to arrive for the weekly encroachment-clearing drive.

According to Vinod, about 25 people came to the spot and asked who the BBMP official was. When Vinod identified himself, the men attacked him. Vinod raised an alarm and the attackers dispersed once passersby rushed to his help. HSR Layout police have arrested Mani, 57, in connection with the assault and said some more people will be nabbed soon.

BBMP sources said they were conducting the drive after several residents complained about the street vendors. On Thursday, the Palike made announcements on public address systems that unauthorised shops on footpaths would be demolished.

“Some vendors were operating there after obtaining permission and they were not touched. There were people who had illegally built makeshift structures and even rented out the premises. They include food joints, garment and footwear shops. We were acting against such structures,” officials added.

Karnataka State Street Vendors Federation president Rangaswamy CE said they will hold talks with the state government about putting in place a system to prevent unauthorised street vendors from renting out spaces to other people.

Title: Police recover 400gm gold, Rs 13.39L
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Aurangabad: Pundaliknagar police, probing a major house break-in and theft case, have recovered over 400 gram of gold and Rs 13.39 lakh in cash from the three suspects.

The suspect trio includes a jeweller and two hardened property offenders heading the infamous Khidki King. They have been identified as Syed Sikandar Syed Akhtar (36), Shankar Tanhaji Jadhav (35) and Anil Shaliram Shelke (39) — the jeweller from Jalna.

The latest crime record retrieved from Crime and Criminal Tracking Network and Systems (CCTNS) revealed that Sikandar has 68 offences registered against him, while Shankar has over 50 offences to his name.

The suspects have claimed that the jeweller has been purchasing the stolen gold from them for some time. After being produced before the court on Monday, the trio has been remanded in judicial custody.

Addressing a press conference on Monday, Aurangabad commissioner of police Chiranjeev Prasad said the case was detected in absence of strong clues in the initial phase.

“The relentless hard work by Pundaliknagar police helped in detection as well as recovery of the stolen goods in the burglary committed on the intervening night of December 29 and 30,” Prasad said.

The suspect duo committed the crime at the house of retired civil surgeon Namdeo Kalvale.

Pundaliknagar police station’s assistant inspector Ghanshyam Sonawne said the burglars revealed that after learning about the crime through newspapers, the jeweller contacted them for buying the stolen gold.

Accordingly, on January 1, the suspects went to Jalna and sold the stolen gold against which Sikandar got Rs 15.39 lakh.

At the same time, police managed to arrest Sikandar. This was followed by the arrest of Shankar from Panchshilnagar of Nashik and jeweller’s arrest from Jalna.

Title: 2 more offences registered in loan against fake gold racket
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Aurangabad: The crime branch of the city police, which is probing the racket involving mortgage of fake gold to obtain loans, registered two more offences on Monday, taking the total to seven cases.

Police authorities told TOI that the number of offences registered is only the tip of the iceberg as many more are likely to come to the fore.

The crime branch sleuths, who busted the racket while tracking down a suspected chain snatcher last week, have raised serious questions over alleged non-cooperation from banks in the probe.

“Some banks appear to be reluctant in providing information about the suspicious gold loan accounts. Their behaviour is forcing us to suspect their role in the racket,” said an officer.

Crime branch inspector Madhukar Sawant quoted the arrested suspects as saying there are many more cases of obtaining loan against fake gold.

An officer said that soon after news of the racket broke, some people cleared the loans and took back the metal they had mortgaged.

Police sources said that in each case, it appeared that the gold valuers played a role in helping the accused bag loans with different banks. A gold valuer and his brother have already been arrested.

City police commissioner Chiranjeev Prasad has asked the crime branch to reach out to all the banks across the city and check the accounts whose details have been revealed by the arrested suspects.

Accordingly, on Monday the crime branch initiated the process of contacting banks. Police confirmed that in some cases, banks have been reluctant in cooperating in the probe while citing the issue of privacy of customers.

“We have asked the banks to either summon the customers with suspicious gold loan accounts or let us video record the opening of sealed packets in the presence of two ‘panchas’ to check its authenticity,” said an officer, who had been to a bank on Monday.

Title: Rajasthan-based ATM breakers in police net
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Though four were arrested, cops are yet to nab one of the accused

Nagpur: Bahadur Bawari, 30, had formed a gang with family members in Nagor district of Rajasthan to break ATMs, so he could pay his lawyer Rs18 lakh to get possession of his sister’s 51-acre land in 2015. After numerous attempts, he had mastered the modus operandi of whisking away the entire cash vending machine from the ATM outlets. He had committed 10 such crimes in Nagpur city, rural and also Wardha district in the last three months before he was caught on Sunday.

Bahadur, whose parents and sisters are also behind bars for ATM thefts, was nabbed along with three gang members, Gopalram Bawari, Toofan Bawari and Shreeniwas Bawari, after a chase of around 32km by Local Crime Cranch (LCB) team from Patansawangi. The chase in their jeep, and then on foot, ended after the cops laid a trap for some of the gang at Nagpur railway station, after some three months of working on the crime.

The LCB team had been alerted after the theft of a light carrier vehicle from Dahegaon on January 24. They were apprehending a strike on an ATM, and they spotted the stolen vehicle in the early hours of January 26, heading from Khapa T-point to Patansawangi.

As the cops started following the light carrier vehicle, Bahadur started employing various tactics to end the chase, first by sprinkling sharp nails on the road. His team also hurled stones at the cops’ vehicle. When nothing worked, Bahadur had picked up an iron rod and pointed it at the police vehicle like a gun, forcing the cops to hesitate about moving in.

An officer said that light carrier vehicle speeding down the bad road was throwing up dust. “We could only make out the red tail-light of their vehicle. Bahadur asked his gang to slow down the vehicle a bit, and pointed the rod towards us, which appeared to be a gun through the dust. We had to take some precaution,” he said.

“Then, Bahadur jumped out of the vehicle and started running. We too ran after him and pinned him down in a nullah with the help of some villagers at Kalambi. The rest of the gang sped away in the vehicle, but abandoned it later. They managed to flee but our team reached the railway station after Bahadur told us the team was heading back to Rajasthan,” he said. “One of them had a master key in his pocket just like one we found in the abandoned vehicle, leading to their arrest,” said the officer.

Police are yet to nab one accomplice, who provided the gang logistics support and knowledge of local roads, ATM targets, and created two dens at Dhawlamethi on Nagpur-Amravati Road, and another at Wardha.

Bahadur, the mastermind, had 14 offences against him in Rajasthan, including nine for breaking ATMs. Gopalram too had eight offences in Rajasthan while Shreeniwas had 13 including nine for breaking ATMs.

LCB team under PI Anil Jittewar, Asst PI Jeetendra Vairagade, Sub-inspectors Sachin Matte, Narendra Gourkhede (Cyber) and Javed Shaikh had started chasing the gang under supervision of SP Rakesh Ola since they stole a light carrier vehicle from Dahegaon in Khaparkheda on October 11, and raided an ATM with Rs16 lakh in Katol.

After a series of such crimes, there was yet another theft of light carrier van from Dahegaon in Khaparkheda again on January 24 this year. The vehicle was traced but another one was stolen.

SP Ola said the theft of the vehicle was both an alarm and challenge for the cops, who knew there would be an attempt on an ATM soon. “The squads of LCB and police stations were alerted about a strike on ATM outlets, which led to these arrests. We are trying to recover the cash, which they had transferred to relatives after distributing it among themselves,” he said.

The gang was nabbed even though they took precautions like not using mobile phones, avoiding CCTVs and toll nakas, and also using gestures like switching vehicle light on and off to signal each other.

LCB squads comprising ASI Laxmiprasad Dubey, Baba Keche, Vipin Gaidhane, Rohan Dakhore and others were instrumental in getting the gang nabbed.

MODUS OPERANDI

* Gang would first steal a light carrier vehicle and roam around like labourers

* They would keep the vehicle for two days before attacking ATMs at desolate places in the wee hours

* They would sever ATM cables from server room

* The gang would push the machine outside before loading it in their stolen vehicle.

* The machine would be taken to their rented rooms before cutting it open with electric cutter.

Title: GI tag for Khola chillies, govt set to put mancurad on same path
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Porvorim: The state government has obtained a Geographic Indication (GI) tag for the popular Khola chillies grown by the Canacona farmers association. The government now plans to pursue GI tags for Goa’s coconut vinegar, local rice varieties, mancurad mango, Harmal chillies, Mandoli bananas and other local produce, said minister for science and technology Michael Lobo here on Monday.

The locally-grown Khola or Canacona chillies are unique owing to their brilliant red colour and medium-pungent taste. Officials of the Goa State Council of Science and Technology and the Khola chili cultivators’ group had met with scientists of the Old Goa-based Central Coastal Agricultural Research Institute (CCARI) to prepare a road map for the GI registration of the Khola Chilli , which TOI reported in September 2018.

“When farmers get GI tags for their crops, they will be able to promote their produce—this is our objective. We want more youngsters in Goa to take up farming,” Lobo said.

The minister rued the lack of interest among youth, in farming and agriculture. He said that getting the GI tag was a step towards making farming profitable, which in turn could help Goa decrease its dependence on other states for food.

“Our elders are engaged in farming but our youth don’t want to take it up. When a product gets a GI tag, our youth will not only be able to sell their produce in the market, but they can also export it. That is why, the government has stepped forward to do this, and this could improve Goa’s agricultural yield,” said Lobo.

“We have got geographical indication for Khola mirchi, the first agricultural produce of the state to get this. Our department started the process some time back,” said Lobo.

Chillies were introduced to Goa by the Portuguese. Over time, the spice has undergone hybridisation, with approximately 15 varieties of chili grown in Goa, ranging from the Portugali mirsaang to the Tharvati chili, and Aldona chili.

Title: 3 poachers held for electrocution
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Chandrapur: Forest officials have nabbed three poachers for electrocuting a carnivore and removing its body parts. “It can be a tiger or leopard,” said divisional forest officer (DFO) AL Sonkusre.

Acting on a tip off, Sonkusre and his team arrested three accused — Suresh Gedam, Ramesh Bhoyar and Ajay Meshram from Kapsi village. “A month ago, the trio had drawn illegal power from an overhead 11kv electric line in compartment number 201 in Saoli forest range to kill a wild boar. Both the wild boar and a carnivore were killed,” said Sonkusre.

Sonkusre said over 2kg bones and skull have been recovered. More seizures are likely. The accused have been remanded to forest custody till February 1.

In another development, the Butibori forest officials have launched a manhunt for killers of a full-grown leopard that was dumped in Nand Lake on Friday. “There is no direct or indirect evidence to show that the leopard approached the water body. It seems the animal was killed at some other spot and body dumped in the lake,” said RFO LV Thokal.

Title: Will generate power to curb stench from dump: GHMC
Content: HYDERABAD: Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) commissioner Lokesh Kumar on Monday told the Telangana High Court that the GHMC is working to mitigate the woes of residents around Jawaharnagar dump yard, who are falling sick on account of the stench emanating from the yard.A bench headed by Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan of Telangana high court took up the issue as a PIL after coming to know of the plight of people in localities such as Sainikpuri, Kapra and Yapral.The bench comprising CJ and Justice Abhishek Reddy had earlier directed the GHMC commissioner to be present before it to explain the steps the GHMC is taking to resolve the crisis.Lokesh explained to the bench that the first thing they did was to reduce the garbage spread area in the 337 acre space at the dump yard to 137 acres. The liquid from 75,000 metric tonnes of the garbage is percolating and this liquid is causing the unbearable stench. “We are planning to generate electricity from methane gas emanating from these liquids,” the commissioner said. “We will come up with one electricity plant in the next two and half months and a second plant, too, will come up three months thereafter.”Lokesh Kumar said, “We are covering this huge dump in layers of polythene and mud, and have laid as many 150 pipelines to allow the gas to come out of the garbage. And this gas will be raw material for our power plant. This is apart from a compost processing unit, a negative vacuum unit and a waste water treatment plant we have to deal with the problem.“We will allow the dump to dry for a week so that the garbage becomes fit for treatment. We have to drain the liquid lagoon at the bottom first to cement the bottom of the dump yard, to prevent the liquid seeping into the groundwater. We will be able to do all that incoming months.”The bench sought an affidavit from him by February 7 and adjourned the case. But before that the court made it clear to the GHMC commissioner that it will monitor the matter, and review the progress once every month.

Title: Village bestows flag hoisting honour on sanitation worker
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Aurangabad: As a mark of respect to the sanitation employee, who has been working in a village for the past 28 years, residents of that village in Jalna district asked him to hoist the flag on Sunday.

Tirthapuri, a village which has a population of 20,000, is known for its sugar factory. The village, situated in Ghansawngi taluka of Jalna district, is considered to be the most vibrant market in the taluka.

Sanitation staffer Laxman Namdeo Kasar has been cleaning gutters and lanes of Tirthpuri for almost three decades.

The decision to honour Kasar was taken by the village sarpanch Shailendra Pawar. A day before of Republic Day, Pawar spoke to his colleagues in gram panchayat and decided on it. Pawar, on Saturday, went to Kasar, who initially thought that the sarpanch has come to ask him to wake up early to clean the gutters and drains in the village on the occasion of the Republic Day.

When contacted, Pawar said, “Sanitary staffers are the unsung heroes of our society, so instead of inviting some politician for flag hoisting, we decided to invite our sanitary staffer.”

On Saturday evening, after Pawar took Kasar to a barber to get him a haircut, Kasar asked the reason behind it. On hearing the reply, Kasar did not believe him, but still followed the instructions of the sarpanch. Accordingly, the sarpanch got him a Khadi cloth so that he can hoist the flag in it. Kasar was felicitated with before being invited to hoist the flag.

Kasar said, “During festive seasons and on the days of national importance, we are expected to wake up early and clean the drains. Even bagging any national award would not have made me happier than getting this honour.”

Kasar said that for the past 30 years, he has never even stood in the first row during any of the official functions of the gram panchayat. He added that his experience of hoisting the flag is a reward for his service.
