Title: High court quashes FIR against three
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad bench of the Bombay high court recently quashed an FIR filed against three people — a police inspector, an education officer and a headmaster of a school in Himayatnangar taluka of Nanded district.

Following the registration of an offence, the trio approached the high court seeking to quash the FIR registered against them under sections 341, 353, 467, 468, 469, 201 and 120 B of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

The case was registered against the trio in 2019 by 38-year-old Anand Uttamrao Bawane, an assistant teacher working at the zilla parishad-run school in Rukmini Nagar of Himayatnagar taluka.

The petitioners approached the high court through lawyer Sudarshan J Salunke challenging the FIR. In his complaint, Bawane said he worked as assistant teacher at the zilla parishad school. On September 25, 2014, he was served a suspension notice at his residence at 9am. He also alleged that a false record was created by the petitioners showing that he was suspended with effect from September 5, 2014.

Bawane said that when he reached school on September 25 and started teaching a class, two policemen arrived there and physically lifted him saying that the police officer had asked them to bring him to the police station.

The police officer said that it was done at the behest of block education officer and the headmaster. Bawane alleged that the police officer abused him and asked him to sit in a corner and meted out insulting treatment.

He later approached the higher police officer and the collectorate against the trio but nothing was done. Finally, Bawane approached the judicial magistrate first class (JMFC) on March 20, 2015 who ordered an investigation into the case under section 156(3) of the CrPC. Later, a crime was registered against the trio on July 19, 2019.

“Initially, the order was not made by the JMFC and the order came to be made in criminal revision by the additional sessions judge Bhokar,” the court high said.

Following arguments, the bench comprising justices TV Nalawade and MG Swewlikar allowed the petition and observed that, “It can be said that by filing the FIR, he (the complainant) is trying to put pressure on the education officer, head master and even the police officer who took aforesaid step. Allowing the informant to prosecute the matter would amount to misuse of the process of law.’’

Title: Bamu should emerge as role model: VC
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Aurangabad: Vice-chancellor of Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University (Bamu) Pramod Yeole said everyone should strive hard in order to ensure that the university emerges as the role model in the field of higher education.

“The university is shedding its unwanted image and trading the path of progress. We have introduced some major reforms in academics as well as administration and there are many more to come. Together we should ensure that the university emerges as the role model,” he said.

Meanwhile, Bamu staff who skipped the flag hoisting ceremony on Sunday are under scanner.

Title: Resolution totally motivated by Pakistani interests: London MEP
Content:
London’s Liberal Democrat representative Dinesh Dhamija

NEW DELHI: As the European parliament prepared to debate and vote on a resolution tabled by some of its members against CAA, London’s Liberal Democrat representative Dinesh Dhamija on Monday took up cudgels for CAA and called the resolution totally motivated by Pakistani interests. He claimed that not all members were consulted while drafting the motion and that some suggestions for amendments to the motion were rejected by fellow Liberal Democrat MP Shaffaq Mohammed.“The call for censure has been led by a small group of British members, unfortunately from my own party, in an attempt to create a rift between the two blocs. I say unfortunately because I was not invited to the drafting of the motion as president of the Indian delegation. When I put down amendments to the motion, my pertinent suggestions were rejected,” Dhamija told TOI. According to him, the draft puts the burden on India rather than asking for sanctions on Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh for creating an atmosphere and pushing persecuted minorities to become refugees. Dhamija said Shaffaq got the motion passed without informing him and that his objections were rejected. He will put in those amendments to the general body and expect those to be incorporated.Dhamija said India, like the European Union , was secular and known to respect human rights, equality, democratic values and freedom. He contended that the resolution is meant to derail the EU-India Summit, which PM Modi is scheduled to attend in March.

Title: One legislature must not judge another: Om Birla to Europe House
Content:
This story is from January 28, 2020

Lok Sabha Speaker Om Birla (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Lok Sabha Speaker Om Birla wrote to president of European parliament David Sassoli on Monday, asking him to “respect the sovereign processes of fellow legislatures” and refrain from passing the proposed resolution over CAA and thus prevent setting an “unhealthy precedent”.

In his letter, Birla said: “As members of the Inter Parliamentary Union, we should respect the sovereign processes of fellow legislatures , especially democracies. It is inappropriate for one legislature to pass judgement on another, a practice that can surely be misused by vested interests.”

Birla’s concerns were echoed by Vice President and Rajya Sabha chairman M Venkaiah Naidu who said there is “no scope for outside interference in India’s internal matters”. Addressing a gathering after a book launch event, Naidu said he hoped they would refrain from making such statements in future, he said.
